HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
Labor Deal Is Nice, but Peace Deal Is Needed

BYLINE:  By DAVE WINFIELD; Dave Winfield was inducted into the Hall of Fame in 2001. He finished with 3,110 hits and 465 home runs.

 BODY:
As a kid, I played the big three sports: baseball, basketball and football. I was drafted in all of them, and as I said in my induction speech in Cooperstown, "Baseball is the best game of all." 
 Players, owners and agents should act now to restore some of the luster and regain some of the respect, admiration and following that we have historically enjoyed and recently lost. It is time for America's pastime to look forward to the future. 
 With the World Series starting last night, it is easy to forget there is trouble in paradise. I'm excited because, of the eight teams that started in the playoffs, I played for three -- the Yankees, the Angels and the Twins. I know the exhilaration of the players, the teams and the cities.
It has been two months since collective bargaining was resolved, when, for the first time, baseball fans were heard loud and clear, helping the sides find common ground. Players and owners listened, and they should keep on listening.
Bargaining opened new doors this time, and we will see if revenue sharing is part of the solution to some of the game's woes. But, until this system is tested, and until trust develops between players and owners who work together in other key areas, there will be no long-term growth or development in Major League Baseball. This mistrust needs to be dealt with or it is just going to fester. 
Without that trust, baseball will not move forward -- it will go nowhere. 
Collective bargaining alone will not lead the way. Any piecemeal strategy to address the problems is only a temporary solution. A comprehensive, long-term strategy is needed. It would be new ground for the two sides, but it is imperative. While many people make valuable suggestions that amount to pieces of the puzzle, few address the underlying element that has kept the sides apart for what seems like forever: basic labor-management mistrust. 
While there has been some thaw in relations, the game is still in trouble. You hear that collective bargaining produced incremental improvements for each side. But I know they have not found the long-term answer. Even before I talked to players, owners and agents, I could tell from the settlement and the body language that the sides (still) do not like or trust each other. Without a major change, we will be looking at (bad) business as usual in four more years.
Despite my position working in baseball management for the San Diego Padres, I am not taking sides. I spent my entire playing career considering the relationship with fans and the community. Now I want to provide some vision and tangible concepts everyone can work with. Call it challenging the status quo, because things are still not right. I want management and the players to build a new team, a winning team where all parties work together, have joint goals and objectives and follow committed leadership.
Without characterizing the leadership on either side, a change in everyone's thinking is overdue. Many feel the players association has done an excellent job representing and advising the players on issues regarding their baseball careers. Major league baseball players today may have the best working environment and opportunities of any organized labor group in the world, but at what cost? 
Many question the efficacy of Commissioner Bud Selig, who is a de facto owner and therefore not an independent and unbiased leader. Their point is valid. And should they commission another blue-ribbon panel to consider the future of baseball marketing, it must be more inclusive; it can't be picked just by the commissioner. If the financial future of the game remains in peril even with these changes, then persuade the players association behind closed doors, but also talk about growing the game together.
Baseball needs a breakthrough, a complete paradigm shift from business as usual. Is everyone willing to make these changes? Are both sides truly prepared to improve baseball for present and future generations? If so, these are the key elements: 1) Trust that will encourage each side to work together. 2) Agreement on a continuing campaign to unify baseball with specific goals and objectives. 3) A meaningful working relationship between the players and the owners. 4) Leadership with the willingness to break free from a deep-seated mistrust and an antagonistic history.
I urge everyone to see the bigger picture and take steps to change the environment. Develop a long-term strategy. Leave a positive legacy, one that really is about changing the game. The future won't boil down to strictly economic issues or winning or losing. It is about each side doing what is necessary for its own sake, for the sake of the still loyal fans and the fans we want and need in the future.
By working together, management and the players can rise to the challenge of keeping games fun, affordable and safe. Management, spend more time promoting the great players, the good guys, the teams and the matchups. It will go far. Players, accept your roles as public figures and role models. Interact with the kids, the fans and your community so that baseball once again becomes preferred family entertainment. Make it something our kids want to grow up with.

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dave Winfield, left, hit a two-run double in the 11th inning of Game 6 to win the 1992 World Series championship for Toronto. As a Minnesota Twin in 1993, center, he celebrated his 3,000th hit. In 2001, right, he entered the Hall of Fame. (Agence France-Presse, left, and Associated Press)

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Office Furniture Stocks Take a Seat and Wait

BYLINE:  By J. ALEX TARQUINIO 

 BODY:
THE market for new office furniture has fallen sharply over the last two years, as waves of corporate layoffs have left many companies with more furnishings than employees.
 After peaking at $13.3 billion in 2000, sales of office furniture in the United States declined 17.4 percent in 2001, and Merrill Lynch estimates that they will decline an additional 19 percent this year, to less than $9 billion. 
 Even so, shares of the two largest office furniture makers -- Herman Miller and Steelcase -- have suffered disproportionately, some value-oriented investors say. Shares of both are down more than 40 percent from their two-year highs. 
John W. Rogers Jr., manager of the Ariel and Ariel Appreciation funds, said he thinks that the industry will "come back very strongly as the economy recovers."
The Ariel fund family, which specializes in socially screened investments, focuses on small- to mid-capitalization value stocks. The Ariel Fund has about 4 percent of its assets divided roughly equally between Herman Miller and Steelcase, while Ariel Appreciation has 1.7 percent of its assets in Herman Miller.
Analysts at the Ariel fund family estimate that the share prices of both companies may roughly double when market conditions pick up, though they are not predicting when that will happen. Herman Miller, which closed at $16.88 on Friday, could trade as high as $33, and Steelcase, which closed at $9.25, could trade at up to $22 once the business environment improves, said Sabrina L. Carollo, a stock analyst for the funds.
Of the two companies, Herman Miller was quicker to initiate big cost cuts. "Steelcase is still in the process of cost cutting," said Pamela Singleton, an equity analyst at Merrill Lynch. "Recently they talked about eliminating another 500 to 800 staff. I think Herman Miller has made the adjustments." 
The bulk of the office furniture industry is divided among small, privately held companies. Steelcase, based in Grand Rapids, Mich., has a 20 percent share of the domestic market, and Herman Miller has 13 percent. The only other major competitor is Hon Industries of Muscatine, Iowa, at 12 percent. But many value investors aren't as excited about Hon because its shares have risen over the last year; they now trade at $22.63, up 16.4 percent in the last 12 months.
Hon is also more diversified than the competition. About 15 percent of its revenue comes from a division that makes fireplaces. But Hon's main advantage is that it mostly makes cheaper, ready-to-order products. That segment of the market has weathered the downturn much better than that for big new offices, the focus of both Herman Miller and Steelcase.
Revenue at Herman Miller, which is based in Zeeland, Mich., was $347 million for its first quarter ended in August, down 15.5 percent from the period a year earlier. But aggressive cost cutting helped generate a profit of 13 cents a share. That is up from 4 cents a share, excluding one-time restructuring charges, from the prior year.
Unless the economy sinks into another recession, Ms. Singleton predicts annual earnings of 56 to 62 cents a share for the company's fiscal year ending May 2003, versus 2 cents a share for the year ended in May 2002.
In addition to layoffs and plant closures, Herman Miller has discontinued two product lines, SQA and Red, that were started in the summer of 2000 to cater to the small-business market. This restructuring could save the company $80 million a year, said Curt Organt, an equity analyst at T. Rowe Price, which owns more than two million shares of Herman Miller in seven funds.
BUT cost savings alone don't justify Wall Street's preference for Herman Miller, said James Norris, manager of the C&B Mid Cap Value fund. Herman Miller currently trades at a price-to-sales ratio of 0.9, versus a ratio of 0.51 for Steelcase. "We think that Herman Miller deserves a slight premium to Steelcase, but not as much as it has now," he said.
There could be another reason for unequal treatment, Mr. Norris said. Shares of both Herman Miller and Steelcase peaked in 2000, just a few months after Steelcase's initial public offering. "There's nothing the Street hates more than a burned I.P.O.," Mr. Norris said. Steelcase makes up about 4.3 percent of his fund.
Typically, demand for new office furniture picks up about six months into an economic recovery, but Roz Bryant, a stock analyst at Morningstar Inc., said the turnaround in demand could take longer this time because of the huge supply of second-hand office furniture sitting in closets.
"Though large corporations won't be scavenger hunting," she said, "that's a secondary market that could take some business away from the manufacturers." 

CORRECTION-DATE: November 3, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Oct. 20 about investing in office furniture makers misstated the year when the stock prices of two such companies, Steelcase and Herman Miller, reached their peaks, and when Steelcase had its initial public offering. It was 1998, not 2000.

HEADLINE: Drilling For Freedom 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN

 BODY:
A funny thing happened in Iran the other day. The official Iranian news agency, IRNA, published a poll on Iranian attitudes toward America, conducted by Iran's National Institute for Research Studies and Opinion Polls. The poll asked 1,500 Iranians whether they favored opening talks with America, and 75 percent said "yes." More interesting, 46 percent said U.S. policies on Iran -- which include an economic boycott and labeling Iran part of an "axis of evil" -- were "to some extent correct."
 Oops! 
 You can imagine what happened next. Iran's hard-liners shut down the polling institute and threatened the IRNA official who published the results. Never mind. The fact that the hard-liners had to do such a thing shows how out of touch they are with Iran's courageous mainstream. 
I relate this incident because it is very useful in thinking about the task of democratic transition in the Middle East. The Arab and Muslim worlds today are largely dominated by autocratic regimes. If you want to know what it would look like for them to move from autocracy to democracy, check out Iran. In many countries it will involve an Iranian-like mixture of theocracy and democracy, in which the Islamists initially win power by the ballot box, but then can't deliver the jobs and rising living standards that their young people desire, so they come under popular pressure and can only hold on to power by force.
But eventually they will lose, because the young generation in Iran today knows two things: (1) They've had enough democracy to know they want more of it. (2) They've had enough theocracy crammed down their throats to know they want less of it. Eventually, they will force a new balance in Iran, involving real democracy and an honored place for Islam, but not an imposed one.
But why is it taking so long? Why isn't Iran like Poland or Hungary after the fall of the Berlin Wall? And why might Iraq not be like them after the fall of Saddam? The answer is spelled O-I-L.
The transition from autocracy to real democracy in Iran is dragged out much longer than in Europe for many reasons, but the most important is because the hard-line mullahs control Iran's oil wealth. What that means is that they have a pool of money that they can use to monopolize all the instruments of coercion -- the army, police and intelligence services. And their pool of money is not dependent on their opening Iran's economy or political system or being truly responsive to their people's aspirations.
Think of it like this: There are two ways for a government to get rich in the Middle East. One is by drilling a sand dune and the other is by drilling the talents, intelligence, creativity and energy of its men and women. As long as the autocratic leaders of Iran, Iraq or Saudi Arabia can get rich by drilling their natural resources, they can stay in power a long, long time. All they have to do is capture control of the oil tap. Only when a government has to drill its human resources will it organize itself in a way that enables it to extract those talents -- with modern education, open trade, and freedom of thought, of scientific enquiry and of the press.
For all these reasons, if we really want to hasten the transition from autocracy to something more democratic in places like Iraq or Iran, the most important thing we can do is gradually, but steadily, bring down the price of oil -- through conservation and alternative energies.
I know that Dick Cheney thinks conservation is for sissies. Real men send B-52's. But he's dead wrong. In the Middle East, conservation and alternative energies are strategic tools. Ronald Reagan helped bring down the Soviet Union by using two tactics: he delegitimized the Soviets and he defueled them. He delegitimized them by branding the Soviet Union an "Evil Empire," and by exposing its youth to what was going on elsewhere in the world, and he defueled them by so outspending them on Star Wars that the Soviet Union went bankrupt. In the Middle East today, the Bush team is delegitimizing the worst regimes as an "axis of evil," but it is doing nothing to defuel them. Just the opposite. We refuel them with our big cars.
Which was the first and only real Arab democracy? Lebanon. Which Arab country had no oil? Lebanon. Which is the first Arab oil state to turn itself into a constitutional monarchy? Bahrain. Which is the first Arab oil state to run out of oil? Bahrain.
Ousting Saddam is necessary for promoting the spread of democracy in the Middle East, but it won't be sufficient, it won't stick, without the Mideast states kicking their oil dependency and without us kicking ours.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Bleak Earnings; 
Is Bankruptcy Good for the Airlines?

BYLINE:  By EDWARD WONG 

 BODY:
THE chief executives of the nation's largest airlines have been engaging in their version of the soup kitchen shuffle. Tin bowls in hand, they have marched up to Capitol Hill in the last few weeks seeking more financial aid for an industry expected to lose at least $7 billion this year. They offer what seems a compelling rationale: Multiple airline bankruptcies could leave a huge dent in the already fragile economy.
 "Aviation is a fundamental prop to the economy," said Leo F. Mullin, chief executive of Delta Air Lines. "Aviation affects 10 percent of our national income, and affects travel and tourism. Suppliers are dependent on it. Enormous industries are dependent on it." 
 But many economists and industry experts say the executives are being alarmist, with some insisting that multiple bankruptcies might even make the industry -- if not the overall economy -- stronger in the long run. 
Certainly, bankruptcies would damage investor confidence in the industry, as well as hurt specific regions, especially if air service to smaller cities is curtailed and workers laid off. Also, carriers that have limped to their deaths under Chapter 11 have left a temporary gap in service. Yet the market could quickly adapt to alleviate those changes, economists argue, and experience has shown that carriers can emerge healthier from bankruptcy.
"Going bankrupt just means reorganizing and getting costs in line," said Steven A. Morrison, an economics professor at Northeastern University. "I don't think 100 percent of those companies would go away. I don't look forward to carriers going bankrupt, but to predict chaos is overstating it."
Bleak earnings reports from the airlines last week make this discussion more than theoretical. The industry lost at least $2.2 billion in the third quarter, with American Airlines, the world's largest carrier, leading with a $924 million net loss. United Airlines continues to say it could join US Airways in Chapter 11.
The immediate effects of multiple bankruptcies would be painfully felt, from the airlines' major hubs to the smaller, low-profit regions they service. Large numbers of workers could be laid off at the hubs, adding to the tens of thousands that major carriers began cutting after the Sept. 11 attacks. The airlines could also ask a bankruptcy court to nullify costly labor contracts. Lower pay would mean less money in the cities where the workers live, and would pressure rival carriers to cut labor costs to remain competitive. Travel-dependent businesses like hotels and car rental agencies would be hit hard.
In addition, shareholders, creditors and suppliers of the bankrupt airlines would suffer financial losses. Most notable in that group is the Boeing Company, one of the nation's largest manufacturers. 
Beyond that, though, multiple bankruptcies would have few ripples. Economists point out that several airlines, including Continental, now the nation's fifth-largest carrier, went into bankruptcy in the early 90's with little effect on the broader economy. Much like US Airways now, Continental kept flying under bankruptcy protection, and eventually emerged from Chapter 11 as a relatively healthy company.
Some industry experts even contend that bankrupt airlines could stimulate travel because deep cost-cutting could lead to lower fares. There is some debate over this, however. Several economists say there is no evidence that airlines in Chapter 11 become more price competitive. And if the number of seats is cut, fares would probably rise if demand remains the same.
IT may prove true that short-term disruption to air travel would result if bankrupt airlines have to sell assets because of unsuccessful restructuring. But even then, financially robust rivals would probably step in -- as long as there are profits to be made.
"The healthier carriers will pick up slack," said Clifford Winston, an economist at the Brookings Institution and author, with Professor Morrison and others, of "The Evolution of the Airline Industry." "They would just fill up more seats."
Overall, many experts say, bankruptcy would force a bloated industry to swallow some bitter, but essential, medicine. They argue that airlines cannot raise prices now because of an oversupply of seats. Generous labor contracts also create unsustainable operating costs. 
"If you buy into the rhetoric and you put more government money into this industry to freeze the current system, there's no end in sight," said Sam Peltzman, a professor of economics at the University of Chicago. "This is no different than the situation in the early 1970's, when the northeastern railroads all went into bankruptcy. The government reaction was to freeze the system. The bailout was growing at 20 percent per year. At some point in the mid-70's, Congress looked around and said, 'Is this the best we can do with our money?' "
Today, politicians in Washington seem as skeptical as economists about the dire claims of airlines. The House aviation subcommittee has proposed a bill that would give only limited financial aid. 
Yet that bill is seen as inadequate even by some economists who play down the negatives of bankruptcy. They argue the government should assume the costs of new security measures mandated by federal officials after the Sept. 11 attacks. No other industry, they say, has been asked to take on this extra financial burden while grappling with many continuing economic woes. 
"If you have multiple major airline bankruptcies, you're going to have a smaller, less vibrant system, and that will support a whole lot less economic activity in the U.S.," said Robert L. Crandall, former chief executive of American Airlines. 
That may be true, but history has shown that a wounded economy -- and a wounded airline industry -- have more resilience than people realize.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends; 
Cheap Mortgages, Expensive Debt

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FIRST it was the stock market. Now the question is whether the housing market, the primary generator and repository of wealth for most people, is a bubble.
 At a time when the recovery from the recession last year is sputtering, the outlook depends heavily on how much longer the economy can rely on surging home prices, low interest rates and the willingness of consumers to keep borrowing and spending. The direction of housing values could also help determine whether the American economy will bounce back gradually or risk a long slide, like the one afflicting Japan, where a downward spiral in stock and real estate values has depressed the world's No. 2 economy for more than a decade. 
 In retrospect, economists from Alan Greenspan on down agree that the run-up in stock prices in the late 1990's was unsustainable. But even as Wall Street has wiped out trillions of dollars of wealth, the economy has been kept afloat partly by what some analysts consider another example of ephemeral financial levitation: a continued sharp rise in home prices, even in the face of the stock slump, fueled by low interest rates. 
The median price of a single family home in August, the most recent month for which figures are available, was $163,600, up 6.4 percent from a year earlier, according to the National Association of Realtors. In many regions, the increases have been considerably higher, and in some places, the prices have been breathtakingly high. 
In Orange County, Calif., the median price of $411,000 this summer was 16.6 percent higher than a year earlier. In the Washington region, the median price of $249,700 was up 20.8 percent. In Bergen and Passaic counties in New Jersey, the increase was 24.7 percent, to $338,800.
At the same time, consumer debt levels -- fueled in part by the ability of homeowners to borrow against the rising value of their houses -- have risen to worrisome levels. 
Mortgage foreclosures hit a record 1.23 percent of all home loans in the second quarter, up from 1.10 percent in the previous quarter and exceeding the previous record of 1.14 percent in the first quarter of 1999, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association of America. Total household debt as a percentage of disposable personal income has risen to 107 percent from 96 percent in 1996, according to the Federal Reserve.
The housing market is "bubble-like," argues Allen Sinai, chief economist of Decision Economics, a consulting firm. "Real estate hangs out there now as the only asset that hasn't yet been hit," he said. "History tells us things don't usually turn out that way."
So far, the combination of low interest rates and rising housing values has been invaluable in offsetting a deep slump in spending by companies, which remain reluctant to invest in new plants and equipment when they are plagued by overcapacity and worried about terrorism and a possible war with Iraq.
Taking advantage of bargain financing deals, consumers have snapped up automobiles, keeping a big industry humming. Most of all, low mortgage rates have set off waves of refinancing, allowing homeowners to put more money in their pockets by reducing their monthly payments or borrowing more against the increased value of their houses.
Mr. Greenspan and many other economists see no evidence that consumers are staggering under their debt loads at the moment or that housing prices have reached irrational levels. 
"We've looked at the bubble question, and we've concluded that it is most unlikely," Mr. Greenspan told a Congressional committee last summer, adding that plenty of reasons exist for home prices to be rising, from low rates to a lack of land in many regions.
"This isn't Japan, and this isn't like the stock market," said Janet Yellen, a former Fed governor and Clinton administration official. Although total debt burdens are high, low interest rates have kept monthly debt payments within reason. Debt-service payments as a percentage of disposable income stood at a little over 14 percent in the second quarter, about where they have been for the last several years, though higher than they were in the mid-1980's.
"Is the consumer extended? Absolutely," said James W. Paulsen, chief investment officer for Wells Capital Management, an investment firm. "Is there a risk? Absolutely. But it's nothing new. All through the 90's we pushed the problem of low savings and high debt out into the future somewhere."
BUT some economists say it is easy to envision a downward cycle in which falling real estate values and heavy consumer debt drag the economy into a morass, especially if unemployment shoots up and the stock market stays down.
"We were in a euphoric or at least confident time in the 90's," said Robert J. Shiller, an economist at Yale University who was one of the first to spot the stock market bubble. "Now we're in an annoyed, angry, betrayed mood. When bad things happen, they can get a lot of attention."

HEADLINE: Mexico Fears Migrant Deaths Will Increase With Despair 

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
Mexico's government, after tentatively identifying 2 of the 11 migrants found dead in a locked boxcar in Iowa this week, says it fears the deaths are a harbinger of many more to come.
 Roberto Esparza, 23, and his cousin, Omar Esparza, 17, left their hometown of Los Conos, Aguascalientes, in central Mexico in June. The two men paid a smuggler $1,500 to bring them to Sarasota, Fla., where they planned to seek landscaping and construction jobs, their family said. 
 Mexican consular officials found identification cards for the two men in a locked boxcar, among the remains of seven men and four women. The boxcar had been sitting in a rail yard in Denison, Iowa, since leaving the Mexican border town of Matamoros and crossing into Texas four months ago.
Tens of thousands of Mexicans cross the border every month looking for work in the United States. They die, on average, at a rate of about one a day. Typically, they die of exposure and dehydration in the deserts and scrublands near the borders of Texas, Arizona, New Mexico and California.
The particularly gruesome deaths of the 11 migrants found in Iowa underscored the desperation driving the migrants from poor farming villages like Los Conos.
Over the past year, illegal immigration appears to have diminished because of the weakened United States economy and strengthened border surveillance.
But Mexican officials say they fear that the desperation will grow next year.
Throughout central Mexico, hundreds of farming villages like Los Conos, the Esparzas' hometown, are already all but empty of able-bodied men who have gone to seek their fortunes in the United States, where they can earn wages 10 times greater than in Mexico.
On Jan. 1, the North American Free Trade Agreement will eliminate duties on heavily subsidized American wheat, rice, barley, potatoes, dairy products, poultry, pork and beef. That will allow the importation of those products to Mexico at much cheaper prices.
Mexican officials, including Foreign Minister Jorge G. Castaneda, are warning that the end of tariffs may crush the ability of millions of Mexican farmers to survive, and drive them north seeking money to feed their families.
Mr. Castaneda and Mexico's president, Vicente Fox, will raise the issue next week with President Bush and Secretary of State Colin L. Powell at a meeting of world leaders in Cabo San Lucas, Mexico.

HEADLINE: Hathaway Closes Maine Factory, Last Major U.S. Shirt Plant 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: WATERVILLE, Me., Oct. 19 

 BODY:
The sewing machines have stopped at the nation's last major shirt factory, which supplied shirts for Union soldiers in the Civil War.
 Its shirts were later promoted in a classic advertising campaign featuring a man with an eye patch. 
 Like Arrow and Van Heusen, C. F. Hathaway shirts will live on, but they will no longer carry the "Made in the USA" label. The plant here closed on Friday. 
After 165 years of making shirts in Maine, the factory kept only a few workers to box and fold the shirts. Distribution of the remaining shirts will keep 25 people employed through December, but the closing will put 235 people out of work.
A few workers lingered in the parking lot on Friday to say their goodbyes.
"It's losing your family," said Sherry Laliberty, 59, who worked in the plant for 35 years. "My God, we've been through divorces and deaths and children growing up and grandchildren. We've been though everything in there, and we are family." 
The factory's demise became inevitable after it failed to win a crucial contract to make shirts for the Air Force and the nonprofit Made in the USA Foundation could not line up investors to take over the plant.
"A lot of people saw the writing on the wall five or six years ago," said Ron Fingel, the Waterville city administrator. "It was expected for so long it wasn't like a shoe dropping in a quiet room."
Hathaway began production in 1837. Windsong Allegiance Group, which operated the factory, was willing to donate the equipment to anyone with the financial backing to keep it going, but nothing worked out, said Colette Sipperly, spokeswoman for the company.
Hathaway is among a growing number of apparel and shoe companies that have moved production out of the country. G.H. Bass and Cole Haan closed their Maine shoe factories in 1998 and 1999, while the Dexter shoe plant closed last year, putting 475 people out of work.
Hathaway was on the verge of closing five years ago. A local investment group financed a bailout. It was again on the verge of collapse last fall when Windsong bought the company. Less than six months later, Windsong announced plans to close the factory in June. A last-minute $5 million contract from Wal-Mart kept it running.
Donald Sappington, president of Hathaway, said it was hard to compete when products can be made elsewhere at vastly lower cost.
The advertisements featuring a man with an eye patch are imprinted in the memories of many men who also remember fathers and grandfathers who wore Hathaway shirts.
Richard Hewes, who bought 10 shirts from the factory store on Friday, recalled that his grandfather gave him Hathaway shirts. Mr. Hewes said he had been wearing them since 1975.
"I'm not saying it's a family tradition," said Mr. Hewes, a lawyer in Augusta. "It's just a good quality shirt."
Windsong, a Westport, Conn., company, has already started a Hathaway sportswear line made abroad, and it will line up plants to continue the Hathaway label for men's shirts, Ms. Sipperly said.
"Basically we think the future looks bright because it's a great brand and there's great recognition," she said.
The company may even bring back the man-with-the-eye patch advertising.
"It really needs to be reintroduced to a new generation," Ms. Sipperly said.

HEADLINE: Utah County's Toxic Tradition Is Under Threat 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL JANOFSKY 

DATELINE: TOOELE, Utah, Oct. 18 

 BODY:
As other places in the United States have struggled to keep dangerous materials away, Tooele County has welcomed some of the deadliest things ever made: radioactive waste, ammunition, chemical and biological weapons.
 For nearly 60 years, government and private facilities here in the vast desert west of Salt Lake City have stored and processed hazardous wastes of all stripes, winning the county a reputation as one of America's foremost dumping grounds. 
 But now, even as some lethal substances are being destroyed under terms of federal mandates and international agreements, efforts to bring new toxic materials into the county have set off bruising political fights, leading to an unusual state ballot initiative next month in one case and a plea to the Nuclear Regulatory Commission in another.
Caught in the breach are Tooele County residents who speak proudly of their toxic traditions and insist that the county and the country have benefited from stockpiling the material here. Since the first federal installations opened in the early days of World War II, Tooele County (pronounced Too-WILL-uh) has tripled in population, reaching almost 41,000 by the last census. 
"We have taken on a huge share of the defense of America," said Gene D. White, a Tooele County commissioner, referring to nearly a dozen federal and private operations in the county that deal with things few other places want. "Instead of getting credit, all we do is get criticized for it."
Tooele County is Utah's second-largest, at 6,930 square miles, about 84 percent of which belongs to the federal and state governments. The gathering of dangerous material here began shortly after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, when Washington designated 200 square miles of its Tooele land for weapons testing. Over the next six decades, county residents have lived alongside Air Force bombing ranges, testing and storage sites for chemical and biological weapons, mineral processing plants, toxic landfills and large incinerators now used to destroy stored weapons. Almost half the nation's supply of chemical weapons is kept at the eastern end of the county.
All the while, the county's largest towns, Tooele and Grantsville, have become thriving bedroom communities to Salt Lake City, an easy commute 30 miles to the east. The towns have affordable housing, scenic mountains, quiet neighborhoods, safe distances from bombing runs and storage sites and no evidence of uncommon health risks. 
But now, as the county waits to open its arms again, strong resistance is building to new toxic imports, although it is far from clear whether the opposition will actually stop the flow or merely delay it.
The disputes have coalesced around two entities with strong ties to the county -- Envirocare of Utah, the nation's largest private disposal company for low-level radioactive waste, and the Skull Valley Goshutes, a small Indian tribe proposing to build temporary storage for spent nuclear fuels headed to permanent entombment at Yucca Mountain in Nevada. 
After a dozen years of processing low-level radioactive waste, like dirt and rubble from cleanups at former weapons plants, Envirocare won federal and state permits to take materials with higher levels of radioactivity, like medical waste. But as the Goshutes' proposal began drawing more controversy, Envirocare suspended plans to seek final approval from the Legislature and governor.
"Maybe not forever and all time," said Betty Arial, a spokeswoman for Envirocare. "But for now, plans are not being discussed."
Gov. Michael O. Leavitt, a third-term Republican, applauded Envirocare's decision to back off, saying he would have denied any permit for higher-grade imports, but opponents to Envirocare were not taking any chances. Led by Doug Foxley, a powerful state lobbyist, they collected enough signatures to get a complex measure before voters, using the promise of desperately needed new tax money for public education as its strongest selling point.
If passed, the measure would bar all higher level radioactive materials from the state and raise taxes fourfold on revenues generated by low-grade material.
As both sides interpret the measure, it would affect only Envirocare, but critics say it would require changes to more than 100 state laws, and "that's not the way to run a democracy," Mr. Leavitt said in an interview this week. Officials in Tooele also objected on economic grounds, insisting passage would put Envirocare out of business, costing more than 250 county residents their jobs and the county a quarter of its annual income, about $5 million.
"This is a scam on state government," said Teryl Hunsaker, another county commissioner. "It will wind up hurting the state of Utah."
Mr. Foxley said, "That's nonsense and absurd, nothing but a malicious scare tactic." Insisting that "monopolies like Envirocare" do not go out of business, he added, "No one in his right mind spends the money to go through the permitting process, to stop short of going through the legislative process."
The Goshutes' effort has been no less emotional. With gaming unlawful in Utah, a band of several dozen Goshutes in Tooele County has turned to nuclear waste as a potential revenue source. A proposed deal between the Goshutes and a group of out-of-state utilities that needs to remove 40,000 tons of spent fuel rods from nuclear power plants is now awaiting federal approval.
The licensing board of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission is expected to announce in December if the technical standards for the proposed site have been met. If so, commission staff members would consider recommending the project to proceed.
The deal would mean millions of dollars for the Goshutes. But court challenges are sure to follow any federal approval, and Mr. Leavitt has vowed to block the plan.
Mr. Leavitt said he was especially concerned about the safety of storing large quantities of nuclear material in one place, where they might be vulnerable to terrorist attack. He said he also worries about fighter jets that train over the area, and the occasional accidents, like cruise missiles that veer off course, striking unintended targets, as one did recently, hitting an abandoned trailer.
From the county's perspective, years of partnerships with the federal government and private disposal companies have brought none of the problems that opponents say are lurking, including health risks. Sherrie Ahlstrom, the community health supervisor, said studies by state officials had never found any links to illness or disease from toxic substances in the county.
Nicole Cline, a county planner who is writing a history of Tooele's experience with waste, conceded that people often poked fun at Tooele County as the nation's dumping ground. Her response is always the same, mindful that every community grapples with toxic waste of some sort.
"I always tell them, 'I know where mine is,' " she said. " 'Do you know where yours is?' "

HEADLINE: BackTalk; 
A Conference Extends the Sun Belt to Logan, Utah

BYLINE:  By ROBERT LIPSYTE

DATELINE: LOGAN, Utah 

 BODY:
Up here in the mountains of northern Utah near the Idaho border, friends of the Aggies characterize Utah State University as a middle-class striver on the brink of national recognition. Down in New Orleans, pals of the Sun Belt Conference describe it as a good-hearted "league of convenience." So when they took their vows here two days ago there was as much relief as celebration.
 "We arranged the best possible marriage," said the Utah State president, Kermit L. Hall. "This is a good business deal." 
 Utah State and the Sun Belt needed each other and both felt disrespected by their trade association, the National Collegiate Athletic Association. It was a deal forced by the economics of college sports and made urgent by new N.C.A.A. rules that will widen the gap between the big-time college teams ("the oligopoly within the monopoly," Hall calls them) and all those others who will never play in a major bowl game. Under new requirements that cover conference membership, number of sports, home-game attendance and athletic scholarships, Utah State and the Sun Belt were each in danger of being dropped from Division I-A, the premier N.C.A.A. classification. 
Utah State needed a conference for its football team, an independent since the Big West Conference dropped football after the 2000 season. The Sun Belt needed another football team to retain accreditation. So, they hooked up. 
Ask Hall, a noted legal historian, why it's so important to be classified I-A, and somewhere in the hours and days ahead (we've been talking about this since we met last January at the N.C.A.A. convention), he will imagine the future Nobel Prize winner lured to Logan by an environment of possibility that includes an airport that has yet to be built and a ski resort that has yet to be developed, as well as good music and football. 
Sometime before that, however, he will talk about what it means financially to have an independent football team that isn't Notre Dame. While the Sun Belt is a low-rent league weak in football, members share about $800,000 a year in N.C.A.A. largess (the high-rent leagues share $16 million and more among their members). In recent seasons, Utah State has been paying about $1 million a year to bring good opponents to Logan. Not great opponents, who won't come; the likes of Nebraska pay Utah State about $400,000 to come to Lincoln and lose by 30 points.
"Some might say we're being prostituted," said Coach Mick Dennehy, whose team is 2-5 after beating New Mexico, 45-44, in overtime yesterday. "But I can use those games to measure our progress. We need to get to a point where we can beat them on occasion. Our kids like to test themselves against the best. They like to go to Nebraska, go to Texas Tech, see the rabidity of fans, see the national importance of college football. 
"We'll still play one of those games a year to make money, but our goal will be to win the Sun Belt Conference. Every kid growing up has the goal of wanting to win the championship, be the M.V.P. Our society is geared to this. It supersedes the reason we play the game, which is for the love of it." 
According to Hall, the coach most negatively affected by the marriage of convenience will be Stew Morrill, the men's basketball coach, who will miss the exposure in California, his recruiting base. All Utah State teams except football, which moves to the Sun Belt next season, will spend three more seasons in the Big West. 
"I hope it's a short-term solution," said Morrill, a big, affable 50-year-old with a 71-25 record and a 10-year-contract. "It's illogical playing in the South, but I'm glad someone wants us. We need I-A football. Utah is a basketball state and this was always a good basketball school, but football rules the N.C.A.A. Life is always changing and I may never have to play in the Sun Belt."
He lifted crossed fingers. 
Meanwhile, he has a more immediate concern. Part of saving the football team was creating a women's basketball team. Morrill will have to share practice facilities. ("I will be stubborn but compromise," he said.) The new women's coach, Raegan Scott-Pebley, at 27, may be the youngest in Division I, but she has been a Utah high school and University of Colorado star, and played two seasons in the W.N.B.A. She seems likable but nobody's patsy. 
"I hired a male assistant coach because you want a male role model and a woman assistant to be sure the players have someone to go to with personal problems," she said. "Often they don't want to go to the head coach with their dramas, and there are always dramas with women. Personal connections are so important; women are more likely than men to carry things off the court, to emotionalize. 
"I'm looking for selfless players with a 3.0 or higher. Discipline is a lifestyle and winning is a learned behavior. What can I offer them?" She laughed. "A lot of playing time."
She will field her first team next season, in the Big West, where women's basketball is less competitive than in the Sun Belt. Western Kentucky, Louisiana-Lafayette, Middle Tennessee and North Texas are among the Sun Belt members. 
Neither newlywed tried to pretend that the marriage was necessarily a till-death-do-us-part match. Both viewed themselves as victims of circumstance. The outgoing president of the N.C.A.A., Cedric Dempsey, has said that some teams don't deserve to be in I-A, which is reasonable if you aren't concerned about losing face, institutional identity and money. Utah State, a strong agricultural and engineering university of some 21,000 students, is considered third in the state behind Brigham Young and the University of Utah. Weber State and Southern Utah are well behind, but presidents hate to lose ground.
"We're not going to be pushed out," Hall thundered. 
But for all his straight-talking -- and he generally rates a I-A in that category -- Hall tends to fade when asked about the recently named new president of the N.C.A.A., Myles Brand. He will say only that it is a step in the right direction that Brand is a former university president, rather than a former athletic director, as were all his predecessors. Brand gained fame at Indiana University for firing Coach Bob Knight after several publicized incidents of abusive behavior. Skeptics noted that Brand had enabled Knight's abusive behavior for years. Utah State coaches and Sun Belt administrators are not so sure that someone with so little college sports experience should be in charge.
As if the N.C.A.A. was about college or sports, rather than TV and sneaker deals for the powerful schools, crippling rules for lesser schools and for the so-called student-athletes.
"When I went to the N.C.A.A. meetings, I might as well have been from Mars," Hall said in an e-mail message to me several weeks before the marriage was announced. "With no help from the N.C.A.A., we have managed to do just what they did not want us to do. Perhaps with a place in the Sun Belt, we'll be able to get a voice in the national discussion, since it is clear to me, as remote as we may be on the map, we are very much in the middle of what is happening in intercollegiate athletics."

Articles in this series about college sports have explored King Football, paying the players and gender equity. Robert Lipsyte's e-mail address is thelipsite@aol.com.

HEADLINE: Island in an Uproar 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Re "More Greens? A Red Light From Martha's Vineyard" (news article, Oct. 18):
 Most Martha's Vineyard residents, seasonal visitors and even day-trippers would agree that the last thing the Vineyard needs is "more greens," especially with a $150,000 to $200,000 price tag for membership. 
 The golf course proposal by Corey A. Kupersmith, a developer from Connecticut, has been rejected three times now, a process characterized by threats, intimidation and personal attacks on members of the Martha's Vineyard Commission. 
And now Mr. Kupersmith is quoted as saying of the commission members, "There's going to be retribution." He also said: "The only way to get a fair hearing is when they start seeing economic harm. Each member of the commission better get a lawyer." So this is how you get a "fair hearing"?
It's sad indeed when that combination of greed, ego and arrogance gets the better of a fellow.

JACK STREET
Vineyard Haven, Mass., Oct. 18, 2002

 INTERNATIONAL 3-10

North Korean Violation May Lead to Isolation
The Bush administration has decided to stop providing Western energy aid in light of North Korea's violation of a 1994 arms control accord. North Korea has a choice between abandoning all of its nuclear weapons programs or facing near-total economic isolation. 1

Iraq Sees Many Allies
As Iraq confronts the possibility of a new war with the United States, its leaders appear to have concluded that, this time, the world is on its side and against the United States. 1

Tariq Aziz, Iraq's deputy prime minister and part of Saddam Hussein's inner circle, said the Iraqi government has had no links with Al Qaeda or Osama bin Laden, denying a charge made by President Bush. 13

Long Trek to Iraq Accord
The United States and other permanent Security Council powers have retreated to closed rooms and telephone calls for more negotiations on a resolution to force Iraq to disarm. 13

Hard Questions Over Bali
The first bodies have finally begun returning home after the terror attack in Bali, and angered Australians are asking questions about why warnings were missed. 14

Indonesian officials have arrested a militant Muslim cleric who has been linked to Al Qaeda, though they say he is not a suspect in the Bali attack. 14

European Union Expansion Vote
Irish voters appeared to have given overwhelming endorsement to the most ambitious expansion of the European Union, a project they rejected only last year. 10

Sharp Rebuff From I.R.A.
The Irish Republican Army was reported to have delivered a sharp rebuff to demands for its disarmament by Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, in what was taken as a significant setback to efforts to cement Northern Ireland's frail peace. 8

NATIONAL 16-33, 36

New Shooting in Virginia Extends Area of Manhunt
Detectives tracking the deadly suburban sniper raced to a shooting near Richmond, Va., as police reported a man was wounded by a single shot in a parking lot outside a restaurant. Detectives in the manhunt for the sniper, who has killed nine and wounded twoso far this month, emphasized it was not immediately known whether the shooting was connected. 1

Casinos Don't Cure Town's Ills
The once dilapidated town of Tunica, Miss., has bloomed into the nation's third-largest gambling center, after Las Vegas and Atlantic City, despite the sluggish economy that has driven most states and the federal government into deficits. Still, 28 percent of all residents are poor. 1

The Threat Posed by Trucks
Fresh threats against economic targets and three attacks overseas this year using fuel trucks have convinced officials that America's trucks, particularly rigs hauling loads of explosive fuel or toxic chemicals, pose a significant security risk. 1

Ex-Mayor Acquitted of Murder
Charlie Robertson, the former mayor of York, Pa., was acquitted of murder in the death of a black woman 33 years ago during more than a week of race riots. The other two defendants were found guilty of second-degree murder. 16

Doubt Over Change in Gun Laws

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DOMESTIC SECURITY; 
Possibility of Using Trucks For Terror Remains Concern

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
After the terrorist attacks last year, intelligence agencies and experts warned that America's vast fleet of trucks, particularly rigs hauling loads of explosive fuel or toxic chemicals, would be ideal terrorist weapons.
 Fresh threats against economic targets and three attacks overseas this year using fuel trucks have convinced security officials that America's trucks pose a greater risk than ever, particularly with aviation security tightened. But little has been done to make trucks safer. 
 Truck security systems already widely used elsewhere in the world remain novelties here. Truck inspections, although there are more of them, remain rare. Industry groups have started training drivers how to spot possible terrorists but have reached only a few thousand of the country's three million licensed drivers. At many truck stops, idling rigs still sit unattended in unguarded lots. 
"We have to consider the trucking industry as a potential target to be misused in a terrorist attack," said George A. Rodriguez, director of cargo security for the Transportation Security Administration. 
Congress set tough deadlines and provided billions of dollars to enhance airline security, but except for $500,000 a year for the industry's driver-training course, little money has flowed so far to secure the most dangerous trucks, even though nearly 800,000 loads of hazardous cargo move on American highways each day.
Some trucking companies, operating on tightening margins, say they have held off investing in new security technologies, like tracking devices in use in South America, while they wait for federal rules or money.
Federal action has also been delayed by bureaucratic tangles at the Transportation Department, which has been trying to impose domestic-security duties on divisions dealing with truck safety and hazardous materials management, department officials say. 
Regulations on truck safety and security equipment are many months away, they say.
Mr. Rodriguez said the size and diversity of the trucking business hampered the effort. "You've got a half-million trucking operations out there," he said. "To come up with some systems that cover all the bases is difficult."
As a result, an array of experts and industry people, including some truckers who haul the hazardous loads, say it is just a matter of time before a deadly load is snatched and put to devastating use.
"A tractor-trailer with the right cargo offers a horrendous weapon," said Richard W. Carr, the vice president for safety and risk management at Quality Distribution Inc., a Tampa, Fla., company. 
The company has the country's largest tank-truck fleet, more than 3,200 vehicles in all.
Recent events overseas have raised fresh concerns.
Two taped warnings attributed to Al Qaeda both specified that attacks would target America's economic lifeline. Intelligence officials say this most likely means transportation or finance.
A more ominous sign, experts say, is that fuel-laden trucks have been used three times this year in terrorist attacks. On April 11, a terrorist driving a truck carrying liquefied natural gas ignited his cargo in front of a synagogue on the Tunisian island of Djerba, killing 21 people, mainly German and French tourists. Germany blames Al Qaeda.
In May and August, terrorists remotely triggered bombs attached to Israeli fuel tankers. Neither bomb caused substantial damage, but the incidents signaled a new tactic. 
A senior terrorism analyst for the federal government said American truckers needed to be alert to the heightened risk. "Information sharing is particularly important when a technique has been looked at or tried overseas," he said.
This month, Mr. Rodriguez has met repeatedly with industry groups, and counterterrorism teams from the Federal Bureau of Investigation have provided fresh updates to local officials and trucking businesses. At one briefing, federal authorities said truck inspectors should watch for drums laid out in a V shape, the configuration used by Timothy J. McVeigh in 1995 to focus the blast of his truck bomb at the Oklahoma City federal building that was his target, meeting participants said.
Still, federal terrorism analysts and other officials concede that a bomb is not necessary because the nation's hazardous cargo offers the same opportunity that airliners provided 13 months ago -- the chance to transform ubiquitous vehicles into mobile weapons of war.
About 50,000 trips are made each day by gasoline tankers, many of which hold as much fuel as a Boeing 757. Many of the depots where they fill up are unattended, dispensing fuel with the stroke of a driver's card. The trips often end with a late-night delivery to a deserted gas station. Experts say that chemicals present an even greater risk, particularly those like chlorine or cyanide, which can form clouds of deadly fumes. 
Across North America, terrorism officials were alerted in May when a truck hauling 96 drums of sodium cyanide was stolen north of Mexico City. Most of the 55-gallon drums were quickly recovered, but the hijacking showed the ease with which terrorists could appropriate a potential chemical weapon.
The very placards that trucks must carry to inform firefighters of toxic contents could also direct terrorists to particularly deadly cargo, experts say.
"Gasoline and propane are very spectacular, but realistically they pale in potential damage or injuries compared to a lot of other products that move by truck," said a senior official at a chemical-hauling company. "And the placards pretty much advertise exactly what's inside."
As officials and the trucking industry focus on security, two strategies are foremost: finding technology that can deter hijackings and changing habits of drivers that expose them to risks.
Technological solutions may eventually help, but the government has only begun to assess them.
Last month, the Transportation Department announced a two-year project to test satellite-tracking systems, coded switches that disable a truck if an unauthorized driver takes control, and other security devices.
Industry groups are helping pay for the $5 million project, which will equip 100 trucks as rolling test beds.
But some companies that make such equipment say it should already be in use, pointing to its popularity in places like Brazil, where hijackings are common. 
One system, sold by QualComm, a San Diego company, allows a fleet manager to disable a truck by remote control if it strays from its route. For nearly a decade, it has been used on 25,000 trucks in Brazil, helping companies recover $500 million in stolen freight, QualComm officials said. Some industry officials have concerns about such systems, which could pose a safety risk if a truck was disabled while moving on a highway.
Drew Robertson, the head of the Freight Transport Security Consortium, a new group representing manufacturers of truck security systems, says the impediment to wider use is disagreement over who pays -- the truck owners, the oil and chemical companies that hire them or the government.
Other experts and industry officials say technology is only half the battle. "Truckers really have to look at how they operate and do basic things like put padlocks on trailers, don't leave tractors running, lock their tractors, be observant," Mr. Rodriguez said.
The clearest vulnerability, experts agree, comes when trucks are stopped. To avoid long layovers, some companies have begun using crews of two drivers or setting up relays in which one driver turns a load over to another without pause.
In May, the Trucking Security Working Group, representing everything from moving companies to the country's 1,100 private truck stops, began a campaign to train drivers how to recognize the rehearsals or reconnaissance that terrorists undertake before an attack. 
Drivers are advised to report people photographing truck depots, following trucks on routes or asking questions.
Sessions for 40 or 50 drivers and managers at a time have been held in 18 states since May, with the goal being raising the awareness of all 3.1 million licensed truck drivers, said officials at the American Trucking Association, a trade group.
But glaring vulnerabilities remain all along transportation corridors. A paucity of secure parking areas causes many drivers to seek quiet side streets, vacant mall lots or highway ramps as a place to rest.
The vulnerability is illustrated by a continuing crime wave. Truck and cargo theft results in more than $10 billion in annual losses, according to industry officials, and some 1,800 large trucks are stolen each year just in New Jersey.
In the absence of quick federal action, some states are intensifying efforts to cut risks of a terrorist truck attack. 
The California Highway Patrol has hired 150 new officers to bolster patrols, said Dwight O. Helmick, the highway patrol commissioner. The state is also installing radiation detectors at weigh stations.
Florida has ordered two gamma ray systems to scan trucks. They are similar to systems being installed at ports to scrutinize cargo containers. State officials said the scanners can identify small details inside an 18-wheeler in 10 to 20 seconds -- including modifications hinting that a truck has been turned into a weapon.
Still, experts acknowledge that inspectors and detectors can screen only a tiny percentage of the endless flow of vehicles.
Mr. Carr, the security chief for the tank-truck company in Tampa, said that roadside inspections of Quality Distribution's trucks tripled over the last year but still involved only 3,600 stopped trucks out of the 300,000 deliveries.
This month, as state inspectors conducted a spot check along Interstate 84 in Promised Land, Pa., the parade of hissing giants spoke of the challenge facing antiterrorism officials. 
Many trucks carried innocuous cargo -- kitchen cabinets, french fries, garbage. But others hauled 40-ton loads of gasoline or toxic chemicals. On one low-slung gray tanker, the orange safety placards read simply: "blasting agents."
While focused on safety, such inspections provide chances to find trucks that might have been stolen or modified by terrorists.
Stan Madurski, one of the inspectors, said three kinds of vehicles were considered the highest terrorism risk: rented trucks, trucks toting the sealed metal containers that move from ship to rail to roads, and tankers. 
Without any cues from the industry or officials, some drivers have begun to change their habits, sensing that they are the last line of defense. 
At a rest stop an hour east of Promised Land, Ronnie Yliniemi, 58, a driver for 34 years, roused himself from a nap and conducted what has become a post-9/11 routine: a quick circuit of his gleaming tanker to check for tampering. 
Everywhere he goes, he said, he still sees trucks idling unattended and others with deadly chemicals but no locks on the valves.
In the wrong hands, he said, it would be simple to crash one into a building or open valves to release clouds of deadly gas. 
"It'll happen eventually," he said. "I've got that feeling."

HEADLINE: Casinos Revive a Town, but Poverty Persists 

BYLINE:  By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: TUNICA, Miss., Oct. 16 

 BODY:
Awnings and young trees line Main Street, where a new town hall, firehouse, police station and town-financed post office have sprung. A new $28,000 carillon-mimicking clock in a new park downtown chimes every 15 minutes and plays hymns on the hour. The city is building and furnishing a supermarket for someone to lease. Residents pay no property taxes or sewer fees. They pay $3 to $5 a month for water. 
 "We have free garbage pickup," said Michael Tutor, manager of the Blue & White restaurant on Highway 61, along the town's eastern edge. "They come to the back of your house and get your garbage can and dump it and put it back." 
 Three streets have new squirrel crossing signs. "They cost $35," said Mayor Billy E. Williams, at the wheel of his city-issued white Buick with leather seats. "It's bad to have a squirrel run over." 
The Town of Tunica, in the otherwise impoverished Mississippi Delta, is the seat of Tunica County and eight miles south of the former cotton fields that have bloomed into the nation's third-largest gambling center, after Las Vegas and Atlantic City. The sluggish economy has driven most states and the federal government into deficits. But once-dilapidated Tunica, which had been best known for slave descendants' squalid shacks along an open sewer just two blocks from Main Street called Sugar Ditch, has money to burn. 
This year the town, which had a population of 1,132 in 2000, expects to collect $3.5 million in taxes from the nine casinos, just under half of its $7.3 million budget. Ten years ago, its budget was $830,000.
With so much money, this cotton-coated county of 9,227, about 40 miles south of Memphis, is building an airport big enough for Boeing 747's to haul in more gamblers and tourists. Next month, in one of many events marking the decade since the first casino opened, Mayor Williams is bringing Oliver North to speak at the unveiling of a $400,000 veterans memorial. Tunica will pay him $20,000.
Still, for all its gains, Tunica County remains poor. Per capita income rose from $8,370 in 1990 to $11,978 in 2000, still below the state's median of $15,853. The 1990 census deemed half of all families poor. Two years ago the figure was 28 percent. But that was still far more than double the national rate. 
Many of the poor have moved from welfare to casino jobs, but many, working or not, still live in shacks. Housing for low-income workers is scarce, and casino jobs are erratic, surging in holiday periods and shrinking in slow periods. In the soft economy, gambling has slowed, so casino revenues have ebbed. 
"But the casinos aren't going anywhere," Mayor Williams said. "I don't worry about it." This year, the town parked $2.4 million in a rainy-day fund. 
On Magnolia Street, just off Main Street, is Hosia Nickson's Package Store, with a small restaurant attached. People hang out on the benches outside. It is a stone's throw from Sugar Ditch, where apartments for the elderly poor have been built where the old shacks once stood. 
"All that stuff is gone," said Robert Leonard, 46, a custodian at the Tunica Institute of Learning, a largely white school. "I'm glad it's gone. Older people up in age, like their 60's, they've got jobs, jobs nobody thought a black person would get." 
Still, said another man, "there's a whole lot left to be done. They put in that million-dollar clock, and people are suffering in this town."
A woman outside the store added: "People got AIDS and no place to go. We need a hospital." She said she works the floor at the Horseshoe Casino for $6.68 an hour. "That's what I make, and I've been there a year," she said. "I have seven kids."
The statistics for the county show some stunning changes. Unemployment has dropped to less than 4 percent from 17 percent in 1990. Households receiving welfare have dropped to 2 percent from 20 percent. The 2000 census found that homes without toilets had dropped to less than 2 percent from 23 percent in 1990, and those without telephones to 11 percent from 30 percent. 
With wages instead of welfare, said Sister Angela Susalla, who works at a Catholic Social Services office in town, "people had some kind of income and could become homeowners." Typically, she said, a mother with one child got a $97 monthly welfare check here five years ago. A woman working 40 hours a week for $7 an hour at a casino earns $1,100. But lately, rents and house prices have risen with incomes, squeezing low-wage workers. 
To the nuns at the office, the notion of building an economy on gambling was once troubling. "It would not have been my choice of what came in," Sister Gus Griffin said. But the jobs and paychecks have stifled those apprehensions. "It's been so helpful that I see no problem."
Addictive gambling seems not to have struck Tunica's casino workers the way it has the casinos' out-of-town customers. "Some people lost a bunch when the casinos first came in," Sister Gus said, "but they learned very fast." 
The proliferation of paychecks has unsettled some merchants in unexpected ways. 
"Our business was built on government checks," said Mayor Williams, who owns a furniture store on Main Street. Welfare recipients borrowed to buy furniture, and Mr. Williams profited from the financing. But with the sharp decline in welfare recipients, he said: "A lot can pay cash for stuff. That has hurt us."
The casino jobs affect merchants in another way. During high seasons, said Linda Tutor, Michael's wife and the owner of the Blue & White, there are more jobs than workers. Her pool of workers is limited, she said, to "people who wouldn't pass a drug test at a casino and some who don't like the atmosphere of casinos."
Charlie Williams, a former Republican state legislator and the county's director of programs and projects, said the county was trying to bring in better-paying jobs. Most casino jobs pay less than $10 an hour, and few higher-paying jobs have been created. 
Education is the key, said Mr. Williams (who is not related to the mayor). Despite one of the state's highest levels of school spending, he said, "we still have a low educational level." The 2000 census found that 40 percent of adults over 25 lacked high school diplomas. "Your better jobs don't come until you have an educated work force," he said. 
While the rolls of people receiving welfare checks have plunged, the poor get other forms of aid. This month, the Main Street office of the federal Women's, Infants and Children program distributed food boxes to 587 pregnant women and women with children up to 5 years old. The number of women served is "basically the same" as it was before the casinos opened, Carolyn Tunsill, the manager of the office, said.
Some people stay poor because they do not qualify for casino jobs. To work for one, they must get a badge from the Mississippi Gaming Commission. To get a badge, they must pay $75, and three years must have elapsed since their last conviction for a felony or a drug misdemeanor. "There are quite a few who have convictions for drug misdemeanors or simple assaults," Jerry King, director of the commission's Tunica branch, said.
Other crimes new to the county have surged around the casinos. "We have credit card scams, slot machine scams, jackpot scams," Mr. King said. There has been a carjacking in a parking lot and a murder in a casino elevator. 
Not much of the crime has spread to the town, however. With nine police officers and a chief, Tunica has about one officer for every 100 residents.
The city has the luxury of dispatching a backup officer to the highway when another officer pulls a car over. Michael Nichols, a police officer having lunch at the Blue & White, said, "We get new cars whenever we need them." 
The spending goes on. All the streets have been paved. Every intersection has reflective blue street signs with recessed white letters.
"We never did have street signs," said Mr. Leonard, the school custodian. "You'd have to know them by knowledge."

 CORRECTION:
An article on Sunday about the economic impact of casinos on Tunica, Miss., misstated the given name of Tunica's mayor. He is Bobby E. Williams, not Billy. The article also misstated the capacity of a planned airport. While it could accommodate Boeing 747's, it is being designed to handle 727's.

HEADLINE: HOME FRONT; 
Work at Last: Marketing Themselves

BYLINE:  By Leslie Eaton 

 BODY:
BEING unemployed is obviously a problem - but did you ever stop to ponder what kind of a problem? A financial problem, of course. An emotional problem, often. A political problem, maybe (or should be, for the politicans).
 In a weird kind of way, it's also a marketing problem - and if you are unemployed, you're the product that needs to be sold. Especially now. 
 Almost 250,000 people in New York City are looking for work right now, according to the state's Labor Department, about 60,000 more than two years ago. Meanwhile, companies have cut more than 123,000 positions. 
 How do you stand out from the herd - and get your resume in front of the handful of peole who might actually have jobs to give you?
 You advertise. That, at least, is the brain wave that swept over three unemployed marketers this summer, and prompted then to dream up WeWantWork. It's a marketing campaign for themselves and 40 other jobless New Yorkers.
 "It's difficult for employers to fidn the right candidate because there are so many out there," said Marc Seago, 33, a marketing manager who has been out of work for a year. "The more people we reach, the more likely it is that our resumes will get in front of the right eyes."
 An ad on prime-time television was obviously out of the question - and probably wouldn't have worked, anyway. The trio instead turned to "in your face guerrilla marketing, which emphasizes direct contact with whoever you're trying to reach," said Lisa Rosevear, 35, an unemployed publicist. 
 That means dressing in eye-catching costumes - business suits under placards saying "We Want Work' - and handing out fliers on street corners. Sometimes the group has tooled around in an old Checker cab blasting work-related music ("Carwash," say, or the Seven Dwarfs' theme song), hopping out to distribute fliers and then tearing off again.
 The fliers direct potential employers to WeWantWork.com, where all 43 members' resumes are posted. Referring other people to the site qualifies you for discount coupons at restaurants.
 The organizers try for an element of surprise, so to find out what the group's attention-grabber will be in their fourth foray into the streets to hand out fliers, you'll probably have to be in Midtown Manhattan on Tuesday morning. A good spot would be near the ferry slip at West 38th Street.
 "People just seem much happier when they commute by water," said Emily Malatesta, 35, who most recently worked in marketing for the National Basketball Association.
 Guerrilla marketing in recent years has been associated with a certain powerful breath mint and with now-defunct Internet enterprises, but WeWantWork is not made up of "dot-com brats," Miss Rosevear said. The group includes people with experience in finance, human resources, sales, accounting, information technology and, obviously, marketing.
 While some, like Mr. Seago, had Internet experience, others, like Ms. Malatesta, are by no means Web-heads. What she is obviously very good at is organizing and at rounding up "supporters" to donate services like printing.
 Indeed, the group has run this effort like a real marketing campaign, down to the Power-Point presentations and Excel spread sheets. And the organizers are listing WeWantWork on their resumes, to show that they're doing more than watching TV and eating Doritos during their unemployed stints. Organizing the group is also giving them emotional satisfaction, the trio said. The group's members enjoy doing something active, rather than passively waiting for the phone to ring.
 "It takes a certain kind of personality to go out on the street," Mr. Seago said. "People sometimes say, 'You're that desperate?' We're not desperate, we're motivated."
 So far, the reaction from New Yorkers has been warm, and the campaign, which started Sept. 24, has produced interviews, if no actual jobs - yet. "Big companies don't usually hire that quickly," Ms. Malatesta said. "But we have two people who are very, very close."
 "Three," Miss Rosevear chinned in. "Keep you fingers crossed for me."
 The group has been hearing from people in cities like Washington and Los Angeles who want to set up similar efforts.
 "We tell them, 'Here's the concept, here's the Web site, go do it!' " Mr. Seago said. "We hope it inspires you."

HEADLINE: The World; 
Under the Lens: Southeast Asia Confronts Its Demons

BYLINE:  By TOM ZELLER

 BODY:
IT was quickly dubbed the second front in the war on terrorism. In the months following the Sept. 11 attacks, a series of arrests in Singapore and Malaysia and the Philippines seemed to imply that Al Qaeda had slipped down-continent and established itself from Bangkok to Manila and across the Indonesian archipelago.
 It made some sense. The region has the largest Muslim population in the world, and small Islamic militant groups with separatist aims - like Abu Sayyaf and Jemaah Islamiyah - were already in Southeast Asia long before Al Qaeda was routed from Afghanistan. Intelligence officials knew some groups had trained in Afghanistan or fought there alongside their Arab counterparts against the Soviet Union. Loose immigration rules in many parts of the region made movement easy, and the Asian financial crisis continued to sap vigor from local economies. 
 But finding direct ties to Al Qaeda - or even to a single, discernible agenda - among the many groups and splinter groups has proved remarkably difficult, even when investigations are stirred by deadly bombings like those in Indonesia and the Philippines last week. The Bali bombing in particular, both American and Indoesian officials said, surely had a helping hand from Al Qaeda, although the dots - and there are many dots - are still being connected.
 A third bombing, in Manila on Friday, may well prove to have Al Qaeda fingerprints as well. But it is also possible that it will have purely local roots, born of a hodgepodge of local ethnic, political and economic tensions that have little to do with a global holy war.
 At right, the overview of terrorism in the region and the many sources from which it springs.

(ORANGE) - ABU SAYYAF Seeks an Islamic state in the southern Phillippines.
(PURPLE) - KUMPULAN MUJJAHIDEEN MALAYSIA Seeks a separate Islamic state stretching across Southeast Asia.
(RED) - LASKAR JIHAD - Pursues holy war against Christians. Announced last week that it was disbanding.
