HEADLINE: Private Art in Public 

BYLINE:  By Gabriella De Ferrari; Gabriella De Ferrari is a writer and former director of the Institute of Contemporary Art in Boston.

 BODY:
In America it is individuals, not governments, who have established public collections of art, books and manuscripts of dazzling quality, diversity and depth. The single-donor museum has long contributed to this nation's cultural richness. While tax deductions support the founding of these institutions, it has been the vision of generous donors that has given the public such treasures as Boston's Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum, New York's Frick Collection, Los Angeles's Getty Museum, and more recently the Pulitzer Foundation for the Arts in St. Louis, the Neue Galerie for German and Austrian Art in New York, and the Kreeger Museum in Washington, D.C.
 Some donors impose few restrictions on their gifts. J. Paul Getty, for example, gave his trustees a relatively free hand in accomplishing "the diffusion of artistic and general knowledge." Others, like Mrs. Gardner, attempted to control every detail, dictating how the collections are displayed, prohibiting loans, forbidding new acquisitions and even requiring the museum's director to live in the museum building. While restrictions can preserve the values of the time when the collection was created, they also carry risks. The Barnes Foundation, one of the most important collections of late 19th- and early 20th-century art in America, is a case in point. 
 Last month, 51 years after Albert C. Barnes died, the trustees of his foundation filed a petition requesting relief from Dr. Barnes's rigorous limitations on operations, use of the collection and governance. The trustees claim that the foundation is on the verge of bankruptcy, unable to meet operating expenses given changing economic circumstances and Dr. Barnes's many restrictions. If the petition is granted, the foundation's governing document would be changed to permit relocation of its gallery from suburban Philadelphia to a new museum downtown and to expand the board from five to 15 members. This proceeding raises the question of how long a donor's control over cultural treasures should last.
Virtually all institutions established by a single donor -- no matter how wealthy when founded -- eventually require public support to survive. That support includes direct cash from the public and indirect subsidies through local, state and federal tax exemptions. These institutions become public burdens as well as public assets, and should therefore reflect the public's interest in ensuring access to important cultural properties. 
Current law permits donor restrictions to run in perpetuity. Yet every museum confronts increasing costs, changing public demands and new approaches to the presentation of collections. Mrs. Gardner could never have foreseen the need for and expense of climate control nor the public benefit of lending artworks for short periods of time to traveling exhibitions. Mr. Frick could not have imagined the many public programs museums must now provide. Flexibility is not merely desirable but also necessary if cultural property is to serve the public as fully as possible.
Today's trustees can go to court for relief, as the Barnes's trustees have done. But these proceedings are time-consuming and their result is uncertain. A better way to balance a donor's wishes and the public's interest is to adopt state laws that would limit the period during which donor restrictions are enforceable, releasing trustees from them after, say, 50 years. This change would give trustees latitude to adjust to changing needs. 
Would such laws diminish gifts of great collections to the public? There is little reason to think so: the drive of collectors to present their holdings as they enjoyed them, even for a limited period, and the tax and personal benefits of giving are simply too compelling. Limiting the period of restrictions would benefit the public and give single-donor museums a more robust life in perpetuity.

HEADLINE: New Economy; 
Chief executives takethe education of Congress in hand to help the Postal Service.

BYLINE:  By Claudia H. Deutsch 

 BODY:
O.K., true or false?
The United States Postal Service is subsidized by the government.
 It has one union, with which it can bargain quite aggressively. 
It can cut costs by consolidating post offices in areas where mail traffic is too meager to warrant separate branches.
David Sable, chief executive of Wunderman New York, a Young & Rubicam unit that does mass mailings, knows that many -- maybe even most -- people wrongly think those statements are true. He can live with that. What makes him crazy is that many members of Congress have the wrong answers, too. 
"You'll hear a congressman ask, 'Why can't these guys negotiate a better deal?' " Mr. Sable said, noting that the federal government decides what benefits the Postal Service can offer. "I've even heard congressmen campaign on the idea of cutting subsidies to the post office, when the feds haven't subsidized the post office for decades."
Now, Mr. Sable and 13 other corporate chiefs whose businesses cannot function without a thriving mail system, have taken the education of Congress into their own hands. They have formed the Mailing Industry CEO Council to set senators and representatives straight on the Postal Service's facts and figures -- and, they hope, to point Congress toward a workable postal overhaul bill.
"We C.E.O.'s represent a tremendous collective ability to encourage a healthier Postal Service," said Gary M. Mulloy, chief executive of the direct mail marketing firm ADVO and the new council's secretary.
The chief executives have specific cures in mind. For example, they want Congress to make it easier for the Postal Service to raise rates, negotiate employment levels and salaries and close operations.
"We want Congress to let the post office act like the independent agency it's supposed to be," said Michael J. Critelli, the new council's chairman and the chief executive of Pitney Bowes, whose postage-meter and mail-services business depends on a functioning Postal Service. "And we want Congress to acknowledge how important a healthy mail system still is."
Congressional advocates for postal change say they welcome help in getting attention for their cause. "My colleagues in Congress understand the financial difficulties facing the post office," said Senator Susan Collins, Republican of Maine, who recently sponsored a bill to create a presidential commission to look into improving the postal system. "But the business community has to make them more aware of the negative impact of frequent, unpredictable rate increases."
This is not the private sector's first foray into Postal Service issues. Since 1988 the Mailers Council, a group of companies and trade associations that represent more than 70 percent of the country's mail volume, has regularly weighed in on postal rate increases. It also has long shared the CEO Council's frustrations with Congress.
"You can count on two hands the members of Congress who have a serious interest in postal reform or who realize that the Postal Service owes billions of dollars in pensions and insurance," said Robert E. McLean, the group's executive director.
Several of the chief executives on the new council are already members of Mr. McLean's group. In fact, several, along with many of their employees, have also served on the mailing industry task force, which was formed at the Postal Service's behest in the spring of 2001.
But the task force has concentrated on improving operations -- for example, finding more efficient ways for sorting mail, for handling payments for postage and for determining mail-delivery routes. The Mailers Council has focused more on public policy, but it represents so many factions -- junk mailers, catalog companies, banks, publishers, in fact anyone using the mail system -- that consensus has been elusive.
"All the Mailers Council can agree on is that we should cut costs and offer great service," said John M. Nolan, the deputy postmaster general.
Mr. McLean acknowledges this. "The best we've been able to do is ask for a presidential commission to investigate the Postal Service," he said. "If Mike Critelli's group can get Congress interested, we will be truly happy."
The chief executives in the CEO Council must overcome conflicting agendas, too. Indeed, the group's name seems a misnomer, in that its concept of a "mailing industry" is an artificial construct; many of the members run companies that rely on the mail to do business but do not get revenue from the business of mailing. And yet, the CEO Council posits that providers of mail services, like Pitney Bowes, and customers of those services, like Wunderman, make up an industry that employs nine million people, generates $900 billion in annual revenue and represents 8 percent of the gross national product.
"Sure, our subissues may diverge, but we have one common need," said William L. Davis, chief executive of the printing firm R. R. Donnelley & Sons. "We must make the people inside the Beltway understand how far-reaching the postal system's grasp is on the economy."
There is little question the Postal Service can use help. It supposedly is a self-supporting independent agency, but it is owned by the federal government. Although it pays no taxes, it is not subsidized. It deals with four unions -- for city carriers, rural carriers, clerks and mail handlers -- and its labor negotiations are subject to final arbitration.
The Postal Service must go through an arduous legislative review each time it wishes to raise a rate or close an office -- and not surprisingly, few members of Congress will vote to allow any post offices to close in their districts. Moreover, its pension liabilities "would swamp most companies," Mr. Davis said.
So encumbered, the Postal Service lost more than $1 billion in each of the last two years. Although its recent rate increases will probably enable it to turn a profit of $600 million or so in fiscal 2003, which began on Oct. 1, Mr. Nolan puts the amount in context. "That's enough for two weeks' payroll," he said.
What is more, the Postal Service is prohibited from lobbying Congress on its own behalf. Which is where the CEO Council comes in.
"These C.E.O.'s have the ability to present the facts of what we are to Congress, and to persuade Congress and the administration that change is needed," Mr. Nolan said.
Senator Collins echoed that thought. "When Congress is dealing with prescription drugs and war in Iraq," she said, "it helps to have high-profile C.E.O.'s pointing out the importance of postal reform."

HEADLINE: TECHNOLOGY; 
A Boon for Nonprofits With Software Needs

BYLINE:  By LAURIE J. FLYNN 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
If these are lean times for corporate information technology purchasers, what is the situation for nonprofit groups that need new hardware or software? Surprisingly good, as it turns out.
 Despite the moribund information technology economy, the nonprofit sector may actually be benefiting from the slump -- as companies like Microsoft see donations as a way of helping keep their products in widespread use, and as large numbers of otherwise unemployed hardware and software professionals demonstrate a new willingness to take jobs in the nonprofit community. 
 At the Family Stress Center, a county-financed nonprofit family services agency in Concord, Calif., Paul Bongiovanni has the task of continually updating the computer system that keeps the agency running.
That is a challenge because the center serves 7,000 clients a year throughout sprawling Contra Costa County, 30 miles east of San Francisco. 
The agency, which offers programs for the prevention and treatment of child abuse, operates on a budget of only about $2 million. And with 70 or so full- and part-time counselors and administrators to pay, that leaves little left to spend on the latest version of Windows software, say, or on installing additional high-speed Internet lines.
But through a relatively new online software store for nonprofit organizations called DiscounTech, Mr. Bongiovanni, the center's business manager, is able to buy leading software like Norton Antivirus and Microsoft Office XP for about 10 percent of the original retail price. That means instead of paying the $500 or so he might spend on each copy of the Microsoft Office XP suite of word-processing, scheduling, spreadsheet and other applications, Mr. Bongiovanni pays only a $60 administrative fee to CompuMentor, the nonprofit organization in San Francisco that created DiscounTech. That way, he said, the agency can spend its money on technology consultants, instead of software, to get the most out of the technology.
DiscounTech was introduced in February by CompuMentor, which has been offering computer consulting at discounted rates to other nonprofit groups for 15 years, primarily in the Bay Area and Silicon Valley.
The advent of DiscounTech, which is available nationwide, has clearly struck a chord with nonprofit organizations, which in the past have had to rely on a hodgepodge of grants, direct donations and assistance from a variety of foundations to pay for new technology. Or they have simply done without.
That had been the experience, for example, of Mark McNeil, information technology director of the nonprofit Economic Opportunity Council, a social services agency in San Luis Obispo, Calif. Before DiscounTech, Mr. McNeil said, he would typically contact Microsoft and other companies directly to request specific product donations.
"Sometimes it worked, sometimes it didn't, but it always took a lot of effort," said Mr. McNeil, adding that he had also received donated software through Gifts in Kind, an organization that helps match donors of various sorts with nonprofit groups.
But not until DiscounTech came along, Mr. McNeil said, did he find it possible to use the most current versions of leading programs, like Microsoft Office XP and Symantec's antivirus software.
"Our organization has to run pretty lean," Mr. McNeil said. "Now for every four licenses of Microsoft Office we save enough to buy another computer."
Rebecca Masisak, the director of DiscounTech, hopes to start offering discounted computers and networking technology by the end of this year, though many of the details have still to be worked out. Once a DiscounTech customer has installed the purchased technology, the user can then turn to CompuMentor for discounted consulting services, online bulletin boards and an informational Web site for nonprofits called TechSoup.
CompuMentor's original charter -- to match volunteers, or mentors, in the technology industry with nonprofit agencies -- is still a large part of the organization's focus. But the current one-stop approach marks a coming of age for CompuMentor. It was founded in 1987 by Daniel Ben-Horin, a former journalist, who set it up with a $2,500 grant from a local foundation.
"I thought I'd do it for about a year," Mr. Ben-Horin said. Considering the enthusiasm for technology at the time, he said, "it seemed like a no-brainer" to match computer programmers and consultants with agencies in need of their specific services. But keeping his own nonprofit afloat proved to be more challenging than he had expected.
In the last decade, Mr. Ben-Horin said, the organization has come close to bankruptcy more than once. But it is now on firmer footing, as it receives financing from Microsoft and AOL Time Warner, along with the Surda Foundation, the James Irvine Foundation, the Carnegie Corporation and the Kellogg Foundation. CompuMentor is also the Bay Area affiliate of the national network of technology assistance providers, called the NPower Network, that Microsoft founded several years ago.
CompuMentor has benefited somewhat in the last year from the demise of the local Internet economy in San Francisco. For one thing, Mr. Ben-Horin has been able to find spacious offices in a converted warehouse once occupied by a Web company. And he has seen the caliber of job applicants rise, as layoffs sent talented Internet entrepreneurs, project managers and designers looking for their next projects.
Recently, for example, CompuMentor received 500 applications for a single editor job on TechSoup. CompuMentor now employs about 65 people in roomy offices in the southern end of San Francisco once known as Multimedia Gulch.
For software companies, CompuMentor's DiscounTech simplifies the process of donating to numerous small and midsize nonprofit groups -- a disparate array of clinics, community service agencies, homeless shelters and other organizations.
Microsoft, which began distributing a limited selection of programs through CompuMentor, has now made DiscounTech one of the company's largest donation outlets.
In its fiscal year 2002, which ended on June 30, Microsoft donated $25 million in software through DiscounTech, accounting for about one of every eight of the company's software donations, according to Bruce Brooks, Microsoft's director of community affairs.
This fiscal year, Microsoft expects to use DiscounTech to donate $30 million of software.
For Microsoft and other software companies, having their products widely distributed, even at steep discounts or for free, can be a way to raise visibility -- a tax-deductible form of marketing.
"There's a definite market-recognition factor in the nonprofit sector," agreed Eran Goren, vice president of business development at Ontero Software, which donates its Web portal program called InfoCentral. "And it's a sector that definitely has a need."

HEADLINE: New Bond Issues Will Be Brought To Market in Week

HEADLINE: A Powerful, Flawed Witness Against Enron 

BYLINE:  By KURT EICHENWALD 

 BODY:
The recent plea agreement with a former senior Enron trader presents new opportunities for the law enforcement officials investigating a range of possible crimes at the company. But it also creates challenges for prosecutors that did not exist before.
 Under the agreement announced last week, the trader, Timothy N. Belden, pleaded guilty to conspiring with others to manipulate the California energy market during the state's energy crises that began in 2000, and he agreed to cooperate in the investigation of Enron. In his statements to the court, Mr. Belden acknowledged submitting false commitments for energy delivery for the purpose of driving up prices. 
 Prosecutors now have both a crucial witness to aid in the investigation of trading irregularities, and one who can create paths of inquiry, potentially going further up the line in Enron's management. Already, people involved in the case said, Mr. Belden has provided information to investigators about Enron's broadband unit as well as about its use of huge reserves from its California energy trading to offset losses in other businesses.
But Mr. Belden also arrives with certain baggage as a witness. He is the first crucial witness in the Enron case to have provided statements in the past about his wrongdoing -- as far back as three years ago -- and presented answers that any clever defense lawyer would use to undermine his accusation of a conspiracy involving others at Enron. At bottom, during those interviews, Mr. Belden has maintained at times that his actions were not illegal and that he, and he alone, was responsible for them.
At issue is the complex system that was adopted by California in 1996 and made operational two years later. The law created two institutions, the California Power Exchange, which served as the primary marketplace for wholesale electricity, and the California Independent System Operator, which was responsible for managing the state's energy-transmission grid. Through those institutions, the energy marketers, including Enron, would schedule deliveries of fixed amounts of electricity to their wholsesale and retail customers.
There were plenty of ways for energy marketers to profit from high demand. If a power line was overcrowded by too much scheduled delivery, a marketer would be paid a "congestion management fee" for rescheduling a delivery or moving power in the other direction. Marketers were also paid for making commitments to deliver standby electricity in the event of a sudden loss of supplies. Then, if generators in the state could not supply the needed power, marketers could sell out-of-state electricity at a higher price.
But the rules seemed to rely on traders not taking advantage of the system -- something Enron did, according to the company's records and other documents. It submitted bogus schedules for huge amounts of electricity for delivery, thus creating congestion, then received payments for "relieving" overcrowding that did not really exist. It guaranteed delivery of large amounts of power it did not intend to deliver. And it shipped power out of California, only to ship it back as high-priced "out-of-state" electricity. 
By 1999, one year into the new California system -- and before the energy crisis hit with full force -- Mr. Belden and Enron were already engaged in some of those activities. On May 25, 1999, Enron scheduled for the transmission of nearly 2,900 megawatts of electricity over a line known as the Silver Peak, which was able to carry just 15 megawatts. The power was never sent, but the bogus scheduling caused energy disruptions and higher prices. California opened an inquiry, questioning executives including Mr. Belden. 
At that time, Mr. Belden said nothing about a conspiracy or acting on the instructions of others. Rather, according to notes from the interview, Mr. Belden assumed responsibility for the event. "He was the sole party responsible for making the decisions to submit the bids and schedules that led to the event," investigative notes from the interview read.
Of course, the statement was limited to the Silver Peak event, and does not explicitly eliminate possible knowledge of Mr. Belden's actions on the part of others. But legal experts said that such a statement was sure to be an issue in any trial in which Mr. Belden served as a main witness.
"A statement like this would certainly be a priority and a key line of questioning for anyone facing charges resulting from Mr. Belden's cooperation," said Stephen Meagher, a former prosecutor in San Francisco. "Any lawyer would want to get to the bottom of why one transaction was presumably so different from the others in which he is now implicating other senior executives." 
Of course, the existence of such a statement does not prove that Mr. Belden was misrepresenting anything; rather, it is simply a piece of evidence that can be used to attack his credibility on the stand. The creation of such problems is one of the reasons lawyers often insist that their clients refuse to testify during a criminal investigation, because they can be locked into an account that later works against them. 
Cristina C. Arguedas, a lawyer for Mr. Belden, did not return a telephone call seeking comment. 
According to the investigative notes, Mr. Belden submitted the bogus bids and schedules on Silver Peak as an experiment. He told investigators that the effort was "only intended by its actions to make clear to the marketplace that a dangerous loophole existed," the notes say.
Ultimately, California fined Enron $25,000 for its maneuvers on Silver Peak, and its then head of trading, Lawrence G. Whalley, signed an agreement never to repeat such maneuvers. But according to Mr. Belden's admissions last week, that is exactly what Enron did during the energy crisis.
The trading pattern was eventually discovered in 2000 by Enron lawyers, who interviewed Mr. Belden about his strategies. And again, the notes of those interviews, which have been obtained by investigators, provide page after page of additional previous statements by Mr. Belden that could be used to undermine his credibility. 
Why would Mr. Belden have been so open in his discussions about potential wrongdoing, when so many others at Enron have refused to speak about the scandal? For one, the interviews took place in 1999 and 2000, before the Enron scandal exploded into public view. Moreover, many traders, Mr. Belden included, seem to have thought that such manipulations were simply clever methods of taking advantage of poor rules, rather than illegality.
But legal experts said, regardless of the regulations in place, obtaining profits through the submission of false documents, as Mr. Belden did, crosses the line into criminal fraud.
"Gaining economic advantage through material misrepresentation doesn't really require regulations to be violated" for a criminal prosecution, Mr. Meagher said. "It's fraud, pure and simple."

 BODY:
Vivendi Moves Up Deadline On Bids for Publishing Unit
Vivendi Universal is rushing suitors of its publishing business, which includes Houghton Mifflin, to submit final bids by today, executives involved in the discussions said.
 Vivendi, which is trying to sell assets to cut its enormous debt, moved up the bidding deadline so that it could negotiate a higher bid, or possibly counter, an offer by the Vodafone Group for Vivendi's stake in Cegetel, the large French phone company. Page C2. 

$2.3 Billion Bid for TXU Europe Unit
Powergen, a unit of Germany's E.On, and Scottish and Southern Energy have submitted bids for part of TXU Europe, the troubled subsidiary of TXU, the former Texas Utilities, people involved in the discussions said. The bids are valued at $:1.5 billion ($2.3 billion) for the retail arm of TXU Europe, which serves 5.25 million customers in Britain, these people said. C2.

First Novel Becomes Best Seller
"The Lovely Bones" by Alice Sebold has become the biggest-selling book of the year, beating competition from Tom Clancy, Nicholas Sparks and Stephen King. It is the literary equivalent of that other word-of-mouth success, "My Big Fat Greek Wedding." How the book, a first novel, became a best seller reflects its strength in a wave of literary novels. It is a trend that appears to be blurring the boundaries of literary and commercial fiction. C7.

Group Aims for a Postal Overhaul
A group of corporate chief executives whose businesses cannot function without a thriving mail system have formed the Mailing Industry CEO Council. The group is lobbying for a postal overhaul bill. New Economy. C3.

Internet Merchants Fight Fraud
Internet merchants, weary of a near constant barrage of credit-card fraud that costs them more than $1 billion each year, have formed a round table to identify users of stolen credit cards, catch criminals and perhaps soothe the fears of millions of would-be online shoppers. Bob Tedeschi: E-Commerce Report. C6.

An End to Cellphone Telemarketing?
The Direct Marketing Association, a trade group, plans to announce a plan today to prevent telemarketers from calling people on their cellphones. The group has identified 280 million existing and prospective wireless numbers and will try to have marketers eliminate them from their lists. C5.

U.S. Battery Maker to Be Rescued
A Chinese state-owned chemical company has agreed to rescue an American battery manufacturer from bankruptcy and continue its global manufacturing operations, a deal both sides called the first of its kind. C2.

Nonprofits Reap Software Benefit
CompuMentor, a nonprofit organization in San Francisco founded by Daniel Ben-Horin, left, created a software store for other nonprofit groups. The store, called DiscounTech, is able to purchase leading software titles like Norton Antivirus and Microsoft Office XP for about 10 percent of their original retail price. Companies like Microsoft are donating software as a way of helping keep their products in widespread use. C3.

Renewed Push on Recording Labels
Federal lawmakers have renewed a push for recording companies to toughen labeling standards on sexually explicit and violent lyrics. But the music industry is resisting. C7.

HEADLINE: Market Place; 
For Big Game Maker, Online Play Is a Big Gamble

BYLINE:  By MATT RICHTEL 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
Electronic Arts is a Silicon Valley company markedly out of step with its neighbors.
 In this region, where the market values of many technology companies have shriveled the last two years, Electronic Arts, the world's biggest video-game publisher, has flourished. On Friday, its shares closed at $70.14, its highest finish since the company went public 13 years ago, and up 13 percent for the year. 
 Analysts attribute the stock's ascent both to continued strength by Electronic Arts and to an industry growth cycle driven by the introduction of hardware platforms the last two years: Sony's PlayStation 2, Nintendo's GameCube and Microsoft's Xbox. Retail and video-game industry analysts say the sale of the hardware, and the games played upon them, could be a rare bright spot this holiday season, though perhaps not as bright as previously projected. 
Electronic Arts remains so confident that it has decided to postpone the release of a potentially top-selling game from the holiday season, the peak period for video game sales. Sims 4 -- the latest version of its popular game in which players control characters as they go through their daily lives -- will be delayed until early next year. 
The idea is to avoid cannibalizing sales of its other major holiday games, including James Bond 007: Nightfire; Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets; and The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers. In particular, Electronic Arts wants to leave the field clear for The Sims Online, an Internet-based game whose success may dictate whether the company will meet its and Wall Street's lofty expectations. 
"The Sims Online is the most important game they've come out with in a long time," said Michael P. Wallace, an analyst with UBS Warburg.
"Everyone knows they're going to have a good Christmas, but that game determines where the stock goes," Mr. Wallace said. "If it's not a hit, you're looking at more losses in the online division, and the stock hits a wall."
A growing number of people are betting the stock will do just that. The interest of short sellers -- investors who bet that a stock falls -- has grown steadily to its highest point in more than a year. As of Sept. 13, the most recent date for which the data is available, there were 11.8 million shares of short interest, the shares that have been borrowed and sold short -- 12 percent of the outstanding shares -- compared with 10.7 million the month before, and 8.8 million shares in Oct. 2001.
At Friday's closing price, the shares are selling at around 34 times projected earnings, not particularly high by historical standards -- the company's stock typically trades at 25 to 35 times earnings -- but it is twice the amount of several of the other major game makers, including Activision and THQ.
So investors will be watching closely when Electronic Arts announces its second-quarter financial results this week. 
So far, the company has had a strong year. For the last two quarters -- its fourth quarter of fiscal year 2002 and its first quarter of fiscal 2003 -- total revenue increased more than 80 percent over the periods a year earlier. For the company's second quarter, Wall Street is projecting revenue of around $393 million, which would be about a 64 percent increase over last year's period, and a profit of 17 cents a share -- compared with a loss of 24 cents a share in the period a year earlier, which analysts attributed to investments in the online unit's start-up.
As an industry, video games are still larger by sales volume than are Hollywood movies, with $9.4 billion of games and hardware sold in 2001. And recently, as in the early 1990's, the industry has seemed to be ignoring the economic recession.
But in the last few weeks, industry analysts said, retailers have expressed concern that video games will sell less well this holiday season than previously forecast, as worries mount that the current economic doldrums are too prolonged to insulate game companies. John G. Taylor, an analyst with Arcadia Investment, said that earlier this year analysts had been projecting industry sales as high as $12 billion for 2002. He now expects the final number to be closer to $10.5 billion.
One game maker, Acclaim Entertainment, publisher of the popular Turok action games, had a nasty surprise for Wall Street last Thursday, reporting a much deeper loss than expected for its fiscal fourth quarter, blaming weak sales for Turok and its other top games. The stock, already weak, collapsed, closing on Friday at 73 cents, only a fraction of its 52-week high of $6.25 last November.
Video-game industry analysts say that retailers had cut back their orders for games, and may cut shelf space allotted to the software.
"Retailers have a decent amount of inventory that is under-performing," said Mr. Taylor He said that average weekly sales of hardware had "flat-lined" since July, leading to lower expectations for software sales. The retailers, Mr. Taylor said, "realized there is a ton of new products they are expected to absorb between August and December."
Indeed, from now to Christmas, video-game makers will introduce 300 games -- more than 20 from Electronic Arts, which took in about half its 2001 revenue of $1.3 billion in the holiday quarter last year.
Among the new games, the most crucial for Electronic Arts may be The Sims Online. The game is an Internet version of the Sims series, which is one of the most successful video games of all time and has an usually high number of female players. In it, players oversee their online characters as they go to work, build a home, and develop relationships. In the online version, players will be able to interact with one another over the Internet, conceivably creating a virtual world where people play out real-world pursuits.
Moving the game online is a potential watershed not just for Electronic Arts, but for the industry. So far, the handful of online games that have succeeded are action-adventure games like EverQuest, a role-playing game, published by Sony Online Entertainment, that are not aimed at the mainstream audience Sims tends to attract.
Electronic Arts has spent some $300 million on EA.com, the Web site and related technology that will support The Sims Online -- an investment that some industry analysts have criticized as too large and too risky. For the Internet operation to break even, analysts say, EA.com will need to attract 250,000 subscribers at a fee that analysts expect to be around $10 a month. 
John S. Riccitiello, the president of Electronic Arts, said that for EA.com to attract a substantial customer base, the game must truly appeal to a mainstream audience even more so than it currently does. In turn, he said, there is a challenge in making the game highly accessible to people who are not inveterate game players.
"To get to one million or more subscribers, we're going to make the game feel really friendly," he said, expressing some doubt as to whether the designers had yet achieved that goal. "We need to do some work to improve the newby experience."
Mr. Riccitiello said the company still expected to have the EA.com unit break even by the end of the year and get "north of 200,000 subscribers." But that would take a remarkably fast start, given that The Sims Online has yet to be rolled out.
It was to better focus consumer attention on The Sims Online that the company decided to delay the introduction of Sims 4 until the spring, Mr. Riccitiello said. "We've got so much going on," he said, "that we needed a little more room for them."
Shawn Milne, an analyst with SoundView Technology, said it made sense for Electronic Arts, which will spend $200 million in the quarter on marketing for all its games, to focus on The Sims Online. "If they don't execute properly, it will mar their core business strength." 
The Sims Online aside, analysts say Electronic Arts continues to do several things right: the company emphasizes sports games, most notably its signature game, John Madden Football, publishing new versions each year to capitalize on evolving technology, and updating players and teams.
Mr. Taylor, the Arcadia analyst, said another reason for the company's strength is that it does not rely on a single game for its revenue. "It's the single most diversified publisher out there," he said, noting that in 2001, even John Madden Football accounted for only 11 percent of the company's total revenue. 
Because of the company's dominance, Mr. Milne and several other analysts said they did not expect Electronic Arts to feel the pinch if retailers reduced the shelf space allotted to video games. Instead, they said, retailers will probably continue to stock the known brands, and sacrifice less popular games from smaller companies that lack Electronic Arts' marketing power. 
The company may also continue to benefit from the fact that the industry is still in only the early stages of the new product cycle for the Sony PlayStation 2, Microsoft Xbox and Nintendo GameCube. Last year, Microsoft and Nintendo sold about a million consoles each, and Mr. Wallace, the UBS Warburg analyst, predicts the companies will sell 4 million each this year. He said that Sony, which sold about 6 million PlayStation 2's last year, will sell about 7.5 million this year. 
The hardware sales are a reason Mr. Riccitiello argues that analysts' forecasts for game software are too low. "People are now seeing growth of 15 percent for the year," he said, referring to industry sales in general. "I think that's low by 5 points, maybe 10."

HEADLINE: Thunder in Paradise: A Resilient Bali Prepares for a Storm 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: KUTA, Indonesia, Oct. 19 

 BODY:
The allure of surf and a Hindu culture of temples and incense that tolerated discos and drinking made Bali the elixir of good time, low-cost contemporary tourism.
 When the attackers blew up the Sari Club on Oct. 12, they hit at the heart of the dream of every young Western traveler. 
 But behind the commercial patina lay a place of local religious devotion and personal elegance that attracted foreign painters and jewelers, fashion designers and furniture makers and their fancy friends for much of the 20th century. 
Drawn to houses with deep cool verandas set in a lush landscape, where living is made easy by smiling, sarong-clad staff members, a colony of Europeans and Americans have lived what many would consider a fantasy life in paradise. 
In recent years, upmarket hoteliers packaged that lifestyle into expensive resorts that included outdoor spas fringed with frangipani, and $1,000-a-night luxury villas. 
Whether the attackers, who are believed to be Islamic militants tied to Al Qaeda, will succeed in destroying all this remains an open question.
In the short term, tourism will plunge, residents said. But in the longer term, they suggested, the island may bounce back because in the past, the Balinese have shown resilience against natural disaster and political turmoil. 
"What will happen now?" asked Idanna Pucci, an anthropologist who splits her time between Bali and Manhattan. "It will depend on how the Balinese react. The religious authorities in every village have been asking the population to keep calm and to face this terrible tragedy in a nonviolent way."
There was some concern, Ms. Pucci said, that the Hindu Balinese would retaliate against the Muslim minority, most of whom have come in recent years from the adjacent and overcrowded island of Java. 
Last Wednesday, in an effort to keep the peace, the island's priests asked their congregations to attend temple and make offerings -- platters of fruit, candy and little cakes -- for the souls of those who died. 
Bali was discovered by European travelers in the 1920's and 30's, when the island's interior -- mountains, terraces of emerald rice fields and banana and coconut trees -- became the stuff of paintings by Dutch and German artists. Walter Spies, a German painter, settled in the village of Ubud, far from the beach in 1927, and helped introduce Balinese painters and culture to the world.
The American anthropologist Margaret Mead studied the religion, and Charlie Chaplin used Balinese comic actors as the inspiration for his famously disjointed walk. By the end of the 1960's, hippies from London and New York found Bali a sanctuary of freedom. 
Ms. Pucci remembers arriving in 1973 as an anthropologist and thinking that her new way of life was "like being high without drugs." 
The Westerners were fascinated, she said, by the integration of religion into everyday life and by the temple ceremonies for various deities. 
But by the late 1970's, the idyll began to change.
The international airport was built near the capital, Denpasar, in 1969; the first major American hotel, the Hyatt, opened in 1973; and Australians looking for a nearby vacation spot poured onto the island. The village of Kuta became a crowded thoroughfare jammed with boutiques, bars and eventually the Sari Club. 
Once the hotels opened, a new economy developed, backed by expatriates and maintained by Balinese labor. The expatriates ran businesses to supply the hotels with food and furniture. Then, exploiting the artistic talents of the Balinese, some expatriates moved into jewelry and clothing. 
Today, an American, John Harding, has entire villages making jewelry that sells at Neiman Marcus and other high-end American stores. An Italian clothing designer, Milo, sells his creations of silk and organza that are hand stitched by Balinese women for wealthy clients in Asia.
An Australian jewelry designer, Lyn Shwaiko, who lives in Ubud, said she arrived in Bali in 1974. In those days, the backpackers' route had three high points, Goa, Katmandu and Bali, she said. For her, Bali was special because it was far from Europe.
"In those days, obviously they had a spiritualism that transcended everything else," said Ms. Shwaiko. "For those of us coming from the West, it was amazing to see people living in such a spiritual way." 
Beyond that, she said, the Balinese were economically smart. The agricultural system based on rice cultivation was so efficient, with natural irrigation from the mountain waters, that the farmers had plenty of time to develop the arts. "The Balinese had the time for the arts; this was immensely attractive to people from the West," she said. 
But in recent years, a darker side has developed. 
So much land has been taken over for commercial use that Bali is no longer self-sufficient in rice. Ms. Pucci said she was worried that layoffs in the hotel industry in the wake of the disco bombing would force people back to their villages where they would probably face a shortage of food. "A lot of people are going to be hungry, for sure," she said.
Along with the hotels on the coast came boisterous establishments like the Sari Club, where scantily attired surfers, footballers and young women mixed in a heady atmosphere of music, sex and booze.
The club was the most popular among young foreign travelers. To the established expatriate community, it represented the worst of the West in Bali, synthetic carpet, flip-flops and T-shirts and all-night carousing. 
Until a recent court case, Ms. Shwaiko said, the club posted a sign saying only "foreign nationals" would be admitted. Later, the admission standard was changed to "invitation only," code for a policy that tried to exclude Balinese, she said.
At the other end of the tourism market, Bradley and Debbie Gardner, a couple who first came to Bali in the 1970's, built a hotel consisting of five villas on a hillside near Ubud.
One of the villas features its own indoor-outdoor swimming pool, and a three-room bathroom pavilion. There have been cancellations since the disco bombing, and the hotel has returned deposits, said Mr. Gardner.
"But this is early days," he said. "You look forward and you move forward. I think the Balinese will do the same. We chose Bali over other places in Asia because Bali is not just another coconut tree and sandy beach."

An article on Monday about potential effects of the Bali nightclub bombing on the economy and people of Bali misstated the surname and nationality of a foreigner who has a jewelry business there. He is John Hardy, not Harding. He is Canadian, not American.

HEADLINE: Metro Matters; 
Upstate Voters Wait to Hear A Plan for Jobs

BYLINE:  By JOYCE PURNICK 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE 

 BODY:
THE campaign for governor has not exactly riveted this city in central New York. Many of the people encountered during a visit here last week didn't even know that Syracuse was playing host to a campaign debate yesterday, nor did they evince much interest when told.
 But when asked what burdens them and their city, they showed no lack of energy, answering in choruslike agreement, from once-grand Salina Street downtown to Carousel Center, the mall a few minutes north. 
 "Oh my God, the jobs," said Fran DeRoberts, buying coffee at the mall's food court. "People are moving out right and left." Ms. DeRoberts, 66, is a native with three children, one of whom has moved to Tucson. 
People follow the jobs. That is the story of central and western New York, and as the public sees it, none of the candidates for governor are saying enough about it.
"They talk about it -- superficially," said Anna Giannantonio, a retired accountant, as she waited for a bus downtown. "And only when forced to."
Onondaga County just cut some programs and raised its property taxes by 4 percent after reducing them for six years running, citing higher Medicaid costs and other state mandates.
"Jobs Stuck in Neutral" read a headline on Friday in The Post-Standard here, above an article about 400 fewer people on payrolls in September than the year before. Unemployment is slightly lower than the statewide figure, but economists say that reflects a drop in the number of job-hunters. Nothing to boast about.
"We're not depressed, just not thriving," said Michael J. Wasylenko, professor of economics at the Maxwell School of Citizenship and Public Affairs at Syracuse University. "We are still creating jobs but also losing a lot of population. It's just going down steadily."
Other cities in central and western New York have it even worse. Census figures show that from 1990 to 1999, Syracuse (population 150,000) lost 9,300 people, or 1.2 percent; Binghamton lost 6 percent; and Utica and Rome, 7.5 percent.
"People keep losing jobs here, keep getting laid off," said Christopher Wiater, 49, a parking attendant at a Murbro parking lot downtown. Mr. Wiater, laid off from a plastics factory a year ago after more than 12 years, now earns half of what he did, and gets no benefits. "It's just a job, keeps me going," he explained.
MOST of the jobs that are being created are low paying, like those at Carousel Center, which plans to expand into the largest mall in the country -- DestiNY USA -- with help from federal and state tax incentives and property tax exemptions.
Fine, say Syracusans, but why doesn't government give equivalent resources to companies that can provide higher-paying jobs?
Jessica M. Lasda, a 20-year-old college junior and a native of Syracuse, is worried about her future. "To be paid equitably you have to move out or start your own business. I have roots here. Syracuse is depleting its own resources. Attempting to make it the largest mall in America is the wrong decision. I've worked here. It cannot sustain the business it gets now."
She's not sure how she will vote, and is not alone. Though ads and posters sell the candidacies of Gov. George E. Pataki, Comptroller H. Carl McCall and Tom Golisano, the campaign seems distant.
Mr. Pataki is still expected to win here, but Mr. Golisano, the businessman from Rochester who is financing his campaign, has made some inroads, and, counterintuitively, seems to be hurting Mr. McCall more than Mr. Pataki, who tried to push Mr. Golisano out of the campaign.
"It's a three-way race," said Assemblyman William B. Magnarelli, a Democrat from the area. "With things going the same old way, people want a change."
Jeffrey M. Stonecash, a professor of political science at the Maxwell School who has conducted polls for Republican candidates from upstate, has found that trend reflected in his polls. "Golisano is taking from Democats and independents, people who are disaffected."
Consider Louis Levine, a lawyer and a Democrat. "Pataki and McCall are downstaters and Golisano is an upstater, so I think he'll pay more attention to us," said Mr. Levine, 50.
People in his city care basically about three issues, in his opinion. "There's the economy, jobs, education. What else is there to talk about?"
During yesterday's debate, six candidates did talk about those issues when asked -- for at least 60 seconds at a stretch.

HEADLINE: News Analysis; 
North Korea's Confession: Why?

BYLINE:  By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
When the United States announced last week that North Korean officials had acknowledged the existence of a secret nuclear weapons program in violation of a 1994 accord, a simple question could be heard echoing around the world: What were the North Koreans thinking? 
 With a tightly controlled, highly secretive country that is home to the world's only Communist dynasty, the temptation of outsiders to write off North Korea's leaders as crackpot Machiavellis or scarily unpredictable weirdoes is sometimes irresistible. 
 Many close watchers of North Korean affairs, however, say that for all of the leadership's eccentricities, the decisions are seldom outright irrational. Experts who disagree on many other matters concerning North Korea say decision making in the country whose future holds the key to peace and stability in northeast Asia is driven by an impulse for survival amid ever constricting options. 
"A lot of people have interpreted the announcement by North Korea of its uranium enrichment program as a sudden tactical move, perhaps trying to take advantage of the fact that the United States is preoccupied with Iraq," said Victor D. Cha, a Korea expert at Georgetown University in Washington, D.C. "But that's not the case at all. This was a case where Washington simply had the goods on them, and Pyongyang just didn't see any other way out." 
For years, North Korea has perfected a kind of bloodcurdling official polemics used by the national radio and newspapers to denounce the United States, South Korea and Japan, and to warn its enemies that they will suffer humiliating defeat if they dare attack.
In fact, North Korea experts say, the tone has grown harsher in almost direct proportion to the country's underlying insecurity. Since the early 1980's, when it was still at rough economic parity with its capitalist rival, South Korea, North Korea's situation has grown steadily more precarious.
The late 1980's opened an era of disasters, from the disappearance of the Soviet bloc, whose countries were North Korea's main economic partners, to a series of catastrophic famines brought on by crop failures, droughts and flooding.
Against this backdrop, the United States, the North's great historical enemy, has emerged as the world's sole superpower, and one increasingly willing to move against nations it sees as threats. In another nightmare come true, South Korea, meanwhile, has become vastly richer. 
Even China, long the ever dependable ally, has taken more distance from North Korea lately, as witnessed last month by Beijing's arrest of a Chinese investor who had just been handpicked by Pyongyang to oversee a newly announced capitalist enterprise zone.
Lacking in generous friends at a time when the economy is crumbling, the country's leader, Kim Jong Il, is facing a moment of unusual vulnerability. He has already introduced major reforms aimed at opening the economy, but he appears increasingly unable to resist pressures for more far-reaching changes. Among those changes, some experts say, may be the recent trend toward diplomacy by confession.
Faced with the urgent need to fend off economic collapse, Mr. Kim's confession of a uranium-based nuclear weapons program appears to many experts to have been a pragmatic, if ultimately misguided response to an insurmountable obstacle: a Bush Administration that had little interest in engagement.
Admission of the nuclear program rather than denial, appears to have been intended to "persuade the world that Kim Jong Il is a new kind of leader, and his leadership does not resort to terrorist means, or secrecy," said Han S. Park, director of the Center for the Study of Global Issues at the University of Georgia. 
Mr. Kim tried the same approach last month, when he was host for a meeting with Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan. Faced with Japanese demands for an explanation of the disappearance of 11 of its citizens in the late 1970's, the North Korean leader bluntly reversed a long tradition of angry denial, and apologized for what he acknowledged were official kidnappings.
Initially, the admission seemed to propel North Korean-Japanese relations strongly forward, with widespread expectations of rapidly normalized ties and large-scale aid from Japan. As the sordid details of the kidnappings have sunk in here, though, Mr. Koizumi has been forced by sensitive public opinion to be far more cautious.
North Korea desperately needs better relations with the Japan and the United States because the former has long promised to provide heavy development assistance once relations are normalized, while the latter controls many of the international financial institutions, whose cooperation is indispensable to North Korea's re-entry into the global economy. 
Looking at his confessions, Mr. Kim appears to have focused on the issues most important to each of those two nations: the emotive question of the fate of its citizens for Japan, and weapons of mass destruction for the United States.
"North Korea has always wanted to pursue normalization with the United States, and however awkwardly, now they are bargaining," said Selig S. Harrison, director of the National Security Program at the Center for International Policy in Washington. "What they are saying is that they are prepared to negotiate an end to all nuclear activity and allow inspections, if we agree to two things: not to threaten them militarily and to pursue normalized relations." 
Mr. Harrison, who is the author of "Korean Endgame: A Strategy for Reunification and U.S. Disengagement," said Pyongyang's position was spelled out to him this week by the country's representative to the United Nations.
Whether or not North Korea seeks to negotiate with Washington along these lines, its acknowledgment of a nuclear weapons program has inflicted faster and far graver setbacks than the missing persons issue with Japan.
"This is not a crisis yet, but it may be the last stage before a crisis," Mr. Cha said. "This administration is not going to pay to go inspect another hole in the ground, and whatever happens, it is not going to be framed as an exchange, where everyone gives up something to obtain Pyongyang's cooperation."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN; 
Pledging to Focus on Lowering Property Taxes and Loosening Drug Laws

 BODY:
 Following are excerpts from the debate yesterday among six of the candidates for governor, as recorded by The New York Times. The participants were Thomas K. Leighton, Marijuana Reform Party; Scott Jeffrey, Libertarian Party; George E. Pataki, Republican Party; H. Carl McCall, Democratic Party; Stanley Aronowitz, Green Party; and Tom Golisano, Independence Party. More excerpts are online at nytimes.com/nyregion.

Property Taxes

Q. . . . Property taxes in New York State are well above the national average of 1.5 percent of the value of a home. Many New Yorkers pay 3.5 to 4 percent of the value of their home in property tax. Do you think this is a problem? And if so, what can you do on the state level to lessen the property tax burden?

MR. JEFFREY -- Yes, it's a terrible problem. Taxes in our state are out of control. We have utility taxes on top of the property. People are paying for electricity, taxing on their telephones, on their cable. What we need to do, I spoke about at the last debate, was we need to end corporate welfare. We need to quit these giant tax breaks, giving giant tax breaks to giant corporations. When we talk about the empire zones in development, these projects aren't free. And they're funded on the backs of small businessmen and on the average taxpayer. And if these projects made economic sense developers would build. . . .

Q. Thank you, Mr. Jeffrey. Governor Pataki.

MR. PATAKI -- Yes, I remember very well, long before I got into politics, I lived in a close community with many of my family members. And I remember my aunt when she was maybe in her early 70's telling me she was going to sell her house. And she lived right next to my parents where I had grown up. And I asked her why. And she said, "I simply can't afford the school property taxes. I have to sell." So I know that it's painful when someone is forced out of their home. And we have put in place a number of programs and are going to do more to deal with this issue. The most important is the STAR program. It is the single greatest effort to help local property owners that this state has ever put in place. And right now it is saving senior citizens from school taxes to the tune of about $2.8 billion a year. All homeowners, here in Onondaga County and across this state, benefit from the STAR program. . . . We have to continue to have state budgets that reduce the burden on local governments. And we have to look to reorganize local governments. And we're putting in place a task force . . . to do that.

Q. . . . Comptroller McCall, your answer to the same question.

MR. McCALL -- Property taxes are really a terrible burden on people throughout this state. We have the highest property taxes in the country, 72 percent above the national average. George Pataki will talk about cutting state taxes, but what he's really done is he's shifted the burden from the state to the localities. Every locality, every county executive is now announcing his budget. And all of those budgets are increasing property taxes on property owners across the state. What the governor has done is passed on to our localities unfunded mandates.
If we want the counties to engage in new activity, then we at the state level are going to have to pay for it. . . . 

Q. Stanley Aronowitz.

MR. ARONOWITZ -- Well, the first thing we have to say is that we need education. And we need health care. And we need environmental protection. And we have to have a way to pay for it. And we can't pay for it by property taxes primarily because property taxes are the most unfair, sales taxes are the next unfair form of taxation. If the state is going to take responsibility for the mandates to, for example, make sure that poor people have Medicaid, you can't cut Medicaid as Mr. Golisano would do. Because if you cut Medicaid, what you're doing is you're hurting people. Now the basic problem that we have is that we have to have a tax program that taxes those who can best afford to pay fairly.
Property taxes are a regressive tax. But incomes taxes are relatively speaking a progressive tax. And I have a tax plan that could help solve those problems. . . .

Q. . . . Mr. Golisano . . .

MR. GOLISANO -- The issue of property taxes obviously is a very important question to New Yorkers. It's almost to the point now where our tax payments are almost larger than our mortgage payments. And that is a situation that we cannot tolerate. Let me tell you this story as a business person. About three months ago, I transferred a senior executive from Atlanta, Ga., to Paychex in Rochester, N.Y. The gentleman bought a house, approximately the same market value, approximately the same square footage. He found out his property taxes in Atlanta, Ga., were $5,000 and are going to $15,000 in New York State. He walked into my office and he said, "Tom, as a business person, what are you going to do about it?" The fact of the matter is, as a business person we have to pay our people higher in New York State just so they can pay their tax burden.

Q. . . . Mr. Leighton.

MR. LEIGHTON -- Well, I think the first thing we have to do is change the way we fund public education in New York. I propose that we shift funding for public education away from property taxes into a combination of sales and income taxes and general revenues. And that way everybody will pay their fair share of costs of public education and all schools will get the same.
Now we all know that nobody wants to pay more taxes. But there is one group who does want to pay more taxes. And I represent today probably one million New Yorkers who are . . . eager and ready to pay more taxes. . . . I know that New Yorkers who smoke marijuana would much rather pay taxes to this state via a regulated market for marijuana rather than buy their marijuana from a black market dealer or face a risk of arrest. And this represents millions of dollars of tax revenue. . . .

Budget

Q. . . . What steps do you plan to take to address the projected deficits? And why haven't more steps been taken before the election to cut costs?

MR. McCALL -- Well first of all, the people who've been in charge haven't done that. Instead what we've seen over the last few years, a year of great surplus, in fact, is that the governor spent money three times the rate of inflation, increased the state's debt by some 35 percent and made no effort to reduce the debt. . . .
We have to have better management of our fiscal affairs. When I become governor, I'm going to inherit a mess. But I'm going to go in with a professional group of people and we're going to analyze the situation and we're going to take whatever steps are necessary to turn this economy around. 
You know, one of the problems we have here is that this is a nice opportunity for us to come and have a minute to talk about the important issues that face the state, but this issue of the budget and how we're going to face the crisis that comes ahead, we need to have a real debate. And I've challenged the governor to sit down with me and let's have a real debate and talk about the issue, about how we're going to face the challenge of the future. We're not going to be able to do it in these one-minute sound bites. . . .

Q. . . . Mr. Aronowitz.

MR. ARONOWITZ -- Well, Mr. McCall, when I took up your challenge to have a real debate with you, you withdrew your offer. You said that I had debated you, but that debate was about housing. So I'm not so sure that you really want to debate with everybody at this table. You may want to debate with Pataki, but you don't want a real debate with anybody else.

MR. McCALL -- You're right.

MR. ARONOWITZ -- Well, Carl, that asks the question, either you meant it or you didn't mean it last time.
Anyway, I think our major problems about budget is that nobody is talking seriously about what to do about the budget. We still say when we want to create jobs that we're going to create corporate welfare, we're going to give corporations money. Mr. Golisano takes $600,000 in his corporation to accept money to keep jobs. 
We really should not be paying the large corporations anything. We should be dealing with the tax issue in a very concentrated way, a way that will allow us to face the music. Either we're going to have public goods or we're going to have nothing. And we're going to have layoffs and libraries will shut down and state workers will shut down. And I'm opposed to that, so I'm for a real tax program.

Q. . . . And your response, Mr. Golisano.

MR. GOLISANO -- Well, first of all, I think it's great that Paychex has created thousands of jobs in this state. We're very proud of it. We're one of the leading edge companies in upstate New York. And I think the governor and all the other candidates should be very proud of what Paychex has accomplished. Secondly, I agree with Carl McCall, trying to discuss these budget issues in a 60-second soundbite is not possible. We know the budget has gone up 45 percent under Mr. Pataki. We know we're the highest in debt population in the country, 18 straight years. . . .
Mr. Pataki has been talking about leadership. I want to bring up another subject as long as I have a few minutes. There is a scandal in our state where we sold paroles for campaign contributions. The U.S. attorney called it the worst campaign scandal in generations. A parole board chairman was an unindicted co-conspirator in these sales. And he's still on the job. My question to the governor is why is this person still on the job running the New York State Parole Board after this indecent scandal?

Q. . . . To try to refocus the issue, Mr. Leighton, we're talking about the budget deficit, the projected deficit and what you'd do about it.

MR. LEIGHTON -- Well, I already addressed this issue in the first question when I talked about new hemp industry, new revenues and paying taxes on the sale of marijuana. . . . Recently, Mr. Golisano has been running campaign commercials about medical marijuana. Now I welcome his support on this issue. But I wonder why now, three weeks before the election, he is choosing to do so. Mr. Golisano has been a candidate for eight years and we've heard nothing about medical marijuana. Why is he doing this now? The answer is very simple. It's an act of political desperation. And he's using the suffering of sick and dying people to his own political advantage. . . . The only way to get the State Legislature to pass a medical marijuana bill is by creating the Marijuana Reform Party for the next four years. And that can only be done by voting for the leaf on Nov. 5. . . .

Q. Again, the question involves the budget deficit, the projected budget deficit and ways to close it. And Mr. Jeffrey, we go to you for an answer.

MR. JEFFREY -- Thank you. . . . I would like to address the budget deficit. My first suggestion would be to Joseph Bruno, perhaps we don't need a new sports stadium in your own name. So we could start with that to cut our state budget. Libertarians are very strong supporters of capitalism, but we are equally loud in our opposition to corporate abuse. I've talked about corporate welfare. There's also eminent domain abuse. And that's where the government steps in and confiscates property from one private owner. And rather than building a public work project like a railroad, now they're turning it over to large corporations. In New York City, we're out today protesting The New York Times, who is confiscating 11 buildings, shutting down 30 businesses or displacing them. And we're out there being vocal, bringing up this issue that you won't see covered in the media. . . .

Q. . . . Governor Pataki, is the deficit going to be that big?

MR. PATAKI -- . . . The question is the budget, and I'm glad that's what we're talking about. Unfortunately, one candidate talked, used his time to debate debates and the other to talk about parole instead of addressing this issue. I've had the leadership and been through budget deficits in the past. In 1995, we had a $5 billion deficit. And there was no reason, no national recession or attacks of Sept. 11. And we dealt with it by closing the gap and cutting taxes. Since 1995, we've set aside record surpluses, multiple billions in surpluses. And we've kept spending below not only what other states have done, but the lowest of five states in America. What we're going to do going forward is continue to make our government operate more efficiently. We've done it in the past working with the public employee unions. And we will continue to do that. We're going to restructure the state's debt, taking advantage of the fact we have the highest credit rating in a generation. And we have the lowest interest rates in a long time. We're going to use some of those surpluses we set aside. And I can tell you that Standard & Poor's just in September said no state is better prepared to deal with the financial difficulties going forward than the State of New York. . . .

Drug Laws

Q. . . . What are your specific plans . . . to make the criminal justice system work more effectively by repealing or changing what is considered to be the Rockefeller drug law?

MR. LEIGHTON -- Well, obviously what we do need to do is repeal these laws outright. . . . And that's why I favor people voting for the leaf on Nov. 5 and forming the Marijuana Reform Party to work on this the next four years.
. . . But I'd like to take the time today to ask the governor and Comptroller McCall, as a titular head of their party, is why can we finally not put politics aside and just get together on this issue? The people who are suffering under this issue are 94 percent black and Hispanic. They come from New York City. And these laws are ruining lives and destroying the future. . . .

Q. . . . Mr. Jeffrey on to you.

MR. JEFFREY -- Well, besides the Rockefeller drug laws, which people are very aware of, in New York City we have 60,000 marijuana arrests every year. And that's too many good New Yorkers going to jail. And they'll spend up to three days in jail just waiting to see a judge to be processed. Now also what we need to do is change the entire dynamic of the drug culture. We need to address the problem of hard drug use. Now I believe marijuana is a steppingstone by being illegal. I think pot smokers are introduced to drug dealers who can try to sell them something else. Pot smokers grow accustomed to breaking the law. And the fact that cocaine is illegal no longer serves as a deterrent. So I believe that if we really want to fight the drugs that are truly destroying both individual lives and entire communities, we need to be honest, get real and legalize marijuana.

Q. . . . Governor.

MR. PATAKI -- I think it's important that we reform the Rockefeller drug laws, but not repeal them. If we were to repeal them right now, there are 5,000 people in prison, convicted of violent felonies as well as drug felonies, who would be eligible to get out on the street. And our streets are the safest they've been in a generation. . . . But having said that, we also know that intensive treatment is far better than incarcerating someone who has made a mistake and used drugs or been involved in drugs in a low level manner. And that's why I've advanced reforms that would allow those, including those who have been convicted of drug felonies, to have a second chance with intensive treatment. . . . And I will continue to work to reform the Rockefeller drug laws to allow those who have made a mistake to have a second chance, but to keep those who are violent away from us and behind bars to protect us.

Q. . . . Comptroller McCall.

MR. McCALL -- Mr. Leighton, the reason it hasn't been done is because of leadership. The governor has made promises. He says he's committed to changing these harsh, discriminatory laws. But he's had eight years to do it and he hasn't done that. Last year, the Assembly passed a bill that substantially changed the laws. For instance, they repealed the mandatory minimum sentences. And I support that. We have to give judges the discretion to decide whether people should be incarcerated. And some people should be incarcerated, but others can be rehabilitated. And we've got to do that. . . .

Q. . . . Mr. Aronowitz.

MR. ARONOWITZ -- . . . The Green Party on Row G is for repeal of the Rockefeller drug laws and the decriminalization of drugs. Mr. Pataki has conflated violence with drug use. I think that's a fudge that needs to be eliminated.
The fact of the matter is that violent criminals should be incarcerated. But drug users should not be incarcerated. Treatment programs are absolutely necessary if we make this a public health issue. We could also save $2.5 billion or a good part of $2.5 billion a year, maybe $100 billion, on the people who would not be sent to jail and who we have to support. And we could take that, excuse me, I'm sorry, $1.1 billion a year, and we'd be able to use that for education, for environment and other uses.

Q. . . . We move on to Mr. Golisano with the same question.

MR. GOLISANO -- You're correct. The Rockefeller drug laws either need to be repealed or reformed. We haven't had the leadership in our state to get it done. The laws are too harsh. The judges should be making these decisions and not the politicians. At least when they have a defendant in front of them, they can look at their character and their personal background and not have to give a sentence that's defined by a politician. . . .

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING; 
A Thoroughbred of a Track to Stage the Breeders' Cup

BYLINE:  By BILL FINLEY

 BODY:
After 75 years, any racetrack would have to have some stories, tales of the memorable and the forgettable, from terrific to terrible. It's just that Arlington Park has had more than most.
 Actually, a lot more. There has been a fire, a scandal, a two-year shutdown. The track goes down, but it never fails to come back. There are a lot of reasons to like Arlington, an elegant racetrack a few miles northwest of Chicago, but there is one quality a bit more remarkable than the rest. This is the track that just won't give up without a fight. 
 Never will that be more evident than Saturday, when Arlington plays host to the Breeders' Cup. Seventeen years ago the track was engulfed in flames. Three years ago it was closed, its owner tired of losing millions and fighting a state government that didn't share his concerns for the sport's problems. Today it is the shining jewel of Illinois racing and about to experience its most important day since its opening in 1927.
"There's no doubt this will be Arlington's finest moment," said Bill Thayer, a senior vice president who has been at Arlington for 30 years. "All the best horses in the world are coming here. We've had some great races here before, but they generally have involved one horse. The Breeders' Cup is the greatest event you can have. It goes to show that this track has had a lot of challenges and we have met them all and we have come out of them all."
Arlington opened in the fall of 1927. It has gone through several ownership changes, some of them involving roguish characters and a chief executive who was once called upon to testify in the bribery trial of an Illinois governor. But the history of the modern Arlington begins in 1983, when an area businessman, Richard L. Duchossois, bought the track from the Madison Square Garden Corporation.
He served as a tank commander under Gen. George S. Patton Jr. in World War II, and after nearly 60 years still likes to battle in the trenches. Duchossois is demanding, hard-headed and driven, but is universally respected for his unwavering dedication to his sport and his track and his refusal to give up easily, if at all.
"There have been challenges here, sure," he said. "You don't stop to think about it. You've been given a job and you do it. It's a challenge to get things done."
If the Breeders' Cup will be the highest point in Arlington's history, the date of July 31, 1985, is surely the lowest.
The trainer Jere Smith Sr. was at his barn that morning, never expecting that this day would be any different from any other on the backstretch. Instead, it became a day no one associated with Arlington will ever forget. It has been described as one of the most spectacular fires anyone has ever seen.
"Once that thing caught on fire, it just went down," Smith said. "When those flames started shooting up in the air like they did, I thought it was all over."
It probably should have been. The cost of rebuilding Arlington would be astronomical, the area had two other thoroughbred tracks in Hawthorne and Sportsman's Park, and racing was at the beginning stages of a slump that has yet to go away. No one knew what Duchossois would do, but those who knew him well knew the track would be back -- new, different and no doubt better.
The first challenge was to run the Arlington Million, the track's signature race, and fulfill a commitment to NBC and the sponsor, Budweiser. The Million was to be run just 23 days after the fire, and few thought it could be done. With work crews putting in 21 hours a day, what was left of the charred stands was removed, the rubble was hauled away and what has become known as the Miracle Million was run before 35,000 fans huddled in tents or simply standing in the wide expanse in front of where a towering grandstand and clubhouse used to be.
Duchossois considers the Miracle Million among his greatest accomplishments in business, but he was only warming up. Instead of building a racetrack, he erected the sport's version of Shangri-La, a facility that opened in 1989 and reportedly cost $200 million. To this day it sparkles and shines like a freshly minted penny.
"I've been all over the world and there's not another racetrack out there as nice as this one," Smith said. But $200 million racetracks need a lot of customers, and Duchossois's timing was not good. He built a track for a different era, not one in which horseplayers, the ones who haven't been converted to casino or lottery players, are far more likely to bet over the phone or at their nearby OTB shop than at a racetrack.
By 1998, Duchossois had had enough. He pleaded with the Illinois legislature and the governor at the time, Jim Edgar, for some legislative relief, but got nowhere. With the intention of sending a message, he did not open Arlington for the 1998 or 1999 racing seasons.
"When Arlington has closed, racing in this area hasn't looked very bright," the trainer Wayne Catalano said. "The people who run the other tracks here do a great job, but it's just not the same there. Arlington is a special place. It got tough around here."
Duchossois never intended to close the track for good. He just wanted to shake up the politicians and show them that a vibrant racetrack was important to the state's economy. It worked. New laws that included tax breaks and revenue from nearby riverboat casinos were passed, and Arlington reopened for the 2000 season. A few months later, Arlington merged with Churchill Downs to take advantage of that company's fiscal might and network of racetracks.
Arlington isn't going anywhere, but track executives long for something better. Its purse structure places it well behind those at the top tracks in New York, Kentucky and California, so it cannot offer top-quality racing. And it is surrounded by riverboat casinos or Indian casinos in Illinois, Iowa, Michigan and Missouri. They have drained millions from Chicago racing. Elsewhere, racing has solved these problems by adding slot machines to the wagering menu. Arlington officials would like them, but nothing is imminent.
But no one will be worrying about slot machines come Saturday. It will be an occasion for celebration, appreciation of the Breeders' Cup and Arlington's latest revival.
"Three years ago," Duchossois said, "we were standing still. In a couple of days, we'll be hosting the Super Bowl. That makes me feel proud."

GRAPHIC: Photos: D. G. Van Clief Jr., left, the president of Breeders' Cup Limited, with Richard L. Duchossois, the chairman of Arlington Park. (Associated Press); The rebuilt Arlington grandstand looming in the background as riders prepare horses during morning workouts on the track. (Scott Olson for The New York Times); Arlington Park burning down on July 31, 1985. Just 23 days after the fire, the Arlington Million was staged at the venerable track. (Daily Racing Form)
