HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE SECOND DEBATE; 
In 2nd Debate, Pataki's Rivals Go on Attack

BYLINE:  By RICHARD PEREZ-PENA 

DATELINE: SYRACUSE, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
Gov. George E. Pataki's opponents battered him today in a televised debate with charges of cronyism, corruption and mismanagement, with Tom Golisano repeatedly accusing the governor's administration of selling paroles for campaign contributions.
 Mr. Pataki did not respond to the charges during the debate, but later his campaign vigorously disputed Mr. Golisano's allegations, calling them "despicable lies." 
 The second of two debates Mr. Pataki agreed to participate in proved to be a far more raucous affair than the first, a week ago, with the candidates ganging up on the governor and making pointed accusations in a way they had mostly refrained from doing earlier. The most persistent attacks came from Mr. Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, and H. Carl McCall, the Democrat, but even the minor-party candidates joined the fray. 
The governor largely held his own, and he was more specific about issues, policies and proposals than he has been through this campaign, talking about plans to lower county property taxes, defending investments in high-tech projects and explaining his proposal to ease the Rockefeller drug laws. Mr. Pataki had been criticized for avoiding such substance through the campaign and during the first debate, when he answered nearly every question by saying that he was proud of his record.
But five times during the hourlong debate, which was broadcast on WCBS-TV in the New York City area, Mr. Golisano turned questions on other subjects to the investigation that sent three State Parole Board officials and a Pataki fund-raiser to prison -- though, ultimately, they were not convicted of trading paroles for contributions.
"There is a scandal in our state where we sold paroles for campaign contributions," Mr. Golisano said here at the studios of WTVH-TV. "A parole board chairman was an unindicted co-conspirator in these sales. And he's still on the job." 
The governor at first ignored the charges, then responded tautly, "Three times now, Mr. Golisano has raised a question in the form of a negative personal attack." 
But he never responded directly to the charges, not even to rebut them, and he never addressed the continued presence on the parole board of its chairman, Brion D. Travis.
Of the charges, he said, "Of course they're untrue." When asked why he had not said so in the debate, he said, "I thought I did." 
Michael McKeon, Mr. Pataki's chief spokesman, said, "He thought he said it, and I think his intention was to say it." It was a rare misstep in a campaign whose discipline has often stood in striking contrast to the opposing campaigns.
Mr. Golisano, a billionaire businessman who is setting campaign spending records, also released a new television advertisement today attacking the governor over the parole issue, bringing a much harsher tone to the race 16 days before Election Day.
After the debate, Mr. McKeon and one of Mr. Golisano's consultants, Erick Mullen, engaged in an impromptu debate of their own in the television station's lobby about the accuracy of Mr. Golisano's allegations, surrounded by a clutch of reporters. 
The argument quickly devolved into an obscenity-laced shouting match, with the two men calling each other liars. When the confrontation grew especially heated, a police officer stepped in. 
Mr. Golisano was not the only one to cry scandal.
Early in the debate, Mr. McCall said, "Governor Pataki's approach to economic development is to provide contracts to relatives." That was an apparent reference to an architect who is a friend and neighbor of the governor's, and also a distant relative by marriage, who was awarded five contracts worth more than $200,000, and was tentatively awarded another, worth more than $1 million, from the State University of New York, after university officials manipulated the contract process. Two top SUNY officials were later dismissed. 
Mr. McCall also referred to recent news reports that Rikers Island correction officers say a high-ranking official there forced them to do work for the Pataki campaign, while the campaign was paying the official more than $200,000 over a period of a few months. The governor did not respond to those barbs, either, during or after the debate. Pataki aides have been insisting that Mr. McCall, whose campaign is short of money, is increasingly irrelevant, and that the contest is now between the governor and Mr. Golisano.
A New York Times poll conducted last week showed that when undecided voters were pressed to state a preference, Mr. Pataki had the support of 42 percent of likely voters, to 31 percent for Mr. McCall and 18 percent for Mr. Golisano. The poll shows Mr. McCall and Mr. Golisano virtually even in the areas outside of New York City, though Mr. McCall is ahead in the city.
Also participating in today's debate were Stanley Aronowitz, the Green Party candidate; Thomas K. Leighton of the Marijuana Reform Party and Scott Jeffrey, the Libertarian Party nominee. Gerard J. Cronin, the Right to Life candidate, did not attend because of illness. Andrew M. Cuomo, who has withdrawn from the race, remains on the Nov. 5 ballot as the Liberal Party candidate.
The exchange of allegations obscured a forum that centered on economic issues like job creation and New York's high property taxes, and featured Mr. Pataki's most extensive defense of his record that he has offered during this campaign.
His challengers blamed double-digit increases in local property taxes on the governor, saying that increased state mandates on local governments were to blame. Mr. Pataki cited the creation of 600,000 new jobs during his tenure, talked proudly of the STAR program that he said has cut property tax bills by $2.8 billion a year, noted that he had appointed a commission to look into consolidating the overlapping layers of local government to save money, and insisted that on balance, he had reduced local mandates.
"We have an aggressive agenda to build on the success we've had," he said. He cited the state's Empire Zones, which attract businesses through tax breaks; the "Centers of Excellence" program he began to invest in various scientific fields at SUNY campuses, and reduced business regulation. "These are all new programs that we're putting in place that are going to allow us to continue to grow in New York State."
The idea that economic development is working may be a hard sell upstate, an issue the challengers seized on. "The way to find out whether there have been new jobs created is to talk to the people of upstate New York," Mr. McCall said during the debate. "They'll tell you about the fact that during Governor Pataki's tenure their young people have left. They're leaving New York because there are no jobs, there are no opportunities."
The parole scandal centered on Yung Soo Yoo, a Korean-born New Jersey businessman who gave $15,000 to Mr. Pataki's 1994 campaign and raised money from others for Mr. Pataki and his one-time political mentor, former Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato. Federal prosecutors said Mr. Yoo told Korean-Americans whose children were in state prisons that paroles could be arranged if they gave to Mr. Pataki's campaign. The Pataki camp stressed that Mr. Yoo had no official role in the campaign, and that they returned his contributions when questions about his conduct surfaced.
Two parole board members, Sean McSherry and Leo S. Levy, and Ronald Hotaling, executive secretary of the board, were convicted of lying to investigators. Mr. Yoo was convicted in 2000 of obstruction of justice for covering up his actions, but a jury deadlocked on the question of whether he had promised paroles in return for contributions.
Prosecutors suggested that the guilt extended farther and called Mr. Travis, the Parole Board chairman, an unindicted co-conspirator. Responding to Mr. Golisano's statement that Mr. Travis should have been removed, Mr. McKeon, the governor's spokesman, said Mr. Travis was never accused of a crime.
During Mr. Yoo's trial two years ago, prosecutors claimed that Patrick Donohue, the former finance director of Mr. Pataki's campaign, knew that Mr. Yoo was promising paroles to contributors. In a blistering cross-examination, Mr. Donohue, who was also never charged with a crime, denied such knowledge.
Mr. Hotaling testified that Mr. Pataki's office had pressured the parole board to release one of the Korean-American youths, a claim the governor's office denied.

HEADLINE: Metro Briefing New York: Manhattan: More Restaurants Open, Despite Economy 

BYLINE:  By Terry Pristin (NYT) (Compiled by Anthony Ramirez) 

 BODY:
 Despite the city's weak economy, almost twice as many restaurants opened in the past year as closed, according to the 2003 Zagat New York City Restaurant Survey published today. 
The survey said 186 restaurants opened and 104 restaurants closed, but the gap between openings and closings was the narrowest since the recession of the early 1990's. Of the shuttered restaurants, 15 were below Houston Street. "There's definitely been a bigger loss of business downtown, " said Tim Zagat, above, a co-publisher of the survey. The Zagat survey also found that people were returning more often to the same restaurant, which may make it harder for new restaurants to attract customers. Terry Pristin (NYT)

HEADLINE: The Bloomberg Way 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael Bloomberg seems not to care that he can be a lightning rod for frustration. He matter-of-factly talks about the fiscal pain to come for New York City, offering no sugar coating. That, as New York is learning, is the Bloomberg way. 
 The mayor has been warning in recent days that property taxes may rise, transit fares may increase, tolls may be imposed for East River bridges, and city services -- perhaps even fire and police departments -- may be hit hard with cuts, all aimed at closing an expected budget gap of some $5 billion. It's bad news and he gives it to the city less like a politician and more like a pathologist. 
 He is also clearly unmoved by hecklers who do not like his proposed ban on smoking in restaurants and bars. It was with similar single-mindedness that he decided to invite actors from "The Sopranos" to the Columbus Day parade, causing a rumble with Italian-American leaders that might have been avoided if he had consulted with them.
New Yorkers, despite their fractiousness, do like a mayor with moxie, and now is a very good time to have someone in city hall who doesn't mind delivering unpleasant truths. Knowing how to take the heat is practically a mayoral job description, and Mr. Bloomberg has filled the bill. But all that decisiveness can verge on insensitivity. He hurts feelings and starts fights that aren't necessary, like the current war between the mayor's office and the public advocate, Betsy Gotbaum. 
While it appears that the honeymoon is over, Mr. Bloomberg didn't become mayor to spend his time publicly canoodling with anyone. His supporters point out -- at least once a day -- that he comes without the strings of special interests, having personally financed his own campaign. Still, Mr. Bloomberg must not appear aloof as he charges full speed ahead with his agenda.
City workers, who will certainly be asked for givebacks, may do so more willingly if they know the mayor understands the problems of working people caught in a slumping economy. Likewise, homeowners and commuters may more easily digest a tax offered with regret and as a last resort. That's not political pandering. It's a mark of leadership.

HEADLINE: THE AD CAMPAIGN; 
Democrats Court the Elderly

BYLINE:  By STEPHEN LABATON 

 BODY:
 This 30-second commercial, titled "Starting Over," is one of four being broadcast beginning this week by the Democratic Party in states where President Bush is campaigning for local candidates. It will first appear on Tuesday in Bangor, Me., and Chester County, Pa. Party officials said they would spend several hundred thousand dollars on the commercial, but they would not specify the amount.

PRODUCER -- Penczner, Burton

ON THE SCREEN -- It is the 1950's. A young, eager junior executive getting ready for his first day of work is knotting his tie while sitting on his bed and talking to his wife in the background. As the ad progresses, the couple is morphed to the present and the executive, now in his 70's, is no longer eager. Instead, he appears apprehensive about being forced to begin a new job. The ad concludes with the caption: "Vote Democratic. A strong America should be strong for all of us."

THE SCRIPT -- Young wife: "So, first day of the new job. Ready for the big adventure?"

Husband, speaking with enthusiasm: "Ready as I'll ever be."

Narrator: "In the last two years, over two million Americans have lost their jobs. And hundreds of thousands of seniors are again looking for work."

Wife is transformed into the present and is now 70 years old: "So, first day of the new job. Ready for the big adventure?"

Husband, speaking apprehensively: "Ready as I'll ever be."

Narrator: "For eight years, Democrats led America to the strongest economy in history. In two, Republicans have brought us the weakest economy in a generation."

ACCURACY -- The economic numbers cited in the ad are accurate, although establishing the causal link between those numbers and the role played by Democrats and Republicans in the ups and downs of the economic cycle is debatable. The economy did expand to unparalleled levels in the 1990's. Unemployment dropped to historically low levels, large numbers of people moved off welfare and the stock market reached new heights. The stock market peaked in March 2000, and the economy began to show signs of slowing later that year. Since then, the markets have sunk and unemployment has risen and the economy has undergone a recession. Sharply eroding retirement savings has forced many older voters to come out of retirement or postpone it.

SCORECARD -- Democrats are hoping to turn the election into a referendum on the administration's handling of the economy. So far, they have gained little traction as the White House has kept the focus on foreign policy.

But as President Bush hits the hustings in a final push before the midterm elections, Democratic strategists are hoping to refocus the campaign and pin all of the economic problems and corporate scandals on Republicans. Republicans have countered that the plight of the economy is a natural consequence of the business cycle. Their strategists have calculated that most long-term investors will not take out economic woes on Republicans because, they say, such voters believe that the economy and the markets will ultimately rebound and are generally beyond the control of a president or Congress. STEPHEN LABATON

GRAPHIC: Photos

HEADLINE: Jolted by North Korea, Japan Grows Angrier 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
American envoys working to forge a united front against North Korea are finding their most receptive ally in Japan, where revelations of kidnappings and spying by North Korea have already hardened opinion against it. 
 James A. Kelly, an assistant secretary of state, started talks here tonight with Japanese officials on what to do about North Korea's latest admission -- that it has restarted its nuclear weapons program -- as Japanese newspapers and politicians called for a tough stance. 
 "It is outrageous that North Korea would have nuclear arms and weapons of mass destruction when its people are starving," Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi said while campaigning over the weekend for his party's candidate in a by-election. "It should ensure good living standards for its people." 
His predecessor, former Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, said of North Korea in another campaign speech, "There is a very dangerous country in the neighborhood that has conducted savage acts such as abductions and is aiming its nuclear missiles right at Japan." 
Mr. Kelly came here after meetings in Beijing and Seoul, where the public concern of political leaders was muted. Separately, John R. Bolton, under secretary for arms control and international security, is visiting Moscow, Paris and London, pushing for a common strategy to block North Korea's bid to become a nuclear power. 
"Close consultation" with the United States was promised this evening by Japan's chief cabinet secretary, Yasuo Fukuda, after meeting here with Mr. Kelly. Japanese and North Korean negotiators are to meet on Oct. 29 in Malaysia for what were originally billed as two days of talks to pave the way for establishing diplomatic relations.
Shinzo Abe, Mr. Fukuda's deputy, denounced reports of North Korea's secret bomb-making program as "a violation of North Korea's promise with Japan, the United States and South Korea."
Referring to the planned talks, he vowed, "We will seek to address this issue on the negotiating table."
The Yomiuri Shimbun, a conservative newspaper, reported Saturday that Japan was considering freezing its contribution to financing construction of two light-water reactors in North Korea. Similarly, the Bush administration has decided to scrap a 1994 arms control accord with North Korea, a move that would mean the end of annual shipments by the United States to North Korea of 500,000 tons of fuel oil as well as the likely suspension of the reactor project.
In Japan, hostility toward North Korea now cuts across party lines.
Mr. Koizumi traveled to North Korea last month, "overlooking the danger and only believing in resumption of normalization talks," charged Yukio Hatoyama, president of the largest opposition party, the Democratic Party of Japan.
Hirohisa Fujii, secretary of the Liberal Party, criticized the joint declaration signed in North Korea last month by Mr. Koizumi and North Korea's leader, Kim Jong Il.
"The declaration only specifies economic assistance and avoids other issues," Mr. Fujii, a conservative, said on television today. "If we enter into negotiations by leaving it as is, the abduction and nuclear development issues could be left buried."
The Asahi Shimbun, a liberal newspaper, warned in an editorial about the bomb program, "North Korea must scrap the program at once and open it up to inspections." 
Fueling the general hostility has been a weeklong drama, played out in daily installments, of the return of five Japanese kidnapped by North Korea in the 1970's. 
On Thursday, Hitomi Soga, one of the returnees, received her high school diploma, a quarter century late. The next day she burned incense at a Shinto shrine where years ago her name had been inscribed on a family monument, along with the names of dead relatives. 
Over the weekend, all five returnees received Japanese passports. One couple is choosing Japanese names for their children and plans to go to their hometown town hall to register their marriage, which took place in North Korea. Many of the kidnap victims' children do not know that their parents were born in Japan, according to news reports. 
With the real number of Japanese kidnapped by North Korea believed to be about 50, the issue has become so pressing in Japan that Empress Michiko touched on it in a written interview released today in honor of her 68th birthday. 
"I felt both surprise and sadness, as well as mortification as partial facts concerning the series of abductions of Japanese nationals were being reported," she wrote, responding to reporters' questions. Alluding to the fact that North Korea has produced only five survivors, she added that her "thoughts are on the families of those who were not able to return this time." 

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hitomi Soga, center, a kidnap victim, was allowed to visit Japan. (Kyodo via Reuters)

HEADLINE: Protesters Fault Mayor in Fire That Killed Six in Baltimore 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Oct. 20 

 BODY:
About 400 people gathered today at the charred row house where Angela Dawson and her family lived to protest what they called the city's neglect of the neighborhood.
 Ms. Dawson, 36, died Wednesday morning with five of her children in a fire the authorities say was set in retaliation for her crusade against drug dealing. 
 Today, residents and ministers rallied in front of her house and criticized Mayor Martin O'Malley and his administration. The ministers accused Mr. O'Malley of refusing to respond to requests for meetings in the last three days to devise a strategy to fight drug-related violence.
They said the mayor's administration had also ignored pleas to increase police patrols and take other steps to revitalize the neighborhood, where boarded-up houses pockmark most blocks and violent drug dealers take over corners at night.
"The community is here; where is the mayor?" asked the Rev. Calvin Keene, pastor of Memorial Baptist Church. "Mayor O'Malley, we're looking for you. Where's O'Malley?" 
Taking his cue, the crowd, carrying white signs with "Thou Shalt Not Kill" written on them in red letters, began chanting, "Where's O'Malley?"
Rally organizers from Baltimoreans United in Leadership Development, a citywide group of about 50 religious congregations known by its acronym, Build, contended that low-income neighborhoods had suffered for years because they were a low priority at City Hall.
Gerry Shields, a spokesman for Mr. O'Malley, accused Build's leaders of politicizing the deaths to get back at the mayor for not providing more money for the organization's after-school programs.
"They have been no fan of the mayor's, and to use this horrendous incident as an opportunity to criticize the mayor is unbelievable," Mr. Shields said.
The mayor's top priority is fighting drug-related violence, Mr. Shields said, adding that more aggressive law enforcement has contributed to significant declines in violent crime in the last two years.
Mr. O'Malley, who is to attend a vigil at the Dawsons' home on Monday, will elaborate this week on further plans to combat drugs and violence, Mr. Shields said.
The police said that Darrell L. Brooks, 21, who was accused of starting the fire, was angry that Mrs. Dawson had confronted drug dealers and reported them to the police. Mr. Brooks is being held without bond on six counts of first-degree murder, arson and many related charges.
The police said Mr. Brooks kicked in the door of the Dawsons' house after 2 a.m. on Wednesday, poured gasoline and ignited the fire, which also critically injured Mrs. Dawson's husband, Carnell Dawson Sr., 43.
At today's rally, the ministers also called for a commitment from the mayor to strengthen schools, housing and health care in the neighborhood and to help provide more drug treatment, recreation and economic development.
"There's definitely a double standard, and this neighborhood is the home of many who are second-class citizens," said the Rev. Curtis Jones, a co-chairman of Build and pastor of a nearby Presbyterian church.
Many also questioned why the police did not protect Ms. Dawson's home after drug dealers had repeatedly threatened her and after the house was firebombed on Oct. 3. City officials have said they offered to move the family or provide more police protection, but that the Dawsons refused.
"Protection should have been automatic," Mr. Jones said. 

GRAPHIC: Photo: "The community is here; where is the mayor?" asked the Rev. Calvin Keene, left, at the Baltimore house where Angela Dawson and five of her children died in a fire apparently set to retaliate for her crusade against drugs. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: A Chat With Sharon 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
After his visit with President Bush and Congressional leaders, Israel's Ariel Sharon returned to his farm, surveyed his cattle and sheep, and as the Sabbath sun set, took my call.
 If war starts, did you promise Bush that Israel would not be provoked by Saddam into responding to his missile attack, thereby troubling whatever Arabs may want to cooperate in his overthrow? 
 "Israel is not interested in being involved in a campaign against Iraq," the prime minister replies, having been assured that U.S. forces would first seek to neutralize Iraq's capability to attack Israel. "We'll support America's decision and will show sensitivity to U.S. needs by exercising maximum restraint. At the same time, if our citizens are attacked seriously -- by a weapon of mass destruction, chemical, biological or by some mega-terror act -- and suffer casualties, then Israel will respond." 
Has he promised to consult Bush before doing anything drastic? 
"Consult? We have a regular dialogue. Israel and America are consulting now as never before in the past." 
Sharon notes an unremarked danger: "The Syrians, together with the Iranians, are playing a double game, escalating tension on our northern border. Assad's son is completely under the influence of Hezbollah, helping them more than his father ever thought about, integrating the terrorists into Syria's front-line forces. And the Iranians have supplied those terrorists with 9,000 to 10,000 rockets, maybe including a new one with a 200-mile range. If war comes, we see what Syria-Iran-Hezbollah are preparing: they'll be surrogates for Saddam, opening a second front to help him." 
In that regard, Sharon persuaded Russia's Vladimir Putin not to sell Syria shoulder-fired antiaircraft missiles. Putin wants our old Jackson-Vanik amendment dropped, and Sharon says "we support that it should be bent already."
Syrian-occupied Lebanon has begun diverting precious water from one of the sources of the Jordan River: "That blatant violation of law does damage to a strategic resource, and is a matter of life and death to us. 
"The Six-Day War in 1967 really started in 1964 when Arabs started to divert the sources of the Jordan. We accepted the U.S. proposal to negotiate, but if the diplomatic process does not produce results, Israel will be forced to act." 
Turning to Intifada II, I asked if he had reacted to Bush's draft of a "Roadmap to a Permanent Two-State Solution" handed him in Washington. "It's six pages in small letters and I haven't read it yet," he says, shifting the emphasis with "We accept the plan outlined in Bush's speech." Then he struck a note of optimism:
"About the Palestinian reforms, one feels that there are changes going on there. There are those who realize Israel won't be able to move forward until the end of the terror attacks and a different leadership emerges. We have seen positive signs that Palestinian society is moving toward reforms, especially economic reforms, though slowly -- first, Arafat must remove his hands from the cash flow." 
Progress was made in Washington on the release of tax money to the Palestinian Authority, which Israel feared would be used for arms. "We agreed to a mechanism to monitor those revenues," Sharon reports, "which is the most important thing right away. The Palestinians chose a man with good intentions. For accountability and transparency, we want a team led by U.S. experts, along with Europeans and Russians and especially Japanese, so that the money we release gradually, under inspections, will not be used to purchase illegal weapons. 
"We will continue our secret contacts with high-ranking Palestinian officials, and we have told them that the appointment of a prime minister is a first, necessary step in Palestinian reform." (That would, I presume, leave Arafat as figurehead president. As for those "secret contacts," they're hardly secret anymore.) 
"The U.S. knows who are the leaders who support reform," Sharon stresses, "and they should be strengthened." 
He's an unabashed admirer of this President Bush. "Thank God, at this historic moment, the U.S. is leading the free world toward liberation from fear of terror."
And his unwavering confidence under sustained pressure makes me an unabashed Arik Sharon admirer. "We go back many years," he says. "Call me more often." I may just do that.

HEADLINE: White House Letter; 
Still Advising, From Afar and Near

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

 BODY:
When last we heard from Karen P. Hughes, one of President Bush's closest and most powerful advisers, she and her golden retriever were in her 1995 Mazda on a hot July day headed south to Texas, where she would take up a sane new life away from the pressures of the White House. Her 15-year-old son, Robert, was leaving the stresses of St. Albans, the private incubator of Washington's male elite, for public school in Austin. Her husband, Jerry, a lawyer who had never found full-time work in the capital, would get a job.
 Ms. Hughes planned to keep advising the president from afar, back in a cramped office in the Austin house that she and her husband had never been able to sell. But some Republicans close to the White House said that she was in denial, and that her physical distance from the Oval Office would make her invisible. 
 So far, that hasn't happened. Ms. Hughes, whose resignation set off another news media boomlet about whether women could balance family and high-powered careers, has in fact kept up such an intense schedule of campaigning, fund-raising, speech writing and travels with the president that she appears only slightly less busy than during the 18 months she kept such brutal hours at the White House. Although Republicans close to the president say she has lost some of her ability to affect policy decisions, she still talks to Mr. Bush two or three times a week, if not more, and is in daily contact with some of the most important officials in the West Wing.
"The rumors of my retirement have been greatly exaggerated," she told a rapturous crowd at a Dallas fund-raiser last month for John Cornyn, the Republican candidate for Senate, according to Republicans who were there. Last week, Mr. Cornyn's campaign asked for and got advice from Ms. Hughes on how to handle questions from Mr. Cornyn's opponent, Ron Kirk, about contributions that Mr. Cornyn received from the Enron Corporation, whose meltdown and political largess have become an issue in the race. At a debate on Friday, Mr. Cornyn deftly fought off the blows by questioning how Mr. Kirk could attack him when Mr. Kirk's own law firm had received $180,000 from Enron.
This week, Ms. Hughes will campaign for Republican candidates over three days in four states -- Colorado, Iowa, Minnesota and North Dakota -- then meet up with Mr. Bush at his ranch in Texas. From there she will travel with him over the weekend to Mexico, where he is to attend an economic conference. Earlier this month, Ms. Hughes edited the speech on Iraq that the president delivered on Oct. 7 in Cincinnati. She also wrote the president's speech marking the anniversary of the terrorist attacks and was heavily involved in his Sept. 12 speech to the United Nations. She said through an aide, Kim Black, that she was too busy to comment for this article.
When Ms. Hughes is in Washington, often for three to four days at a time, she works in the small West Wing office, once used by Dan Bartlett, that was next to her big corner space that looked out toward the Truman Balcony. (Mr. Bartlett, the White House director of communications, is now in Ms. Hughes's old space.) Ms. Hughes, who is paid by the Republican National Committee, still takes time to work out in the gym in the Eisenhower Executive Office Building with Mary Matalin, a top adviser to Vice President Dick Cheney. She had dinner one of the last times she was in Washington with Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser.
Ms. Hughes has also found time to meet with New York publishers about a book about her time at the White House and to campaign for Jim Talent in Missouri and Norm Coleman in Minnesota, two White House-recruited Senate candidates in crucial races. 
Friends describe her as unusually content. When she is at home in Austin, they say, she drives Robert back and forth to school, a switch from her days in Washington, when she left the house before he was up and returned late at night. Her husband, who no longer practices law, now works as assistant director of adult education at the Westlake Hills Presbyterian Church, where Ms. Hughes remains active.
"She's very happy," said Mr. Bartlett, who noted that he and Ms. Hughes worked apart for long months during Mr. Bush's 2000 presidential campaign, when he was at headquarters in Austin and she was on the road, and that modern communications could bridge the distance. "Instead of e-mailing it upstairs, you're e-mailing it to Texas," he said.
The one big change? "I think she misses the president," Mr. Bartlett said.

The White House Letter article yesterday, about Karen Hughes's part-time presence in Washington as an adviser to President Bush, referred incorrectly in some copies to the view from her former White House office. It looked out toward the Truman Balcony, not the South Portico.

HEADLINE: Autism Therapy Is Called Effective, but Rare 

BYLINE:  By LAURIE TARKAN 

 BODY:
No one has found a cure for autism, the neurological disorder that leads to lifelong impairments in a child's ability to speak, respond to others, share affection and learn. But there is a growing consensus that intensive early intervention is both effective and essential -- the sooner after diagnosis, the better.
 Early intervention, which involves many hours of therapy with one or more specialists, does not help every autistic child to the same degree. It is best started no later than age 2 or 3, and for reasons that are unclear, it does not help some children at all. But for those who are helped, their parents say, the changes are miraculous. 
 Yet the success of early intervention is posing a painful predicament for schools and families -- a predicament made more immediate by a rising tide of diagnoses of autism. Last week, researchers reported that the number of austistic children in California had risen more than sixfold since 1987, and other states and the federal government have also noted sharp increases. 
By federal law, public schools must provide appropriate education for children with disabilities, starting at age 3. But the treatment is so expensive -- averaging $33,000 a year, according to research published in the journal Behavioral Intervention -- that many families cannot persuade their school districts to pay for it. 
Brian and Juliana Jaynes of Newport News, Va., can testify to that. As a baby, their son, Stefan, developed normally, if not ahead of the curve. By age 2, his vocabulary was well over 100 words. He knew his address and his colors, and he spoke in short sentences. But soon after his second birthday, he started to regress, forgetting the words he once knew.
His parents suspected a neurological disorder. A specialist confirmed their suspicions, telling them Stefan was severely autistic and urging them to get intensive therapy for him.
Instead, school officials placed Stefan in a special-education preschool, where, the Jayneses say, he rapidly regressed. (The school district says the placement was appropriate.) After the neurologist told the frantic couple that their son might have to be institutionalized, they removed him from the preschool and began 40 hours a week of behavior therapy at home.
It cost them more than $100,000 over three years. Today, Stefan, 11, attends a school for autistic children and has vastly improved his language, social and self-help skills. He can say some simple sentences and communicate his needs; perhaps most important, he spends more and more time interacting with his family, and less time in his own world. The behavior therapy, his father said, "has brought about an awakening in this little boy's personality that is truly a miracle."
In recent years, four leading institutions -- the American Academy of Pediatrics, the American Academy of Child and Adolescent Psychiatry, the Surgeon General and the National Academy of Sciences -- have called for early intervention, including one-on-one therapy, for children with autism. A panel of experts convened by the academy last year recommended a minimum of 25 hours a week, 12 months a year.
But Dr. Catherine Lord, the panel's chairwoman and a psychology professor at the University of Michigan, estimates that fewer than 10 percent of children with autism are getting the recommended level of therapy. "Almost everywhere, schools will say kids are getting services," she said. "But what they're getting varies enormously."
Because the young nervous system has a great deal of plasticity, many experts believe that early intervention enriches neural growth.
Dr. David L. Holmes, president of the Eden Institute, an autism center in Princeton, said, "If you have a child with autism who's not wired correctly, and we allow that to continue without intervention, those neuropathways will become fixed, and it becomes far more difficult to undo that tangled mess."
Autistic children lose the ability to learn by observation, something other children do constantly. Behavioral therapy is aimed at teaching these children how to learn. Teaching an autistic child to wave goodbye, for instance, can take 40 hours of repetitive lessons.
There are several kinds of therapy. The most popular -- the one Stefan Jaynes receives -- is applied behavioral analysis, in which a therapist asks a child to perform small tasks and then offers feedback to reinforce correct responses.
Other programs use sensory integration therapy, based on the theory that autistic children have defects in processing the messages from their five senses; auditory integration therapy, which assumes that some are oversensitive or undersensitive to sound or have problems processing sounds; speech therapy; and group programs.
The federal education law leaves decisions about therapy to professionals and parents. But administrators say parents often demand far more therapy than the experts recommend. "Is the school system going to override teachers, and substitute the teacher's decision with the parent's decision?" asked Bruce Hunter, associate executive director for public policy at the American Association of School Administrators in Arlington, Va.
The biggest obstacle is budgetary. "When you're looking at limited resources in a school district, sometimes the available resources drive what services schools will propose to offer," said David Egnor, policy director at the Council for Exceptional Children. "It's simply pragmatic."
Mr. Hunter added: "The problem all along in special ed is that you have a chronic shortage of money that is exacerbated by downturns in the economy, which is when it really gets bad. You get the joy of taking the money from one group of children and spending it on another group."
Under law, the federal government may reimburse states up to 40 percent of the extra cost of educating a child with a disability. But this year, Congress is paying just 17 percent, or $7.5 billion. President Bush has proposed adding $1 billion next year.
"The federal and state governments ought to pay attention to these children who have disabilities and need to be educated and need special treatment, and that costs money," said Representative Dan Burton, Republican of Indiana, who has an autistic grandson.
But the chairman of the House Committee on Education and the Workforce, John A. Boehner, Republican of Ohio, opposes full financing of the act until major changes are made. He and others have called for reforms in identifying students with disabilities -- minority students are classified far out of proportion to their numbers -- and in the daunting paperwork for the schools.
Many experts believe society would pay less in the long run if children received appropriate early intervention. An article in Behavioral Intervention in 1998 found that if 100 children were given early intensive intervention and 40 of them had only partial improvement, the public would save $9.5 million over their school years, ages 3 to 22. 
Most insurance companies do not pay for therapy for developmental disorders like autism, though a few companies offer reimbursement as part of their health benefits. 
Another obstacle to treatment is a lack of specialists. Public schools have a shortage of more than 12,000 special education teachers, and the number is expected to grow as many teachers retire or leave the field. 
Advocates say the supply of teachers trained to deal with autism is even shorter, so schools are forced to rely on expensive outside specialists. 
Even parents who decide to pay for treatment have trouble finding private specialists. Autism schools and private behavioral therapists typically have waiting lists of more than a year. This forces parents to set up their own in-home school and hire teams of people to provide the 20 to 40 hours a week of therapy. Many parents train themselves in the behavioral therapies, and then train college students, whom they can hire for considerably less money than specialists.
Yet another obstacle to early intervention is delayed diagnosis. Autism is most commonly diagnosed at 20 to 36 months, but experts say the signs often surface earlier. Many families experience delays because pediatricians often dismiss their concerns.
The growing awareness of autism may ease that problem. (Autism is now diagnosed in 1 out of 600 children, by most estimates.) But without appropriate therapy, early diagnosis does little but create frustration for parents, as Stefan's mother, Juliana Jaynes, recalled recently. "I had the doctor telling me that every moment counts," she said. "There's that horrible feeling of time slipping away and nothing being done."

HEADLINE: In Germany, Banks Mirror Wide Malaise In Economy 

BYLINE:  By MARK LANDLER

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
With plummeting share prices, faltering credit ratings and bad loans that keep piling up, Germany's banking system has come to symbolize the country's broader economic distress.
 The news is so bleak that a recent rumor, later discredited, of a liquidity shortfall at one of the largest banks, Commerzbank, was enough to stir talk that Germany was facing a full-blown banking crisis. 
 Not so, says one of Germany's banking elders, Rolf E. Breuer, the chairman of the supervisory board of Deutsche Bank and president of the German banking association. At least, he added, "not in the traditional sense." 
" 'Banking crisis' is a very risky expression, because usually people then think of 1929," Mr. Breuer said in an interview today. "We're not talking about a liquidity problem. We're not talking about a credit crunch. What we are talking about is a lack of profitability." 
Two of Germany's four big commercial banks, Commerzbank and the HVB Group, are likely to lose money this year in their core banking business, according to a new report by Salomon Smith Barney.
Deutsche Bank is expected to eke out a modest profit; the fourth, Dresdner Bank, which was acquired for $20 billion last year by the giant insurer Allianz, had heavy losses in the second quarter.
Despite the red ink, Mr. Breuer said the chances of a big bank failure in Germany were remote. He said foreign investors had been rattled unnecessarily by the rumor about Commerzbank, which circulated against a backdrop of political tension between Germany and the United States over Chancellor Gerhard Schroder's opposition to an American-led war on Iraq.
"It added to the overall mood that German banks are not the flavor of the month," Mr. Breuer said.
Still, he acknowledged that the banks had been whipsawed by a combination of global economic woes and home-grown weaknesses, chiefly their bloated costs and the fact that there are simply too many of them.
"I do think we have double what is needed," Mr. Breuer said, comparing Germany with its European neighbors. With more than 2,700 lending institutions and 42,350 bank branches, Germany has more branches per capita than any major country except Belgium. Even in the United States, the undisputed champion of consumer credit, there are about half as many bank branches in proportion to population.
"We missed an early consolidation," Mr. Breuer said. "And we are too expensive vis-a-vis our competitors in Europe." 
As Germany's economy teeters on the edge of a recession, the winds are turning even more harshly against the banks. Commerzbank predicts that the number of corporate insolvencies in Germany is likely to rise by 30 percent this year and not reach a peak until sometime in 2003, not 2002 as had been expected.
That will drive up the number of bad loans, in some cases to as much as 1 percent of a lender's total portfolio. That may not seem high by the standards of Japan or China, where the banking systems have been plagued with huge volumes of defaulted loans. But in Germany, it is enough to wreck the banks' profits.
"The banks need to focus on areas where they have real prospects of making economic returns," said Jeremy Sigree, an analyst at Salomon Smith Barney in London. "It may mean less is more." 
Along with eroding loan portfolios, German banks have been hit by steep declines in the value of their stockholdings as the market has crumbled. In this jittery atmosphere, mere rumors can prove devastating.
"People are willing to believe things are worse than they think," said Mark Hoge, a banking analyst at Banc of America Securities in London. "You get into a situation where you have a self-fulfilling crisis, where people end counterparty relations and credit spreads widen." 
The major credit-rating agencies have steadily downgraded Commerzbank and HVB, putting them in danger of losing their A ratings. Mr. Breuer said he wished the agencies had given more warning before the downgrades, which he said had deepened the mood of uncertainty.
Mr. Breuer is speaking out to dispel what he views as a canard: that Germany is headed for the same kind of banking crisis that afflicts Japan. There, many of the largest banks are fundamentally insolvent and are kept in business only by injections of public money and by the forbearance of bank regulators.
"We don't have a real estate bubble," he said, referring to a major cause of Japan's crash. "We also have the flexibility, and have used the flexibility, to expand to other shores of the business sector."
Japanese banks, he said, have historically been much more restricted than German banks in their ability to expand into ancillary businesses like investment banking and asset management.
The question is whether German banks are prepared to undergo the painful cost-cutting and humbling consolidation that Mr. Breuer says is necessary for the industry to claw its way back to profitability.
"We don't have our back to the wall yet," he said. "You can really argue that the worst has to happen before you really get it. It is a very sad statement, but it is supported by the evidence."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA; 
This year, marketers are trying to take the boo out of Halloween.

BYLINE:  By Stuart Elliott 

 BODY:
FOR the second consecutive year, Madison Avenue is exorcising many of the spooky, ghoulish and violent elements from Halloween advertising.
 You don't need witchcraft to conjure up the reasons the more monstrous images are disappearing from most Halloween marketing, replaced by smiling ghosts and pumpkins and phrases like "Playful fun" and "All treats! No tricks!" A more sober national mood after 9/11 and anxiety over the sniper attacks in metropolitan Washington as well as the struggling economy have swayed many marketers from their typical Halloween tactics. 
 The trend is particularly noticeable in advertising aimed at children. "What we're tracking is more restrained marketing to kids, with less of the supernatural," said Dr. Robert Passikoff, president of Brand Keys in New York, a brand and customer-loyalty consulting company. "The biggest change is the upsurge in costumes like firemen, policemen, doctors and nurses," rather than skeletons, werewolves, mummies and other creepy creatures. 
For instance, a print advertisement for Nestle showing young trick-or-treaters depicts them dressed as a ballerina, a baseball player, a fireman and a wizard. 
And of the 10 children wearing Halloween costumes on the cover of a circular from the Toys "R" Us retail chain, 8 are dressed in mild, not wild, outfits ranging from a Disney princess and a Power Ranger to Spider-Man and a prom queen. Only two of the children are conventionally clad, as a witch and a vampire. 
Susan McLaughlin, a spokeswoman for Toys "R" Us in Paramus, N.J., said the company's focus in recent years had been on costumes based on characters licensed from marketers like the Walt Disney Company.
Dr. Frances Roy, a psychologist who is president of Frances Roy & Associates in Nashville, said: "People are trying to move away from things that are painful in nature. There have been so many negatives, people want to hold on to what's more positive."
And marketers do not want to scare off consumers from shopping for what has grown into a major American holiday. During the 1990's, Halloween expanded beyond its focus on children to embrace adults looking for a reason for a party between Labor Day and Thanksgiving. That fueled substantial growth in sales of costumes, candy, decorations and other related merchandise, which increased to $6.9 billion in 2001 from $2.5 billion in 1996, according to the National Retail Federation, an industry trade association.
However, a survey by the federation indicates that consumers are pausing in their Halloween spending spree. They said they planned to spend $44 a household this year on such items compared with $45 last year.
"I've toured the stores and talked to shoppers and I'm hearing that Halloween is going to be pretty disappointing for retailers, like back-to-school," said Candace Corlett, partner at WSL Strategic Retail in New York, a consulting company.
"People are saying, 'I'm scared about the economy, the talk about war, I just don't know what's going to happen,' " she added, "and it's scary enough for them to count how much they spend."
Those grownup thoughts are reflected in Halloween campaigns aimed at adults for products like alcoholic beverages. For example, last year the Miller Brewing Company sponsored a promotion carrying the theme "Get vamped," showing a model with vampirelike teeth.
This year, the promotion "is more sexy than ghoulish," said Rob Acosta, a spokesman in Milwaukee for Miller, part of SABMiller. The theme is "It's the fright time for Miller Time" and the posters and signs depict a young woman in a tight red dress. 
Another beer marketer, the Gambrinus Company, which imports beer brands like Corona Extra and Corona Light to 25 states, the Caribbean and Washington, is bringing back a humorous Halloween campaign that shows limes carved into grinning jack-o'-lanterns. The "lime-o'-lantern" character spoofs the limes that many beer drinkers squeeze into bottles of those brands.
"Everything we do is tongue in cheek, very lighthearted," said Don Mann, group director at Gambrinus in San Antonio.
"Many consumers are expressing interest in traditions they like that they want to continue as they always have," he added. "That's a consideration here as well."
To that end, some marketers say, they are continuing to run the softer, less intense Halloween advertising that, they believe, consumers have come to expect from them.
"Our Halloween ads have always been lighthearted and kid-friendly," said Peg Buchheit, a spokeswoman for the Pillsbury cookie products sold by General Mills in Minneapolis, "because our target is families with kids." The ads show what are described as "spooky-shape cookies," though the pumpkins, ghosts, bats and black cats are all smiling, and carry the theme "Playful fun."
Of course, there is an exception to every rule, and this year it is the Universal Orlando Resort in Orlando, Fla., owned by Vivendi Universal. The resort's Halloween Horror Nights are being promoted with television commercials replete with grisly images of the fiendish goings-on in the laboratory of a mad scientist. 
David Angelo, chairman and chief creative officer at the resort's agency, David and Goliath in Los Angeles, offered a counterpoint to the kinder, gentler Halloween.
"The client encouraged us to be as bold as possible," Mr. Angelo said, "and come up with something that would scare people out of their pants."
And there does appear to be a pop-cultural appetite for scary fare, at least on the movie screen as the success of movies like "The Ring" and "Red Dragon" can attest.
"We're very mindful of all the events going on," Mr. Angelo added, "but we wanted to stay true to Halloween, which for the most part is about fear."
And selling, too; Mr. Angelo said tickets to the Horror Nights "have pretty much sold out in the first couple weeks."

HEADLINE: Index of Leading Indicators Off For Fourth Consecutive Month 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
The index of leading economic indicators fell in September for the fourth consecutive month, a private research firm said today, the first time that has happened since the start of the 1990-91 recession.
 The drop suggests the recovery may stall through the first quarter of next year. 
 The research firm, the Conference Board, said its index dropped 0.2 percent after falling a revised 0.1 percent in August. 
Over the last six months, the index has declined at an annual rate of 0.5 percent. It would take a 3.5 percent rate of decline over six months to signal a recession, the New York group said.
"A little bit of patience is probably appropriate," said Gary Stern, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis. His comments on the economy came in a speech to a business group in Bloomington, Minn. He said the economy might accelerate in the second half of next year.
Falling stock prices, rising jobless claims and a drop in consumer optimism contributed to the decline in the Conference Board's index. The group uses 10 gauges of economic activity to indicate the economy's direction over the next three to six months.
Economists had expected a 0.2 percent decline in the leading indicators index after a previously reported 0.2 percent drop in August, based on the median of 40 estimates in a Bloomberg News survey.
"As a general matter, our economy is doing O.K.," Treasury Secretary Paul H. O'Neill said earlier today. "We continue to look at possible things that might be done to help it along."
Ken Goldstein, an economist who compiles the report for the Conference Board, said: "Except for the financial markets, there is little evidence of a developing economic decline. A stalling-out of growth is a more reasonable prospect than the economy falling back into recession."
The economy will grow at a 2.2 annual rate this quarter, down from a projected 3.6 percent rate in the third quarter, according to the latest Blue Chip Economic Indicators survey. 
Five of the 10 indicators the Conference Board uses to calculate the index declined, and four rose. The group bases its measurement on seven previously reported economic statistics and estimates for three others.

HEADLINE: Public College Tuitions Rise 10% Amid Financing Cuts 

BYLINE:  By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
Battered by government budget cuts, public colleges and universities raised tuition almost 10 percent this year, with tuition at private institutions going up almost 6 percent, according to a survey released today by the College Board.
 The survey found that over the last decade, a period of minimal inflation, tuition at both public and private institutions had gone up 38 percent. 
 With net family worth declining over the last two years for the first time in a half century, middle-class families have been hard pressed to keep up with rising costs and have sought more financial aid.
"For millions of American students, college is the dream of a lifetime," said Gaston Caperton, president of the College Board. "But financing that dream causes many sleepless nights." 
While private institutions have raised tuition about 5.5 percent annually in recent years, tuition at public colleges and universities is rising more quickly each year. Two years ago, public institutions raised tuition 4.4 percent. Last year, the increase was 7.7 percent. This year, it is 9.6 percent, or $356, according to the College Board. About 75 percent of American undergraduates attend public colleges or universities.
"The main thing here is the recession and state fiscal responses to the recession," said Thomas J. Kane, a professor of policy studies and economics at the University of California at Los Angeles.
Public institutions are reeling from economic blows from several quarters. The plunging stock market and worsening economic outlook have cut the revenues states collect from capital gains and income taxes. And colleges, which can raise tuition, present a more vulnerable target for budget cuts than elementary and secondary education or Medicaid payments, Mr. Kane said.
At the same time, returns from endowments and donations to colleges are down. And institutions are carrying greater debt than ever before, said John Nelson, a senior vice president at Moody's Investor Service specializing in higher education. Just three years ago, the median debt held by a public college or university was $87 million. By last year, it had topped $140 million, he said.
"Many colleges have had a decline in endowment two years in a row, some three years in a row," Mr. Nelson said. "They have these high tuitions, and if you marry it with the family profile, the number of families that can afford to pay these fees is declining."
In its annual report on the cost of attending college, released here today, the College Board charted increases in tuition and fees of 5.8 percent this year, or $1,001, at four-year private colleges and universities. While the rate of increase is smaller than for public colleges, the gap between public and private college continues to widen in terms of real dollars because private colleges charge so much more to begin with.
The increases come after a decade of steadily rising tuitions that consistently outpaced the consumer price index, currently by 8.4 percent for public institutions and by 4.7 percent for private colleges and universities. But financial assistance in the form of grants and loans increased 10 percent this year, to $90 billion, according to the College Board report.
For the second straight year, the board said, aid in the form of grants rose more than loans, reversing a trend over the previous decade.
Mr. Caperton argued the rise in tuition was something of an illusion: while the "sticker price" of a college education is rising, the percentage of families that pay full tuition is declining. Today, only 8 percent of all college students pay full tuition.
David L. Warren, president of the National Association of Independent Colleges and Universities, predicted that thanks to greater financial aid, "out-of-pocket costs for most students at these institutions will not rise appreciably."
But much of the help offered students is in the form of loans, with the typical college graduate carrying $18,000 of debt. That burden is likely to get heavier in coming years.
Asked at a news conference today for her advice to middle-class parents of college students who face financial setbacks, Georgette DeVeres, associate vice president for admissions at Claremont McKenna College in California, stressed that her college and many others were now offering families loans to cover the full amount of tuition.
At the same time, a greater share of financial aid, at both public and private institutions, is awarded on the basis of merit rather than need alone, in an effort to attract stronger students. 
Based on interviews with university officials, Mr. Nelson of Moody's estimates that just 50 private institutions admit students without regard to their ability to pay, and 25 award all scholarships on the basis of need alone. More than 1,900 institutions, Moody's estimates, offer a combination of merit and need-based aid.
As the financial pressures on families have grown, more and more families are turning away from small, independent colleges to state universities, with their far more modest tuition.

HEADLINE: A Little Bordeaux With That Bagel?; 
Huge Wine Show Brings a Taste Of France to New York City

BYLINE:  By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
The French are coming. Well, at least the ones from Bordeaux, the city of wine. And they're bearing tons of it: some 20,000 bottles to be tasted, tout de suite! 
 When the Bordeaux wine festival opens today at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center for an unprecedented visit to North America, there will be an exuberance of promotion, an abundance of networking and a surfeit of traditional swirling, and, yes, spitting. 
 But the question among some wine mavens is: can the show, which many argue is the world's most prominent, find happiness in the New York area -- the leading consumer of imports in America -- despite the economic downturn and an overabundance of production? 
The three-day paradise of wine -- called Vinexpo Americas International Wine and Spirits Exhibition -- is a trade show, barred to the public, open only to more than 10,000 expected industry professionals. But a frenzy of ancillary Francophilic events will be open to the general public right through the weekend, including tastings, auctions, art and antiques shows and special menus at top French restaurants celebrating Bordeaux, the capital of the French region of Aquitaine. 
Beyond this, the show is expected to enrich the city's coffers by at least $30 million, according to a Vinexpo study that estimates spending on hotels and restaurants, as well as payments to truckers, exhibition carpenters and party suppliers for all the blowout socializing. 
Some think the show represents a high-profile effort by the French to pursue the American market. In fact, the kickoff ceremony today will feature Alain Juppe, the former prime minister of France, who just happens to be the mayor of Bordeaux. He said, before leaving for New York: "We are here to do business." 
There have been wine conventions before in New York, but most have been open to consumers as well as the trade, and have confined their wares to wines already in distribution. "But at Vinexpo the trade meets the trade, offering new things that are not distributed in the United States," said Daniel Boulud, the Manhattan chef who is offering cuisine from Bordeaux in two of his restaurants, Daniel and Cafe Boulud. "There will be a huge concentration of winemakers here."
More than 5,000 different wines will be poured by the smiling cadres of 600 exhibitors from 28 countries in 204,000 square feet of Javits space. Tasting their way from booth to booth will be distributors, wholesalers, importers, retailers, restaurateurs, sommeliers and auction devotees. 
Francois Janoueix, one of the growers who were uncrating their wares yesterday, expressed high hopes "that we can find new importers for our products," as he unpacked eight cases of wines.
"It's our first time in America," he said. 
His and other booths will offer a torrent of wines for tasting from the world's 10 top-producing wine countries (Argentina, Australia, Chile, France, Germany, Italy, Portugal, Spain, the United States and South Africa). There will be tastings of the 2000 grands crus from Bordeaux, and new offerings including Clos Poggiale, a Corsican wine, and Fresita, a sparkling Chilean wine with strawberry pulp. 
"Vinexpo has the international reputation of being the most important trade show in the world," said Jon Fredrikson, a wine analyst who is president of Gomberg, Fredrikson & Associates, industry consultants in Woodside, Calif. "Now they are trying to market to the vast trade audience that doesn't go to Bordeaux." 
Despite threats of war and gyrating markets -- or possibly because of them -- United States imports of table wine are projected to be up 12 percent to 52 million cases over last year, out of the total of 214 million cases expected to be sold in 2002, according to Mr. Fredrikson. 
Many in the city's wine trade are pleased that Vinexpo has come to town. "I applaud them in bringing the show to New York, which really needs the convention business," said Richard Genova, president of House of Burgundy, a Manhattan wine importer. "New York deserves to have a pre-eminent wine trade fair." 
But he added: "Whether this show is organized to be that pre-eminent show is another question. The jury will be out until next week." 
The organizers hope that Vinexpo will be a United Nations of wine, said Robert Beynat, chief executive of Vinexpo, that will "help develop the North American market." But Mr. Fredrikson said the economic downturn "has negatively affected the consumption of wine in high-end restaurants." He added that the timing of the show could be "inopportune," since the industry has already booked all its imports for the holiday season. 
Mr. Fredrikson said that Vinexpo has arrived at a time in the business cycle of the $19 billion United States wine market "where there are large supplies of wine available right now, and so it's a very competitive situation."
The wine glut, he added, "may make it difficult for the sellers to get the attention of retailers."
This is more than a theoretical consideration. Admission to the trade show is free to preregistered professionals (and $40 to latecomers). But exhibitors pay an average of $13,000 to sell their wares. Given all the incidentals, including promotional parties and dinners, Mr. Genova said, "the cost is at least $25,000 to exhibitors." 
But Mr. Beynat of Vinexpo said that the trade show "is not here just for this year's market; it is a multiyear investment for the future." Planning for the show, which started 18 months ago, only intensified after the terrorist attack at the World Trade Center "because we very much wanted to show our support for New York City," he said. 
Organizers of the host of related events are hoping for high visibility in the fall Manhattan social swirl. Aside from the catered galas, tasting dinners and auctions, there is the Bordeaux and Aquitaine Grape Harvest Festival, a selection of food and wine from the region at 15 Manhattan restaurants, including Alain Ducasse, Le Bernardin and Lespinasse. 
Mr. Boulud, for example, will be presenting a country-style cabbage soup -- garbure au canard et foie gras -- at Cafe Boulud. The dish is on the menu of La Tupina, a revered restaurant in Bordeaux whose owner and chef, Jean-Pierre Xiradakis, will attend Vinexpo. 
In addition, a show at a town house called the Embassy, on East 67th Street in Manhattan, will display art and antiques from Aquitaine chateaus, imported to New York by French dealers. A listing of events can be found at www.vinexpo.com.
Vinexpo, founded 21 years ago in Bordeaux, has raised its ensign every two years since, drawing ever-increasing hordes of thirsty wine professionals to its turf among the world's greatest vineyards.
Last year the show drew more than 2,000 exhibitors from 40 countries and 54,000 visitors. The New York show is its first North American satellite.
"It's all about networking; floating, tasting, seeing, looking for what's new," said F. Paul Pacult, editor of Spirit Journal, a quarterly with 12,000 subscribers that is published in Ulster County, N.Y. 
Although offerings were predominantly French in the early years, now 40 percent of the exhibits are of non-French wines from around the world. 
The event in New York "is long overdue," said Mr. Pacult, who added that "this is the first time that the French are actually looking at North America as a market that they must capture." 
Some are looking to buyer inquisitiveness for success. "No two bottles of wine are the same, and wine people are always curious," Mr. Genova said. "We're always willing to fall in love again."

HEADLINE: Alaskans Worry About Future Of Their Oil Royalty Checks 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: ANCHORAGE, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
The state's oil royalty fund, which pays every man, woman and child in Alaska a dividend each year just for living here, may be running dry for the first time since it began 20 years ago.
 The state Constitution says that the principal of the Alaska Permanent Fund, about $22 billion, cannot be touched, and because of the downturn on Wall Street, it has been dangerously close to that level and sometimes below it. 
 The dividend checks have been mailed out every fall since 1982. This year's payout was $1,540 per person; all told, about 600,000 Alaska residents are splitting $900 million. 
The loss of the dividend next year could have a huge effect on Alaska's economy and the lives of its poorer residents. Many use their checks on shopping sprees at the mall or put the money down on new cars, snowmobiles or hot tubs.
"I would guess over 75 percent of the folks that come in here during the Permanent Fund time are spending their Permanent Fund dividends," said Maggie O'Hara, co-owner of Bill's Cat House, which sells Arctic Cat snowmobiles and other recreational vehicles. "And they usually spend them on coats, helmets and used snow machines. Which is why we have our big sale at this time."
If there is no dividend?
"People will buy fewer toys, I think," Ms. O'Hara said.
But while some Alaskans spend the dividend on luxuries, poorer people often depend on it for help with housing and other basics like gasoline, heating oil and electricity, which are expensive in Alaska's remote areas.
"The dividend helps a small community a lot, because there's no work out here," said Moses Toyukak, one of three employees at the power plant in the village of Manokotak, a 350-mile flight from Anchorage. "I've been putting mine toward housing the last eight years."
Nearly half of Manokotak's 80 families have incomes of $25,000 or less. Because the average Manokotak family has five members, the loss of the dividend would cut family income by 30 percent or more. 
Villagers catch and dry fish and hunt moose, caribou and beaver for food. But their hunting forays are on all-terrain vehicles or snowmobiles, and gasoline costs $2.45 a gallon.
Pete Andrew is a salmon fisherman in Dillingham, a town of 5,000 where the cost of living is about 50 percent higher than in Anchorage. Milk costs $6 a gallon, cabbage $7 a head.
Mr. Andrew has been putting away the dividends for college for his four children, ages 11 through 16. 
The Permanent Fund was set up in 1976 after oil from Prudhoe Bay began flowing via the Alaska pipeline. Royalties paid to the state by the oil companies are put in the fund and invested, about half in the stock market, 40 percent in bonds and 10 percent in real estate.
In 2000, the fund's value peaked at $27.8 billion, and the dividend that year reached a record $1,964 for every Alaskan.
This year's dividend was equal to roughly 5 percent of Alaska's $17 billion economy.
"If there was a loss of the complete dividend, it would be a lean Christmas for our retailers," said Gregg Erickson, an economist in Juneau, "and for many families and households who depend on it."

HEADLINE: The Science and Politics of Super Rice 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH KAHN 

DATELINE: HANGZHOU, China 

 BODY:
Huang Danian, an expert at the National Rice Research Institute here, has created a rice so resilient and tasty, he says, that "every farmer in China will certainly want it."
 So far, however, it grows only on a few acres in Mr. Huang's walled garden near Hangzhou, about 100 miles southwest of Shanghai. Though he has passed government safety tests and has a national patent for his creation, China has banned his rice from grocery shelves because it depends on altering rice genes to create a breed immune to the toxic effects of herbicides. 
 Reversing its formerly enthusiastic embrace of genetic experiments, China has imposed restrictions on domestic varieties of genetically modified crops like rice, soybeans, vegetables and tobacco, and required lengthy safety tests and cumbersome labeling rules for imports of such food. 
The go-slow approach reflects rising concerns about food safety, but mainly, many critics say, the restrictions are a convenient tool for trade protection.
Officials in Beijing fear that small-scale, and therefore relatively inefficient, Chinese farmers cannot compete with food imports from the United States, many of them genetically modified. Officials also think that the country's own food exports may suffer in the world market, where fears of so-called Frankenstein food are rampant, if China becomes a pioneer in genetically altered foods.
China's entry into the World Trade Organization earlier this year was supposed to open its markets permanently and make it difficult to manipulate trade in such ways. But new rules and regulations governing farm products and some crucial services like banking and telecommunications, show that it has no intention of making domestic producers fend for themselves overnight.
"The U.S. hoped China was just going to get out of the market, but it obviously isn't happening that way," said Robert Paarlberg, a political science expert at Wellesley College who has studied China's policies on genetics. "In some ways, the genetics issue is just an excuse to control trade."
The newly cautious approach to genetically modified foods has disappointed American farmers, who expected to sell far more goods to China after it joined the trade organization early this year. Instead, their sales of soybeans, the largest export crop, fell 23 percent in the year through September compared with the similar period of 2001, largely because of complications related to China's new testing and licensing procedures.
Bush administration trade officials have made repeated trips to China in recent months aimed at persuading officials to allow unfettered imports of soybeans. Trade in farm products is also expected to be a sensitive economic issue on the agenda when President Jiang Zemin meets President Bush in Crawford, Tex., on Oct. 25.
Possibly to ease trade tensions, China recently announced that it would extend a provisional arrangement allowing imports of soybeans until next September, giving it more time to review health and environmental effects.
This concession relieves some of the uncertainty that had disrupted the $1 billion soybean trade. But it may also push back the date when China decides whether to certify American soybeans as safe.
More broadly, the guarded approach to genetically modified foods appears to be ascendant. Officials in the agriculture ministry want more restrictions on genetically altered foods because of safety and competitiveness concerns, several Chinese officials said. They have outmaneuvered people in the nation's science establishment who wanted to see the fruits of genetic research harvested quickly.
"China has long wanted to be No. 1 in developing rice and other staple foods," said Mr. Huang, who had been negotiating with Monsanto and other big foreign biotechnology companies to commercialize his rice breed. "But it is becoming clear that we will not develop faster than the rest of world. We are not going to be first."
That would amount to a decisive shift for China, which until recently seemed to want to become the developing world's leader in biotechnology. It has invested large amounts -- as much as $100 million annually, according to a survey team from the University of California -- to develop more than 140 varieties of genetically modified plants.
The idea is to rearrange genes in important crops to maximize their resistance to pests or to pesticides and herbicides. Other strains have been designed to grow in arid or salty soil, while still others were tweaked to improve taste.
China saw genetic research as the way to maintain basic self-sufficiency in staple foods and get the most from its arable land, which is already scarce and is shrinking every year.
So strong was its commitment to genetic engineering that it was the only developing country to join the Human Genome Project. Its scientists played a leading role in deciphering the complex rice genome. And China produced genetically modified seeds to grow potatoes, tomatoes, soybeans, rice and even trees and flowers.
But some early failed experiments with genetically modified tobacco plants in the 1990's, as well as reports that genetically modified corn had unintentionally been mixed with organic corn in Mexico in 1999, began to diminish its ardor, local and international experts said.
Growing consumer resistance to genetically modified food in Japan and South Korea, as well as in Europe, provided another warning. Chinese officials feared that they would lose important export markets by pushing ahead too quickly.
Polls also showed that domestic shoppers preferred food that had not been genetically altered. After Chinese officials issued new labeling rules this summer, supermarkets were supposed to begin putting notices on products that contained genetically modified ingredients. Few products carry such labels now, but there are many, like Rong's brand corn oil, that have bright yellow labels saying they contain only organic ingredients.
Both the Bush and Clinton administrations had hoped that China would become an ally on farm issues in the World Trade Organization, where the fight over the safety of genetically modified food may eventually end up. Instead, China now appears more inclined to support a cautionary stance like the one taken by the European Union. If its position does not change, it may slow the trade of genetically modified food globally.
"In the long run, China could still be an ally of the U.S. within the W.T.O.," Mr. Paarlberg said, "but in the short run they are definitely not going to be a stalking horse."
Indeed, the trend is toward more restrictions. Although China has had new seed varieties available for years, it has allowed the widespread planting of only one crop, a strain of cotton modified to resist the bollworm.
This spring, Beijing banned biotechnology companies like Monsanto and Syngenta from investing in the development of genetically modified strains of corn, soybeans and rice seeds.
More recently, it canceled plans to allow the broad use of corn plants modified to fight bugs in the main grain-producing provinces in the northeast. Field tests showed that in China's tightly concentrated farm plots, pests evolved quickly to overcome the resistance of genetically modified plants.
"The general sense is that the risks are too high and the market is too small" for most genetically modified plants, said Wu Kongmin, who heads a panel of experts conducting safety tests for the agriculture ministry.
At his laboratory near Hangzhou, Mr. Huang is waiting for approval to develop rice seeds based on his herbicide-resistant breed. But he puts most of his energy into developing a new grade of rice that has an extra long grain, which he plans to market under the brand name Tianmei. He achieved that result, significantly, through conventional crossbreeding, not by rearranging genes.
"At least," he said, "we can make some progress the old way."
