HEADLINE: 35-Story Tower Is Planned For Last Open Times Sq. Lot 

BYLINE:  By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Twenty-two years after the city and the state announced an ambitious project to transform a seedy and forlorn Times Square, a prominent real estate family is planning to build a 35-story tower on the last remaining parcel in the 13-acre redevelopment district.
 The family, Howard and Edward Milstein, plan to break ground today on the 850,000-square-foot building, which will combine office space, street-level stores and possibly apartments on a parking lot at the southeast corner of 42nd Street and Eighth Avenue. 
 It is designed by Fox & Fowle, the same architects who designed the Conde Nast and Reuters buildings a block away on Times Square.
The Milsteins' $500 million project will sit in an area that has already undergone a neon-glazed sea change as T-shirt shops and pornography stores gave way in the mid-1990's to new theaters, sleek glass office buildings, a World Wrestling Entertainment restaurant, the largest toy store in the world and, last week, a colorful 860-room Westin hotel. 
But, until now, the last piece on the Times Square checkerboard sat quietly.
"Eddie and I are 100 percent committed to completing this building by 2004," Howard Milstein said yesterday. "Even in these times of uncertainty, New York City and Times Square remain the crossroads of the world."
Former Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, who spent much of the 1980's and early 1990's trying to get the Times Square project off the ground, said it was a long time coming.
"It's gratifying," Mr. Cuomo said yesterday. "It took longer than it should have and was more tortuous. But the energy and the power of the place is so formidable."
Despite frequent news conferences and much fanfare, the redevelopment of Times Square was stymied for many years by community opposition, 47 lawsuits and a deep recession in the early 1990's.
But companies and retailers flooded into the area beginning in the late 1990's, after Disney announced it would rehabilitate the New Amsterdam Theater, on 42nd Street near Seventh Avenue, and Douglas Durst, the developer, began building a new skyscraper in Times Square.
State and city officials provided developers with hundreds of millions of dollars in subsidies to build in Times Square. They also granted tax breaks to tenants like Conde Nast Publications, Ernst & Young, Reuters, The New York Times and others.
Even after the transformation was well under way, the subsidies got larger, not smaller. Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani provided Conde Nast, for instance, with incentives worth about $10.7 million in 1996, while Ernst & Young got $20 million in 1999.
Although the resurgence of Times Square is certain, the Milstein project is not without some risk for a family that has not erected a new office building in 19 years or a new residential building in a decade.
The booming economy of the late 1990's, which brought tourists, new restaurants, stores, investment bankers and even accountants to once-forbidding Times Square, has faded a bit.
Boston Properties is scouring the city for tenants for its tower under construction on the south side of 42nd Street between Seventh Avenue and Broadway, as is Forest City Ratner for space in the proposed headquarters for The Times on Eighth Avenue, between 40th and 41st Streets.
Developers have also completed, or are building, eight apartment towers with more than 3,000 apartments on 42nd Street, west of Eighth Avenue, or nearby.
But Mr. Milstein said he expected to complete his tower in 2004 after Boston Properties opens its building and before Forest City completes its project.
If the office market remains soft, he said, he has the option of building apartments instead of a large block of office space. The Milstein building will also have a parking garage and retail space on three floors.
Charles A. Gargano, chairman of the Empire State Development Corporation, which has overseen the Times Square redevelopment project, said he was "pleased that the last empty lot on a booming 42nd Street is being developed."
The Milsteins have long wanted to be a part of Times Square redevelopment. The family bought a decrepit hotel at Eighth Avenue and 44th Street in 1978, renovated it and opened it as the Milford Plaza, just outside the Times Square redevelopment area.
But they were rebuffed by state officials when they wanted to be designated as an official project developer for the 42nd Street site. 
The Milsteins bought the parking lot at Eighth Avenue in 1983 for $5 million, after state officials, short of cash, turned down an offer to buy it. But little happened afterward. In recent years, Howard Milstein tried to develop a one-million-square-foot tower on the site, but it became contested territory in a feud between different wings of the Milstein family.
Early last year, Howard, his father, Paul, and his brother, Edward, bought out their cousins' interest in a deal that valued the parking lot at $111 million.

HEADLINE: Tunnel Vision; 
The Fare Dance, and Paying the Piper

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
The band is still playing very softly, but make no mistake: the familiar waltz that a transit official once affectionately called the "dance of death" is under way again.
 Anywhere else, it might be considered strange to use such a macabre phrase to describe what is, after all, only the chance that subway and bus fares will rise. But in New York, with the largest transit system in the Western Hemisphere and an economy entwined in it, the description seems somehow apt for the grim political pas de deux that occurs as reliably as wildfires in the West. 
 Since the subway opened in 1904 at a nickel a ride, the dance has ended in an increase 13 times, five of those in the last two decades, bringing the basic fare up to $1.50. As with most of the previous performances, the newest dance is proceeding according to a set of inviolable rules, rendered much stricter because this particular dance has begun during a gubernatorial election year. 
Among the rules are these:
*Everyone in an official position to decide whether the fare will rise -- in other words, Gov. George E. Pataki and the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which he controls -- must act as if the very idea is only slightly less outrageous than levying a special tax on breathing. At least until after Election Day.
*Those same people must become even more evasive than usual about the true nature of the transit agency's finances. For example, while some transit officials talk about a dangerous operating deficit for next year of more than $600 million, the most recent figures show subway and bus revenues actually running $33 million ahead of budget right now. How do those two figures jibe? And how did last year's equally dangerous deficit projection, of more than $700 million, manage to vanish?
*A subset of those same people, while denying that a fare increase is looming, must carefully begin laying the philosophical groundwork for one. At a City Council hearing in March, the M.T.A.'s budget director, Gary G. Caplan, stressed that it had been seven years since the last increase, and added that MetroCard discounts had driven the cost of an average subway or bus ride down to $1.06. (He did not add an important related point, but his critics quickly did: the drop does not mean that the agency now collects less money. Ridership has increased, so fare revenue has actually remained about the same over the last five years.)
Returning to the Council this month, Mr. Caplan appeared to place another important brick in his foundation, contending that New York riders pay slightly less than half of the transit system's operating costs.
Once again, his dance partners countered vigorously, citing federal statistics that show that riders actually pay almost 60 percent of running the subways and buses, much more than many other cities' riders do. In Boston, for example, the $1 basic subway fare and 75-cent bus fare foot only 29 percent of the bill, while government subsidies make up the rest.
In many ways, the background music for this newest dance is the same sad tune that has been playing since the M.T.A. was created in 1968 and the state took over the system. And it is that, while transporting a huge percentage of the state's citizens every day, the system has always received less than this percentage in state transit aid. The gap is considerable: the system moves 84 percent of the state's riders and gets only 63 percent of state aid, meaning that it regularly finds itself needing to raise fares and makes itself a huge target for accusations of unfairness.
But there are other melodies complicating the dance music this year. One is that the system is in better shape than it has been in past fare-increase situations, making it much harder to argue that riders would be forced to pay more for less. (Opponents counter that service has not nearly kept pace with ridership increases, leading to a lot less of many important things, like space and seats.)
The other difference this time is that the city's mayor -- whose dance role has always been to pirouette wildly in protest of any possible increase -- seems to have forgotten his part. Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg is trying to balance his own troubled budget and is looking for ways to cut even the city's meager contribution to the subways. So he has all but welcomed an increase, leaving opponents even more isolated and meaning that the dance is more likely to end with higher fares. 
While it might seem that this is always the inevitable result, it has not always been so. In 1981, for example, state officials responded to public pressure and worked through the night to pass a tax package giving more money to the subways and buses and staving off an increase.
How will it all end this time? "It's much harder to tell, because nobody is leveling with the public," said Gene Russianoff, staff lawyer for the Straphangers Campaign, playing its traditional role of opponent in the dance. "But you can expect a whole lot of leveling very soon."

GRAPHIC: Photo: More than half a century ago, there was opposition to the first proposal to raise the subway fare, in 1948. The fare rose that year, to 10 cents from 5. (Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, N.Y.U., District 65/U.A.W. Collection)

HEADLINE: For Indonesia Leader, Small Talk Edges Tough Talk 

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
When the Australian foreign minister arrived here after the bombings in Bali to talk about terrorism, President Megawati Sukarnoputri greeted him with the kind of inconsequential remark expected from a protocol officer.
 The Indonesian weather, Australian officials say she told the minister, Alexander Downer, was very hot. 
 The daughter of Sukarno, Indonesia's charismatic founder, Mrs. Megawati often behaves like a court princess, bound by codes of formal conduct and minimal public expression. 
There are frequent accounts in Jakarta of Mrs. Megawati, when confronted with a serious question by a visiting diplomat, replying across the tea set, "Have another cookie." 
Yet, beneath the polite exterior lies a desire, say her admirers, to bring stability to an ethnically diverse nation that has known terrible violence and a dedication to democracy after three decades of authoritarian rule.
She is very supportive of the military, a sympathy that can be explained, they assert, by a yearning for national cohesion. Her reluctance to take on Islamic militants, even as the United States has repeatedly linked some of them to Al Qaeda, stemmed, they say, from her concern that a crackdown would lead to turmoil. 
President Megawati is scheduled to leave here on Tuesday for the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation summit meeting in Mexico, where she is scheduled to meet with President Bush to discuss terrorism. In an unusual challenge to a foreign president, Mr. Bush said last week that he hoped to "hear the resolve of a leader" when he sat down with Mrs. Megawati in Mexico. 
That is the question in Indonesia, too: Can the 55-year-old president of the world's most populous Muslim nation, who has spent much of her life as a housewife, change her modus operandi after 14 months on the job? Can she rule rather than reign?
"She has started to move, but not fast enough," said Jusuf Wanandi, the director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies in Jakarta. "She's trying to lead. She is now at last calling frequent cabinet and security meetings." 
Those cabinet meetings exposed the divisions within her government. They also underscored the balancing act Mrs. Megawati must try to carry off as she faces the international community over terrorism and as she faces re-election in 2004.
Overwhelming numbers of Indonesians practice a moderate form of Islam, but there are increasing calls for an Islamic state with Shariah law. President Megawati is in the contradictory position of wanting to avoid a harsh crackdown that might increase sympathies for the Islamists while avoiding looking too weak in the face of a challenge from her vice president, Hamzah Haz, who is likely to be an opponent in the 2004 contest, political analysts say. 
Mrs. Megawati was able to smooth the severe divisions in her cabinet last week and, finally, after a marathon cabinet session that ran until midnight last Friday, the government issued two new antiterrorism decrees that provide for sweeping powers of investigation and detention. They were laws that the United States had been urging on the government since last year. 
True to form, Mrs. Megawati did not speak publicly about the stern edicts she had been previously reluctant to push. But one thing was clear. She had somehow laid the political groundwork so that not only were there no immediate public protests, but the most important moderate Muslim leaders openly embraced the new laws.
Like a number of other leaders in Asia who are women, Mrs. Megawati ascended with the help of a political pedigree. But hers was a difficult rise, fraught with personal unhappiness and political persecution. 
She was born in 1947, in Yogyakarta, the intellectual center of Indonesia when it was still battling the Dutch. Her name means cloud, and she grew up in the pleasant surroundings of the presidential palace in Jakarta. Sukarno took her on his frequent trips abroad, including one to meet President John F. Kennedy. 
Apparently upset about the bloody overthrow of her father, Mrs. Megawati dropped out of college after only a year. Soon after her father's death in 1970, her first husband, Surindro Supjarso, an air force officer, was killed in a plane crash. She then eloped with an Egyptian diplomat, only to have the marriage annulled by her family. 
In 1973, she married her present husband, a businessman, Taufik Kiemas. After staying at home for more than a decade raising children, she joined her husband in running for Parliament in the mid-1980's as members of the opposition Democratic Party of Indonesia.
By 1999, largely on the power of her name as Sukarno's daughter, she had become the country's most popular politician. Her party won 35 percent of the votes in the first free elections since the 1950's.
But even though she was the top vote getter, Mrs. Megawati could not bring herself to negotiate with other political parties to form a government. She became vice president to Abdurrahman Wahid and, when Mr. Wahid's tenure ended amid impeachment charges last year, she emerged as president with a coalition that included Islamist politicians.
The broker behind all her political moves has been Mr. Taufik. As she has moved up the political ladder, he has moved from managing a chain of gas stations during the Suharto era to becoming the consummate dealmaker of his wife's administration. 
Until the attack in Bali, however, the dominant question in Indonesian politics was whether Mrs. Megawati's election prospects would survive the political damage from Mr. Taufik's business deals, American diplomats said. The perception that Mrs. Megawati is unable to move decisively against corruption does not help, nor does her announced ignorance of economic matters. For example, she referred during a recent foreign trip to applying the "housewife's management system" to the nation's economic problems.
Mrs. Megawati has proved a perplexing problem for the Bush administration. She was one of the first foreign leaders to see President Bush after the Sept. 11 attack, and promised to fight terror. But when she came home to a widespread anti-Americanism, she carefully distanced herself from Washington.
Last month, the White House dispatched Karen B. Brooks, 31, a specialist on Indonesia on the National Security Council, and the person Mrs. Megawati likes best in the administration. Only Ms. Brooks, it was reasoned, could persuade her that Qaeda-linked militant Islamic groups were operating in her country. Sadly, however, Mrs. Megawati took notice only after the deaths of more than 200 people in Bali, a senior American official lamented.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
Making a Case for a U.S. Invasion of Iraq

BYLINE:  By RICHARD BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
THE THREATENING STORM
The Case for Invading Iraq
By Kenneth M. Pollack
Illustrated. 494 pages. Random House. $25.95
 In "The Threatening Storm," Kenneth M. Pollack makes what is very likely the best and strongest case that can be made for invading Iraq. His argument is not that it is desirable to send 200,000 American troops to Baghdad, but that an invasion is the least bad option faced by the United States -- the only option that can solve what Mr. Pollack presents as a dangerous and deteriorating situation that will only get worse as long as the Iraqi dictator Saddam Hussein remains in power. 
 It is fair to say that whatever your feelings about the question of Iraq, you owe it to yourself to read Mr. Pollack's book, which is both hawkish and judicious. Its essential argument is that the containment policy followed since the Persian Gulf war of 1991 -- consisting of economic sanctions, a continued American military presence in the Persian Gulf and United Nations weapons inspections -- is fast eroding. Sanctions are being circumvented by the rampant smuggling of Iraqi oil. The presence of American troops in the region, especially in Saudi Arabia, is breeding local resentment. Meanwhile, the most important element in the containment policy, United Nations inspection teams searching for and destroying Iraq's weapons of mass destruction, ceased in 1998 and, in Mr. Pollack's view, is not likely to be effective even if revived.
What to do? Mr. Pollack reviews all the options, from doing essentially nothing to a military effort relying on anti-Hussein Iraqi resistance forces supported by devastating air strikes, somewhat like what was done with the Northern Alliance and the Taliban in Afghanistan. He reviews the pluses and minuses of each of the options, giving due weight to opinions contrary to his own, and then concludes: "The only prudent and realistic course of action left to the United States is to mount a full-scale invasion of Iraq to smash the Iraqi armed forces, depose Saddam's regime and rid the country of weapons of mass destruction."
Mr. Pollack spent the 90's studying this issue, first as an analyst for the Central Intelligence Agency and then as director of gulf affairs for the National Security Council. He is a man, in short, who knows his subject, and the implications of what he is arguing, most important the deaths of American soldiers and the expenditure of billions of dollars. "Every time I say or write this, I find myself wondering whether it is truly necessary," he declares of his pro-invasion conclusion. In this sense, his book reconstructs his own experience in studying the question of Iraq and how he arrived, even somewhat reluctantly, at his overall conclusion.
This does not mean that it is impossible to detect weaknesses in his argument. Mr. Pollack waxes positively rhapsodic about the benefits that would accrue once a democratic, pro-Western Iraq has arisen from Saddam Hussein's ashes, but while, as always, he demonstrates an awareness of the risks and costs of the nation-building that would be required, he glides a bit lightly over them. Put another way: he has no confidence in the ability of Western public opinion to pursue a containment policy over the long term, but he seems to have no doubt about the ability of public opinion to stay the course after Mr. Hussein has been safely disposed of. More generally perhaps, those who oppose an invasion will find that Mr. Pollack is more attuned to the dangers posed by an Iraq seeking nuclear weapons than he is to the dangers of an essentially unilateral invasion.
On the other hand, for those who have faith that a newly conceived, intrusive United Nations weapons-inspection regime can do the job will meet a tough challenge in this book. Mr. Pollack contends that any such effort would be a dangerous trap. Mr. Hussein would surely cooperate if troops were massed on his border and an invasion was otherwise unavoidable, but it would take far longer for inspections to work than it would be possible to maintain the credible threat of an invasion.
"All Saddam would need to do is wait until we were forced to start scaling back our forces in the region, and as the threat receded he would return to his past tactic of 'cheat and retreat' with the inspectors that served him so well in 1991-98," Mr. Pollack writes. 
Other matters are dealt with: Mr. Pollack measures the likelihood of a military success and what the best-case and worst-case American losses would be. He analyzes the attitudes of important other countries. He graphically describes the "pervasive climate of terror throughout the country, which is the linchpin of Iraqi totalitarianism." In short, Mr. Pollack has written a timely book that should be read as the public debate on Iraq continues.

HEADLINE: The Price of Stability 

BYLINE:  By Michael O'Hanlon; Michael O'Hanlon is a senior fellow at the Brookings Institution.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
The Bush administration is now debating a postwar occupation of Iraq modeled on the United States occupation of Japan after World War II. Under this approach, Iraq would initially be ruled by an American military officer while a new Iraqi government is formed. Coalition military forces would perhaps remain in Iraq for years to make good on President Bush's promise of a post-Saddam Iraq where "the oppression of Kurds, of Assyrians, Turkomans, Shia, Sunnis and others will be lifted" and in which "the United States and our allies will help the Iraqi people rebuild their economy and create the institutions of liberty."
 War is not yet inevitable, but if there is a war, rebuilding Iraq will have to be part of the planning. A prolonged occupation is reportedly unpopular with some Pentagon officials who prefer a quicker option by which the United States would invade Iraq, overthrow Saddam Hussein, pass power to a government-in-exile that would be brought back to Baghdad, and then withdraw its forces. 
 One view put forward by Richard Perle, chairman of the Defense Policy Board, an advisory panel to Defense Secretary Donald Rumsfeld, is that a post-Saddam Hussein Iraq might resemble Romania after the fall of another tyrant, Nicolae Ceausescu, at the end of the cold war. Under this model, Iraq would gradually struggle toward democracy on its own, remaining relatively stable in the process without the help of occupying forces.
However, the Romania analogy is highly optimistic given that country's relative ethnic homogeneity and the cohesion of the resistance movement that overthrew the Communist regime. For every Ceausescu, there is a Mobutu or a Tito whose death has contributed to the disintegration of his country.
If we overthrow Saddam Hussein and then quickly leave Iraq, civil war is likely. Some will seek retribution against elements of the old regime, like Republican Guard troops and Saddam Hussein's kinsmen from the Tikrit region. Those loyal to Mr. Hussein may try to reconstitute their power base once American forces leave. The Kurds might try to secede; Kurds and Sunni Muslims may fight for oil-rich Kirkuk in the north of the country. Such chaos could entice Iran into pursuing territorial gains in Iraq's oil-rich and Shiite south and make it possible for terrorist groups to find refuge and even gain access to some chemical or biological weapons in the ensuing chaos.
So making plans for a postwar occupation makes sense, though it would be wiser to have the United Nations administer the government rather than an American officer. But what level of military effort would such an occupation require? The United States has almost one million law enforcement officers for a population of just under 300 million. It used a comparable density of forces to police postwar Germany in the American occupation zone. Protecting and resettling refugees and internally displaced Iraqis, as well as searching for weapons of mass destruction, will also be labor intensive.
Based on past experience, stabilizing a country the size of Iraq with a population of more than 20 million people would require an occupation lasting several years and at least 100,000 foreign troops in the initial phase. Perhaps a quarter to a third of that force strength would be American troops, depending on how much allied help we could recruit, in which case annual costs to the United States might be $5 billion to $10 billion or more (on top of war costs likely to be in the vicinity of $50 billion). Costs could be even greater if the military has to increase its size to carry out this mission.
The good news is that most of the labor-intensive tasks could probably be completed within one to two years. Just as NATO's forces in Bosnia have declined to less than 20,000 from 50,000, an occupation force for Iraq might be reduced to 50,000 from 100,000 within a few years, with the American presence cut proportionately.
Even so, costs will be substantial and higher than anything publicly acknowledged by the administration so far. Until we face up to the very real possibility that a multiyear occupation will be needed, we have not yet accepted the reality of what war to overthrow Saddam Hussein could entail.

HEADLINE: Pataki Calls Commuter Tax a Bad Idea 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
With an uncomfortable-looking Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg standing by his side, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he did not support reinstating the commuter tax to help the city out of its fiscal crisis. 
 "Reimposing the commuter tax now would be extraordinarily counterproductive," Mr. Pataki said at a news conference in Harlem. As the governor spoke, Mr. Bloomberg, his Republican ally, drifted away from the lectern they were sharing, looked up at the sky and shifted his weight from foot to foot. 
 The mayor recently dropped his opposition to tax increases as he works to close the city's second $5 billion budget gap in a row, and his aides have made it clear that they would welcome the nearly $500 million that a commuter tax would generate.
The tax, which was levied on people who work in the city but live elsewhere, was repealed by the state in 1999 over the strong objections of city officials.
Mr. Pataki said that reinstating it would hamper the city's economic recovery.
"We have thousands of jobs, tens of thousands of jobs, that have been temporarily dislocated," he said. "And it's very important that we fight very hard to bring all those jobs back. And we can't do that if we're telling employers, we're telling employees, 'Come back to Lower Manhattan, come back to New York City, and by the way, we're going to hit you with a new tax.' "
When Mr. Bloomberg was asked to weigh in, he thanked the governor for his help in the past and stressed that his first order of business would to be to cut the city's expenses. He did not use the word "tax" once.

HEADLINE: 3M Reports 38% Increase In Net Income 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: ST. PAUL, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
The 3M Company said today that its third-quarter net income increased 38 percent, the largest quarterly profit in five years.
 The company, which changed its name from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing in April, said that it cut costs and that sales increased in Asia, its fastest-growing market. 
 Net income rose to $545 million, or $1.38 a share, from $394 million, or 99 cents, a year earlier. Revenue increased 4.5 percent, to $4.14 billion from $3.96 billion. 
Revenue overseas rose 8.8 percent, while sales in the United States were little changed. About a quarter of 3M's sales are from Asia and about half in the United States.
The company reduced costs by changing the way it buys some material, including through auctions, the chief financial officer, Patrick D. Campbell, said.
W. James McNerney Jr., the chief executive since January 2001, is managing 2,500 cost-cutting projects, using methods he learned in his 18 years at General Electric.
Charles Carlson, a money manager at Horizon Investment Services in Indiana, said of today's report: "Volume wasn't bad outside of the U.S., but inside was a disappointment." He said Horizon did not hold 3M shares because the company "is pretty expensive considering the rate of top-line growth."
In New York Stock Exchange trading, shares of 3M, the largest component of the dollar-weighted Dow Jones industrial average, rose $3.69, to $129.
The company said it might take a $1 billion charge against equity for its pension plan in the fourth quarter. It added that last quarter it contributed $789 million to its United States pension fund.
3M said it did not see signs of the global economy improving. 
It projected the full year's net income to be in the range of $4.95 to $5 a share. Excluding certain benefits and costs, 3M said, profit will be $5.22 to $5.27 a share. Its previous estimate was for profit of $5.15 to $5.30. Fourth-quarter profit, 3M estimated, will rise to the range of $1.25 to $1.30 a share from 98 cents in the fourth quarter of 2001.

HEADLINE: Bush Sees Korean Nuclear Effort as Different From Iraq's 

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 21 

 BODY:
President Bush said today that the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, had to disarm his nation "for the sake of peace," but indicated that he saw a significant difference between North Korea's development of nuclear weapons and Iraq's pursuit of them.
 In his first public remarks about North Korea since the White House announced last week that the country was conducting a covert nuclear weapons program, Mr. Bush said he would use diplomatic pressure, not threats of military action, to try to persuade North Korea to dismantle its nuclear efforts. 
 "It is a troubling discovery, and it's a discovery that we intend to work with our friends to deal with," he told reporters in the Oval Office after a meeting with the NATO secretary general, Lord Robertson. "I believe we can do it peacefully. I look forward to working with people to encourage them that we must convince Kim Jong Il to disarm for the sake of peace." 
In contrast, Mr. Bush said he was threatening military action against President Saddam Hussein of Iraq because his case was "unique" in that he had gassed his own people and "thumbed his nose" at United Nations resolutions for more than a decade.
The president's remarks reflected recent comments by Secretary of State Colin L. Powell and Condoleezza Rice, the national security adviser, that Iraq poses a greater threat to the United States, even if it does not yet have nuclear weapons, because of its record of using chemical weapons and its hatred of the United States and its allies.
Nonetheless, Mr. Bush said that he viewed North Korea's admission "very seriously" and that he would work with the leaders of China, Japan, South Korea and Russia at an economic summit meeting of Pacific nations this weekend in Los Cabos, Mexico, to exert pressure on Mr. Kim.
The No. 2 official in North Korea made a public overture to the United States today, saying he was willing to negotiate over the country's nuclear weapons program "if the United States is willing to withdraw its hostile policy toward the North." American officials said they were uncertain how to respond to the overture by Kim Yong Nam, the country's nominal head of state. Mr. Kim made the offer during a meeting in Pyongyang, the North's capital, with a South Korean delegation.
For now, the administration remains embroiled in an internal debate over how and even if the United States should negotiate with North Korea. Hard-liners in the administration argue that the North should be required to dismantle its nuclear program before any talks can begin, but some State Department officials say negotiations will be necessary before the North can be induced to move. The administration is at the same time under growing pressure from Asian allies, which are urging that talks should begin.
A 1994 arms control accord between the United States, its allies and North Korea that might have served as a framework for talks is for all practical purposes dead, and has been ever since the North Koreans admitted to the United States early this month that they were conducting a secret nuclear program. At the same time, North Korea said it had "nullified" the 1994 accord, which provided Western energy aid in exchange for the North's promise to freeze the development of nuclear weapons. Today, senior administration officials said that because the North Koreans had walked away from the accord, the United States had no intention of honoring it.
Similarly, the European Union, which is helping finance the construction of two nuclear reactors in North Korea to generate electricity, promised under the accord, said today that it would almost certainly terminate support of the program.
"It is difficult in present circumstances to see how we can continue with our contributions unless the North Koreans make clear pretty rapidly that they are going to stop their attempts to develop nuclear weapons," Christopher Patten, the European Union's commissioner for external relations, said after a meeting with European foreign ministers.
In Moscow today, John R. Bolton, the under secretary of state for arms control, turned over a dossier of American intelligence on the North's clandestine project. Some American officials have suggested that Russian companies have been among the North's suppliers, though they indicated that the Russians provided less crucial technology than did Pakistan. 
After the meeting, the deputy Russian foreign minister, Georgi Mamedov, appeared to put the blame for the showdown with North Korea, at least in part, on the administration's new doctrine of military pre-emption and its inclusion of North Korea as part of an "axis of evil."
"We think that such statements may aggravate the situation and don't facilitate constructive solution of the nonproliferation issues," Mr. Mamedov said.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST 

 BODY:
S.E.C. May File Complaint Against Martha Stewart
Martha Stewart, the domestic tastemaker caught up in an insider trading scandal, has been notified by the Securities and Exchange Commission that it has sufficient evidence to bring a civil complaint against her, a person involved in the investigation said.
 The formal notice, stemming from an inquiry into Ms. Stewart's sale of nearly 4,000 ImClone Systems shares last December, came on Sept. 12, the person said. Lawyers for Ms. Stewart filed a formal response earlier this month. Commission lawyers next will make a recommendation to the S.E.C. Page A1. 

Planned Cuts at UAL Mean Layoffs
UAL, the parent company of United Airlines, told employees in a phone message yesterday that it had pinpointed a total of $1.4 billion in annual operational cuts that it intends to carry out. In addition, the company said in a separate announcement that it planned to save $100 million a year from a streamlining that includes the loss of about 1,250 jobs. The planned cuts are intended to help bolster the company's application for a $1.8 billion federal loan guarantee. C6.

Continental Airlines will give mechanics with 30 years or more of service $40,000 to retire by 2004 under the terms of a tentative contract reached with the workers' union. C6.

Bush Plan on Generic Drugs Faulted
Consumer groups and lobbyists for the elderly welcomed a plan announced by President Bush to speed the approval of low-cost generic versions of prescription drugs, but they said it came too late and did not go far enough. A24.

Recent Rally Continues on Wall St.
Stocks rose, driving benchmark indexes to their highest levels in more than five weeks. The Dow Jones industrial average added 215.84 points, or 2.6 percent, to 8,538.24. The S.& P. 500 gained 15.33 points, or 1.7 percent, to 899.72. The Nasdaq composite index rose 21.81 points, or 1.7 percent, to 1,309.67. C14.

The index of leading economic indicators fell in September for a fourth month. C14.

E.ON to Buy TXU Europe Retail Unit
TXU agreed to sell its British retail business and power generation plants to E.ON of Germany for $:1.37 billion, or about $2.1 billion, as it struggles to protect its investment grade credit rating. World Business, Section W.

The Canadian Imperial Bank of Commerce said that it would "substantially reduce or close" its money-losing venture with supermarket chains in the United States. C2.

Kmart Losses Narrowed Last Month
Kmart lost $176 million last month as sales continued to decline, but the rate of that decline slowed considerably as the company unveiled new products and tried fresh strategies in some stores. "While we have a way to go before we can truly celebrate, there is a lot of good news inherent in this result," the president and chief operating officer, Julian C. Day, above, said. C2.

Coach will report today that sales are up 28 percent and that per-share earnings are up 79 percent, exceeding expectations. C11.

Swiss Life to Restate Results Again
For the second time in less than a month, Swiss Life, Switzerland's biggest life insurer, said that it had to restate its results by hundreds of millions of dollars to correct an accounting error. World Business, Section W.

Japan's Companies Get a Break
Moody's Investors Service raised Japan's foreign currency debt ceiling, making it easier and cheaper for big Japanese companies like Toyota to borrow dollars and other foreign currencies. World Business, Section W.

Travelers Should Fear Street Crime
The State Department's list of international travel warnings is lengthy at a time when there are deep discounts now available on many overseas fares. Still, travel security experts say, street crime, not terrorism, is by far the main threat to business travelers abroad. Joe Sharkey: On the Road. C10.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: NEW YORK SENATOR; 
For Hillary Clinton, A Dual Role as Star And as Subordinate

BYLINE:  By ADAM NAGOURNEY and RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: BETHESDA, Md., Oct. 21 

 BODY:
By all appearances, the rally and fund-raiser in the overcrowded hotel ballroom here the other night was for Kathleen Kennedy Townsend, the Democratic candidate for governor. Yet Mrs. Townsend was not to be the star of her evening.
 That became clear when Hillary Rodham Clinton took the stage to an eruption of cheers and a shout from the crowd, "President Hillary Clinton!" And when Mrs. Clinton finished her speech -- a brass-knuckled appeal to vote Democratic this fall -- and stepped back to allow Mrs. Townsend her turn, people started drifting out of the hall. 
 But in the United States Senate these days, Mrs. Clinton has become known as anything but the star of the show. She is the celebrity senator who is forever offering to bring a colleague a cup of coffee, or volunteering to sit in as presiding officer in the deserted chamber on a Friday night, or stepping back at news conferences to let other senators speak. 
Two years after Mrs. Clinton left the White House, the former first lady has presented what would seem to be two very different personalities in the new orbits of her life, but in a clear pursuit of a single goal: To finally establish herself as her own power in Democratic politics and American government, at a time when there is renewed evidence that she remains a polarizing force in much of the nation today.
As Mrs. Townsend saw here, the senator from New York has emerged this fall as her party's single best fund-raising draw, a source of advice to candidates, a partisan cheerleader in what Democrats see as an increasingly tough election, and the only Democrat, other than perhaps her husband, who can pack a room.
Mrs. Clinton has campaigned, or held fund-raisers, on behalf of more than 30 Democratic candidates for the House and Senate who are in close races, as well as for three Washington-based Democratic campaign committees. She has donated $1 million from her own political action committee, out of the $2.5 million she has raised, to candidates of her choice across the nation.
In Washington, "Whitehaven," the five-bedroom Clinton home on Whitehaven Street near Embassy Row, has in these post-White House years become a conveyor belt of fund-raising dinners and receptions that Democratic candidates are clamoring to climb aboard. Some of the party's largest donors pay as much as $25,000 to eat dinner with Mrs. Clinton and occasionally Bill Clinton, in a tent set up in the sprawling gardens behind the house, or in the more intimate dining room inside. 
"She has done more to raise money for Democratic candidates than almost anyone else," said James M. Jordan of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
Beyond that, at a time when the party is struggling to recover from its dispiriting defeat in the 2000 presidential election, and worried that what once seemed like a strong chance for a Democratic sweep in November may now be slipping away, Mrs. Clinton has positioned herself as a sometimes ferocious Democratic partisan, warning at every opportunity of the perils of a Republican sweep this fall. 
"The stakes are so high in this election -- I just have to impress upon you how critical this is," Mrs. Clinton said. "If we were to lose the Senate, there would be nothing standing between the Republican leadership and confirming the most extremist judges, in rolling back environmental regulations. And certainly, you might as well say goodbye to fiscal responsibility."
Yet if Mrs. Clinton is cheered in friendly places like Maryland, and has won over some members of the Senate, she remains in much of the country a highly polarizing and disliked figure: a symbol of liberal excess and Clinton misdeeds in the White House. Republicans continue to use her, to great success, to goad contributions from their mailing lists, and her name appears often in Republican television advertisements across the country.
Most recently, the National Republican Senatorial Committee is running two television advertisements -- one in Montana and one in Louisiana, at a cost of about $300,000 -- trying to tie the voting records of the Democratic incumbents in those states to hers. 
When Mrs. Clinton sought to help Jean Carnahan, a senator facing a tough re-election battle in Missouri, the Carnahan campaign chose an unusual venue to do it: a closed fund-raiser in Los Angeles. Mrs. Clinton has been pointedly absent on the campaign trail there and in much of the country.
And while Mrs. Clinton's name has been increasingly mentioned as a potential candidate for president in 2008, some of her closest supporters said that as of now, that remained unlikely. "Her image among average Americans is not likely to change anytime soon -- and it's a disproportionately negative image," one senior Democratic strategist said.
Still, Democrats were quick to note Mrs. Clinton's success at changing perceptions of her both in New York during the 2000 campaign and in the Senate today. And when it was suggested that she remains highly unpopular in large parts of the country, Mrs. Clinton smiled brightly and responded: "That's because they don't know me."
Mrs. Clinton's evolution both as a member of the Senate and as a power in her own right in the Democratic Party captures what friends describe as a complicated transformation she has undergone in the two years since she has left the White House. First in the Senate and now on the campaign trail, Mrs. Clinton has moved to establish her own personality and political orbit.
"It's a quantum leap," said one longtime friend, who asked not to be identified. "You see somebody who -- really for the first time probably since she was in law school, or married to Bill Clinton -- is basically able to reach for her limits. For the first time, she has been able to blossom in a way she was never able to do as a wife of a governor, wife of a president." 
By day, Mrs. Clinton has embarked on a meticulous effort to win acceptance in the Senate. She has treated more senior members of the Senate with deference, and regularly declines interviews that might accentuate her celebrity. And she has avoided the heated, partisan language that she uses in her campaign appeals.
Mrs. Clinton has sought to master the rules and traditions of the Senate in a way that one friend likened to the methodical approach Lyndon B. Johnson took as a Senate newcomer, ingratiating himself with the more senior Southern Democrats who ruled the body. (Johnson succeeded in becoming majority leader in his first term).
"The thing that has impressed me is sitting down at our Tuesday caucus meeting and watching her get up to get coffee and ask the other senators whether she could bring them back some coffee," said Senator John B. Breaux, Democrat of Louisiana. "She aggressively avoids the spotlight and intentionally holds back, while most of us try to do the opposite."
"She is a very congenial colleague," said Senator Arlen Specter, a Republican from Pennsylvania, sounding surprised at his own words.
Mrs. Clinton has approached other senators on the floor and asked to be co-sponsor of legislation that interested her, rather than trying to claim it on her own. She has identified herself with some national issues, like extending unemployment benefits, but also on issues of New York concern, including working with her senior colleague, Senator Charles E. Schumer of New York, to win federal assistance to rebuild downtown New York and help out the ailing economy upstate.
"There was a lot of feeling at the beginning of the term that she was going to Hollywood: klieg lights, high visibility," said Senator Bob Graham, Democrat of Florida. "In fact, she has been very hard-working, diligent and well-prepared."
By night, at Whitehaven, Mrs. Clinton has created what party officials describe as one of the most effective, and sought-after, fund-raising venues of the season. She has twice held back-to-back fund-raisers on the same night.
"It's like an event at the White House," said one senior Democratic Party official. "There is a big difference between going to a fund-raiser at Hillary Clinton's house and going to one at Ted Kennedy's house.'
Mrs. Clinton has also been a mentor for more junior Democrats. Christopher Van Hollen, a Democratic candidate for Congress in Maryland, said Mrs. Clinton pulled him aside when she was campaigning for him to suggest how he should unseat Representative Constance A. Morella. He should, she said, remind voters that a vote for Mrs. Morella was a vote for a Republican Congressional leadership, no matter how moderate Mrs. Morella might be.
Mrs. Clinton has to tread cautiously as she builds her own profile, mindful that critics have long warned that her goal in running for Senate is to obtain a platform to return to the White House. The favors she is collecting now would certainly benefit her if she does.
Mrs. Clinton pledged during her campaign that she would serve out her term, which would rule out 2004, though she has left open the possibility of running in 2008. "I'm not planning anything other than to be the best senator I can," she said.
Still, if Mrs. Clinton has changed over these last two years, she remains a cautious figure, at least in public. Her attacks on Republicans at private fund-raisers -- the ones where there are no cameras present -- are described by attendees as much more brutal and alarmist than her public statements.
In an interview at her office, Mrs. Clinton was critical of President Bush's economic policy but offered no criticism of his approach to Iraq, declining even to say if she, like many Democrats, was suspicious of the timing of the Iraq initiative.
Asked, for example, to discuss her view of the Democratic field for 2004, she responded: "Come talk to me when that election is as imminent as this election. I mean, I am so focused on the next three weeks."

HEADLINE: The Foreign Policy of S.U.V.'s 

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Thomas L. Friedman ("Drilling for Freedom," column, Oct. 20) convincingly explains that Middle East tyrannies will end when their oil revenues decline. The United States can help this happen by consuming less fuel. 
 The only way the United States can reduce fuel use is to increase the fuel tax. Adding a nickel per gallon every month until the United States buys its last barrel of imported oil would cause no more than minor disruption of the economy. Yet fuel use would decline almost immediately. 
 Our political process refuses to discuss a tax increase, the only measure that can work. We are like a 300-pound patient asking a doctor how to lose weight but insisting that the answer must not mention eating or exercise.

LEONARD EVANS
Bloomfield Hills, Mich., Oct. 20, 2002

HEADLINE: In Campaign, Subject of Race Is Banished To Background 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
In the campaign of H. Carl McCall, the first black candidate from a major party to run for governor in New York, there is no surer way to kill a conversation than to bring up the subject of race.
 Asked about it recently, Representative Charles B. Rangel, the dean of the New York Congressional delegation and an architect of Mr. McCall's campaign, said, "I'm not allowed to talk about race in this race." 
 Mr. McCall himself has consistently played down the subject. At a dinner two weeks ago for black journalists, he was asked if his race had limited his fund-raising. "Race is a factor in everything," he replied, moving swiftly to the next question. 
The moment summed up how subtle a role race has played in the campaign for governor. Although it cannot be discounted as an influence on voters, it is not something that either side has emphasized.
While the de-emphasis has so far spared Mr. McCall the divisive politics that marked Fernando Ferrer's run for mayor last year, some analysts say it has also cost him some crucial attention, national momentum and financial support.
"There's not this sense that there's this historic opportunity here," said Richard Schrader, a Democratic consultant. "To his credit, McCall has successfully crossed over. In order to get that, he's had to in a lot of ways -- very subtle ways -- deracialize these campaigns."
Mr. McCall, whose strategy has been honed by his two successful statewide runs for comptroller, said recently that there was a simple reason why he did not discuss his race more often: "It's so obvious. I mean, why do I have to talk about it?"
Gov. George E. Pataki, his Republican opponent, has also steered clear of the issue. Aides to Mr. McCall said they could cite no examples of even the back-channel racism sometimes employed in campaigns.
Some supporters say that this could actually cost Mr. McCall votes he needs to overcome Governor Pataki's inroads into the Democratic base. Though polls show that Mr. McCall will get most of the black vote, it usually goes to the Democratic candidate anyway. The issue is whether black voters will come out in greater numbers than they normally do.
"The question is, where's the energy in the black community for Carl McCall?" said Hank Scheinkopf, a longtime consultant who has worked on the McCall campaign.
Some Harlem residents said that Mr. McCall has not effectively reached out for their support, adding that they had seen Hillary Rodham Clinton more often when she was running for United States senator than they had seen Mr. McCall.
Sikhulu Shange, the owner of the 125th Street Record Shack, said yesterday that no one had offered him a McCall sign for his window, even though a news article on Sunday quoted him as saying he would be happy to have one. "I'm in the heartbeat of Harlem and I haven't seen no signs out here," Mr. Shange said.
Some contrast the seeming lack of street-level momentum with the Pataki campaign, which announced a development plan in Harlem yesterday. The governor has also made a point of learning Spanish and of reaching out to Latino voters. Yesterday, his daughter Emily opened an Amigos de Pataki office in Washington Heights.
Political scientists cite many reasons for the quiet submersion of race. Among them is the notion that black voters increasingly accept the fact that black candidates like Mr. McCall must win support from white liberals and moderates.
"There's also a generational change going on in the black community, where symbolism matters less than actual performance," Mr. Scheinkopf said. "There's a new maturity."
Andrew M. Cuomo, who dropped out of the primary against Mr. McCall, felt that race was still enough of a factor to have prevented him from attacking Mr. McCall for fear of being perceived as racist.
And no Democrat, least of all Mr. Rangel, who persuaded Mr. Cuomo to drop out, wanted race to erupt as it did last year, when the supporters of Mr. Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, said that supporters of Mark Green, his opponent in the mayoral run-off, had used coded language to scare white voters. A cartoon suggested that Mr. Ferrer was beholden to the Rev. Al Sharpton.
This year, many analysts say, Mr. McCall has kept Mr. Sharpton at arm's length.
Not true, according to Mr. Sharpton. "I've done more with Carl McCall than I did with Freddy Ferrer," he said. The difference is, he said, that no one has made it an issue.
"Some people learned last year that where they thought they could incite a white backlash vote, they instead incited a black and Latino backlash vote against playing what appeared to us to be the race card," he said. "You've not seen Pataki trying to play that card."
In fact, Governor Pataki is the only person in this race who has been attacked for his association with Mr. Sharpton. Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, mailed out literature pointing out that both had gone to Vieques, Puerto Rico, to condemn the Navy bombing there.
Mr. Pataki has so scrupulously avoided charges of racism that in a recent attack ad, an official state photo of Mr. McCall was used instead of one that might have been perceived as deliberately unflattering.
"Pataki has chosen to try to define Carl as a white liberal," said Mr. Schrader, the consultant. "Because he's beaten two white liberals, Mario Cuomo and Peter Vallone."
Still, Mr. Pataki offered one of the few overt comments about race, one that was perceived variously as a magnanimous gesture or a cynical attempt to draw attention to the fact that Mr. McCall is not white.
"I'm proud as well that the Democratic Party has made a historic move in nominating the first African-American to be the governor of this state," Mr. Pataki said at a union rally a few weeks ago. "We should all be proud of that."
Mr. McCall is very different from minority candidates of the past. He does not speak of the "gorgeous mosaic" of diversity central to the campaign of David N. Dinkins, the first black mayor of New York City. Nor does he mention, as Mr. Ferrer did, "the other New York."
Yet if Mr. McCall has not played the race card, he sometimes acts as if he has it tucked up his sleeve.
Mr. Dinkins describes how Mr. McCall addresses black audiences. On occasion Mr. McCall says, " 'You have a chance to make history,' " Mr. Dinkins said. "He says: 'You can elect the first governor who's a minister. You can elect the first governor who's been the president of the Board of Education.' The audience kind of chuckles. He doesn't say, 'You can elect the first black governor.' "
At a Congressional Black Caucus dinner, Mr. McCall attracted only a smattering of applause when Al Gore mentioned him onstage. And national money has been slow to pour in.
"It's been assumed, and the polls have supported it, that he's probably not going to win," said David A. Bositis, a senior political analyst at the Joint Center for Politics and Economic Studies in Washington and an expert on black political candidates. "And that really has, if anything, deflated the enthusiasm about the historical nature of it."

HEADLINE: NEW LOOKS; 
Bumper-to-Bumper Details of the Crossover Era

BYLINE:  By PHIL PATTON; Phil Patton is the author of, most recently, "Bug: The Strange Mutations of the World's Most Popular Automobile."

 BODY:
AMERICANS want more space in their vehicles without adding length. They also want a single vehicle to play the role of many. Those conflicting demands make these the toughest times for car designers since the late 1970's, when fuel crises forced sudden downsizing. Designers now speak of "crossovers" -- vehicles that are part truck and part car, part sport utility vehicle and part sports car. 
 This century, in fact, began with one failed crossover experiment, the Pontiac Aztek, which is already legendary for its ugliness, and another that succeeded beyond expectations: the Chrysler PT Cruiser. Both offered many of the same elements -- generous, versatile interior space wrapped in forms suggesting sports-car handling. 
 Crossbreeding of types has led to crossbreeding of styles. There's the Ford Sport Trac model of the Explorer, for instance, which is an S.U.V. with a pickup bed. Chrysler is readying the Pacifica, due out next year, and Mercedes-Benz the Grand Sports Tourer in 2005; both are minivans with S.U.V. height. 
More experiments lie ahead, marriages of traditional shapes that have never bonded before. "Is it going to be Princess Bride," asked Daniel A. Gorrell of Strategic Vision, a San Diego company that tracks customer attitudes toward automobiles, "or the Bride of Frankenstein?" 
In the 40's, cars had distinctive rounded, Moderne lines. In the 50's, it was tail fins. In the 80's, it was the aero, or "bar of soap" look. Pinning down what is distinctive in today's crossover era is trickier, but here are some stylistic influences. 

The Hatch Is Back
The rear hatch door, long detested as a relic of the downsized econobox, has come back. And why not? A rear door that opens upward makes sense, offering easy entry to small cars and, when the rear seats are folded, storage for large objects. Hatchbacks appear in models of the Suzuki Aerio, Mazda MP3 and Protege and the Honda Civic Si. Ford's Focus, especially in its Special Vehicle Team version, combines the hatch with racy rear taillights to make an economy car look sporty. The hatch also shows up in the Pontiac Vibe (above) and the Toyota Matrix, siblings that many consider the most successful crossover designs so far because of their height, interior space and agile handling. Paradoxically, Saab, which for years kept producing hatchback styles when the rear door was in disfavor, has abandoned it in its latest 9-3 model.

Car-Truck or the Return of the El Camino?
We remain a nation of truck drivers. The best-selling vehicle in America is still the Ford F-Series pickup. But pickups have been turning into passenger vehicles for a while now. Most can hold four passengers, either in a small back seat or with four full doors in the "crew cab." A new generation of car-truck hybrids is making the distinction between car and truck hazier. Chevrolet, which produced the El Camino, an early version of a sport pickup, almost 50 years ago, has updated it with two models -- the SSR (for Super Sport Roadster), to be issued early next year, and the Avalanche (below), which offers a folding partition between passenger cab and bed. The old El Camino had many fans, but was never a star car. The Avalanche, Cadillac Escalade EXT pickup and Subaru Baja have already far surpassed it in popularity.

Big Wheels
The larger the wheels, the more macho a car's image. Which explains why the wheels of all but the smallest econocars have been gradually growing over the last decade. These days, manufacturers are offering even larger wheels as factory options and sales of huge, custom wheels have increased exponentially, especially for trucks and S.U.V.'s.
Tire and parts dealers sell an astounding variety of sizes and patterns, notably 19- and 20-inch models in bright chrome. Favored by celebrities, and most frequently seen on Cadillac Escalades, Lincoln Navigators and other large S.U.V.'s, they are the stylistic equivalent of the wide whitewall tires of a generation ago. Big wheels have their own style and slang. Twenty-three-inch models are known as "Jordans" -- after the basketball star's number -- and fetching faceted patterns suggesting Cuisinart blades are called "slice and dicers."

The Bentley Back
No styling feature of recent years caused more controversy than the raised trunk of the new BMW 7 Series, right, which appeared in the United States earlier this year. Condemned as a "hunchback," the high rear end suggested a last-minute compromise between the designer and the trunk-space committee. But combining rear-end aerodynamics with adequate storage has produced many higher backs in cars, some jarring and awkward. Designers are groping for a solution. High backs look stiff and stern, as on many small cars, or sliced off, as on Volvo sedans. But history offers solutions. BMW's rear bears an accidental resemblance to the Bentley of an earlier age. The back end of the Hyundai XG350, the South Korean maker's top model, bears an intentional resemblance to the Bentley -- an economy car's claim to elegance. 

Matte-Metal Interiors
Apparently weary of gray plastic and black knobs, many drivers have signaled a thumbs up to Audi and Volkswagen, whose simple black and brushed-aluminum interiors are part Bauhaus, part Krups coffee maker. The Germans have set a standard for simplicity and elegance at comparatively low cost, which many American and Japanese interior designers are trying to match. The new Lincoln Navigator, for instance, plays down traditional chrome and wood in favor of matte-surfaced metallic parts it calls "nickel," giving a higher-tech, richer look (above). Actually an advanced, rugged plastic with a metallic surface, the material echoes the look that is currently popular in small electronic devices, like cellphones and MP3 players. The 1990's brought more chrome, inside and out. Now, in a less upbeat time, the metal is literally less flashy. 

Hot Color: Sport Yellow
Soft, pale yellows vanished from the auto palette a decade ago, but a yellow as bright as a beach ball has long been reserved as a signal of sportiness. On a Mustang or a New Beetle, it was a rare, eye-catching, self-advertising color for people with outgoing personalities. Manufacturers are currently moving it to the center of their plans. Hummer's ads for the new H2 model (below), a smaller but still hefty version of the S.U.V. made famous by Arnold Schwarzenegger, show only the sport-yellow models. The Suzuki Aerio, Mazda MP3 and Protege and Mitsubishi Lancer (below, bottom) balance their low prices by pushing yellow models that suggest raceworthy performance, and Chevrolet will be using the color to emphasize the sportiness of its new hybrid SSR pickup (in the middle, below). 
Next to return: the bold oranges of the 70's.

The Honeycomb Grille
 Grilles offer subtle, even subliminal signals about the vehicles they front. Jaguars, notably the new S-Type R model, and Bentleys evoke nobility with grilles that recall a knight's chain mail. Rolled metal, perforated grilles on Mercedes's M Class S.U.V. or the Mercedes SLK sports car, radiate vigor. Ford and Nissan trucks and the Toyota Matrix (above) offer grilles in a pattern of joined hexagons, like honeycombs, suggesting the industry of the honeybee, and perhaps its efficiency. 

Complex Headlights
Designers think of headlights as the eyes of a car. In Chryslers, Mercedeses and Chevrolets, complex arrangements of tubular mirrors and lenses give several new models a staring expression. Using high-intensity discharge lamps with a bluish glow that first showed up in BMW and other European makes (as well as other advanced lighting systems), these headlights suggest that the car is packed with sensational gadgetry. 
Such headlights appear behind faceted front glass in Cadillac's CTS sedan, introduced last year, and its new XLR roadster. The Range Rover uses a pattern of overlapping circular lights (left) to contrast with its boxy lines. The Nissan Altima offers a set of crystalline tubes that make it look aggressive. 

Riding High
Because of S.U.V.'s, drivers have become used to sitting higher up and seeing farther down the road. That broader vantage point is particularly popular with women, said Susan Jacobs, president of Jacobs & Associates, an automotive consulting firm in Rutherford, N.J. Now, the height of the driver's seat -- the "H point" or "hip point," as designers call it -- is moving up. Higher "command position" seating was critical to the shape of the Pontiac Vibe crossover (below), with its sibling Toyota Matrix, said John Mack, who designed the Vibe.
The Ford Motor Company's chief designer, J Mays, has made the high H point a crucial element of Ford's 500 family sedan, due out in 2004. 

The Rubber Boot Look
Dark, thick-looking cladding, like rubber bumpers, has become a universal signal of toughness in cars, emulating the protective rims on outdoor shoes. 
As the station wagon and S.U.V. blend together in such vehicles as the Audi Allroad, the Volvo Cross Country and Volvo XC90 (left), more wagons are wearing these lower body guards, apparently ready to defeat rock and mud. Because these sport wagons are several inches higher than their less-rugged cousins, it seems as if they have rolled up their trouser legs for wading, and the dark cladding enhances the effect, as if they have put on L. L. Bean boots. Although the cladding resembles rubber, it is usually made up of thermoplastic olefin and other materials more symbolic than functional. And it is far from impervious to nicks and scrapes. 

Jeweled Taillights
 In 1997, Jaguar's S-Type introduced a stunning taillight composed of intersecting ovals of orange and red that rendered in miniature the flowing, ovoid shapes of the car's body. Now, the cost of such lenses has dropped, thanks to computer aided design, and far humbler models, like Toyota's new Corolla, above, or Daewoo's Lanos, offer them. Such lights, said Gerhard Steinle, the president of Prisma Design International, a design studio in Tustin, Calif., are "the jewelry of automobiles" -- costume jewelry, that is, making inexpensive cars look richer.

GRAPHIC: Photos (Toyota); (Tony Cenicola/The New York Times); (Volvo); (Ford Motor Company); (BMW); (Mitsubishi); (General Motors Corporation)

HEADLINE: THE ENVIRONMENT; 
Ford Gives River Rouge a Green Coat

BYLINE:  By KEITH SCHNEIDER 

DATELINE: DEARBORN, Mich. 

 BODY:
SINCE 1918 around Detroit, the words "River Rouge" and "Ford" have been associated with simple, traditional things: steel, coal, cars, trucks, smoke, soot and jobs. Now it means sedum, too. 
 At a time when nearly all of the auto industry's attention has been focused on the tumbling stock price and multibillion-dollar losses at the Ford Motor Company, the company's chief executive, William Clay Ford Jr., has created a buzz by installing sedum, a rugged plant that is used as ground cover, in an unlikely place -- on the roof of a new 1.1-million-square-foot assembly plant in the River Rouge complex here. 
 On Oct. 4, the first thin sheets of sedum, which absorb heat and water, were put in place. In the next months more than 10 acres -- 454,000 square feet -- of sedum will be rolled out, watered and encouraged to thrive on the world's largest "living" roof. The roof -- a centerpiece of an innovative and potentially risky $2 billion redevelopment project that will take 20 years to complete -- will cool the factory inside during the summer and keep things toasty in winter, reducing the amount of energy needed to maintain working temperature in the building. The roof will also cleanse rainwater flowing off the building. 
The roof is also drawing attention because of what it represents. The sedum feeds into a yearlong debate over which Mr. Ford is operating his family's company: is he the self-proclaimed environmentalist who has raised hopes among advocacy groups, or is he the cost-cutting truck lover whose new slogan is "No Boundaries"?
In 1999, when Mr. Ford announced his vision to "transform a 20th-century industrial icon into a model of 21st-century sustainable manufacturing," few people beyond the company's front office knew what to make of it.
But as the River Rouge modernization project (which includes a new assembly factory and updates on some existing buildings) evolves from ambitious concept to actual construction, the plant's 7,000 workers and millions of Detroit-area residents are beginning to recognize a significance that extends beyond the plant's walls. The entrance to the complex is being transformed into a 1.5-mile-long green boulevard with 22 acres of wetlands, trees and shrubs. Some 1,500 trees and other plantings are starting to surround the new assembly plant. To control rainwater and pollutants, the plant's 15-acre parking lot is covered with a porous surface through which water is filtered, cleansed and stored in underground basins to be slowly released into the canals and wetlands. 
All across the Rouge complex shallow drainage canals and multiple artificial wetlands are being built and seeded with indigenous plants. The exterior greenery, wetlands and canals are designed to use nature's ability to soak up and cleanse rainwater that drains into the nearby Rouge River. This "green" approach is designed to save Ford $35 million, when compared with the cost of installing a conventional water-treatment system. The plant's walls will be covered with ivy to produce oxygen and help cool the building.
Inside the new assembly plant, Ford is preparing to install equipment capable of producing up to nine different vehicle models. This "flexible" factory is designed to save money and drastically reduce waste by making it much easier to retool to manufacture different models. Ford says the plant will use space more efficiently because parts will be installed soon after they arrive and 90 percent of vehicles will be shipped the day they are completed. 
"People are going to be astounded at how well these systems work," said William McDonough, an architect in Charlottesville, Va., who was chosen by Mr. Ford to lead the design team. He says the immense scale of Ford's project could elevate green manufacturing principles from a useful niche to a mainstream industrial movement.
The living roof, for instance, costs roughly the same as a conventional roof but is expected to last twice as long because it will not expand during the day and shrink at night. (Like ivy, it will need minimal maintenance.) Its insulating capacity will help Ford reduce the amount of ventilation duct work by 40 percent. It will store four million gallons of rainwater, eliminating pollutants that would ordinarily pour off the roof and straight into the river. Skylights will provide the plant with so much natural light that Ford engineers anticipate turning off half of the interior lights during the day, saving nearly $50,000 annually. 
Environmental leaders say they admire what Ford is doing at the Rouge plant -- renamed the Ford Rouge Center -- but call for the same pollution-reducing principles to be applied across the company's policies and product line. Several environmentalists said, for instance, that Ford fought hard earlier this year to block Congress from enacting higher fuel economy standards.
"The environmental impact of cars comes in three stages -- manufacturing, use and disposal," said Lana Pollack, the president of the Michigan Environmental Council in Lansing. "Ford is making great strides in the first. We've yet to see any tangible progress in the second and third, and that's where it really counts."
INDUSTRY analysts say they are waiting for the plant to begin production before making a judgment. "Internally, Ford thinks this project will help them," said Bruce Belzowksi, a senior research associate at the University of Michigan's Office for the Study of Automotive Transportation in Ann Arbor. "But the industry and the analysts will judge this after it's been in action for a while."
There is little dispute, however, that Ford's aim to increase production of vehicles with new, energy-efficient technology, while substantially reducing air and water pollution, represents a realistic paradigm in American industry. It's a model that Mr. Ford is pushing in the very same place that his great-grandfather invented the concept of "vertical integration" and set the worldwide standard for manufacturing innovation that endured for more than 50 years. 
Ford's 1,100-acre River Rouge plant opened in 1918 and began to turn iron and other raw materials into completed cars. To the relief of most people in southeast Michigan, the factory remains open and among the largest employers in the Detroit region. That is not taken for granted in a city and a state numbed by companies that closed obsolete plants and sent tens of thousands of high-paying auto jobs to the South and overseas. "While most companies would rather move than invest in an 83-year-old site," Mr. Ford said two years ago, "we view this as an important reinvestment in our employees, our hometown."
Ford officials say that the River Rouge plans are a notable exception to the deep retrenchments that were caused by the company's money troubles. "When we started this, we were flush with money and it was easy to get going," said Donald Russell, the manufacturing sustainability manager who is overseeing the assembly plant's new roof. "The chairman is 100 percent behind us and we haven't left off anything that we wanted to do. The main components are all intact." 
Ford is not alone in the idea of improving Detroit's economic competitiveness by cleaning up and restoring the region's waterways, especially the Rouge River. Ford's plant, which sits on a bend just upstream from where the Rouge empties into the Detroit River, is essential to the project and the region's economic health, city officials say.
More than $535 million in federal, state and local grants have been invested in making the Rouge River, once one of the country's dirtiest, clean enough to swim in and beautiful enough to attract new residents, businesses and visitors. The work is slow and expensive, but after nearly a decade of planting trees, controlling rainwater, restoring wetlands and improving parks, the Rouge is clean enough to support a small sport fishery and its banks are much greener. Mr. Ford is the chairman of one of the committees that oversees the cleanup.
Still, even as Ford's new and cleaner factory attracts national attention, Mr. Ford acknowledges that his work is viewed skeptically in another arena critical to the company's success: Wall Street. Nevertheless, Mr. Ford says he is convinced that the green measures will have a tangible payoff. "It's still a tough sell," he said in an interview published on the company's Web site. "I do believe that I'm building a stronger Ford Motor Company for my children and my grandchildren."

GRAPHIC: Photos: ICON -- The River Rouge plant, built in 1918, has produced plenty of soot, smoke and cars. (Tom Pidgeon for The New York Times)
