HEADLINE: Under the Arab Street 

BYLINE:  By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

DATELINE: DOHA, Qatar 

 BODY:
At a seminar here this week on relations between America and Islam, one of the questions discussed by American and Muslim scholars was that elusive issue: Where is the Arab street and how might it respond to a U.S. invasion of Iraq? For my money, the most helpful answer was provided by the Jordanian columnist Rami Khouri, who said that "what's really important today is not the Arab street, but the Arab basement." 
 This is an important distinction. The "Arab street" is the broad mass of public opinion, which is largely passive and nonviolent. The "Arab basement" is where small groups of hard-core ideologues, such as Osama bin Laden and his gang, have retreated and where they are mixing fertilizer, C-4 plastic explosives and gasoline to make the bombs that have killed Westerners all over the world. 
 Over the years, Arab leaders have become adept at coping with the Arab street, which is why not a single one of them has ever been toppled by it. They know how to buy off, or seal off, its anger and how to deflect its attention onto Israel. They also know that the street's wrath can be defused by progress on the Arab-Israeli front or elections at home.
The Arab basement, though, is a new and much more dangerous phenomenon. These are small groups of super-empowered angry men who have slipped away from the street into underground cells, but with global reach and ambitions. While issues like Israeli and U.S. policy clearly motivate them, what most fuels their anger are domestic indignities -- the sense that their repressive societies are deeply failing, or being left behind by the world, and that with a big bang they can wake them up and win the respect of the world. 
"These guys started in their living rooms," said Mr. Khouri, "then they went out into the streets, got pushed back, and now they have retreated to the basements." Unlike the Arab street, no diplomacy can defuse the Arab basement. It doesn't want a smaller Israel, it wants no Israel; it doesn't want a reformed Saudi monarchy, it wants no Saudi monarchy.
So what to do? The only sensible response is to defeat those in the Arab basement, who are beyond politics and diplomacy, while at the same time working to alleviate the grievances, unemployment and sense of humiliation that is felt on the Arab street, so that fewer young people will leave the street for the basement, or sympathize with those down there -- as millions of Arabs do today.
There is no question that America can help by making a more energetic effort to defuse the Israeli-Palestinian conflict and by speaking out for the values that America has advocated everywhere in the world -- except in the Arab world: namely democracy. I met yesterday with 50 students from an elite Qatari high school and the new Cornell Medical College in Doha. They were so hungry to talk, to have their voices heard; and what you heard when you listened was how much they still looked up to America, but how much they thought America looked down on them. 
But the Arab states have a huge role to play too. You cannot seal the door between the Arab street and the Arab basement without addressing the reasons for Arabs' backwardness and humiliation cited in the U.N.'s Arab Human Development Report, which are their deficit of freedom, their deficit of women's empowerment and their deficit of modern education. 
"It takes many years of political, social, economic and human degradation to create a terrorist," notes Mr. Khouri. "So fighting terror can only succeed by rehumanizing degraded societies, by undoing, one by one, the many individual acts of repression, obstruction, denial, marginalization and autocracy that cumulatively turned wholesome developing societies into freak nations, and decent, God-fearing people into animals that kill with terror."
My guess is that the only way to stop the drift of young Arabs from the street to the basement is by administering some shock therapy to this whole region. Could replacing Saddam Hussein with a progressive Iraqi regime be such a positive shock? I don't know. I don't know if the Bush team really wants to do that, or if the American people want to pay for it. But I do know this: If America made clear that it was going into Iraq, not just to disarm Iraq but to empower Iraq's people to implement the Arab Human Development Report, well, the Arab basement still wouldn't be with us, but the Arab street just might.

HEADLINE: Climate Talks Will Shift Focus From Emissions 

BYLINE:  By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

 BODY:
The latest round of international talks on global warming begins today in New Delhi, with delegates focused more on ways to adapt to changes than on cutting emissions of gases that scientists say are the main cause of rising temperatures.
 The shift in focus is to some extent motivated by the Bush administration's rejection of the Kyoto Protocol, a 1997 climate pact completed last year and endorsed by most of the world's countries, rich and poor. 
 Without the United States, the world's largest producer of greenhouse gases, the Kyoto treaty is so weak, experts and government officials say, that it may have little effect. Others say the treaty has in any case been so watered down through years of negotiations that it is likely to be of limited benefit. 
Instead of looking mostly at ways to reduce the level of heat-trapping gases, then, the 10-day conference "will discuss how to build greater capacity, especially in developing countries, for minimizing vulnerabilities and preparing for worsening droughts, floods, storms, health emergencies, and other expected impacts," said a statement issued by the United Nations, which supervises the talks. 
The shift satisfies the Bush administration, which has fought to avoid mandatory cuts in admissions for fear it would harm the economy. "We're welcoming a focus on more of a balance on adaptation versus mitigation," said a senior American negotiator in New Delhi. "You don't have enough money to do everything." 
Many developing countries also embraced the change as an opportunity to press for more aid from rich nations. A central question in New Delhi, several delegates said in interviews, will be how much should the industrialized countries -- which generate most of the greenhouse gases released into the air -- pay to help poorer countries deal with the consequences. 
Some private environmental groups criticized the shift, saying that it was essential for countries to intensify efforts to blunt the human impact on climate even as they seek ways to deal with the consequences. 
Others said that even a weak treaty was better than none at all. "The protocol does not do much of anything for the atmosphere," said Eileen Claussen, the president of the Pew Center on Global Climate Change, a private group. "But you've got to get a framework in place before you can take more than relatively small steps." 
The treaty, if it enters into force early next year as most delegates expect, would technically require industrialized countries that are signatories to cut their emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases by 2012 to more than 5 percent below levels measured in 1990. 
But it includes a host of compromises that limit the need to cut releases from smokestacks and tailpipes. For example, it grants credits for growing forests, which absorb carbon dioxide. 
The Kyoto pact grants billions of tons of carbon-dioxide credits to Russia, where the economic implosion of the last decade resulted in emissions diving far below 1990 levels. 
Other countries can meet their treaty targets at least in part by purchasing some of Russia's surplus credits, which some environmental groups have taken to calling "hot air" credits. 
One of the biggest weaknesses, experts say, comes from the abandonment of the treaty last year by the United States, which produces about half of all the carbon dioxide released by industrialized countries and a fourth of the global total. 
President Bush this year called for voluntary American measures to slow, but not halt, growth in emissions, saying the strict timetables of the treaty would have harmed the economy. He also said that global warming needed to be attacked by all countries. The treaty required no action by big developing countries like China and India, whose emissions could soon surpass those of wealthy countries. 
Most scientists agree that the main cause of a 50-year global warming trend is a rise in atmospheric concentrations of greenhouse gases, mainly carbon dioxide released by burning coal, oil and other fossil fuels. 
The warming is projected to affect ecosystems, agriculture, and coastlines around the world, with most of the harm focused in poor countries that are least able to build defenses.

HEADLINE: Schools, Transportation, Air Quality Are Issues in Debate 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., Oct. 22 

 BODY:
In their third debate, Gov. John G. Rowland and his Democratic challenger, William E. Curry Jr., sparred tonight over many of the same issues raised in their first two meetings: education, transportation, the environment and the possibility of a third Indian casino in Connecticut.
 But unlike the first two debates, this one took place in Stamford, in the heart of affluent and vote-rich Fairfield County, where issues like urban sprawl and increasing traffic congestion are election priorities. 
 Accordingly, if there was a difference tonight in the two candidates' increasingly familiar refrains from the two past debates -- Mr. Rowland's steady recitation of his achievements in eight years, and Mr. Curry's itemized indictments of the ways in which he says the governor has failed to improve life for middle- and low-income people -- it was in Mr. Curry's eagerness to compare his thoughts on open space and commuter trains with Mr. Rowland's two-term track record. 
Mr. Curry painted the Rowland administration as a group of road builders uninterested in innovative public-transportation solutions to relieve the congestion that clogs Interstate 95 many hours a day. 
Mr. Rowland countered with statistics on how many buses and commuter-train cars have been added to solve congestion. 
Mr. Curry also hammered Mr. Rowland for supporting a plan to build towering high-capacity electricity lines through Fairfield County instead of investing in renewable energy sources. He also accused Mr. Rowland of not doing more to improve Connecticut's air quality, which is among the nation's worst.
"The governor could have been a hero to every school kid who carries around an inhaler," Mr. Curry said. "Instead, he caved in to the energy companies."
Mr. Rowland stuck to his main points: 150,000 new jobs in the last 10 years; 30,000 acres of recently bought open space in Fairfield County; public schools whose students that score among the highest in the country; experienced leadership in tough economic times. 
Political experts say Mr. Curry has refined his message and curtailed his habit of giving meandering answers since the first debate with Mr. Rowland on Oct. 7, moves that may translate into more votes on Election Day. 
But, they added, with only two weeks left to campaign and only one-quarter of the money that the Rowland campaign has raised, Mr. Curry has reached the moment of truth. If he is to win, experts say, he must do something immediately to catapult himself ahead or damage the governor. 
Mr. Curry remains publicly optimistic. On Monday, he highlighted the silver lining in a just-released University of Connecticut poll that showed Mr. Rowland leading by 15 percentage points among likely voters. Two weeks ago, Mr. Curry noted, he had trailed by 18 points, evidence, he said, that his message was beginning to sink in. The poll, of 608 likely voters, has a margin of error of 3.9 percentage points. 
But the UConn survey held other clues suggesting that a full-fledged Curry comeback may not be imminent. Those surveyed indicated that improving public education is their top concern in choosing the next governor, and that Mr. Rowland would do that better than Mr. Curry, by 43 percent to 31 percent.
Balancing the $12.3 billion state budget, which now faces a $400 million deficit, was the second-greatest concern of those surveyed. On that issue, respondents favored the governor over Mr. Curry by 46 percent to 30 percent. 
But perhaps most worrisome for Mr. Curry is his relative lack of support from fellow Democrats. While 85 percent of Republicans support Mr. Rowland, Mr. Curry carries only 57 percent of Democrats, the poll found.
Most Connecticut voters are independent; among them, the poll found Mr. Rowland leading Mr. Curry by 42 percent to 31 percent. 
The two candidates are scheduled to debate once more, next Monday.

HEADLINE: Japanese Plan To Overhaul Banks Hits A Stone Wall 

BYLINE:  By JAMES BROOKE and KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Heizo Takenaka, Japan's new economy czar, was forced late today to postpone his plan for sweeping changes in bank regulation to deal with the country's $420 billion mountain of bad bank loans, just before he was scheduled to lay it out in detail to reporters. 
 The development, which took most people in Tokyo by surprise, appeared to have been engineered behind the scenes by a conservative alliance of bankers, bureaucrats and ruling-party legislators, who bitterly oppose Mr. Takenaka's plans to force the banks to recognize and write off bad loans much faster than they are now willing to do. 
 The bad-loan plan, developed by an 11-member task force of experts named by Mr. Takenaka when his responsibilities were expanded to include financial regulation early this month, would tighten the rules governing how banks count their capital and take away much of their discretion on which loans to classify as nonperforming. 
Analysts say those changes would result in banks having to book losses so large that several of Japan's -- and the world's -- biggest institutions would be rendered insolvent. The plan would oblige those banks to accept public funds to shore up their balance sheets, and in doing so give the government the power to dismiss their managements, or in some cases to nationalize the banks completely.
Though called a postponement, today's action raised serious questions about whether Mr. Takenaka's plan would be allowed to proceed at all, or whether it would be delayed and watered down to the point of impotence, the fate of many past efforts to deal with the banking crisis.
Apparently unaware of the brewing rebellion against Mr. Takenaka's plans, a Bush administration official lavished praise on the minister by name in a press club luncheon speech today, and the minister's staff was still working through the afternoon to prepare for the minister's scheduled briefings with reporters in the evening.
But the cracks had already begun to open beneath Mr. Takenaka's feet. Mikio Aoki, an influential member of the upper house of Parliament, openly criticized Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi today, saying that "what he lacks most is leadership vis-a-vis the economy," a remark that analysts later interpreted as a declaration of political war against Mr. Takenaka's plan. Speaking to reporters, another ruling-party member of Parliament, Hideyuki Aizawa, said of Mr. Takenaka, "The party's worried about him pursuing his own radical way."
Conservatives were rattled earlier this month when Mr. Takenaka broke with 12 years of cautious government policy and told reporters that he thought no bank or borrower was too big to be allowed to fail. 
Though Japan's seven largest banking groups lost a combined $32.8 billion last fiscal year, they all exceed minimum capital requirements as they are now defined. But analysts say that most of them would be in danger of failing to meet the requirements under Mr. Takenaka's plan. Most bank stocks fell today, as did the Japanese stock market generally.
Masashi Teranishi, president of UFJ Bank and chairman of the Japanese Bankers' Association, spoke out forcefully today against aspects of the plan, telling reporters at a news conference: "It's like being told we can suddenly use our hands and play American football, when all along we've been ordered to play soccer. If the longstanding regulations were to change rapidly, it would cause confusion in the markets and among investors."
His reference to America was pointed: Mr. Takenaka taught economics at Harvard University before joining the government, and his proposals are widely seen -- and resented -- as an attempt to impose on Japan an American approach to bank regulation.
John B. Taylor, United States under secretary of the Treasury, told reporters in his luncheon speech today: "Minister Takenaka, I understand, has established some principles for dealing with nonperforming loans. I agree very much with these principles. They make sense, and we're supportive of those."
At midafternoon, one of the 11 members of Mr. Takenaka's task force on the bad-loan crisis was in a downtown hotel, sipping hot cocoa to combat Tokyo's autumn chill and summarizing the main points of the plan that was to be announced in a few hours.
"The task force has a very big sense of urgency," he said. The state of some of Japan's major banks is so bad, he said, that nationalizations "are very possible."
Pressed for details, he answered serenely that Mr. Takenaka would be furnishing them in handouts to reporters at briefings in a few hours.
But that never happened. Instead, Mr. Takenaka was summoned to a meeting late in the afternoon with the eight top executive members of the ruling party. Mr. Aizawa, who leads an economics panel for the party, said that the leaders "are worried that the tax force's plan would cause the bankruptcy of many banks and their corporate borrowers."
Emerging from the meeting, Mr. Takenaka said that he had "consulted with many people on their opinions" and decided to delay announcing the bank cleanup plan. The Japanese news media reacted with excited reports of Mr. Takenaka's humiliation at the hands of the conservatives, and one television reporter even described the day's events as a "coup d'etat." 
Analysts were more measured. "This is good news for the bad banks, good news for the bad companies, and bad news for the economy," said Brian Waterhouse, senior Japan bank analyst at HSBC Securities. "It is very disappointing that the very person who we hoped was actually going to get something done has been stymied at the first hurdle."
With Mr. Takenaka, Mr. Koizumi's chosen point man on bank reform, unable to overcome the opposition of the conservatives on his own, analysts said the situation had become a crucial test of Mr. Koizumi's leadership in the run-up to voting to fill seven vacant parliamentary seats on Sunday. 
"It's going to be a serious issue if the ruling party continues to object to Takenaka's plan after the elections," said Takeshi Sasaki, the president of Tokyo University and a former political scientist. "If the results of the elections are bad, there will be even more attacks against Takenaka, which may inflame the situation further."
Mr. Koizumi's own credibility is on the line, said Robert A. Feldman, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Japan. "If they backpedal on this reform, they are politically dead," Mr. Feldman said of Mr. Koizumi's cabinet. "The strategy for the antireform people was to convert Koizumi into a puppet."
Japan's prime minister was noncommittal this evening.
"There are various views as a matter of course," he said after Mr. Takenaka postponed his plan. "Some say the disposal of bad loans should be accelerated and others say it should not be accelerated."

HEADLINE: 54% Who Lost Airline Jobs After 9/11 Are Still Jobless 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Many airlines laid off a fifth of their workers after the Sept. 11 attacks, and a report released yesterday found that 54 percent of New York-area airline workers who lost their jobs remained unemployed.
 The report, based on surveys by the machinists' union and three City University of New York professors, also found that half of those laid off had no medical insurance at some point in the last year and that a fourth still had no coverage. 
 The survey, one of the largest conducted on post-Sept. 11 layoffs, also found that 12 percent of the area's laid-off airline workers had to move for financial reasons, while 31 percent said they feared they might have to move soon because of financial difficulties.
"There is an ongoing disaster for these airline workers who were displaced by the events of 9/11," said Bill Kornblum, a City University sociology professor and the main author of the report. 
For the survey, the machinists' union and three professors at City University Graduate Center mailed questionnaires to 1,800 mechanics, customer service representatives, baggage handlers and other workers laid off by United, American and Trans World Airlines, and 609 workers returned completed questionnaires.
One jobless worker, Joel Garhartt, an avionics crew chief who had worked for T.W.A. for 27 years, said he and his wife were selling their house in Astoria, Queens, because they could no longer afford their $885 monthly mortgage payments. Mr. Garhartt's unemployment insurance, $405 a week, ran out after nine months.
"It feels strange having to sell our house after living there for 27 years," he said.
At a news conference at City University Graduate Center, James Parrott, deputy director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, estimated that the airlines laid off about 10,000 workers in the New York area.
"This was an industry that was hit harder than any other industry in New York City," Dr. Parrott said.
The Fiscal Policy Institute and the Consortium of Worker Education, a labor-backed group that helps retrain workers, sponsored the study.
Unemployment benefits for most of the airline workers expired in July, causing the report's authors to recommend federal legislation to extend benefits at least three months.
Tom Daschle, the Senate majority leader, attended the news conference on a day when he was campaigning for H. Carl McCall, the Democratic candidate for governor. Calling the airline workers victims, Senator Daschle, Democrat of South Dakota, said, "They didn't lose their lives, but they did lose their livelihoods, and now many of them are starting to lose hope."
He noted that when President Bush's father was in the White House, unemployment benefits were extended three times.
"We were able to agree that extending unemployment benefits was the right approach then; we should be able to agree that it is the right approach now," Mr. Daschle said.
Many workers said they had looked for other jobs with little success.
"I'm extremely depressed," said Helen McFarland, a ticket counter supervisor who had worked 35 years for T.W.A. "I was making $17 an hour, and I just went for an interview for an administrative job at a doctor's office that paid just $8 an hour," Ms. McFarland said. "I can't afford to live on that."
Steve Sleigh, director of strategic resources for the International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers, criticized lawmakers in Washington for approving $11 billion to bail out the airlines industry while doing little to help aviation workers.
"The crisis for New York's airline workers and their families is about to get worse," Mr. Sleigh said, adding that many of the unemployed would soon lose their medical coverage because they could no longer afford the premiums.
Gloria Daniels, who was a station support clerk for United, said she could not afford the $350 a month needed to keep her medical insurance.
"I have to go to the doctor next week, and I'm going to have to pay for it out of my own pocket," said Ms. Daniels, who was carrying job-rejection letters from Delta, JetBlue and Sabena.
In the survey, 21 percent of the laid-off white workers said they had no medical insurance, while 39 percent of the black workers and 37 percent of Hispanic workers said they were without coverage.

HEADLINE: Wider Support Is Sought For Disclosing Fund Votes 

BYLINE:  By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Three organizations yesterday urged investors to campaign for a new regulation that would require mutual fund companies to disclose how they voted on company issues. In doing so, they contended that the nation's major funds have too often sided in secret with corporate America when making proxy votes for their individual investor customers.
 The campaign is a joint effort of Pax World Funds, a mutual fund company; the A.F.L.-C.I.O.; and Funddemocracy.com, a shareholder-rights group. The effort is an attempt to overcome opposition by mutual funds to a rule proposed by the Securities and Exchange Commission on Sept. 20. The S.E.C. has given the public until Dec. 6 to comment on the proposal. 
 "There is strong industry opposition to the S.E.C.'s rule proposal," said Thomas W. Grant, president of Pax World Funds. "The reality is, individual investors are going to have to speak up."
By requiring that fund managers disclose how they vote shareholders' proxy votes, the S.E.C. hopes to ensure that advisers vote in the best interests of clients. This may not always be the case, according to the S.E.C., which has noted that conflicts of interest may arise when fund managers oversee 401(k) accounts or other employee benefit plans for the same companies whose shares they own and whose proxy issues they vote on. To keep these accounts -- and the fees they generate -- from moving to another fund company, fund managers might vote with corporate management even if the vote was not in the best interests of public shareholders. 
Investment managers oversee $19 trillion in assets today, the S.E.C. said, including large equity stakes. As a result, funds can be a powerful force in protecting shareholders from weak corporate governance or pernicious managerial practices. 
But in the years since the stock market bubble burst, and even in the recent past, as scandals have dominated the business scene, few fund companies have been willing to take up public fights against corporate executives. Funds have even been silent on runaway executive compensation, a trend that almost all investors seem to agree is unacceptable. 
As a result, some investors wonder whose side fund managers are on. "The tendency of mutual fund management to vote with corporate management has contributed to the $1.5 trillion that has been lost by investors," said Michael Garland, corporate transactions coordinator for the A.F.L.-C.I.O. "Fund managers have a fiduciary duty to vote in the best interests of their fund investors, but they're basically saying, 'Trust us.' The only way to monitor this fiduciary duty is to give clients the information they need to monitor it."
The Labor Department requires pension fund managers that oversee investments of union pension plans to disclose their proxy votes. But mutual funds that oversee 401(k)'s are not subject to such a rule.
The mutual fund industry has not yet formally commented on the S.E.C.'s rule. But it rejects the existence of a conflict of interest involving the shares it holds for clients and the fees it earns from managing large accounts for corporations.
"The voting of proxies is part of all mutual funds' duties to shareholders, and the funds take this obligation very seriously," said John Collins, spokesman for the Investment Company Institute. "For the first 62 years of the fund's modern existence the shareholders have been well served by the current system."
Mutual fund companies have also argued that compliance with the rule will be costly. Fund companies also say that if their votes are made public, outside groups might use the information for their own purposes and might campaign for funds to vote in ways that were not in the best interests of shareholders. 
Mr. Grant of Pax World Funds rejected the argument that disclosing proxy votes would be expensive. His company, which specializes in socially responsible investing, has disclosed its proxy votes since 1971 without incurring excessive costs. 
Mr. Garland noted that in 1998 Fidelity voted against a shareholder proposal that would have increased the number of independent directors at Tyco International.
"Stronger board oversight may have been able to prevent the kind of abuses that went on at Tyco," he said. "Instead you had a board that was largely beholden to the C.E.O."
Vincent G. Loporchio, a Fidelity spokesman, said it never discussed specific proxy votes. "We are carefully reviewing the S.E.C.'s proposal," he said. "We vote over 5,000 proxies every year, and we have long believed in quiet diplomacy where we work with management for the best interest of our shareholders."

HEADLINE: The Healthier Side Of Health Care 

BYLINE:  By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
Health costs are spiraling into another year of double-digit increases. Patients, employers and government health programs are feeling the financial pain.
 But where is the money going? And why do health costs continue to rise when in so many other parts of the economy -- from cars to clothes to computers -- prices are falling and profit margins are being squeezed? 
 The big winners for now include hospitals, particularly those that have assembled networks that dominate local markets, and makers of ingenious medical devices like advanced heart pacemakers and the latest hip and knee replacements that cost more than the earlier versions. Nurses, in short supply through much of the country, are getting big raises and better working conditions. 
And the strongest managed care companies -- even though they long ago lost their power to check health care costs -- are reporting sharply higher profits, as premiums rise even faster than do underlying costs.
By contrast, the growth of spending on drugs is slowing, after a decade-long bonanza of profits for drug companies. As health plans require members to pay a steeper share of drug costs, more consumers are turning to lower-priced generic versions of blockbuster drugs like Prozac whose patents have expired. Doctors are writing more than eight times the new prescriptions for the generic version of Prozac, fluoxetine, than for Prozac itself, according to IMS Health, a health care information company.
The pattern, in other words, is a classic one: the less competition, the higher the prices. 
"Anybody that charges money and has close to a monopoly is ahead of the game," said Dr. Paul M. Ellwood, head of the Jackson Hole Group of health policy experts, which drafted an early version of the Clinton health proposal. "The losers are the patients."
Many health insurers are enjoying robust profits, passing on their costs -- and then some -- to employers, dropping money-losing customers and doing little to compete on price, analysts say.
Last week, the UnitedHealth Group, one of the largest managed care companies, reported a 44 percent leap in earnings per share for the three months ended Sept. 30, compared with the period a year ago. This month, Aetna, a big insurer that lost money last year, said its third-quarter profit would be twice what Wall Street was expecting.
Employers say that they are fed up with the increases, but their main response so far has been to shift more costs to workers in the form of higher deductibles, higher co-payments and a larger share of insurance premiums.
In 2003, employees will pay an average of 19 percent of total premiums for individual coverage, up from 17 percent in 2001, according to a survey of large employers released last week by Hewitt Associates, the benefits consulting firm. For family coverage, employees will pay 24 percent of premiums, up from 21 percent last year.
Employers, which typically still pay the greatest share of health costs, are putting up with the substantial increases because they know that coverage is a big item in recruiting and retaining workers, said Helen Darling, president of the Washington Business Group on Health, a group of big companies nationwide. For their part, workers are eager for more, rather than less, health care, as long as they have insurance to pay most of the bills.
More than half the increase in health spending is for hospital services. Outpatient costs are now the fastest-growing health care category, outpacing drugs, according to a study published last month on the Web site of Health Affairs, a scholarly journal. 
Hospital executives say that they are just passing along their own increased costs, notably for medical technology like the latest in catheterization and for higher salaries in a nursing shortage.
On Monday, 10,200 nurses at 17 hospitals and 34 medical offices in California operated by Kaiser Permanente ratified a contract that includes wage increases of 26.5 percent over four years, expanded retiree health and pension benefits and a ban on compulsory overtime. The California Nurses Association said that hospital staff nurses with eight years of experience in the Bay Area currently earn close to $75,000 a year.
(Physicians' fees, by contrast, have been rising less than 2 percent annually, the Health Affairs study said.) 
Of course, if hospitals were merely covering their costs, the earnings of some for-profit hospital chains would not be growing. Insurers and government officials say that some hospital systems have won the power to raise prices and profits by developing oligopoly-like concentrations of hospitals in markets like Houston, Long Island, Boston and San Francisco.
Some of the largest hospital operators point to other explanations for their profit gains. The Tenet Healthcare Corporation, among the nation's largest hospital chains, reported a rise in profit of 118 percent, to $338 million, in its latest quarter while revenue increased 12 percent, to $3.7 billion., It said the increase resulted from treating sicker patients and getting higher rates from H.M.O.'s and increased reimbursements from Medicare.
Another big engine of rising costs is new technology. Purchasers of health care rarely say no to a hot new product or drug that can extend or improve the quality of patients' lives, but advances generally carry premium prices. 
In just over a year, for instance, sales of a new type of pacemaker that coordinates the action of both sides of the heart have hit $470 million, a figure that Glenn M. Reicin, an analyst at Morgan Stanley, projects will rise to $700 million next year. 
The pacemakers are offering a new lease on life to 40,000 people in the United States with congestive heart failure. And they have contributed to a rise exceeding 15 percent this year in sales and profits at both companies that make them. Medtronic of Minneapolis has more than half the market; Guidant of Indianapolis has the rest.
Advances in cardiology have been a steady source of profits for medical device makers. Minimally invasive procedures to open clogged arteries are another case in point. 
First, in the 1970's, there were $300 balloons, inserted through an artery. But arteries often clogged up again within months, so surgeons began inserting tiny metal props called stents that cost $1,000 each to prop the artery open. 
One patient in six still had serious reclogging and needed a repeat procedure. So device makers developed drug-coated stents, which tests and experience overseas have shown to be much more effective. But they cost $3,000 each.
Wall Street analysts estimate that the coated stents will add more than $3 billion next year to the nation's $1.5 trillion health care bill. Kurt Kruger, a health care technology analyst at Banc of America Securities, expects that most of the money will go to Johnson & Johnson. Last night, a Food and Drug Administration advisory panel unanimously recommended approval of the company's coated stents. Final approval is likely to come later this year. 
The outlook may be less promising for makers of prescription drugs. Richard T. Evans, an analyst with Bernstein Research, said that pharmaceuticals were "no longer a growth industry." The drug makers seem unable, he said, to raise prices and reduce costs of production and sales enough to keep profits rising during fallow periods when important new drugs are scarce. 
Spending on new drug research and development is less productive than formerly, Mr. Evans added, while consumer resistance to high drug prices is rising. On Monday, when President Bush offered a plan to speed the approval of lower-cost generic drugs, the stocks of most big pharmaceutical companies fell.
Like so much in the economy, of course, the prospects of health providers move in cycles. 
Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton, said that insurers would probably prosper for the next two to three years before competition among them brings prices down and squeezes profits.
Hospitals may be the next target for protests by patient advocates. Although one hospital in four is in financial trouble, strong hospital groups "have the upper hand these days, so they will come in for greater scrutiny," said Mark Pauly, a health business economist at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania. "People are looking around for some other bad guy."
Dr. Arnold Milstein, a health care consultant at William M. Mercer, agreed. "First it was H.M.O. executives, then pharmaceuticals that got their comeuppance," he said. "Now it's the hospitals' turn."

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about hospitals and others that have benefited from increased health-care spending misstated the name of the consulting firm of Dr. Arnold Milstein, who commented on the potential political repercussions for hospitals. It is Mercer Human Resource Consulting, not William M. Mercer Inc.

HEADLINE: Golisano, Battling Red Tape, Bites the Hand That Fed Him 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
As the Independence Party's nominee for governor of New York and the star of his own expensive advertising campaign, Tom Golisano has repeatedly condemned the tax and paperwork burdens that he says Albany imposes on small businesses.
 "The bureaucracy and the administrative red tape of being an employer and a business in this state are way too complex for small business," he told voters in a recent debate. "We have to change these things to make it better." 
 But helping small businesses cope with that red tape is exactly how Mr. Golisano built the substantial fortune that is financing his run for state office, his third since 1994. And his Rochester-based company, Paychex, has itself sought some of the corporate tax breaks that Mr. Golisano, who is 60, deplores. 
The company's application for about $600,000 in state tax subsidies to help finance its expansion, which was criticized in a televised debate on Sunday, was defended by Mr. Golisano in a recent interview. "Imagine the situation I'm put in as a C.E.O.," he said. "They offered it, we're entitled to it, other companies are getting it, I represent the shareholders today -- and I said 'yes.' "
This balancing act has left the billionaire businessman vulnerable to accusations of hypocrisy, like those raised in the recent debate. But to corporate watchdogs, it simply underscores how carefully Mr. Golisano has separated his private ambitions from the duty he owes to Paychex's shareholders, including several large public pension funds, most of Paychex's 8,000 employees -- and himself.
Although the campaign Mr. Golisano is running has been described as a bit haphazard -- "He's an amateur, an outsider and a neophyte," said Mark Alesse, the New York state director of the National Federation of Independent Business, the small-business trade group -- the company he runs as chief executive is anything but. 
Paychex's basic business is handling the back-office personnel chores, from generating payroll checks to withholding income taxes, for more than 440,000 small and medium-size businesses across the country.
Measured by its client count, Paychex is the second-largest payroll processing company in the country, after the older and better-known Automatic Data Processing. (As it happens, A.D.P.'s co-founder, Frank R. Lautenberg, is also on the ballot this fall, as the Democratic Party's replacement for Senator Robert G. Torricelli in New Jersey's United States Senate race.)
Paychex has a financial position many C.E.O.'s would envy. It has a fat cushion of cash, and no debt. Since its shares were first listed on the Nasdaq market, back in 1983, its annual revenues have soared and so have its profits. After adjusting for stock splits over the years, the price of Paychex's stock has increased from roughly 19 cents a share in 1983 to $28.79 a share yesterday -- a gain of more than 30 percent a year for nearly 20 years.
Besides a host of other investments, Mr. Golisano still holds just under 40 million shares, or just over 10 percent, of Paychex's stock; at recent prices, that stake alone is worth more than $1.1 billion.
Although Paychex's track record has made Mr. Golisano glitteringly rich, his personal style is not extravagant, friends say. His toys are unremarkable for a man of his wealth: a Gulfstream jet, a Mercedes convertible, boats and three homes (a 2,500-square-foot ranch outside Rochester, and vacation homes on Canandaigua Lake and in Naples, Fla.)
And the corporate culture is spare almost to the point of eccentricity. "That's part of being an entrepreneur -- you watch your pennies," Mr. Golisano said during an interview in his corner office, about the size of a single room at a Holiday Inn.
Paychex's red-brick headquarters building on the outskirts of Rochester is fresh and functional but not lavish. The art on the walls could have come from Sears; the desks, which are supposed to be kept clutter-free and tidy, are early Marriott. Mr. Golisano's pay package, just under $750,000 a year, is remarkably modest, executive compensation experts say. He did not get a bonus last year because the weak economy and low interest rates slowed the company's revenue growth, and he receives no stock options.
Neither he nor any of his executives receives even the most common perks of corporate life -- no company cars, no reserved parking spaces, no country club memberships, no company-owned jets, not even fancy titles on the business cards.
Originally christened Paymaster, Paychex was born in 1971, the brainchild of Mr. Golisano, a young Rochester-area native who seemed to have been born with an entrepreneurial itch. (When he married, his father-in-law offered to lend him the price of a house; Mr. Golisano asked instead for a loan to buy two small rental properties and, he recalls, "became a landlord at 21.")
His formal education after public high school was a two-year stint at Alfred State College, sandwiched between two unsatisfying bouts of working in a bank. "From the day I got out of school" in 1962, Mr. Golisano said, "I was looking for an idea."
He found it in 1966 when -- at age 25 -- he quit a sales job at a large corporation to start Bidder's Guide, a newsletter that collected bidding information from local newspapers and made it available to companies interested in selling goods and services to local governments.
It was a good little business but not enough to support his young family, so he got a job as a salesman for a payroll processing company. But he kept looking for another business idea -- and found it in the potential customers his employer overlooked.
"It struck me that most businesses have less than 100 employees, but most payroll services were going after bigger companies," he said. So he thought up a way to provide payroll services to very small companies at a price they could afford.
He proposed that instead of sending employees out to collect payroll information in person, they do so by telephone -- "cheaper, easier and faster," he said. (Today, it can be done over the Internet.) He also calculated that if he could collect the payroll taxes that employers have to withhold, he could free them of a difficult chore, and earn a little interest on the collected tax funds besides. That would help him keep his fees low enough for small businesses to handle.
Even today, Paychex's average customer has just 14 employees, about a quarter of A.D.P.'s average customer, according to John Morphy, Paychex's chief financial officer.
After Mr. Golisano was unable to sell his concept to his employer, he quit and, in 1971 at 30, he started the company that became Paychex. "My original business plan? To work hard, get 300 clients in the Rochester area and live happily ever after," he said. "But it took four years to get to 400 clients -- it was during the gas crisis, in a terrible economy."
His drive to build Paychex took its toll on his early marriage to Gloria Austen, with whom he has a son and daughter. (Neither is active in his business or his campaign, and Mr. Golisano is firmly protective of their privacy.) At the time of the divorce, in 1978, Ms. Austen asked to be installed as the Paychex franchise owner in New York City, and when the company went public in 1983, she retired on her profits, he said. They remain friends, he added, and she serves on the board of his private charitable foundation.
In 1994, a second marriage also foundered, perhaps because of Mr. Golisano's entrepreneurial appetite. "I'm a 7-times-24 person," he said a bit awkwardly. "I'm always in on weekends. This is what I love to do."
He also owns a private company that provides vintage radio programming to nursing homes. He bankrolled a nephew who started a documents-storage company that was later acquired by Iron Mountain, an industry giant on whose board Mr. Golisano still serves. He is backing a college student who has developed an Internet company that provides e-mail, scheduling and data storage services to small businesses that lack an internal computer network. 
Sounds like that last one might be a good fit for Paychex. "You mean because it has recurring revenues, is service-based and is aimed at the same customer base?" he asked, grinning broadly. "No, I hadn't considered that at all."
Not every idea works. Jobline, a job clearinghouse service he started in the early days at Paychex, was a costly flop, as predicted by the naysayers whom Mr. Golisano ignored. "One of the mistakes that entrepreneurs make is to think they're a little immortal," he said. "Once we closed Jobline, I didn't have any illusions on that score."
Mr. Golisano's freewheeling creativity stops at the chief financial officer's desk at Paychex. Mr. Morphy said he and his boss were in "total agreement" about the need for credible, conservative accounting and bulletproof audits. Indeed, Mr. Morphy said he almost fired the company's outside auditors a few years ago for not being tough enough on the company.
Corporate reports to shareholders are prompt, clear and candid. But one thing has not yet been officially disclosed: that the company's C.E.O. is running for governor and, if he wins, will leave the company.
Mr. Golisano says the company has not kept his candidacy a secret. "It's been discussed on our conference calls with analysts, and they're all posted on our Web site," he said.
It's also been discussed by the board, said Grant Inman, a venture capitalist who has served on the Paychex board since 1983. "He'd be a great governor -- but I hate to even say that because I love him running this company."
But no, his candidacy and its potential consequences for Paychex have not been mentioned in the company's reports to shareholders, Mr. Morphy acknowledged. And why not? He thought for a moment, and then composed a diplomatic answer. "One of the tests for determining whether something is material," he said, "is to weigh the likelihood that it will actually happen."

HEADLINE: Technology Briefing Software: Shares In 2 Video Game Companies Fall 

BYLINE:  By Matt Richtel (NYT) 

 BODY:
 Share prices of two video game companies dropped markedly yesterday, as industry analysts have begun to wonder whether video game sales will be as robust this holiday season as originally expected. Shares in Eidos P.L.C., based in Britain, fell about 15 percent, to 84 pence, after the company said it would delay the release of "Tomb Raider: The Angel of Darkness" until February. 
The company said it needed more time to test the game. Shares in THQ Inc. lost 39 percent after the company said Monday that its 2002 profits would be at the low end of earlier projections, and its 2003 earnings would be far below analyst consensus estimates. The company blamed poor global economic conditions, and the lower-than-expected sales of the Nintendo GameCube and Microsoft Xbox. The news came as the industry prepared for the crucial holiday sales season. But not all video game makers were expressing concern. Take-Two Interactive Software Inc., based in New York, said yesterday that it had received more orders for the new version of "Grand Theft Auto," than it did for the first version of the game, one of the most popular games ever. The new version, "Grand Theft Auto: Vice City," is scheduled to reach stores next Tuesday. Matt Richtel (NYT)

HEADLINE: SAFETY; 
Deaths Mounting Again In War on Drunk Driving

BYLINE:  By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
FOR 15 years, the United States was winning the war against drunken driving, steadily reducing the percentage of deaths from accidents involving alcohol.
 But at some point in the mid-1990's, the progress stopped and then reversed. Now, the struggle is a war of attrition, with drunken driving claiming about 17,000 deaths a year and inflicting tens of thousands of disabling injuries. Experts offer many explanations as to why the war bogged down, but they are mostly variations on a theme. 
 "People think the problem has been solved," said Wendy J. Hamilton, president of Mothers Against Drunk Driving. 
The increase in the number of young drivers has very likely played a role, experts say, and attention has been diverted to other issues, like road rage, cellphone use and defective tires.
Whatever the cause, the reversal has been striking. In 1982, when drunken driving became a national issue (President Ronald Reagan convened a task force against it and Congress established a National Drunk and Drugged Driving Awareness Week), the fraction of fatal crashes in which someone had a blood alcohol level of at least .08 was 53 percent, translating into 23,246 deaths. 
By 1997, that figure had fallen to 34 percent, according to the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, with 14,421 fatalities, a reduction of about a third carried out over a period of huge growth in vehicles, drivers and miles traveled.
But since then, the figures have crept back up last year, to 35 percent and 14,953 deaths, based on .08 alcohol concentration level, which Congress recently set as the national standard for drunken driving and encouraged states to incorporate into their laws. (Two-thirds of the states are now at .08.)
The statistics are more important as a yardstick of progress than as a precise measure of deaths. There is no actual count of fatalities caused by a drunken driver; rather, the count reflects the number of fatal accidents in which the driver, a pedestrian or someone else involved had a blood alcohol level of .08 or above. 
Making further progress would require a stronger sense of urgency, but it would also need a strategy as to what kind of problem driver to pursue: the large group of people who occasionally drink a bit too much, or the smaller but far more dangerous group of drivers who drive when very drunk? 
To illustrate what this means, Annette Sandberg, the deputy administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration and a former superintendent of the state police in Washington State, pulled out a bar chart showing the blood alcohol concentration of the most inebriated driver in each fatal crash. More than half the fatalities involved people who were at twice the legal limit or above. The median was .16.
Ms. Sandberg thinks that there are fewer deaths involving even drunker drivers because it is difficult to operate a car above that level, although the chart topped out with nine drivers who had astounding blood measures of .43. 
It's easier to drive a car at levels around .08 and .10, which was the common legal standard until now. But experts think that fewer cars are crashed with drivers at that level because many people who might in the past have drunk themselves to .08 or .10 have stopped drinking and driving.
In an interview, Ms. Sandberg said: ".08 scared a lot of people. It's a lot easier to get to .08, and you need to be more cautious." Lowering the standard and enforcing it, she added, may have impressed casual drinkers but not people who can reach .16.
"A lot of states need to have stricter rules with regard to their problem drinkers," she said.
In fact, some states are running short of tactics against casual or heavy drinkers. California, which adopted many laws to fight drunken driving early on, has felt the effect of most of them by now, said Cliff Helander, chief of research at the state's Department of Motor Vehicles. Progress has stopped, he said, because "there's been a stoppage of major legislation."
California's last major law was almost 10 years ago, he said, allowing the police and the courts to seize the cars of drunken drivers and hold them for 30 days. It also uses tactics that other states use, like automatic license revocation if a Breathalyzer test shows illegal blood alcohol concentration. He said the next big step might be to raise the tax on alcoholic beverages.
Representative Nita M. Lowey, a New York Democrat who was instrumental in the federal .08 legislation, introduced a bill this year that would set national minimum standards for sentencing repeat offenders.
Repeat offenders and those convicted with especially high-blood-alcohol concentrations would face vehicle impoundment, alcohol ignition interlocks (which work like a Breathalyzer built into the car), treatment and imprisonment. People stopped by the police who refused to take a Breathalyzer test would face penalties tougher than those for drunken driving.
The bill did not even get a hearing. Ms. Lowey, in a telephone interview, was philosophical. "We're not doing much of anything in this Congress," she said. Next year, when the major transportation appropriations bill comes up, she added, she would try to append her proposal to it, and MADD would be knocking on legislators' doors.
Ms. Lowey's bill, named after Burton Greene, a constituent in her Westchester County district who was killed by a drunk driver, focuses on repeat offenders. But in 2001, drunken drivers involved in fatal accidents who had had a conviction in the previous three years represented only 8.4 percent of all alcohol-related fatalities, amounting to 1,461 lives.
Deaths involving drunken drivers with no previous convictions were 10 times more of a problem. Thus, some experts say that a campaign to stop first offenses is vital. 
Some of those experts say that the next step should be in the other direction, to continue cutting the rate of drunken driving among lighter drinkers, who are more open to reason. They suggest lowering the blood alcohol concentration further. The limit is set by states, but Congress twisted the arms of all 50 legislatures in 2000 by tying future highway aid to the blood-alcohol limit, just as it forced the states in the 90's to raise the drinking age to 21. 
The hospitality industry, as it calls itself, fought tooth and nail against .08, arguing that petite women would be over the limit with two drinks. So, stricter limits would be hard to win. The international experience, though, might support a lower limit. At the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, an organization of industrial nations, a researcher pointed out that the .08 or .10 allowed in America was "at the high end of the range of blood-alcohol-concentration levels adopted as the legal limit by O.E.C.D. countries." 
Ceallach Levins, of the organization's transport division, said that some Western European countries and Australia had set the allowable blood alcohol concentration at .05 or lower.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Levins said, "The message you're giving by having a higher blood alcohol concentration is that it's O.K. to have a couple of drinks and then drive." But if the limit is set closer to zero, some people cannot legally drive immediately after drinking, even if they had only a single drink, he said. "Socially, you're getting a very different message across." 
ON the other hand, there is forward movement in seat-belt use, which is up to about three-quarters of adults, and offers a collateral benefit to drinking and driving. Dr. Jeffrey W. Runge, the administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, points to seat-belt use as a cure-all, reducing fatalities and the severity of injuries among people hit by drunken drivers, people riding in cars driven by drunken drivers and drunken drivers themselves -- not to mention accident victims in cases where everyone was sober. 
In states that allow the police to stop cars because someone is not buckled, there is an opportunity to smell for alcohol.
The drunken driving challenge is frustrating because, generally speaking, the procedures and equipment needed to fight it are already available. For all the fanfare about stricter laws governing drunken drivers, they cover only the ones who are caught. According to the AAA, with 1.5 million arrests in 1999, the chance of being arrested while driving drunk were fewer than 1 in 50. Even those whose licenses are revoked still drive. 
"We know what needs to be done," said Barry M. Sweedler, the president of the International Council on Alcohol, Drugs and Traffic Safety and the former chairman of the National Transportation Research Board's committee on alcohol and drugs in transportation. "But we must summon the political and social will to make it happen."

HEADLINE: Untypically, a Rockefeller Tells the Story of His Life 

BYLINE:  By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
John D. Rockefeller, the famously secretive oil baron who founded his family's vast fortune, once confided that of all his grandchildren, the one who most resembled him was David A. Rockefeller, the only one of his generation to follow his grandfather into a life of business. They were exceptionally close from the boy's infancy in 1915 until the old man's death in 1937.
 Yet it is David Rockefeller who, at age 87, has become the first in three generations of Rockefellers to publish an autobiography, breaking a century-long habit of fierce privacy instilled in his clan by his grandfather. 
 "Memoirs," a candid account of Mr. Rockefeller's life at the busy intersection of global banking, family business and unofficial diplomacy, made its debut from Random House yesterday. And the attendant publicity splash would make the old tight-lipped titan flinch: an 11-city author's tour and a media blitz that has run the gamut from the early-morning "Today" show to late-night's Charlie Rose. The whole exercise is remarkable for a Rockefeller, said Ron Chernow, the author of "Titan," a biography of the dynasty's founder. "John D. Rockefeller, as a monopolist of the gilded age, believed as fervently in corporate opacity as we believe today in corporate transparency," Mr. Chernow said. "And his son was an extremely private and self-effacing man." 
He added, "It is a mark of strength and self-confidence that David Rockefeller can come out and tell his life story in a very forthright way."
Mr. Rockefeller does indeed lay the family linen out on the lawn -- his painful conflicts with his older brothers, his insecurities as a child and shortcomings as a father, his battles over art and real estate and his proud but rocky career at Chase Manhattan Bank, now part of J. P. Morgan Chase.
Why did Mr. Rockefeller, who remains busy with the many cultural, educational and public policy groups supported by his family's fabled philanthropy, undertake this atypical project?
"Well, it just occurred to me that I had led a rather interesting life," he said mildly during an interview in the red-walled library on the second floor of his Manhattan town house. "I thought maybe my own children and family might be interested." Once the idea took root, roughly in mid-1984, he was encouraged strongly by his wife and former colleagues at the bank to see it through, friends said.
One impulse behind the memoir was almost certainly Mr. Rockefeller's desire to show that he had worked for his place in the world and not simply inherited it, especially his place at Chase, long associated with the Rockefeller family.
"It is a very strong element of the family to resent the knee-jerk assumption that 'you can get whatever you want because you're a Rockefeller,' " said Peter J. Johnson, a historian who has worked at the Rockefeller family office for decades and oversaw the memoir project.
Thus Mr. Rockefeller recounts how he labored to earn his doctorate in economics, spending a winter marooned at the family's opulent Tarrytown estate to work on his dissertation and then defending it at the University of Chicago. He tells how he came to enlist as a private in the Army in 1942, shunning the commission his father could have obtained for him and not only surviving the rigors of basic training but also carrying out well-regarded military intelligence work in North Africa and Europe. And he explains at considerable length how hard he worked making Chase an international bank and tackling internal problems that brought his board to the brink of firing him in 1975.
But whatever his initial motive, he says the approach he took -- a candor wholly uncharacteristic of the family previously -- was a lesson he learned from his friend Katharine Graham, the publisher of The Washington Post and the author of "Personal History," her own Pulitzer Prize-winning autobiography.
"We were both working on our memoirs at the same time, and she encouraged me to do it this way," he recalled in the interview. "It just seemed to me that people would enjoy the book more if I were pretty frank and open -- without causing embarrassment or unhappiness to people," he added. "I tried to avoid being unkind."
He confesses in the book, for example, to his own fearful ambivalence about enlisting for military service after Pearl Harbor, even though his college roommate and dearest friend, Richard Gilder, had done so immediately. He enlisted after his mother prodded him, he said. "I knew that Mother was right," he wrote.
He is equally open about some of his stumbles at the bank. There was, for example, the "unity retreat" he organized for senior management in late January 1969, at which one of his top executives got drunk and wound up in a fistfight with the bank's controller.
Some of the most revealing passages in "Memoirs" deal with the relationships among the Rockefeller brothers, the five sons of John D. Rockefeller Jr. and Abby Aldrich Rockefeller. "Winthrop faced an unusually difficult situation within the family," Mr. Rockefeller wrote. "Nelson and Laurance were a club to which he wasn't invited. I, three years his junior, was a club he didn't want to join." Of his brother Nelson, he wrote: "A family adviser once said the two most expensive things a Rockefeller can do is run for public office and get divorced. Nelson did both." And the divorce, in 1961, profoundly altered his view of his childhood hero. "The scales fell from my eyes and I no longer saw him as the hero who could do no wrong but as a man who was willing to sacrifice almost everything in the service of his enormous ambition," he wrote.
Perhaps only a historian would notice, but Mr. Chernow pointed out that Mr. Rockefeller's book is coming out almost exactly a hundred years after the famous muckraker, Ida Tarbell, published the first installment in her historic magazine series about Standard Oil, the iron-fisted monopoly that was the source of the family's immense wealth.
Because Mr. Rockefeller neither types nor uses a computer, producing his 469-page autobiography required a team that perhaps only a Rockefeller could afford. Besides Mr. Johnson, who had worked with the family on a two-volume biography of John D. Rockefeller III, at least 15 other people assisted in the project at various times, searching family and bank archives, transcribing long interviews with friends and former colleagues, and building a day-by-day chronology to guide the elderly banker's recollections.
"He talked his memoirs out," Mr. Johnson said. Those conversations would be reduced to typed drafts, which Mr. Rockefeller would revise extensively by hand. Those changes would be incorporated in new drafts, with which he would again tinker. It was a time-consuming approach that tested the patience and diplomacy of all involved.
Inevitably, there were courteous but firm disagreements. "David loves the passive voice," Mr. Johnson recalled with a laugh. "He loves to have had things happen to him. So that was something we had to work on."
Now that his labors are done, Mr. Rockefeller seems quietly delighted with the book, the proceeds of which he will contribute to charity. His wife, Peggy, to whom he was married for 56 years, did not survive to see it finished, but their six children have applauded their father's effort, especially his handling of the generational strife within the family, Mr. Johnson said, adding, "They feel he told their side of the story very well."
And Mr. Rockefeller's only surviving sibling, the reclusive 92-year-old Laurance S. Rockefeller, has read the book and liked it well enough that he gave copies to all his staff, Mr. Johnson said.
Despite the army of people who worked on the book, those who know Mr. Rockefeller say it still sounds like him: gentlemanly, slightly detached about his wealth, diplomatic but firm in his opinions. "Knowing the process he was using, I was afraid it would sound like it had been written by a committee," said Mr. Chernow, the historian. "But based on my knowledge of the man, it is David's voice, most certainly."

HEADLINE: Political Memo; 
Money and Momentum Elude McCall

BYLINE:  By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. and SHAILA K. DEWAN 

DATELINE: ALBANY, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Short of cash and struggling to find a penetrating message, the campaign of H. Carl McCall has been pushed largely to the sidelines in recent days, while Gov. George E. Pataki and Tom Golisano, the Independence Party candidate, wage a war to win over moderate and conservative voters, political strategists say.
 Mr. McCall has been hamstrung by a lack of money since he won the September primary. Recent polls show that he has failed to make headway outside New York City. Indeed, he is running neck and neck with Mr. Golisano in upstate counties and in the city's suburbs. In two previous campaigns, Mr. Golisano never got more than 8 percent of the vote statewide. 
 Mr. McCall, the 67-year-old state comptroller, is stuck in a politician's Catch-22: it is difficult to raise money unless he can show he is gaining momentum and it is hard to gain momentum without spending money for advertising.
Mr. Golisano, meanwhile, a billionaire financing his own campaign, has spent more than $40 million on ads, most of them attacking the governor. His aides say he is spending more than $1 million a day. 
Governor Pataki, who holds a 9- to 10-point lead in most polls, had more than $12 million to spend as of the last campaign filing three weeks ago. At that time, Mr. McCall had only $1 million, and though he has been raising funds furiously, his aides concede he still lags far behind the other two candidates.
"He's locked in almost as a spectator," said Richard Schrader, a Democratic campaign consultant not involved in this race. "He's a bystander while Golisano and Pataki go to war." 
Making matters more difficult for the Democrats, Mr. McCall has been forced onto the defensive by the governor, who has made significant inroads into traditionally Democratic voting blocs like union members and Latino voters. The upshot is that the Democrat has spent most of his time campaigning in New York City, trying to galvanize his base of support. He has flitted from issue to issue, seeking a message that will resonate. 
Privately, several national and state Democratic officials complain that Mr. McCall has not done enough to raise money. At the same time, Mr. McCall's allies, like Representative Charles B. Rangel of Manhattan, have criticized the Democratic National Committee for not doing more to help Mr. McCall.
In recent days, Mr. McCall has been dogged by questions whether the national party had lost faith in his campaign. "No, they're not doing enough for me," Mr. McCall said without rancor at a rally in Manhattan on Saturday. "And I want them to do more, don't you?" 
The Democratic National Committee has yet to fulfill its promise to raise $500,000 for Mr. McCall's campaign, though it has given him about $240,000 so far, and the party chairman, Terry McAuliffe, remains committed to raising the rest, a spokeswoman said. Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton and former President Bill Clinton are also holding fund-raising events for Mr. McCall. 
Yet some Democratic officials say that Mr. McAuliffe appears to have lost confidence that Mr. McCall can win and has decided the party's resources would be better used in key Senate races around the country.
"The party has a finite amount of money," one national official said. "The races most likely to win are getting the money."
Mr. McCall has seemed listless on the campaign trail since last month, when he weathered criticism over letters he had written on official stationery recommending his daughter and friends for jobs. He rarely reverts to the fiery rhetoric and preacher's cadences that he was wont to lapse into after his primary victory in September.
And without cash to broadcast attack ads against Mr. Pataki, the McCall camp has pinned its hopes on Mr. Golisano's barrage of ads questioning the governor's ethics and record on the economy.
Some Democratic strategists believe the higher Mr. Golisano climbs in the polls, the more votes he takes away from the governor. They also hope Mr. Golisano's attack will drive down the governor's support among conservatives and encourage the governor's Democratic supporters to return to their party.
Recent polls show Mr. Pataki with about 4 out of 10 votes statewide, while Mr. McCall has about 3 and Mr. Golisano has about 2. The theory is, if Mr. Golisano sneaks up a few points and takes Mr. Pataki down a few points, Mr. McCall might be able to squeak in with only 40 percent of the vote. 
"You are not going to have to have 50 percent to win this race," one McCall aide said. "If Golisano can rip off a little bit more on the right side, and we can bring the Democrats home, we can beat him."
But waiting for one's enemies to destroy each other has risks. "Carl won't be on the air," Mr. Schrader pointed out. "The danger for Carl is he disappears."

HEADLINE: Big Turnaround at Nissan Leads to Record Profits 

BYLINE:  By KEN BELSON 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Wednesday, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Thanks to strong sales of Altima and Infiniti cars and progress in cutting costs, Nissan Motor will announce record profits today for the six months ended Sept. 30. The automaker will also raise its profit forecast for the year and consider paying shareholders a dividend for the first time in four years, the company said.
 The strong results extend a remarkable turnaround for Nissan, Japan's No. 3 carmaker, which just a few years ago was buried in debt and nearly bankrupt. The latest period will be the fifth consecutive half-year of rising earnings. 
 By selling assets, closing factories and squeezing costs in other ways, Nissan has reduced its debt by nearly 90 percent from its peak.
Having strengthened the balance sheet, the chief executive, Carlos Ghosn, is now trying to close the gap in sales between Nissan and its bigger Japanese rivals, Toyota Motor and Honda Motor. To freshen its product line, Nissan introduced 11 models around the world in the first half of the fiscal year, and Nissan is scheduled to roll out another dozen models in the next six months. To meet expected demand for these cars, Nissan will step up production by 240,000 vehicles a year in existing plants, and gain additional capacity when it opens a plant in Canton, Miss., next year.
The upbeat numbers from Nissan come as something of a surprise, given the economic weakness in Japan and Nissan's reluctance to offer cash incentives to American buyers. Sales rose 12.1 percent in Japan and 8.3 percent in the United States from the period a year earlier. 
Nissan had an operating profit of 348 billion yen ($2.8 billion) in the period, the officials said. The operating income figure is about 20 percent more than many analysts had forecast.
Net income after taxes and charges was 286 billion yen ($2.3 billion) in the six months, a 24 percent increase from the period a year ago. The company expects full-year net income of 490 billion yen ($3.9 billion).
Nissan's revival presents new challenges to Toyota and Honda, which have dominated Japan's auto market in recent years. Nissan's subcompact car, the March, has become a hit with young drivers, and demand for its new Z sports car has been strong in the United States. The company plans to introduce a sport utility vehicle, the Murano, and three new Infiniti models before March 31.
"In a slowing economy, it's who has the new models coming out," said Kurt Sanger, an analyst at ING Barings Securities here. "Of the Big Three in Japan, Nissan has the most new product."
By reducing the company's debts and scrapping old factories, Mr. Sanger said, "Ghosn is essentially putting Nissan's balance sheet in line with Toyota's and Honda's."
Renault of France owns about 37 percent of Nissan. 

CORRECTION-DATE: October 25, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Wednesday about earnings for Nissan in the six months ended Sept. 30 included an erroneous reference from the company to its record of dividend payments in recent years. Nissan did not pay dividends in the years ended in March 1999 and 2000 but paid them in 2001 and 2002; a payout in March 2003 would not be its first in four years.
