HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS; 
IN HOMESTRETCH, BUSH MAKES PUSH FOR G.O.P. GAINS

BYLINE:  By ELISABETH BUMILLER with ADAM NAGOURNEY 

DATELINE: DOWNINGTOWN, Pa., Oct. 22 

 BODY:
The White House is mounting an all-out push over the final two weeks of the midterm elections, dispatching President Bush to campaign almost nonstop between now and Election Day, as officials seek to turn Mr. Bush's popularity into Republican victories this fall. White House officials today said they were poised for a "historic" Republican triumph next month.
Mr. Bush's travels took him to Pennsylvania and Maine today, as he campaigned on behalf of Republicans running for Congress and governor and, for the first time, specifically exhorted voters to turn out and support Republicans. In recent days Mr. Bush has talked increasingly about domestic issues in what White House aides described as an effort to prevent the Democrats from gaining traction on the issues they consider vital this fall.
White House officials said today that they now believed that the Republicans would at least hold on to the House, where they have a six-seat edge. They said they were less optimistic about the Senate, where Democrats hold a one-seat edge, and still expected that the Republican Party faced a net loss of governors, if only because more seats held by Republican governors are up for election this year.
But in an unusual setting of expectations, senior White House officials said that the Republican Party was in a position to defy historic trends and increase the party's margin in the House.
Only twice since 1934 has the party in power in the White House added seats in the midterm elections, and Mr. Bush's advisers said they believed that the president could help make that happen again.
"If Republicans are able to either keep the House or win back the Senate, we would make history by defying history," Ken Mehlman, the White House political director, said in an interview.
White House officials, who settled on the strategy after prolonged internal discussions, acknowledged that having Mr. Bush campaign had its risks. For one thing, Mr. Bush has now irrevocably tied his prestige to the outcome of these elections and runs the risk of a bad outcome being interpreted as a judgment by voters on his policies. 
For another, several Democrats argued that Mr. Bush was taking a chance in leaving the White House to campaign, noting that President Bill Clinton did much the same thing in 1994, when the Democrats lost 52 seats in what was the equivalent Congressional election of his presidency.
Mr. Clinton's chief of staff at the time, John Podesta, said he now believed that Mr. Clinton might have had a more positive influence on voters had he stayed above the partisan fray and remained in the presidential setting of the White House.
Beyond that, Democrats said they saw opportunity in the course Mr. Bush has chosen, arguing that he was making the election a national referendum on his policies, both foreign and domestic.
The Democrats are broadcasting television advertisements attacking Mr. Bush's economic record in the areas where he is campaigning. In e-mail messages to reporters, they send economic statistics tailored to Mr. Bush's location, and Democratic Party officials are saying that Mr. Bush's activities have provided a much-needed opportunity for the party out of power.
"We believe that Bush's decision to embark on a 14-day, 17-plus-state political tour is going to give Bush his own unwelcome and unexpected 'October Surprise' by having the consequence of nationalizing the mid-terms around the issue of the economy," Mr. Podesta and Joe Lockhart, a Clinton White House press secretary, said in a memorandum to Democratic Party leaders over the weekend. "Bush's strategy presents Democrats with the opportunity to exploit Republicans' most potent political vulnerability -- their mismanagement of the economy and poor leadership record on domestic economic issues."
White House officials expressed confidence that Mr. Bush could withstand those attacks and dismissed the comparison with Mr. Clinton in 1994.
Matthew Dowd, a Republican Party pollster who advises the White House, noted that Mr. Bush was riding a wave of popularity that no president had enjoyed at this point in his presidency since John F. Kennedy in 1962. Mr. Clinton was viewed favorably by about 45 percent of the electorate in 1994; by contrast, Mr. Bush's favorability rating these days is around 65 percent in several polls. 
"This year, the opposition is not running against George W. Bush," Mr. Mehlman said.
Beyond that, White House officials said they concluded that potential benefits of this campaign-closing strategy clearly outweighed any risks.
With Democrats and Republicans saying that turnout has emerged as a decisive factor in these elections, Republicans argued that Mr. Bush's presence was critical to counter what they are expecting to be extraordinary turnout operations by Democrats and their supporters. "In our calculus, the net gain is for the president to appear on behalf of these candidates, in order to get our voters to the polls," said Dan Bartlett, the White House communications director.
Accordingly, White House officials said that most of Mr. Bush's political stops over the final two weeks would be get-out-the-vote rallies, typically in airport hangers and field houses and that they would open up the stage to Republican candidates running for all levels of office. Today, Mr. Bush repeatedly appealed to voters to make sure to show up on Election Day.
"I'm here to ask you to do whatever it takes to make sure you crank up a good, healthy vote," Mr. Bush shouted at a rally here in Downingtown, a suburb of Philadelphia.
White House officials said Mr. Bush's latest schedule called for him to campaign on 9 of the 14 days before the election.
"The travels of the president over the next week will be to places where his presence can make the difference," Karl Rove, his senior political adviser, said today.
That said, Republicans said they were aware that in some cases Mr. Bush's presence could be problematic. For example, as of now, he is not scheduled to return to Florida to help his brother, Jeb Bush, who is in a difficult re-election campaign for governor. Given what happened in the 2000 presidential election, officials in both parties said that an appearance in Florida by the president could do more to turn out Democratic voters than anything the Democratic Party might do.
Further, Democratic officials said they were moving to try to turn Mr. Bush's high profile against him.
"It gives us an opportunity to engage on a topic that we have been itching to engage in for the past six months," Mr. Podesta said in an interview.
He added, "Rather than to continue in the role of commander in chief, rather than looking big and strong on the national front, he is out there in the dirt with candidates."
Democratic officials said they believed that Mr. Bush's political stature would be hurt if Republicans suffer setbacks despite his efforts. Mr. Bush's aides said they had considered that, but concluded there would be such speculation no matter what Mr. Bush did.
 "Those stories will be written whether he's sitting at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue or whether he's on the road," Mr. Bartlett said. More than that, several White House officials argued that even a bad showing by Republicans this November would say little about how Mr. Bush might do in 2004 -- as Mr. Clinton demonstrated decisively in 1996.

CORRECTION-DATE: October 25, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article on Wednesday about President Bush's campaigning on behalf of Republican candidates misstated the White House position once held by John Podesta, who commented on the political risk to President Bush. At the time of the 1994 elections, Mr. Podesta was staff secretary in the Clinton White House; the chief of staff was Leon E. Panetta.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place; 
New WorldCom Losses Hint at a Disputed Future

BYLINE:  By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
Despite its troubles, WorldCom is still an immense company, generating about $80 million in revenue daily, according to data WorldCom released yesterday. It is also a deeply unprofitable company. 
 So how WorldCom may behave if it emerges from bankruptcy protection next year has become a hotly debated question in the telecommunications industry in recent weeks. It is a debate with important ramifications for consumers, business customers, WorldCom's myriad creditors and its competitors. 
 The regional Bell giants are telling anyone who will listen that a revamped WorldCom could plunge the entire industry back into the destructive price wars from which it is only now emerging. Some of the regional Bell allies in research institutes are even suggesting that the Federal Communications Commission strip WorldCom of its licenses and essentially shut the company down. 
But many independent analysts and WorldCom's most direct competitor, AT&T, say that the company would have no choice but to emerge a wiser and more conservative business, one more focused on making money than on generating sales at any cost.
Yesterday, in its first financial report since an accounting scandal resulted in the company's filing for bankruptcy protection in July, WorldCom said it lost $429 million in July and August, while recording revenue of about $4.9 billion in that period. Those figures would seem to support the argument for prudence.
The report of such a big loss might be expected to cheer WorldCom's competitors. But it could also undermine the arguments by the Bell companies and their allies that the government ought to place restrictions on WorldCom if it emerges from bankruptcy protection with most or all of its $42 billion debt wiped off the books.
Without the need to service a debt load comparable to those of its competitors, the new WorldCom could afford to cut prices -- particularly in lucrative business markets -- far below those of other carriers, the Bells say.
"We have a problem with companies that use bankruptcy as a way of cleansing themselves of all their sins and then driving prices down," Ivan G. Seidenberg, chief executive of Verizon Communications, the nation's biggest local phone company, said at an industry conference in Washington yesterday.
In an interview yesterday, Edward E. Whitacre Jr., the chairman of SBC, the No. 2 local service carrier, made a similar case, saying the terms of WorldCom's emergence would have "huge implications for the industry and the people we serve."
John W. Sidgmore, WorldCom's chief executive, said in an interview yesterday that the company would have no motivation to keep losing money. "We have been a competitive business from the beginning and we will continue to be competitive in the future," Mr. Sidgmore said, "but we don't want to start a price war." 
That could have implications for the bargains that millions of consumers and business callers have been enjoying in recent years. While the collapse of stock prices and the loss of jobs in the telecommunications industry has been devastating to investors and employees, for many customers the telecommunications boom of the 1990's has never ended.
As recently as a decade ago, consumer long-distance rates of 35 cents a minute or more were common. Now, astute consumers rarely pay more than 10 cents a minute.
More important, price deflation has been the rule for many years in corporate communications markets, where chief information officers learned to play AT&T off WorldCom, Sprint and Global Crossing, and to play all of them off the regional Bells.
In the 1990's, the much-discussed oversupply in the telecommunications industry was at least as much an oversupply of competing carriers as of raw communications capacity.
Now, according to senior executives across the industry, pricing is finally beginning to firm. (There are few public sources of pricing information for corporate communications because terms are often negotiated case by case basis.)
"In general we feel like prices have stabilized," David W. Dorman, AT&T's president, who is to become the next chairman and chief executive, said in an interview yesterday. Mr. Dorman said WorldCom appeared to be negotiating some especially good deals to retain some important corporate clients. But he added: "Prices have generally stabilized. We're not seeing any new lows, no crazy kinds of behavior."
These days, as Mr. Sidgmore helps lead WorldCom's search for a new chief executive, the company's future direction depends largely on its creditors.
There are essentially five constituencies among the creditors. One consists of companies (like the Bells) to which it owes about $9 billion for services rendered and goods provided. Another is the banks to which WorldCom owes some $2.65 billion. There are the holders of WorldCom's approximately $25.5 billion of its own bonds, as well as the holders of roughly $3.3 billion in bonds issued by MCI, which WorldCom acquired in 1998. And there are the holders of about $1.2 billion in bonds issued by Intermedia, a small communications company that WorldCom bought last year. (There are also holders of preferred stock, but they will essentially be wiped out along with the company's common shareholders.)
For now, the creditors are trying to piece together WorldCom's historical financial records -- the real numbers, not the cooked-books version -- to determine whether any of the three groups of bondholders are entitled to proportionally more of the company than the others.
But in a few months there will come calculations with more far-reaching consequences. The creditors will decide the total amount of debt that they will essentially reissue to the new WorldCom -- or, more likely, to the new MCI, as the company may be known, to distance itself from the tainted WorldCom brand.
For the creditors, the main choice is how much debt they want to retain. By keeping a lot of debt, they may have more confidence in getting at least a few pennies on their dollar. But a lean and relatively debt-free WorldCom might be a nimbler competitor, leaving more potential upside for holders of the revamped company's stock.
Whatever the final creditor calculus, a new WorldCom -- or MCI -- will probably emerge with far less debt than the $42 billion it now carries, and potentially none at all. It is the none-at-all end of the range that the regional Bell companies say they fear, because of the potential it could give WorldCom to engage in new rounds of destructive pricing.
Many analysts dismiss the Bells' argument as regulatory posturing. The analysts say that WorldCom's new shareholders (initially, at least, the current creditors) would demand a conservative approach to profitability rather than unprofitable growth. So would other investors who might consider buying stock in the new company, analysts say. 
WorldCom's loss-laden financial report yesterday may only strengthen the argument that it must focus on achieving profitability. Spokesmen for the WorldCom creditors' committee declined to comment.
"They have been pricing at an unprofitable level for the last three years and that's not sustainable," said Scott Cleland, chief executive of the Precursor Group, a communications research firm in Washington. "They used fraud to subsidize their price offerings. I doubt WorldCom will be a disruptive pricer, going forward. They can't afford to be. Their creditors want profit from their prices, not losses."
On condition of anonymity, two Wall Street telecommunications analysts concurred yesterday. They said that WorldCom's corporate customers were far more worried about service quality and reliability than about price.
Perhaps most surprising, WorldCom's chief rival, AT&T, also argues that the company will need to maintain some pricing discipline.
"It's not like there's this huge multibillion-dollar pricing advantage that they can immediately get," Mr. Dorman, AT&T's designated successor, said yesterday. "I don't think predatory pricing from someone who is not generating positive operating margins is a possibility. They will have more capital flexibility and that will be an advantage for them, but it doesn't translate immediately into some market-price advantage because there are other parts of the cost equation besides debt that they have to work on."
At WorldCom, Mr. Sidgmore sees the Bell companies' argument as a cynical ploy in support of their own long-running campaign for various forms of regulatory relief.
"Isn't it a little bit distasteful," he said, "that we have the Bells, a bunch of monopolies with multimillion-dollar lobbying budgets, running around complaining about a company coming out of bankruptcy?"

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: MOSCOW; 
Briefed Further on North Korea, the Russians, Openly Skeptical Before, Are Silent

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Oct. 22 

 BODY:
Under Secretary of State John R. Bolton briefed Russian officials for a second day today on American intelligence evidence that North Korea has an active nuclear weapons program. Russian officials, who indicated on Monday that the initial evidence fell short of proof, were silent after today's presentation. 
 But it was not clear whether that silence signaled continued skepticism or Russian agreement that the program -- which North Korea has admitted to the United States -- must face united opposition, as the White House has urged. 
 Mr. Bolton left Moscow today after talking with Foreign Minister Igor S. Ivanov about North Korea, Iran and other issues that are likely to dominate talks this weekend in Mexico between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Bush. 
The two presidents will meet during the so-called APEC summit meeting of Pacific economic powers. The United States has ruled out further talks with North Korea until it forswears its nuclear ambitions. For its part, North Korea has remained unyielding and even threatening in the face of American condemnation. 
"If the U.S. persists in its moves to pressure and stifle the D.P.R.K. by force, the latter will have no option but to take a tougher counter-action," the official Korean Central News Agency said today. 
In Moscow, Mr. Bolton presented the American case against North Korea to a range of senior Russian officials on Monday and today. Mr. Ivanov was said to have received the most detailed account of American intelligence conclusions about the North Korean weapons effort. 
An American diplomat who spoke on condition of anonymity said before that meeting that Russian officials "concur that what North Korea is doing in the uranium enrichment field amounts to a clear violation of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty" and a brace of other nuclear agreements. 
But Mr. Ivanov had nothing to say today about his meeting with Mr. Bolton. On Monday, his deputy, Georgi Mamedov, told reporters that Mr. Bolton's presentation to him had been unconvincing, and suggested that American belligerence toward North Korea and other nations in the so-called axis of evil were at the root of world tensions. "This information has come only from one source," he said of Mr. Bolton's briefing. "This is why we have to resort to all possibilities for gathering objective information." 
Russia's government does not always speak with one voice, and so it was not clear whether Mr. Mamedov's obvious skepticism reflected Kremlin policy or a personal view. Russia has openly disagreed with American characterizations of Iraq and Iran, the two other nations in Mr. Bush's "axis of evil," as would-be nuclear powers with potential ties to terrorists. 
The American diplomat expressed hope today that Mr. Putin would override any reservations among his advisers and use his personal relationship with President Kim Jong Il of North Korea to press for an end to the nation's nuclear program. 
North Korea has signed the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, which commits nations to forswear developing or spreading the technology to develop nuclear weapons, as well as a 1994 accord in which it agreed to abandon any nuclear ambitions in exchange for help with a civilian nuclear-reactor program. 
The United States has said it has unalloyed proof that North Korea has broken both pledges by trying to acquire sophisticated centrifuges used only to purify uranium for nuclear bombs. 
American officials say it admitted its program early this month after initially denying the American accusations. 
Since then, Korean officials have made no further public admission of their nuclear efforts. --------------------

Koreas Agree to a Dialogue
 (By The New York Times), SEOUL, South Korea, Wednesday, Oct. 23 -- North and South Korean negotiators agreed early today on a joint statement to cooperate "through dialogue" after the North rejected a demand that it pledge to abide by its previous commitments, including the 1994 Geneva framework under which the North was to abandon work on nuclear weapons.
The statement issued by the South Korean unification minister, Jeong Se Hyun, and the North Korean chief negotiator, Kim Ry Song, dropped the North's demand for the United States to stop "hostile" activities.

HEADLINE: BOOKS OF THE TIMES; 
California and Computers In Two Murder Mysteries

BYLINE:  By JANET MASLIN 

 BODY:
CHASING THE DIME
By Michael Connelly
371 pages. Little, Brown & Company. $25.95.

THE MURDER BOOK
By Jonathan Kellerman
408 pages. Ballantine Books. $26.95.
 Gumshoe tactics used to be clever enough for detective work. But increasingly these days typing plays a major role. In their sneaky new California murder mysteries, both Michael Connelly and Jonathan Kellerman make computer research and other technological dexterity integral parts of crime-solving and successfully use this to generate suspense. Mr. Connelly has even had the ingenuity to make a voice-activated lighting system vital to his book's combative denouement. 
 "Chasing the Dime" is steeped in up-to-the-minute science. Its main character -- a new one for the author best known for Harry Bosch -- is a research chemist named Henry Pierce. And he has done innovative work in the field of molecular computers and nanochips ("What if your computer was in the button of your shirt or the frame of your eyeglasses?"), to the point where his company is involved in a race to patent its breakthroughs. Henry has named the cutting-edge project Proteus, in honor of the white submarine in "Fantastic Voyage" that traveled through human bodies.
Speaking of bodies, "Chasing the Dime" also has a lot to do with cyberpornography. Henry has just moved into a new apartment in Santa Monica (after his breakup with the woman in his life, a weary and obligatory subplot for this genre) when he gets a phone call for someone else. And then another and another. It seems that his new number previously belonged to a hot number named Lilly, who advertised her availability as an escort for a service named L.A. Darlings. Presto: Henry begins investigating this outfit once he figures out that Lilly is permanently unavailable for future dates.
So Henry enters a world with disembodied sex for sale and criminal shadows lurking in the background. It is the same world that entraps Adam Sandler's character in the current film "Punch-Drunk Love," and it also snares this "longhaired surfer chemist." Mr. Connelly uses this accidental voyeurism as a way of hooking readers, but the scientific side of his book is actually sexier. While "City of Bones" had a more gripping mystery plot, "Chasing the Dime" creates a scarily high-tech brand of intrigue.
Mr. Connelly is a spare, expeditious storyteller with a natural talent for generating forward momentum. Mr. Kellerman takes a more detailed and photographic approach. In "The Murder Book" he creates quite the roller-coaster ride for fans of this genre, leading the reader through a panoramic range of West Coast settings and always stopping to catalog the particulars. Only occasionally (at a ranch redolent of "that curious maple syrup-and-rot tang of dried equine dung") do his descriptive powers get out of hand.
"The Murder Book" opens by providing Dr. Alex Delaware, the psychologically probing hero of many of the author's earlier novels, with a chilling gift for the man who has everything. Without explanation, a photo album full of crime-scene pictures arrives at his home. They are captioned unremarkably but guaranteed to prompt a reaction from the homicide detective Milo Sturgis, Alex's longtime friend and sidekick. The book reminds Milo of a grisly case (a murdered teenage girl who disappeared after a wild party in Bel Air) that he failed to solve 20 years ago. And of course it gets his goat.
While Milo cruises through Los Angeles and environs looking for witnesses with long memories, Alex boots up his computer and checks out search engines. "The Murder Book" makes amusing note of how much off-base information such methods can provide (stories on tourism and hundreds of resort links from the name "Playa del Sol," though Alex is trying to find out about a construction project). But it also finds Alex checking data much more thoroughly than he otherwise could, which gives "The Murder Book" a very knotty and abundant set of clues. Mr. Kellerman habitually has trouble streamlining the whodunit part of his mysteries, so the book unearths many acts of treachery. As Alex himself might observe, the author cannot commit.
Alex is having trouble with his longtime girlfriend, Robin, who rarely says anything interesting. She is out of town for almost all of the story (with "the two of us tripping through the calisthenics of separation," as Alex puts it). But as the book travels from Oxnard to Ojai to Santa Fe, from spoiled rich kids to sullen gang members, Alex pauses periodically to mope and worry about Robin. "She's really had it with my risk-taking behavior," he confides to a fellow therapist.
These digressions help turn Mr. Kellerman's latest into Milo's book. Milo is a big guy -- blunt, funny and no nonsense. The presence of a glamorous Vietnamese restaurant with a Bavarian chef in Los Angeles typically brings out his caustic acumen. ("Milo figured the patrons had never served in the military.") He is stung by the guilt-producing Murder Book, and it is his past that gets re-examined here. And the fact that Milo is gay (his partner is Rick, a doctor) and has had to conceal that fact during a long career with the Los Angeles Police Department adds another element of tension to the story. Mr. Kellerman has a way of succinctly noticing all sorts of bigotry in matters of race, gender, sexual orientation and economic caste that supply the underpinnings for his far-reaching story.

HEADLINE: Wary Companies Are Staying in the Muslim World 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL ALTMAN

 BODY:
Despite the apparently globe-girdling reach of Islamic terror groups, some of the biggest Western multinational corporations are holding fast to their investments in most Muslim countries.
 Though foreign investment is falling in countries where terrorists have struck, other predominantly Muslim countries with a good record of controlling violence have experienced little or no diminution. 
 Most developing countries, including those with large Muslim populations, badly need foreign investment to help develop modern industries and service sectors. Such investment has been depressed in recent years by the global economic slowdown. But now, as the worst of the slowdown appears to have passed, the threat of terrorism is continuing to hamper foreign economic engagement in some countries. 
Even before the devastating attack in Bali, investment in Indonesia was declining as the country's problems with terror groups received more attention. In the first nine months of 2002, the country attracted 780 investment projects worth $5.4 billion, compared with 1,017 projects worth $6.1 billion in the period in 2001, according to the country's Investment Coordinating Board.
Contrast that experience with nearby Malaysia, half of whose territory lies on Kalimantan, an island it shares with Indonesia and Brunei. About 60 percent of Malaysia's population is Muslim, according to estimates by the State Department. Yet it is light-years distant from Indonesia's troubles in the eyes of multinational companies and foreign portfolio managers.
"Being a Muslim country has not been a deterrent" to investment, said Rafidah Aziz, the minister of international trade and industry in Malaysia, in an interview last week. "We have become the kind of Muslim country that people do not fear."
On Sept. 11, 2002, the United States closed its embassy in Malaysia -- along with those in Cambodia, Indonesia and Vietnam -- after officials cited "credible and specific" threats of terrorism. Yet at virtually the same time, all three major credit-rating agencies raised their ratings of Malaysia's unsecured foreign-currency debt, a vote of confidence.
Foreign investment in Malaysia has not suffered; rather, it has risen as the country has come to be seen as a more affordable alternative to Singapore, Ms. Aziz said.
Central Asia has also been called a potential hotbed of terrorist activity. Some terrorists from Al Qaeda who trained in Afghanistan may have come from nearby Uzbekistan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan, and may have slipped back there since the Taliban's fall. But terrorism and the fear of it have not affected all the region's largely Muslim countries.
"In countries like Kazakhstan and Azerbaijan, domestic politics is much more important for the way foreign investment works out," said Alexander G. Zaslavsky, director of consulting at the Eurasia Group, a political consulting firm. These resource-rich countries, he said, "have much more pressing issues than those of religious conflict."
More than one-third of Kazakhstan's foreign investment has come from the United States, and that trend shows no signs of slowing. Much of the investment has been in oil, but earlier this month, the two countries began a program to make more of American investors' money available to small- and medium-size businesses in Kazakhstan.
"Relationships with companies have been strong for the past 10 years," said Roman Vassilenko, press secretary at Kazakhstan's embassy in Washington. "They have seen no change whatsoever in the past year. They have even strengthened."
Even in the countries abutting Afghanistan and Pakistan that have not yet received much money from the West, Mr. Zaslavsky said, the business climate may be improved by the new presence of American armed forces. "It brings legitimacy to the regimes," he said. "It changes the perception, perhaps, of foreign investors as well -- it conveys the image of greater stability."
Among most big multinationals, the mantra is to stay the course, with a bit of extra care. "We have certainly changed security procedures, but not slowed down any investments," David J. O'Reilly, chairman and chief executive of ChevronTexaco, said in an interview last week. "You can't be deterred from your ambition by one set of events." ChevronTexaco has big stakes in oil fields in West Africa and Indonesia.
Coca-Cola has significant investments in more than a dozen Muslim countries in the Middle East, Southeast Asia and Central Asia. The company has not canceled or delayed any investment plans in these countries, said Kari Bjorhus, a spokesman. The same goes for Sara Lee, which operates divisions in Malaysia and elsewhere in Asia, said Hillary Sterling, a spokeswoman.
In the view of General Motors, a big Muslim population is not enough, by itself, to suggest the presence of a radical fringe or a major risk of terror.
"I don't think whether a region or a country is predominantly Muslim or otherwise is even a criterion for us," said Toni Simonetti, a spokeswoman for the company, which has both a sales subsidiary and an assembly plant in Indonesia. "We look at things like the stability of a country, the merits of a proposal, the needs of our business."
Nevertheless, Ms. Simonetti said, General Motors assesses the security situation of its far-flung divisions just about every day. "To the extent that there are political risks to conducting business, we go into that with open eyes," she said.
Though multinationals with extensive experience investing abroad appear undaunted, small companies have begun to seek extra assurances that their investments will be safe.
Ms. Aziz regularly travels abroad to drum up investment. In meetings during her latest trip to the United States, she said, "there would be one odd question out of one local guy, who has never stepped out of his state," about security. In such cases, she said, she would try to ease the potential investor's jitters by explaining Malaysia's situation.
"Then," she said, "I tell them, 'If you're still worried, you'd better not go. It's not good for your health!' "

GRAPHIC: Photo: The turbine room at a hydroelectric plant in Kazakhstan operated by AES, a global energy company based in Virginia. Western companies have continued to invest in Muslim countries with stable governments. (Staton R. Winter for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Historians Are Doing the Mambo; 
After Decades, Latin Jazz Develops Its Own Academic Canon

BYLINE:  By BEN RATLIFF 

 BODY:
By one measure, the invention of Latin jazz could be dated to 1940, when Machito Grillo started his band, the Afro-Cubans, here in New York City. Before long he would be famous for his glorious combinations of jazz harmony and phrasing with Cuban percussion. By another, it could go back farther, to W. C. Handy's composing "St. Louis Blues" over a habanera rhythm. Or to Louis Armstrong's recorded version of "El Manisero" ("The Peanut Vendor"). Or to the early years of the century in New Orleans, when Cuban and African and Creole cultures mixed so effectively. 
 Whatever the measure, until now there has never been any serious movement to study it, canonize it, historicize it. As recently as five years ago jazz bands were still playing a watery pseudo-clave rhythm and calling it Latin jazz. And the enormous amount of jazz scholarship activity since the 1970's -- biographies, discographies, documentary films, CD reissue work -- had no equivalent on the Latin-jazz side. Now several long-flowing streams of interest in Latin jazz are running together, and it seems that the form is becoming recognized as official culture in America, ready for heritage-building, specialized analysis and education. 
 Jazz at Lincoln Center has put its imprimatur on the music with its own in-house Afro-Latin Jazz Orchestra, led by the pianist and composer Arturo O'Farrill; it will play two concerts this weekend, tomorrow at Hostos Center for the Arts and Culture in the Bronx and on Saturday at Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts. And the Smithsonian Institution in Washington has taken note: a traveling multimedia exhibition, "Latin Jazz: La Combinacion Perfecta," opened there last weekend and will go to 10 American cities by 2006. (In conjunction with the exhibition, Chronicle Books has published an illustrated companion volume, and Smithsonian Folkways has released a CD anthology of Latin Jazz.) Another show on the local roots of Latin music is currently at the Museum of the City of New York. 
The parallel rise of Latin jazz as an increasingly bigger part of college-level jazz education also suggests that America is finally beginning to come to grips with a music that has been around for longer than most have noticed. "I think there's a practical reason for why this is happening," said Mr. O'Farrill, who is the son of the venerated Chico O'Farrill. (The elder O'Farrill, who died last year, composed long-form works like "The Afro-Cuban Jazz Suite" and "The Aztec Suite," both basic to the repertory of the Lincoln Center group.) "As we see in popular culture with the acceptance of Jennifer Lopez and Ricky Martin," he continued, "the Latino population is a heavy demographic, and people in positions of money and power are realizing that this is an economic force to be reckoned with." 
But, Mr. O'Farrill said, the vision of Wynton Marsalis, artistic director of Jazz at Lincoln Center, was central to the creation of the orchestra.
"Wynton asked me to come and rehearse the Lincoln Center Jazz Orchestra at its benefit concert last year," he said. "They were having trouble with some of the phrasing in one of the Latin pieces, and Wynton's wheels started turning. He understood then that you can't just put jazz players in a Latin band. The guys that play this music the best, I'm telling you, are the guys that really know how to phrase in clave." (Clave is the primary Afro-Cuban rhythm.) 
"It takes years just to stop being terrorized by the clave," he added. "And then if you listen to the music of Machito, Chico O'Farrill, Mario Bauza, this is music on a very high level. It's sophisticated rhythmically, but also in terms of harmony, orchestration, arrangement. It's on a par with the best of orchestral big-band jazz. Wynton understood that this is specialized music that's equal and worthy of investment in terms of bringing the highest-quality performance to it. In doing so, he's taken a very bold step." 
The Smithsonian's touring exhibition -- small, colorful and introductory, in the manner of exhibitions produced by Sites, the Smithsonian's traveling-show extension -- makes an effort to get the terms right and to have the audience see Latin jazz in almost participatory terms. One section, complete with pillows on the floor, is dedicated to a video of the drummer and educator Bobby Sanabria demonstrating aspects of the clave rhythm; there are bongos, shekeres, clave sticks and guiros available for anyone to play along. 
The exhibition is not collection based, because Sites has no collections; aside from a 20-minute video on the evolution of Latin jazz and some display cases holding items like Tito Puente's set of timbales, much of the space is given over to tall, conga-shaped kiosks with texts printed on them. Some of that material draws on the Smithsonian's jazz oral history project.
Raul Fernandez, curator of the exhibition, conducted some of those interviews -- traveling to Stockholm, for instance, to speak with the great Cuban pianist Bebo Valdes. Mr. Fernandez sees the exhibition as part of a growing movement to preserve the history of Latin jazz. "When it comes to jazz, I've read biographies dating back to the 1930's with big repositories of photographs and documents," he said. "In Latin jazz there are few collections of significance."
The practical challenges Mr. Fernandez encountered during four years of work on the exhibition taught him, he said, that conservation shapes history. "We met people who said, 'I used to have this instrument, but I didn't know it was important, so I threw it away.' " Other sources had extensive collections of film and photographs, but didn't know their provenance, and the film was of dubious quality.
The short film in the exhibition -- which includes brief but tantalizing scenes of the bandleaders Perez Prado and Mongo Santamaria -- features Mr. Sanabria as one of its chief narrators; Mr. Sanabria also co-produced "The Palladium: Where Mambo Was King," a documentary for the Bravo channel that was first broadcast last June. 
It's noteworthy that Latin jazz is breaking into America's big cultural institutions, but it is perhaps even more meaningful that it is becoming a greater part of college jazz education. Jazz programs in universities all over the country are starting Latin-jazz ensembles. 
Justin DiCioccio, assistant dean at the Manhattan School of Music in New York, created a full-fledged Afro-Cuban jazz curriculum within the jazz division when he started there four years ago. He began with an Afro-Cuban jazz orchestra, led by Mr. Sanabria, who also teaches a class on history and percussion in Latin music. (For the last decade Mr. Sanabria has filled a similar role with the Latin jazz program at the New School University.) The Manhattan program now has two different smaller Latin combos and provides private lessons. 
Some well-recognized young players in New York from Latin-music backgrounds -- John Benitez, Miguel Zenon, and Luis Bonilla, for example -- have enrolled at Manhattan to start or finish degrees; their presence enlivens and alters the school. 
"Up until recently even professional jazz musicians were not playing Latin jazz correctly," said Mr. DiCioccio, who is a drummer as well as an educator. "They just didn't understand the importance of the clave. The Latin music that most young people were coming up with was a fusion kind of thing -- a salsa approach, or a rock approach, as opposed to the deep tradition of the son clave and the rumba clave."
Latin jazz is a history of border-crossings between white, black and Latin cultures: Examples range from Handy's sojourn in Cuba to the Cuban conga player Chano Pozo's entry into the New York jazz world in 1947, to the jazz and mambo scenes in New York intermingling because the clubs for each kind of music were set close together. Mr. O'Farrill sees the possibility, and the need, for a new kind of border crossing, this time on the part of audiences. 
"I think it's important that the Latino community not be scared of institutional culture," he said. "It's been too long that we've allowed this kind of high culture-low culture mentality to permeate us." 
If the concern is about bringing in sufficient audiences to support Latin jazz in a high-culture setting, however, there should be little to worry about. All of Jazz at Lincoln Center's 21 Latin-jazz-themed concerts since 1991 have sold out. "It's like it was in the 50's again," said Chris Washburne, a trombonist professor of music at Columbia. "The jazz record companies start saying, 'All right, you're a jazz musician, jazz isn't selling, do a Latin album.' And I've played in Latin-music concerts at both Lincoln Center and Carnegie that have sold out. The thing is this: Latino culture in general supports music. It's part of Latino society."

HEADLINE: Peso's Devaluation Gives Argentina Cost Advantages 

BYLINE:  By TONY SMITH

DATELINE: BUENOS AIRES 

 BODY:
Over the last six months, Andres Prieto, president of the Argentine subsidiary of Oracle, has been doing something highly unexpected here: hiring, not firing.
 Admittedly, it has been only 20 software technicians so far, but Oracle has plans to take on another 100 in 2003. 
 The drastic devaluation of the peso in January is finally giving the country's service sectors and some of its export industries a cost advantage over even the most competitive of their competitors.
And that, along with other tentative signals like a rise in industrial production, a growing trade surplus and a partial relaxation of the yearlong freeze on savings account balances, is giving some analysts hope that the economy is finally bottoming out after a four-year slump. 
During the recession, in which the economy has contracted by more than a fifth, the long-suffering Argentines have watched in horror as even their once-proud middle class has slid relentlessly toward poverty, their savings have lain frozen in the banks and the Argentine peso, once pegged at one to the dollar, has lost almost three-fourths of its value.
"Today in terms of price-quality, we are very competitive with India," Mr. Prieto said. "Just a year ago, the costs of developing software projects in Argentina were prohibitive." 
According to Jorge Cassino, president of a trade association for Argentine software companies, Argentina's programmers, who have a reputation for being creative, exacting, well educated and bilingual, cost $10 to $15 an hour -- $5 an hour less than in India and only 10 to 15 percent of what their American counterparts cost.
"That means a U.S. company can make huge savings by farming out programming to an Argentine company," Mr. Cassino said.
Oracle can use the help -- it has had six consecutive quarters of falling sales and profit margins -- and it has been expanding the use it makes of other Latin American units as well, starting projects in Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Paraguay. 
According to Pedro Lacoste, a partner at APL Economia consultants in Buenos Aires, the weak Argentine peso is also helping a wide range of other industries, including agribusiness, which accounts for 70 percent of Argentina's exports; steel and aluminum; advertising; and film production.
Mr. Lacoste says the renewed activity in these areas is a first sign that an economic rebound is on the way.
After shrinking by 22 percent in the last four years, more than it did during World War I and the Great Depression, Argentina's economy appears to be stabilizing. By September, the trade surplus had surged to $11 billion, and fears that the peso's loss of value would reignite hyperinflation have ebbed, largely because wages have effectively been frozen in peso terms, keeping a tight lid on consumer spending.
Inflation is running at about 1.5 percent a month, according to Exotix Ltd., a London-based emerging markets brokerage firm -- a manageable rate by Latin American standards. While industrial output has not caught back up to where it was before the devaluation, it has climbed every month for the last six, including a 2.7 percent jump in August.
"The economy hit bottom three or four months ago," Mr. Lacoste said. "The question now is just when and by how much it will rebound."
That, he said, very much depends on politics. Eduardo Duhalde, the caretaker president since January, has called for elections in March, and his successor is to take over in May. But Mr. Lacoste and others say elections should be held earlier, as the current government has no popular mandate to tackle the country's most urgent problems.
Unemployment has hit a record high of 24 percent, and more than half of the population is living below the poverty line, which the government defines as enough income to afford basic food and housing. For a family of four, that level is about 400 pesos ($108.25) a month.
To unlock the economy's potential, the banking system must be restructured and foreign debts renegotiated, economists and analysts say. 
Contracts with Argentina's utilities, most of them foreign-owned, must also be reworked. They have generally not been allowed to raise their rates for electricity, gas, water and telephone service to take account of the peso's fall in value, but their debts are still largely owed in dollars. 
But a cheap peso works to the double advantage of some sectors in Argentina. Not only is labor cheaper now, but some industries are particularly well equipped, thanks to a decade when the peso's parity with the dollar made importing capital goods affordable.
The film industry, for example, is booming.
Austral Films, a Buenos Aires studio, has opened representative offices in Los Angeles and Madrid to encourage film producers to shoot in Argentina.
Juan Jose Jusid, a partner in Austral and a film director, said his latest film, "Apasionados" ("In Love"), a $2.5 million Argentine-Spanish co-production shot last year, would now cost just $450,000 to make in Argentina. 
Austral has also begun producing commercials, because the demand is high and the government can no longer afford subsidies for feature film production.
Maria de la Paz Marino, Mr. Jusid's partner at Austral, said that during the years when the peso was worth one dollar, "the movie industry equipped itself with the latest technology and served its apprenticeship -- now we have years of know-how."
Across town, at a Chilean-owned postproduction house, Videocolor, the studios are buzzing with work on commercials shot in Argentina for Renault, Coca-Cola, Sony, Budweiser and Toyota.
About 25 commercials a month are being produced for export, five times last year's levels, according to Videocolor's commercial manager, Jose Luis Cabrera. "We must make the most of it, because to keep up this level of technology you have to invest, and all that equipment must be bought in dollars," Mr. Cabrera said. "In five years, this technology we have will become obsolete."
What are the chances Argentina's economy will pick up again soon?
"Over the last month I have received more visits from foreign private equity funds than in the rest of the year," Mr. Lacoste said. "And it's not simply because it's springtime in Buenos Aires."
But he acknowledges that Argentina's fate depends on being able to successfully conclude drawn-out negotiations with the International Monetary Fund for a rescue package.
With $8 billion in payments to multilateral lenders like the World Bank coming due before May, there may be as little as $1.5 billion left in the central bank's reserve vaults when the next president takes office.
In addition, if the global economy continues to slow and neighboring Brazil slips into a widely feared debt crisis of its own after its presidential election runoff on Sunday "risk aversion to the region would undoubtedly grow," Mr. Lacoste said.
"Argentina will have to learn to 'vivir con lo nuestro' -- live with what we've got," he said. "I wouldn't recommend it, but we may have no option."

HEADLINE: Toronto Exchange Is Still Set to Go Public 

BYLINE:  By BERNARD SIMON

DATELINE: TORONTO, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
South of the border, the NASD has yet to go ahead with its planned public offering for the battered Nasdaq stock market. And the New York Stock Exchange, which had talked about demutualizing in the late 1990's, currently has no plans to list itself. But in Canada, TSX Inc., the holding company for the Toronto Stock Exchange, is moving forward with plans to become a public company around mid-November.
 The Toronto exchange, which will celebrate its 150th anniversary on Thursday, is plowing through the same choppy waters as the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq, with new listings down sharply and trading activity stagnating. Canada's benchmark S&P/TSX composite index is down around 18 percent this year, as the New York Stock Exchange composite has dropped 19 percent and the Nasdaq has slid 32 percent. 
 While the brokerage firms that are the Toronto exchange's present shareholders initially expected to price the stock issue at 17 to 23 Canadian dollars, for a total of 371 million to 531 million Canadian dollars ($236 million to $338.6 million), the price target was recently lowered to 14 to 17 Canadian dollars.
Still, Barbara Stymiest, TSX's chief executive, said in a recent interview that she was undeterred by the markets' turbulence. Canada's growing economy and the sophistication of the country's financial markets should lure investors, she said.
But besides volatile markets, the Toronto exchange faces the challenge that dozens of its most heavily traded stocks are also listed on United States exchanges, siphoning sizable trading volume.
"We have both the advantages and disadvantages of being next to a market that's 20 times our size," said Joe J. Oliver, president of the Investment Dealers Association in Toronto, which represents Canada's brokerage industry.
The Toronto exchange's 3,841 listed companies -- two-thirds of which trade on a separate TSX Venture Exchange, a market for small, more speculative stocks -- have a market value of slightly over 1 trillion Canadian dollars ($635 billion).
Despite the difficult investment climate, TSX's revenues from listing and trading fees and other services rose to 107.2 million Canadian dollars in the six months ended June 30, up 24 percent from the period last year. Earnings almost doubled, to 27.6 million Canadian dollars.
Holders of 21.6 million shares of TSX, or 64 percent of the total, have indicated that they will sell their stock. No single shareholder will be allowed to own more than 10 percent of the exchange, though TSX has left the door open for an approved "strategic investor" to acquire a bigger stake later on.
With ownership of the exchange set to pass from a cozy club of brokerage firms to a wide circle of institutional and individual shareholders, "we'll be completely free to focus on our sole objective, which is to build a stronger Canadian capital market," Ms. Stymiest said.
Some investors, however, were less sanguine than Ms. Stymiest about the offering's prospects.
Donald Coxe, chairman of Harris Investment Management, a Chicago-based unit of the Bank of Montreal, said that "what you're buying is something most Canadians don't believe in." Still, he added "because of Nasdaq's collapse, there is room for another stock exchange."
And Douglas Davis, president of Davis-Rea Ltd., a Toronto portfolio manager, said, "I'm not knocked out by it." With many of the exchange's existing shareholders included in the underwriting syndicate, Mr. Davis said the coming stock offering was likely to be priced to favor sellers rather than buyers. "It will favor investors only if the business thrives and grows," he added. "It depends whether the market turns."
Mr. Davis said he was also concerned about growing competition for listings of Canadian stocks and trading in their shares, both from American exchanges and from electronic trading services.
Seventy-eight companies now have listings on both the TSX and the Big Board, including the country's biggest banks; natural resource giants like Alcan and Barrick Gold ; and the five companies spun off by the breakup of Canadian Pacific.
Another 71 Canadian companies are "interlisted" on the Nasdaq and 29 on the American Stock Exchange, which is also owned by the NASD. As Mr. Davis sees it, if trading on private electronic networks grows, "the TSX's business will have found its long-term weakness."
Ms. Stymiest, who described the competition for listings as a "battleground," said the Toronto exchange still accounted for an average of 60 percent of trades in these interlisted stocks. "We continue to win," she said. "We have the most liquid market." The TSX, she added, is "faster, better and cheaper than our competition."
The exchange is also working on a plan to help Canadian and European brokers shop around for American stocks among the various stock exchanges and electronic trading systems in the United States. "The brokers would be assured that clients are getting the best price," said Richard Nesbitt, president of the TSX Markets unit.
Some experts, however, see the Toronto exchange's future mainly as a kind of natural resources version of the technology-heavy Nasdaq.
Mining, oil and gas stocks now make up 28 percent of the main Toronto board's listings and 48 percent of listings on the TSX Venture Exchange.
During the dot-com boom, said Mr. Coxe of Harris Investment Management, the TSX "was trying to constitute itself as an alternative to Nasdaq.
"But now that's all flamed out. It's going back to rocks and trees that make Canada unique," he continued.
According to Mr. Oliver of the Investment Dealers Association, "the natural resource area has been one in which Americans have included the Canadian marketplace in their thinking." More than half the world's publicly traded miners already trade in Toronto.
The TSX also hopes to attract more business by ploughing its own furrow in the area of corporate governance. While the New York Stock Exchange has proposed rigorous new standards and disclosure requirements in the wake of the Enron and other corporate scandals, Ms. Stymiest says that voluntary guidelines and the discipline of the market are more effective in preventing such abuses.
"What seems softer is in fact tougher," Ms. Stymiest said in a recent speech. "When people see a guideline, their usual focus seems to be -- not how to get around it -- but whether to do it." If they decide not to follow the guideline, "the tough part is explaining why," she said. If companies do comply, the view is that "they might as well do it right."
On the other hand, "when people see a rule, they seem to look for ways to comply that will have the least impact on what they're already doing," Ms. Stymiest said. "The rule becomes the maximum that's required, rather than the maximum that's possible."

CORRECTION-DATE: October 26, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in World Business on Thursday about a planned stock offering by TSX, parent of the Toronto Stock Exchange, included an incorrect price projection supplied by the company. In its revised prospectus, TSX projected an offering price of 17 to 19 Canadian dollars a share, not 14 to 17.

HEADLINE: Turkish Government Takes Steps to Shut Popular Islamic Party 

BYLINE:  By IAN FISHER 

DATELINE: ISTANBUL, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Just 10 days before national elections, Turkey's chief prosecutor moved today to outlaw the most popular political party, a moderate Islamic group whose leader had already been barred from running for office. 
 The case seemed unlikely to be decided before the elections, which take place on Nov. 3 -- and the more immediate question was whether the legal troubles of the beleaguered party, called Justice and Development, would hurt its standing at the polls. Public opinion surveys show it with roughly 30 percent of the vote, far ahead of its nearest competitor. 
 "I say this clearly: this closure case will in no way damage our party," said its chairman, Recep Tayyip Erdogan, the popular former Istanbul mayor who founded the party less than a year ago. He called the move to shut down the party "another heavy blow to Turkish democracy."
Last month, the nation's highest electoral board disqualified Mr. Erdogan from running because of a conviction in 1998 for reading a poem that a court said incited religious hatred.
The nation's avowedly secular political leadership and business community view him with deep suspicion, at a time when Turkey's long relationship with the United States is especially important because of the Bush administration's vows to disarm Iraq, Turkey's neighbor to the southeast. 
Mr. Erdogan, 48, who had stood a good chance of becoming Turkey's next prime minister, denies that his party espouses an Islamic agenda.
Despite Mr. Erdogan's roots in political Islam, he staged his political comeback over the last year with a carefully thought out, moderate, pro-Western image. 
Though barred last month from running, Mr. Erdogan retained the title of party chairman. 
That appeared to be the basis for the court case filed today: Sabih Kanadoglu, the chief prosecutor, said in a statement carried by the Anatolian news agency that the party had not complied fully with a court decision barring Mr. Erdogan from being a founding member of the party.
Mr. Kanadoglu was quoted as saying that the party was trying to "deceive the law" by allowing Mr. Erdogan to remain as chairman. 
Murat Mercan, a party spokesman, said tonight that he believed that the ruling would only anger Turkish voters, who polls show are disenchanted with most mainstream political leaders because of corruption and the nation's poor economic performance. 
"Turkish people, after all, would not find this case a reasonable one," Mr. Mercan said. "Therefore it may even increase votes for the party."
Mr. Erdogan's troubles date to his recital of a poem during a political speech in 1997 while mayor.
"The mosques are our bayonets, the domes our helmets and the believers our soldiers," he said at the time.
A court ruled that the words incited religious hatred and sentenced Mr. Erdogan to prison for 10 months, stripped him of his office and barred him from politics. He served four months in 1999.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Strength in Semiconductor Shares Leads a Broad Rally

BYLINE:  By Reuters 

 BODY:
Stocks steamed ahead yesterday, shaking off an earlier decline, as investors snatched up companies like Intel on budding hopes for a sustainable upswing in the market.
 "There is a lot of cash out there, and I think the market acts like a million bucks," said Michael Murphy, head of equity trading at Wachovia Securities. "People are buying on the dips and putting some money to work." 
 The market languished in negative ground much of the session before rallying late in the day. Investors are debating whether the rise is a short-lived rally in a bear market or the start of a new bull run. 
"There's a great deal of apprehension, and there's a great deal of hope," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany. "You have an intersection between hope that the rally will continue and apprehension that this is another false start. The atmosphere seems to be thick with that conflict."
Intel, a Dow component and a Nasdaq heavyweight, shot up almost 7 percent and led the semiconductor sector higher after it fell a day ago on a bleak forecast from Texas Instruments. Other technology giants, including Microsoft, added to the upward momentum.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 27.43 points, or 2.12 percent, to 1,320.23, after losing more than 1 percent earlier. It hit its highest close since Aug. 29.
The blue-chip Dow Jones industrial average advanced 44.11 points, or 0.52 percent, to 8,494.27, after dropping more than 1.8 percent earlier. The broad Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 5.98 points, or 0.67 percent, to 896.14.
Advancing stocks beat declining stocks by a ratio of 5 to 3 on the New York Stock Exchange and Nasdaq. More than 1.61 billion shares changed hands on the Big Board and more than 1.59 billion shares on Nasdaq in moderate trading.
The market shrugged off mixed economic readings. The Federal Reserve's beige book report, an anecdotal survey showed the economy was in the doldrums in the early autumn, held back by a listless job market and soft retail sales.
But Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sounded an upbeat note in a speech earlier in the day. He said that most of the surge in productivity rates since the mid-1990's appeared likely to remain intact in coming years.
Intel jumped $1.04, to $16.16. There were gains for other companies involved in chips, as Applied Materials soared $1.32, or 10 percent, to $14.41, and KLA-Tencor rose $2.18, or 7 percent, to $32.71.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange semiconductor index climbed 7.84 percent after a drop of more than 6 percent the day before.
Other technology shares rose. Microsoft climbed $1.53, or almost 3 percent, to $53.20. Hewlett-Packard gained 51 cents, or more than 3 percent, to $14.39. Both stocks helped lift the Dow. 
SBC Communications emerged as the big loser on the Dow, falling $1.20, or more than 4 percent, to $25.85. Morgan Stanley downgraded the Baby Bell group of local telephone companies, including SBC, citing the recent rally in the sector's stock prices. --------------------

Treasury Prices Rise
(By Bloomberg News) -- Treasuries rose yesterday as declines in sales at companies like Xerox and Eli Lilly suggested that the economic expansion remained weak.
Yesterday, the Treasury priced $27 billion of new two-year notes to yield 2.14 percent. In when-issued trading by late in the day, the yield had increased to 2.16 percent.
The current-issue two-year note was up 3/32 , to 99 16/32 , yielding 2.14 percent, down from 2.19 percent on Tuesday.
The 10-year note rose 8/32 , to 101 6/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 4.23 percent from 4.26 percent. The 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 103 8/32 ; its yield was unchanged.

HEADLINE: 7th Victim Dies In Baltimore Arson Tied to Drug Fight 

BYLINE:  By The New York Times 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
An East Baltimore man who was badly burned in an arson fire that killed his wife and five of her children died today.
 The man, Carnell Dawson Sr., 43, had been the sole survivor of the Oct. 16 fire, which the authorities said was set in retaliation for his wife's repeated confrontations with drug dealers outside the family's home. 
 Mr. Dawson, who had jumped from a second-floor window to escape the flames, died this afternoon at Johns Hopkins Bayview Medical Center in Baltimore. 
Darrell L. Brooks, a 21-year-old who once worked as a clerk for the Baltimore City Council and lived a few doors from the Dawsons, has been arrested. The police said Mr. Brooks kicked in the door of the Dawsons' home after 2 a.m., poured out gasoline and ignited the fire. He was being held without bond on first-degree murder, arson and numerous other charges.
Mr. Dawson's death came on the eve of a funeral for his wife, Angela M. Dawson, 36, and five of her children, ages 8 to 14. Mrs. Dawson also had an 18-year-old daughter who did not live at the house.
After the fire, in tense meetings and at rallies and vigils attended by hundreds of people, ministers and residents called on the city to increase police patrols in the neighborhood, improve its schools and housing and strengthen drug treatment, recreation and economic development efforts.
On Monday, Baltimore's mayor, Martin O'Malley, said Maryland had agreed to provide more than 100 state troopers to patrol city thoroughfares, hire 75 more parole officers and provide more jail space to help the city fight drug-related violence. Mr. O'Malley said he was also pushing for more protection of those who report drug dealing.

HEADLINE: 2 Yugoslav Aides Are Fired for Sales of Fighter-Jet Parts to Iraq 

BYLINE:  By DANIEL SIMPSON 

DATELINE: BELGRADE, Serbia, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Yugoslavia has fired a senior military official and the director of the state trading company Yugoimport as a result of NATO's accusations that a Bosnian Serb company exported military hardware to Iraq via Belgrade.
 Officials in Bosnia and Herzegovina, Yugoslavia and the United States have released few firm details about the case, which appears to be focus on the violation of the United Nations arms embargo rather than the military significance of any sales. 
 After searching the offices of Orao, a state-owned company in the semiautonomous Serbian republic within Bosnia, NATO peacekeeping troops said on Tuesday that they had found proof of ongoing exports to Baghdad. 
The American Embassy in Bosnia accused Orao last month of selling spare parts and services to Iraq for its Soviet-era MIG-21 warplanes, continuing a longstanding trade that began when Bosnia was a republic in a larger, socialist Yugoslavia.
But the company, which in the 1980's was part of a Yugoslav industry that armed Iraq against Iran (as did companies in the United States, Britain and France), does not appear to have heeded the warning.
When NATO soldiers raided the Orao factory, they found a document dated Sept. 25 telling five staff members to remain in Iraq and remove all traces of the company's involvement there, diplomats in Bosnia said.
Military analysts said that even if the spare parts kept aging Iraqi aircraft in good condition, they would hardly help Saddam Hussein's military defend against the high-technology weapons that the United States could deploy.
One Western diplomat said the only significant question was whether assistance from Orao was decisive in helping Iraq to put antiquated planes in the sky at all.
"Given that Saddam has had 10 years of sanctions, how does he keep his old equipment going?" the diplomat asked. "If Orao is sending in spare parts, they would be very useful in keeping his decrepit air force flying."
But the United States has not specified whether this is part of its accusation.
"The U.S. expects the relevant authorities in Bosnia and Herzegovina, and Yugoslavia, to undertake the necessary steps to immediately halt any ongoing cooperation with Iraq, to conduct a thorough investigation and to hold accountable those responsible," said the State Department spokesman, Richard A. Boucher.
Yugoslavia's response was immediate, as it hopes next month to be admitted as a junior partner in NATO, the first step for aspiring members of the alliance.
After a special meeting this evening, the government dismissed Ivan Djokic, a deputy defense minister, and Jovan Cekovic, the head of Yugoimport, declaring them ultimately responsible for the shipments.
"Regardless of how significant this case is," a Yugoslav government official said, "we have to demonstrate our complete rejection of any cooperation with Iraq at this time. We need American support so we have to act decisively."

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: ISLAMISTS; 
U.S. Labels Indonesian Faction as Terrorist

BYLINE:  By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: JAKARTA, Indonesia, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
The United States today formally declared a Southeast Asian radical Islamic group suspected by the Bush administration of involvement in the Bali bombing to be a foreign terrorist organization.
 In addition, Australia and the United States called for the group, Jemaah Islamiyah, to be added to the United Nations list of formally declared terrorist organizations. 
 Under pressure from the Americans and the Australians, the Indonesian government, which as recently as two weeks ago said the group did not exist in its country, expressed support for having the group placed on the United Nations list.
The leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, an Indonesian cleric, Abu Bakar Bashir, was arrested last weekend at his hospital bed in his home city, Solo. 
Western governments and Indonesia's Asian neighbors viewed the move by Indonesia today as a welcome change of heart by the government of President Megawati Sukarnoputri. In the immediate aftermath of the bombing on the Indonesian island of Bali on Oct. 12, which killed more than 180 people, senior officials here hesitated to label the group a terrorist organization, but they slowly moved in that direction, finally doing so today in a letter to the United Nations.
The United States and Indonesia's neighbors -- Australia, Singapore, Malaysia and the Philippines -- have argued for some time that Jemaah Islamiyah was linked to Al Qaeda.
At the United Nations today, Australia submitted information outlining the group's history and its connection to attacks in Indonesia before the Bali bombing, as well as a plan to blow up the American Embassies in Singapore and Malaysia.
The Indonesian government's letter supports the Australian request. The United States and Indonesia's key Asian neighbors also backed the Australian initiative. Malaysia is expected to do so on Thursday.
"The significance is political," a Western diplomat said of Indonesia's move. "It is the first time that Indonesia has publicly associated itself with a Western initiative" on the question of terror. The practical effects of the United Nations listing, and the separate designation by the United States, will probably be minimal, the diplomat said. Officially, the designations impose financial and travel sanctions on the group, but Western governments have little influence on the group's finances.
The Bush administration, poised for a month to declare the group a terrorist organization, waited until Indonesia recognized its serious nature. The administration made its designation under Executive Order 13224, which gives the government broad authority to freeze assets held by terrorist organizations and their members in the United States. 
Much of the background information on Jemaah Islamiyah that the United States and Australia used for declaring it a terrorist organization came from the interrogation by the Central Intelligence Agency of a Qaeda operative, Omar al-Faruq.
Mr. Faruq told his interrogators that Mr. Bashir had provided money, explosives and men for terrorist acts including a plan to blow up the American embassies here and in Malaysia and Singapore in December 2001, American officials said.
Mr. Faruq also alerted his interrogators to a plan, which he said Mr. Bashir had helped to organize, to attack the American embassies here and in Malaysia on the first anniversary of the Sept. 11 attack on the World Trade Center, the American officials said.
Mr. Bashir, 64, who is called the intellectual leader of Jemaah Islamiyah, has maintained that he was not involved in terrorist activities and has blamed the United States for the Bali blast. From his hospital bed he issued what he called an oath on Tuesday in which he repeated his previous denials of terrorist links.
Western intelligence officials describe the operational head of the group, an Indonesian known as Hambali, or Riduan Isamuddin, 36, as an acolyte of Mr. Bashir. Despite efforts of various intelligence agencies to find Hambali, his whereabouts are unknown, they said.
Indonesian investigators said today that they were looking for three male Indonesians as suspects in the Bali bombing.
"There are three sketches of possible suspects," said Made Mangku Pastika, the police chief in charge of the investigation in Bali. "They are males and Indonesians."
But Mr. Pastika said the men were not "official" suspects. He declined to give details about them for fear, he said, of harming the investigation.
State Department officials said Washington's announcement was not the result of any single event. Yet in a statement on Jemaah Islamiyah released today, Secretary of State Colin L. Powell specifically mentioned the Bali bombing.
"It is an example of how terrorism threatens democratic institutions, undermines economies and destabilizes regions," Secretary Powell said. "The world's response to these heinous crimes must be comprehensive and steadfast."
State Department officials said the group did little fund-raising in the United States. They also acknowledged that many terrorist groups had changed their operations to avoid having their assets frozen.
"This is not the be-all and end-all that's going to take them off the map," a senior State Department official said. "There's a lot of hard work ahead of us."
