HEADLINE: Mostly Sprawling and Warmer; 
Scientists Factor Land Use Into New Jersey's Climate

BYLINE:  By KIRK JOHNSON 

DATELINE: NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J. 

 BODY:
Scientists who study climate change can sometimes sound as if they have their heads in the clouds, with all the talk of invisible gases and nefarious hydrocarbons. Here, the search for atmospheric explanation is more down to earth. 
 A team of scientists at Rutgers University is looking at the land in New Jersey -- the transition from farms and forests to strip malls and subdivisions --for clues about the state's weather in the past, and how future development could affect the climate 100 years from now. 
 "How would our local weather be different with a different land use?" said Alan Robock, a professor of meteorology who is leading the multidisciplinary team of urban planners, historians and biologists. "That's the question." 
It's certainly not news that what's on the ground has an impact on what's in the sky. Deforestation in the Amazon has been studied for years in South America. Scientists have also shown how cities can often generate their own weather, creating so-called heat islands that spawn storms or change the paths of storms that come along. A parking lot absorbs heat differently, and channels water runoff differently, than a golf course.
But researchers say that the Rutgers study is one of the most ambitious attempts in the nation to pull all those strings together into one regional model. Half of the project looks back at how population growth and the sprawl of development over the last century have made for a different weather pattern. (An astonishingly detailed 17-foot-long map of New Jersey created in the 1880's figures in that part of the story, along with a hard-working graduate student.) The project's other half looks forward, at how the state's communities and residents could be affected by long-term climate change as a result of local land-use decisions in years to come.
The idea is not that New Jersey is an island, the researchers say, making its own little weather in splendid isolation, or that the global atmospheric system doesn't matter, but rather that in the end, weather and climate is like politics: it's all local. People and climate connect not in equations or theories, but on the ground. 
"Say you build a new 100-acre development and then you get 10 inches less precipitation than normal -- what will be the effect of that?" said Ying Fan Reinfelder, an assistant professor of geology who is working on the water-flow portion of the climate model. "What's the effect on ground water, and on stream flow? One side of this is climate; the other are man-made changes. We want to link them."
The Rutgers project, which is partly financed by the state's Department of Environmental Protection, has huge potential implications for the debate about open space and suburban sprawl, state officials and environmentalists say. If a housing development or a new shopping center can be scientifically linked to regionwide effects on water supply or weather, for example, then the battles over development and zoning that now seem purely local will be transformed. Regulators and courts will have a powerful new scientific tool, they say, as global warming becomes an aspect of urban planning becomes an aspect of politics.
"We've long known that better land-use practices reduce the costs of cleaning up our water and cleaning up our air," said Bradley M. Campbell, New Jersey's commissioner of environmental protection. "This work makes clear that good land-use policy is essential to stabilizing our long-term climate, as well."
Environmentalists say that the interconnections are the key, because the model is expected to show how residents many miles from a proposed development project can be affected by something they had perhaps never even heard of.
 Gov. James E. McGreevey struck a similar note on Tuesday, when he told a conference on so-called smart growth that state government -- from transportation to economic development -- would coordinate to fight the sprawl that he said threatened New Jersey's future. 
"A study like this can really change the way we think about land use in New Jersey," said Barbara L. Lawrence, executive director of New Jersey Future, a research and planning organization that focuses on development issues. "To the extent that science can document changes that go way beyond the border of a municipality, you can build a case for more regional planning."
Scientists who are leading the project say that their ultimate goal is to produce a kind of scientific tool kit that planners could use to envision, through the grinding out of a few hundred million equations, multiple versions of the state's future based on land-use and climate trends.
"Once we get our tools working, we can say, 'What if the future of New Jersey 100 years from now is this, or what if it's this other plan -- how will that affect the climate?' " Professor Robock said. "We'll be able to do those experiments in the next couple years and maybe that can give information to policy makers that will actually help them decide what the future development will be like."
But there are historical puzzles to be pondered, as well, and that's where the old map and the graduate student figure in.
In the 1880's, Prof. George H. Cook, who later had a college at Rutgers named after him -- which, in the fullness of time, came to employ Dr. Robock, among others -- led a team of topographers who crisscrossed New Jersey, recording and measuring as they went. In the annals of Victorian-era science, it was an amazing feat that few other states apparently ever attempted or completed. The Cook map -- really multiple maps created over nine years -- is 17 feet long when fully assembled and only a bit less accurate than a photograph taken from space.
Paul Stuart Wichansky's Ph.D. dissertation is aimed at figuring out how the changes since Professor Cook's time have altered the state's climate. More to the point, he'll be running the same weather through the two very different New Jerseys, really: the current state, captured by satellite, and the version Dr. Cook saw in the 1880's, when farms dominated the landscape. 
The computer, stocked with all that science knows about how land conditions can alter wind and water evaporation and runoff and albedo (how different surfaces reflect or retain heat), will replay history. 
Mr. Wichansky spent a year in the Rutgers Library creating a digital version of the Cook map that could be fed into the school's climate modeling program. The huge map was divided into 3,774 individual cells, each of which had to be put into the computer one by one. He has just started his computer runs. 
"I feel like Prof. George H. Cook is speaking to me through his maps," Mr. Wichansky said. 
At the backdrop of the climate work here is the unavoidable reality that a record-breaking warm trend -- short-term or long-term, no one can say -- is under way. The 12 months through the end of September, in particular, was the warmest in New Jersey since the 1890's. Mr. Wichansky said that part of what he was looking for in his results were clues about how much of that warming effect was a result of atmospheric changes, and how much came from the ground. 
"The land cover change project may enable us to quantify how much of this warming may actually be due to changes in the land surface itself as a result of human modifications," he said.
Some New Jersey environmental officials say they think that the results of the Rutgers project will be illuminating about how land and climate fit together, but that information, in the end, might still be problematic. 
"It's one thing for the state to say you have to control this amount of polluted runoff," one senior state official said. "It's another to say you have to maintain this forest cover or this result will occur far away. That's not the traditional bailiwick of environmental regulation. We'll have to evolve ourselves to get to that point."

HEADLINE: BLOCKS; 
Planners Urge Decisions on Downtown

BYLINE:  By David W. Dunlap 

 BODY:
DELAYED and diverted by the race for governor, interagency rivalries and a bit too much wishful thinking, the planning process in Lower Manhattan must begin showing results soon if it is to counter the very real threat that downtown could lose the financial-service industry, its economic backbone. 
 This was the collective warning delivered Tuesday night -- in bits and pieces and in slightly more politic language -- by a half-dozen chairmen and chairwomen of the New York City Planning Commission, past and present, whose experience goes back to the days before the World Trade Center was built. 
 Given their involvement with earlier attempts to resuscitate Lower Manhattan, they made compelling witnesses. The setting of their forum, organized by the Skyscraper Museum, was 1 Chase Manhattan Plaza, the 1950's answer to the question of what could be done to save downtown. 
"Time's a-wasting," said Donald H. Elliott, the planning chairman in the Lindsay administration, from 1966 to 1973. He is now a partner in the law firm Hollyer Brady Smith & Hines. 
"Many of us are concerned about dispersion, the lack of leadership and a sense that everything's on hold until after the election," Mr. Elliott said. "The time has come for a serious narrowing down of issues. If you want the private sector to build millions of square feet, they've got to be convinced that the environment they build into is going to work."
Mr. Elliott and five of his successors spoke with varying degrees of candor about issues that politicians prefer to avoid, like: why does the commission have no formal role in planning the single most important site in Manhattan? 
"The city planning agency needs a seat at the table," said Sylvia Deutsch, who led the commission from 1987 to 1989, the last years of the Koch administration. She said the planning chief "should by statute" serve on the 16-member Lower Manhattan Development Corporation board, to which the mayor and governor appoint eight members. The corporation is working with the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on the trade center site. 
"The setting up of state authorities by governors is often useful but it has the potential of making unified city planning an impossibility," said Ms. Deutsch, now an adjunct professor at New York University. 
Buttonholed after the forum, Amanda M. Burden, the current chairwoman, sidestepped the issue at first by saying that city planners are "working very closely" with the Lower Manhattan Development Corporation. "Whether that has to be formalized or not is not critical," she said. 
But when pressed just a bit further about the utility of a guaranteed city planning seat on the board, she answered, "I wouldn't say no."
Implicitly acknowledging that the city has little control over the trade center superblock, the planning alumni scarcely mentioned it in the 90-minute gathering, though Herbert J. Sturz, who served from 1980 to 1986 under Mayor Edward I. Koch, spoke of a prospective museum on the site that would merge the New-York Historical Society and the Museum of the City of New York.
There was almost no talk of design. Instead, the focus was on infrastructure, particularly expanding or extending transit lines to bring commuters directly into Lower Manhattan. 
"If we don't make these investments, we will encounter a catastrophe in the next decade, decade and a half," said Joseph B. Rose, the planning chairman for all eight years of the Giuliani administration. He is now a partner in the Georgetown Group real estate company but still sits on the commission.
THE alumnus with the most at stake in Lower Manhattan is John E. Zuccotti, whose tenure, 1973 to 1975, bridged the Lindsay and Beame eras. He is now chairman of Brookfield Properties Corporation, which owns the World Financial Center (100 percent of two towers and 51 percent of the other two) and 1 Liberty Plaza, on either side of the trade center site. 
In that role, Mr. Zuccotti champions a super express subway from the trade center site to Jamaica, Queens, using the Long Island Rail Road right-of-way or existing subway tunnels for much of its route. He said it could be built for $1.9 billion, contrasting it with a $15 billion price tag on the Second Avenue subway. "It's not real to think about projects that will exceed the cost capacity of the government," he said. "All it does is distort planning."
Ms. Burden offered her own vision of where short-term investment might do the most good: redeveloping the East River waterfront and creating "green rivers" of parks and open space throughout downtown.
She recalled the decision 19 years ago by the Battery Park City Authority, of which she was then vice president, to construct a generous esplanade in the earliest phase of development, though "there was nothing around it but sand," as a way of encouraging private investment. 
"We needed to show," she said, "what public life could be like."

HEADLINE: DaimlerChrysler Has Big Profit Gain, but Is Pessimistic 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
DaimlerChrysler said today that net income more than tripled during the third quarter because of aggressive cost-cutting at Chrysler and elsewhere in its operations. But it issued a pessimistic forecast for sales of cars and light trucks in the United States next year, blaming economic and political uncertainty.
 Further, DaimlerChrysler said it expected to have an underfunded pension liability of $3 billion for North America by the end of the year, sharing in the woes that have afflicted General Motors and Ford Motor as falling stock prices reduce the investments that feed their retirement funds. 
 DaimlerChrysler said it earned $881 million during the quarter, after adjustments for one-time costs, compared with $281 million for the period a year earlier. That was well above analysts' expectations of about $800 million for the quarter, historically the most difficult of the year for auto manufacturers because of the cost of introducing new models. 
As a result, DaimlerChrysler said it was raising its profit forecast for the full year to about $5 billion, a target that analysts said the company could easily meet, given that it earned $4.6 billion during the first three quarters of 2002.
Even so, the company's share price fell 81 cents today, to close at $37.05, on the New York Stock Exchange. During a conference call with journalists and analysts, conducted from the company's headquarters in Stuttgart, Germany, the chief financial officer, Manfred Gentz, said he expected overall sales in the United States to drop significantly during the coming year, possibly below 16 million vehicles. 
By contrast, auto companies will sell about 17 million vehicles this year, thanks in large part to wide-ranging incentive programs. But Mr. Gentz noted that sales had already softened this fall and said he expected the trend to continue. 
"We have to assume the total market in 2003 will be below 2002," Mr. Gentz said. "Most of the relevant car markets in the world are down. Europe is down. Germany is down for the third year in a row. Japan is certainly down."
Mr. Gentz added that there was uncertainty in the United States, with coming elections and the question of whether there will be war with Iraq. Should Mr. Gentz's prediction be right, sales in the United States would be the lowest since 1998, when auto companies sold 15.5 million vehicles. Analysts pointed out, however, that Mr. Gentz had a history of being cautious and they said his forecast seemed overly dire. 
"That's way too pessimistic," said Art Spinella, president of CNW Marketing Research of Bandon, Ore. Mr. Spinella's forecast calls for sales next year of about 16.6 million vehicles. He noted that DaimlerChrysler, like other auto companies, began this year thinking that auto sales would fall precipitously, and had to increase its sales forecast several times throughout the year as incentives propped up the market.
Mr. Gentz said the outlook would prompt further cost-cutting at DaimlerChrysler, including the Chrysler unit, which posted strong results that showed further evidence that its turnaround program had taken hold.
Chrysler had an operating profit of $321 million, in contrast to a loss of $264 million in the quarter a year ago.
The Chrysler performance came despite higher incentive costs, which translated to 16.3 percent of revenue, up two percentage points from a year ago. "To a certain degree we have to follow our competitors," Mr. Gentz said. "We can't have empty showrooms." 
Lately, Chrysler's chief executive, Dieter Zetsche, has vowed not to join other Detroit auto companies in flooding the market with incentives, and the company's per-vehicle incentive expense has already dropped this fall.
The Chrysler performance helped to offset a 2 percent decline in operating profit at Mercedes-Benz, which earned $782 million during the third quarter. Mr. Gentz said, however, that he was optimistic about Mercedes-Benz, because of expected demand for the new version of the E-Class sedan, which just went on sale in the United States, and a freshened version of the flagship S-Class.
Mr. Gentz said DaimlerChrysler's revenue grew 1 percent, to $35.5 billion, during the quarter. For the first nine months of the year, revenue was flat at $111 billion.
He said the company would decide at the end of the year how it would finance a shortfall in its North American pension plan, which includes not only workers at Chrysler but those at Freightliner, its heavy-truck operation in Portland, Ore., and at the Mercedes-Benz North American operations. The $3 billion is far less than the underfunded pension liabilities at Ford, with $6.5 billion, and G.M., where the pension liability could grow to $20 billion by the end of the year.

HEADLINE: U.S. Carmakers Losing Ground To Imports Despite Deals 

BYLINE:  By MICHELINE MAYNARD 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
The billions of dollars that General Motors, Ford and Chrysler have spent during the last year on the most generous sales incentives in automotive history have not bought them what they wanted: a bigger share of the market.
 The latest offers -- for everything from Chevrolet Cavaliers to Cadillac Escalades and Ford Focuses to Jaguar S-Types -- include zero percent loans, with no money down and no monthly payments until 2003, or else thousands of dollars in cash rebates. The deals are available not only on leftover 2002 models, but also on the newest cars and trucks. 
 In all, Detroit carmakers are spending an average of $3,764 a vehicle, or 14 percent of the selling price, on all manner of incentives, according to CNW Marketing Research, a firm in Bandon, Ore. That is twice as rich as the average deal on Japanese and Korean brands. And plenty of imports, including Lexuses and most BMW's, are selling well without any incentives at all. 
Indeed, analysts say that Detroit's deals have proved all but powerless against the imports' reputation for quality, durability and high resale value. Over all, Detroit has lost roughly another 1.6 percentage points of market share this year, with sales by G.M., Ford and Chrysler falling to 61.7 percent of the market for cars and light trucks in the United States. 
The domestic carmakers are failing to attract committed import buyers or to keep their own customers from defecting. Only 12 percent of customers who have purchased Detroit's vehicles this year were replacing a Japanese or European vehicle, according to data from AutoPacific Inc., an industry forecasting firm in Tustin, Calif. By contrast, 43 percent of people purchasing Japanese vehicles, and 32 percent of those buying European models, were replacing an American vehicle. 
"The numbers are all going the wrong way for Detroit," said George C. Peterson, AutoPacific's president. The data on defections is virtually unchanged from five years ago, despite the Big Three's efforts to improve their vehicles' quality and introduce attractive new models, he said. 
Customers like Randall C. Meachum, a 50-year-old manager for a telecommunications company in Lawrenceville, Ga., exemplify Detroit's problem. Zero percent financing on Cadillacs could not draw him into a G.M. dealership when he bought a Lexus sedan last month for his wife, even though he had to take on a loan with 4.9 percent interest.
The Lexus is one of five Toyota-brand vehicles that Mr. Meachum owns. He switched to imports in the mid-1990's after owning more than 30 G.M. and Ford vehicles over the previous decades.
"They still don't make a car I like," he said.
By continuing to focus its marketing on deals, Detroit may only be making matters worse for itself -- a warning that no one is delivering as sternly as Dieter Zetsche, the chief executive of Chrysler. Lately, Mr. Zetsche has tried to wean Chrysler, part of DaimlerChrysler, from incentives as generous as Ford's and G.M.'s, matching their deals only selectively.
"I see it as like a drug," Mr. Zetsche said in an interview today. "It might give you short-term relief, but long term, it is extremely harmful. The problem is that all parties involved get used to it, and it only works if you are increasing it all the time. Inevitably you run against some wall."
G.M. introduced the zero percent financing plans a year ago in an effort to energize sales after the Sept. 11 attacks, and it has repeatedly revised and renewed them. Though executives acknowledged this week that G.M. might, nonetheless, fall short of its goal of 29 percent of United States sales by the end of the year, they insisted that the incentives had generated showroom traffic, brought attention to G.M.'s lineup of vehicles and improved the credit profile of its customers.
"The drive towards zero financing is superb for us," said William J. Lovejoy, group vice president for sales, service and marketing. By shifting its marketing emphasis to loans, G.M. has been able to cut its leasing business in half and reduce the strain on its financing operation. (A high volume of trade-ins is depressing the prices of used cars, but for now that is a problem for car dealers, not carmakers.)
Depending on their creditworthiness, consumers can drive away from a G.M. showroom knowing they will spend nothing on their new car for the rest of the year. Less than a month into the 2003 model year, the company's television commercials promote deals on every vehicle in its lineup, except its Hummer sport utility vehicles.
Mr. Lovejoy said that the deals were likely to be a feature at G.M. for months to come. But their effectiveness is already diminishing. G.M, is forecasting that auto sales, which have run at an annual rate of 17 million so far this year, will dip to 16 million through the rest of the year.
At best, analysts say, the deals have been a holding action, helping the Big Three tread water in a market that officials acknowledge would collapse without incentives. 
G.M., despite its relentless efforts, has gained just one-tenth of a percentage point of market share this year, according to statistics from Autodata Inc. of Woodcliff Lake, N.J. (The figures do not include sales at Saab, the Swedish auto company that G.M. acquired in 2000.) Market share for Ford, which has matched G.M.'s offers, has slid 1.7 percentage points this year. Chrysler, third in sales among the domestic manufacturers, has actually picked up two-tenths of a percentage points.
That performance has come at a heavy cost. According to CNW Marketing, Ford spent $3,894 a vehicle on incentives last month, G.M. spent $3,862 and Chrysler spent $3,636. CNW's figures include sales incentives paid by carmakers both to dealers and to consumers. The automakers say that the numbers are too high, but decline to provide data.
There are special deals available on some import brands, too, but for the most part the numbers are much smaller and the incentives are not the centerpiece of marketing.
Toyota, which has offered zero percent financing in some parts of the country, averaged $2,209 a car in incentives last month, while Honda spent $1,577. Yet over the course of the year, Toyota has built its market share three-tenths of a percentage point, to 10.4 percent of United States sales. Honda also has added three-tenths of a percentage point, giving it 7.3 percent of the market.
Many analysts conclude that the Detroit carmakers have no chance of attracting import-brand customers. 
"The economy is bad, and the natural assumption that companies make is to lower prices" to draw customers, said Aradhna Krishna, a marketing professor at the University of Michigan's School of Business Administration in Ann Arbor. "But emotionally, people are shaken up. They are looking for dependability, reliability and consistency. And that affects their purchase decisions more than everything else."
Surveys by CNW show that buyers of Asian-brand vehicles -- a growing percentage of them built in American factories -- have a distinctly different profile from Detroit's customers. They are wealthier and better educated, less likely to enjoy the car-buying process and far more concerned with a vehicle's performance than its sticker price. 
The Big Three say that the quality of their vehicles has significantly improved, as measured by industry surveys from J. D. Power & Associates. Detroit still owns 76 percent of the market for light trucks, including minivans and sport utility vehicles, where it makes virtually all of its money and analysts see the best hope for attracting import owners. 
Executives delight in stories like that of Meredith Rackoff-Muldoon of Melville, N.Y., who chose a Jeep Liberty sport utility made by Chrysler over a Honda CR-V last May, even though she and her husband, Michael, had previously leased a Honda Civic.
"It's definitely roomier and has a more solid feel" than the CR-V, said Mrs. Rackoff-Muldoon, 31. "We're thrilled with the Jeep." The only incentive on the Liberty was a $500 rebate for recent graduates; she had just finished graduate school.
Mr. Zetsche of Chrysler said such customers supported his determination to wean customers off incentives, though Chrysler would have to remain diligent about cost-cutting to keep prices competitive.
"At the end of the day, it's in the best interest of the customer to have five years of a happy ownership experience, than to have one day of satisfaction at getting a good deal," he said. 
Experts doubt that G.M. and Ford will follow suit any time soon. Robert Kurilko, vice president for product development and marketing at Edmunds.com, a Web site that offers buying advice to consumers, said he expected those companies to offer 72-month interest-free loans and to extend the deals to less creditworthy customers before they stop.
"They're going to ride it until the horse is dead," he said.

HEADLINE: Los Angeles Police Chief Faces a Huge Challenge 

BYLINE:  By CHARLIE LeDUFF 

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
The afternoon that William J. Bratton was confirmed as police chief, a man was beaten to death in the South-Central section of this sprawling megalopolis.
 Robbie Hanzy, an unemployed member of the Rolling 60's Crips gang, was killed by his brother Alton, also an unemployed member of the Rolling 60's, the police said. The fight, the authorities said, was precipitated by an afternoon filled with alcohol and by two men with nothing better to do. 
 The killing was the 97th homicide this year in this part of the South-Central neighborhood, a precinct of fewer than 12 square miles, population 185,000. It is by any standard, the bloodiest area in the West, infested with gangs, narcotics and armed teenagers. The area is on pace for 120 homicides this year, a 43 percent jump from last year and a 240 percent increase since 1998. The three-precinct South-Central area reported 197 homicides through Oct. 18. 
Homicide in the city as a whole is up nearly 19 percent from last year. The reason, the authorities say, is the re-emergence of gang warfare.
"The Gaza Strip probably has more deaths, but this is a busy area, and the problem is gangs," said Detective Rudy Limos, the ranking homicide investigator in the 77th Station, which is within South-Central. "How you control it is beyond me." 
Violent crime is rising around the nation after a decade of striking decreases, and Los Angeles is among the leaders. If things hold to form, this city of 3.8 million people will earn the title of the Murder Capital, succeeding Chicago.
A beleaguered citizenry has turned to Mr. Bratton, regarded in some corners to be the most innovative police executive since J. Edgar Hoover and in others to be a man of enormous ego who took too much credit for the precipitous drop in crime in New York City, where he was police commissioner for 27 months. At his confirmation hearing this month, Mr. Bratton seemed well aware that his stewardship of the demoralized and scandal-plagued department may very well be the standard by which his legacy is judged.
"This department will be my last police department that I will have the opportunity to work with and lead," Mr. Bratton told City Council members. "I would like to see it as the capstone of my career."
The circumstances he walks into here are the inverse of what he walked into in New York in 1994. The crime rate is skyrocketing, not inching downward, as it was in New York. The economy is busting, not booming. Federal, state and local tax money is drying up, and fewer officers, not more, are on the streets. At the same time, a steady stream of violent parolees is finding the way back to the old neighborhoods.
Moreover, Mr. Bratton takes over a damaged force that is operating under a federal consent decree that punishes overly aggressive officers. By many officers' accounts, the beat cop has virtually stopped working.
"Members of this department are demoralized," said Cmdr. Richard Roupoli, assistant commander of the South Bureau, which includes many poor and violent precincts of Los Angeles, including South-Central.
"We disbanded our gang units two years ago and then reinstituted them with new people without extensive gang knowledge," Commander Roupoli said. "At the same time, we've got multiple gang wars going on. The result are the murders we're seeing now."
When it was learned in late 1999 that a renegade gang unit, the Rampart Division, was planting evidence, racially profiling and, in some cases, unjustifiably shooting suspects, all gang units were disbanded, and the city accepted a consent decree that among other provisions uses monitors to weed out corruption and wrongdoing. In a few months, years of street intelligence was lost, along with the reassigned officers. A strict discipline system was put in place, and nearly 1,000 officers left to work elsewhere. A result, officers said, has been a steadily rising homicide rate.
"It stems from an oppressive discipline system," the commander of the robbery-homicide unit, Capt. James Tatreau, said. "Since Rampart, every complaint made, whether by a chronic complainer or nut, meant that it would follow a cop through his career and enter into the mix of promotion or special assignments. 
"The cops' solution?" Captain Tatreau said. "Stop being a cop." 
Mr. Bratton said his first priority after being sworn in on Oct. 28 would be ending the smile-and-wave approach to crime fighting. He said he wanted policing based on the so-called broken-windows theory. That idea holds that small quality-of-life crimes eventually encourage greater lawlessness. If graffiti and broken windows are tolerated, for instance, eventually prostitution and drug dealing and companion violence will find their ways to the street corners.
It is a concept that Mr. Bratton instituted with great success in New York, where the homicide rate once topped 2,200 a year, almost four times its current level. 
It is hard to know whether the strategy can translate here. Los Angeles, sprawling over 463 square miles, is a city where community policing is often little more than the lights of a helicopter washing over bedroom windows. New York's five boroughs add up to 309 square miles. New York has 39,000 police officers for a city of eight million people, and Los Angeles has 9,000 officers for four million. 
"You can only hope he's going to have some kind of effect," Detective Limos said. "Because we don't have many answers." 
After a decade of declines in crime across the country, crime rates not only here but also in other major cities may have no place to go but up, said Jeremy Travis, a senior fellow at the Urban Institute.
"It's a bad time right now," Mr. Travis said. "The economy is weakened. State and local budgets are tight, and that hampers overtime flexibility and new hires. There are 600,000 people coming out of prison every year. Four times as many parolees were released this year than 20 years ago. At the same time, transitional services are cut and people are dumped on streets."
The mix, especially here, is a witch's brew. Jobs are disappearing, and welfare changes are leaving marginal people in the lurch. Moreover, 1,000 people a year return to the city streets from prison after having been locked up in the get-tough-on-crime 90's. With violent unrehabilitated felons back on the streets and many officers heading for suburban work, the streets are volatile. 
"If Bratton can turn it around in this climate, it says he's a great police manager," Mr. Travis said.
Mary Phipps, a grandmother from South-Central whose bedroom window faces a wall scarred with graffiti of the simmering war between Bloods and Crips factions said: "Things are out of control. First it's these gangs. And then it's the police out of control, and now it's the gangs again. There has to be someone to put it in balance." 
At any given time in Los Angeles County, 112,000 young men and women are listed as gang members or "wannabes" in a database created by law enforcement officials.
As of Oct. 5, Los Angeles had 517 homicides compared with 436 last year. The police said 75 percent were gang related.
"If we could get rid of the gangs, we'd be living in heaven," Detective Limos said.
In the county, with more people and a seemingly endless sprawl, homicide is also increasing, but at a rate nearly three times slower than in the city. 
"There is a whole latitude of policing within the law," Lt. Bob Rifkin, a supervisor in the gang unit of the County Sheriff's Department, said. "But society has to decide the balance between safety and civil rights. How much of one are you willing to sacrifice for the other?"
A gang member in Compton, one of 3,000 parolees there, laid out the thinking of the criminal mind in terms of the disarray in the Police Department, as opposed to the Sheriff's Department. "If you're going to mess around," he said, "it's better to do it outside the sheriff's area and in the Police Department's."
It is not as though the county is without problems, too. Take the case of Jose Sanchez, 19, who the police said had two things going against him. One was the telltale dead eye that he neglected to cover with a mask before he carjacked and beat a stranger and, second, the wisecrack smile that never left his face. Sheriff's deputies executed a morning raid against him and his crew, netting drugs and automatic weapons.
"I ain't afraid of prison and I ain't afraid of you," Mr. Sanchez said as he left his mother's house in handcuffs. "I was just on my way to school."

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE MEDIA; 
National TV Focuses on Sniper, but Local Stations Pick Up the Slack on Political Coverage

BYLINE:  By JIM RUTENBERG 

 BODY:
Menacing images of cross hairs dominated the screens of the national television newscasts on Tuesday night, as did the chilling words from the Washington sniper's letter: "Your children are not safe anywhere at any time."
 But when residents in Sioux Falls, S.D., tuned to the 6 p.m. local news on KELO-TV, the CBS affiliate there, they encountered a far different world view: First, they saw a brief account about a nearby tanker crash, then a much longer report about pledges by the candidates for United States Senate not to produce negative political advertisements. 
 So it goes throughout the battleground states of the midterm elections. Robbed of the chance to capitalize on broad themes that set agendas in the national media, the political parties have had to rely on piecemeal coverage market by market to get messages across. 
Democrats, and to a lesser extent Republicans, say the sniper news coverage has hindered their ability to seize the focus on national issues that will help lift their candidates in the battle to control the House and Senate. Still, they said, those races are receiving more than adequate coverage from local television stations, partly because the Washington-area shootings are far removed from their broadcast areas.
"Local media is talking about the local races," said Stuart Rothenberg, publisher of The Rothenberg Political Report, a nonpartisan political newsletter. "If you turn on a television in South Dakota, you're going to see political ads and the debates are getting covered."
Even so, a successful, national theme can galvanize an entire party in a midterm election, as Newt Gingrich proved in 1994, when the Republicans' "Contract With America" helped promote candidates across the country and ultimately gave the Republican Party control of Congress.
In the absence of such a national campaign, the results can be less overwhelming. "Without the national wave, you're cherry picking," Mr. Rothenberg said. "You could cherry pick with 2 or 3 seats. But netting 6, 7, 8, 12, 15 is really hard to do."
With Republicans running behind a strong president who is weighing war with Iraq, analysts said the onus is on the Democrats to build nationwide momentum around economic issues.
"The fundamental issue for the Democrats is whether they can get people to go into the voter booth and say 'Gee, my 401k is down because of George W. Bush's policies,' " said Chris Lehane, a Democratic consultant who was the spokesman for Al Gore's presidential campaign in 2000. "To get people to make that connection, you need to break through nationally."
According to Andrew Tyndall, a consultant who tracks network news coverage, the half-hour evening newscasts on NBC, ABC and CBS -- watched by a combined audience of about 30 million people -- devoted 76 minutes to the sniper case last week. Iraq, the second-most covered issue that week, commanded 28 minutes. The 2002 Congressional races were covered for 5 minutes.
Economic news has not been at the top of Mr. Tyndall's list of the 10 most-covered topics since July.
The 24-hour cable networks -- Fox News Channel, CNN and MSNBC -- have essentially offered a similar news mix. Even many of the political programs that help set the tone of the election -- NBC's "Meet the Press," ABC's "This Week," CNN's "Crossfire" -- have devoted considerable time to the sniper in recent weeks.
But each side said local news, along with the heavy political advertising spending, is helping to offset the loss of attention at the national level.
While the sniper story had the nation's attention, Steve Schmidt, spokesman for the National Republican Congressional Committee, "it's not impinging on anybody's ability in Congressional races in Arizona, in Alabama, in Mississippi, to get their messages out."
Station news directors said their local political races often make for more compelling television than the Washington sniper story. 
Mark R. Millage, news director of KELO in South Dakota, said the campaign season in his state, featuring several tight races, was "almost like a sporting event, a prize fight," adding that "they're entering the 15th round."

HEADLINE: Officials Seek Changes in Rules For Sept. 11 Business Program 

BYLINE:  By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Businesses that were in the World Trade Center should get more money than other businesses from a program granting relief from the Sept. 11 terrorist attack, a group of officials said yesterday.
 Under the current rules for the aid plan, called the World Trade Center Business Recovery Grant Program, small businesses that were in the trade center when it was destroyed are treated the same as small businesses on the blocks around them, the officials said as they called publicly for different rules for the program. 
 "It only makes sense that businesses destroyed totally are treated differently from business that remained physically intact," said one of the officials, Alan J. Gerson, chairman of the City Council's committee on Lower Manhattan redevelopment, who also represents the area. 
Another council member, Domenic M. Recchia Jr., said of the companies that were in the trade center, "They have nothing to go back to." 
Under the program, all businesses that have up to 500 employees and that are in the area between Chambers Street and Rector Street on the north and south and Broadway and the Hudson River from east to west -- the trade center and the blocks immediately around it -- are equally eligible for the program's maximum grants of up to 25 days of lost revenue.
The two council members spoke at a news conference outside City Hall. They were joined by the speaker of the Council, Gifford Miller; the speaker of the State Assembly, Sheldon Silver, and about 75 owners of businesses that had been in the trade center or were in Chinatown.
A spokesman for the Empire State Development Corporation, which runs the program with the city's Economic Development Corporation, said his agency was "focused on helping World Trade Center tenants." That focus, he said, was a reason for recently increasing the maximum business recovery grants for those in and around the trade center.
The spokesman, Michael Marr, also suggested that "partisan politics" was "at play" in yesterday's news conference. All those backing the changes in the programs were Democrats.
The legislators also called for expanding the boundaries of another program, the Small Firm Attraction and Retention Grant Program, which provides up to $5,000 per worker to businesses with up to 200 employees that sign new or renewal leases in the area as far north as Canal Street. That, the legislators say, covers only part of Chinatown, though the portion of Chinatown north of Canal Street was hurt just as hard by the decline of tourists and other visitors. Thus, they said, eligibility for the program should extend as far north as Delancey Street.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: DIPLOMACY; 
SECURITY COUNCIL GETS U.S. PROPOSAL ON DISARMING IRAQ

BYLINE:  By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
The United States formally presented the full Security Council today with a draft resolution that includes a threat of military action against Iraq, sharply increasing the pressure on France, Russia and China to agree to a tough measure to force Baghdad to disarm. 
 The administration's step followed six weeks of wrangling among the five veto-bearing members of the Council that did not yield agreement on linking a proposal for tough weapons inspections in Iraq with a threat of military force to back them up. 
 The United States submitted its draft to all 15 Council nations to show its reluctant allies, France and Russia, that it had sufficient support among the 10 other members.
American diplomats calculated, but without any guarantees, that neither France, Russia nor China would veto the latest resolution. But the move today forced the pace and put pressure on the five to decide soon how they would vote. 
"You're either with us or against us" was the message that Washington was sending to the other permanent members, an administration official said today. 
France, supported by Russia, has opposed the American draft because it includes a legal basis for a military attack if Iraq fails to disarm. France has favored a two-stage approach, which would leave the authorization of force to a second resolution, a position Russia and China favor. 
The United States action today came after France and Russia, and less forcefully China, criticized the American proposal yet again in closed negotiations on Tuesday. 
American officials said they were carrying out a strategy that Mr. Bush outlined on Sept. 12 when he first challenged the United Nations to confront Iraq, saying that if the world organization would not act to disarm Iraq, the United States was prepared to do it alone. 
American diplomats argued that the negotiations among the five veto-bearing countries were among the most arduous ever for a resolution. American and British diplomats insisted they had made significant concessions to the complaints from France and Russia in the draft they presented on Monday. Britain will co-sponsor the resolution. 
"The moment has come to give an added sense of urgency to this question," said the American ambassador, John D. Negroponte.
The draft presented today underwent only minor modifcations in negotiations since late Sunday.
The full Council will return for discussions on Friday, and decided today to meet on Monday with Hans Blix, the head of the United Nations weapons inspections team, extending the negotiations into next week. 
The Russian ambassador, Sergey Lavrov, made an unusual display of irritation as he went into the meeting. Visibly angry, he said he was "preoccupied with the real problem," the hostage crisis in Moscow.
"That's the sort of real threats we experience these days," Mr. Lavrov insisted, suggesting that the threat posed by Iraq's weapons programs was less immediate. 
He said Russia opposed the American draft because it still included an automatic authorization for the use of force and imposed "unimplementable, unrealistic" demands on inspectors and Iraqi officials.
When asked if Russia had assured the United States that it would not use its veto, Mr. Lavrov said: "The short answer is no. But this was never discussed."
He dismissed suggestions by American diplomats that his views did not represent the thinking of President Vladimir V. Putin. "In case someone has any doubts, what I'm presenting in the Council is not an invention of my own," he said. 
The closed meeting this afternoon with all 15 Council members was the first time the 10 rotating members, who do not hold vetoes, had officially seen the United States draft. They have complained openly about being excluded from the talks, and American officials said today's move was in part to mollify them. 
Under the terms of the United Nations Charter, a Council resolution is adopted by nine votes in favor and no negative vote from the five permanent members. As they emerged today with the text in their briefcases, the nonpermanent ambassadors were noncommital. 
Making an informal count, administration officials said they were confident of the support of Bulgaria, Colombia, Guinea and Norway and believed they could secure the votes of Singapore and Cameroon. Syria and Mauritius were expected to vote against it. As a result, Ireland and Mexico emerged as pivotal votes. 
Mexico, whose president, Vicente Fox, has enjoyed a warm friendship with President Bush, has been frustrated with the lack of progress with the administration on immigration and other bilateral issues. Mexico has very vocally backed France's demand for the two-stage approach.
Moments after meeting tonight with Secretary of State Colin L. Powell, Mexico's foreign minister, Jorge G. Castaneda, spoke positively of the new draft, although he said he had not read the very latest version.
"We think that with the French, the Russians and the Chinese, we have been able to generate important progress on the issue of two stages," he said in a telephone interview from Los Cabos.
Secretary Powell, who is also in Mexico for an economic conference of Asian and Pacific nations, said the new draft was a product of the United States having "listened carefully" to suggestions from other countries. He said the United States would listen to any proposed changes as long as they did not violate the objective of threatening "consequences" against Iraq.
"It's not a fiat that we have put down," he said, but he did not specifically say the United States would make any further changes.
The permanent members have the choice of voting in favor, abstaining or vetoing. With the support of Britain assured, American officials were calculating that if they secured seven votes from nonpermanent members, France would almost certainly acquiesce in the final hour. The last time that France vetoed an American resolution was in 1956.
President Bush is to meet on Friday at his ranch in Crawford, Tex., with President Jiang Zemin of China. He is also to speak on Saturday with President Putin at the meeting of Pacific rim nations in Mexico.

HEADLINE: Xerox Reports a Profit, but Revenue Is Down 6% 

BYLINE:  By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
Xerox, offsetting a 6 percent slump in sales with a 13 percent cut in costs, said yesterday that it had earned $105 million, or 5 cents a share, in the third quarter.
 That was in contrast to a loss of 5 cents in the period a year ago, and beat analysts' estimates for the quarter by 3 cents. 
 "We've been really tough-minded on costs, and our margins are exceeding everyone's expectations," an ebullient Anne M. Mulcahy, chief executive of Xerox, said in a telephone interview after her conference call with analysts. "Our new products and lower prices are indicative of a new Xerox." 
Ms. Mulcahy reassured investors that 2002 would be a profitable year, the first for Xerox since 1999. But the reassurance did not buoy the company's stock. Shares of Xerox, which is based in Stamford, Conn., closed at $6.41, down 29 cents.
Many factors damped ardor for Xerox shares. Charles L. Hill, director of research at Thomson First Call, noted that Xerox had beaten earnings expectations four consecutive times, and that some analysts were more cynical than impressed. 
"Xerox wouldn't be the first company to low-ball earnings guidance in order to look good," he said. 
Xerox also announced a $3 billion shelf registration -- a notification that it might issue that amount in new equity or debt. New shares would dilute existing ones, and Xerox already has about $9 billion in debt coming due in the next three years. Ms. Mulcahy said she had no immediate plans to issue new shares or bonds, but some investors might have sold just in case.
This quarter, job cuts resulted in a 6-cent charge against earnings. In the fourth quarter, Xerox will probably write off pension obligations, and take further charges for job cuts. 
"They have hugely improved their balance sheet, but it is still an unholy mess," said Ulysses Yannas, an analyst with Buckman, Buckman & Reid, who rates Xerox shares a buy.
Sluggish sales remain the big reason for Wall Street's thumbs-down vote on Xerox. Third-quarter revenue was $3.79 billion, down from $4.05 billion a year ago. About half the decline came when Xerox exited the low-price printer market last year, and dropped many unprofitable customers in developing markets. But leery investors are not appeased.
Timothy M. Ghriskey, a principal in the money management firm of Ghriskey Capital Partners, had been considering buying Xerox shares. But after yesterday's report, he decided not to. 
"They've controlled expenses, but we've seen 10 quarters of sliding sales," he said. "We keep coming back to, 'where's the growth?' "
Ms. Mulcahy insists that order rates are picking up and that "we're seeing momentum on new products."
Jack L. Kelly, an analyst at Goldman, Sachs, said that as recently as July companies were still cutting their capital spending plans. 
"The expected economic pickup never came, they are husbanding cash, and they are not buying business equipment," said Mr. Kelly, who is neutral on Xerox stock. 
Xerox is in good shape to grab share when customers do spend again. It has a number of new products that analysts say are priced to compete with Canon and Ricoh, Xerox's main rivals.
Xerox cut 1,600 jobs this quarter, and more job cuts are expected soon. Xerox generated $611 million in cash in the quarter. And earlier this week, Xerox announced that GE Capital would provide as much as $5 billion over the next eight years, enabling Xerox to continue to finance equipment leases for customers.
"I give Xerox the best chance of all my fallen angels for turning itself around," said Carol Levenson, director of research at Gimme Credit, a corporate bond research service. 
Xerox has restated several years' worth of sales and earnings and paid a $10 million fine, thereby ending a lengthy Securities and Exchange Commission investigation of its accounting. Indeed, no analyst asked about accounting fraud during the conference call.
"It was so nice," Ms. Mulcahy said. "Finally, an earnings conference that focused on the business."

HEADLINE: Hicks Nix Blix Fix 

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM SAFIRE; E-mail: safire@nytimes.com

DATELINE: WASHINGTON 

 BODY:
North Korea proudly announced in 1994 that it had begun withdrawing plutonium-rich fuel rods from one of its nuclear reactors, which the world knew would enable the Stalinist government to build a half-dozen bombs. Coupled with its threat to turn South Korea's capital, Seoul, into "a sea of fire," this threat to the nonproliferation treaty deeply worried Bill Clinton's Pentagon.
 Tough-minded negotiators were needed to head off the dictator Kim Il Sung's plan. Two senators steeped in arms control were selected to go to Pyongyang: Richard Lugar and Sam Nunn. They prepared to board a military transport plane, but the dictator refused them permission to enter his country; he had a different kind of intermediary in mind. 
 Enter Jimmy Carter. Within a month after the rejection of Lugar and Nunn, our former president was in the dictator's office, in front of CNN cameras, announcing -- as only an unofficial emissary, of course -- that he had personally worked out a deal to defuse the crisis. In return for suspending plutonium production, the Koreans would receive free oil, a light-water nuclear reactor said to be less dangerous, and the top-level diplomatic contacts it long sought.
"It was kind of like a miracle," breathed Jimmy Carter about his supposed conversion of the North Korean leader from lion to lamb on live TV. Ignoring the protests from realists in this space and all over about appeasement and lack of verification, the Clinton administration embraced Carter's "miracle." After all, hadn't the North Koreans agreed to inspections by the International Atomic Energy Agency, headed by the sternly unfoolable Hans Blix?
As we now know, the Carter-Clinton crowd was taken to the cleaners by a totalitarian regime that snatched our payoff and secretly kept on building nukes. When confronted this month with indisputable evidence of years of double-crossing us and the world, the Communist North headed by Kim's dictator son said, in effect, "Sure we did -- and your nosiness means that the deal is now nullified." 
With the arrogance of successful con men, they now want to sell us the same phony bill of goods again: more oil and food and "safe" reactors in return for more empty promises of shell-game inspections. The so-called unilateral cowboys of the Bush administration won't buy that. (Suggested Variety headline: Hicks Nix Blix Fix.)
Instead, at his Crawford, Tex., ranch, the president will lay it on the line to his visitor from China, Jiang Zemin: Do you want a loose cannon on your border loaded with nukes? Or will you, with exquisite Chinese subtlety and Communist camaraderie, put the economic and diplomatic squeeze on your hungry neighbor lest it gain the destructive power to threaten China's Asian sphere of influence? 
America and its allies will not use our military to take out the Pyongyang gang for the simple reason that North Korea already has the conventional troop strength and artillery power to inflict horrendous casualties on the South (including 40,000 U.S. tripwire troops) as well as in Japan, which Pyongyang will soon be able to reach with nuclear missiles. 
That strategic fact of life and death invites the question that coolly consistent sophists love to ask: If we are disinclined to attack the nuclear buildup in North Korea, why are we hot to attack a somewhat less imminent threat of mass destruction from Iraq? 
Saddam Hussein is a recent, serial aggressor, while totalitarian North Korea has not launched an invasion in the past half-century. Moreover, the potentially high human cost of wiping out the Korean threat should be an unforgettable lesson to every nation: The world must not allow Iraq to gain the level of destructive power that appeasement and misplaced trust permitted North Korea to achieve. 
Our failure to demand intrusive, relentless inspection of North Korea in the past decade has made everyone more vulnerable to the spread of terror weaponry. (Libya's secret nuclear work relies on Korean know-how.) 
The U.S. has learned its lesson from Pyongyang's duplicity. If oil-fixated France and Russia should awake to the danger of Saddam and join with us at the U.N. to stop him while he's readily stoppable, that would turn the proliferation tide. It's a long shot. It would be kind of like a miracle.

HEADLINE: Longshoremen Accused of Slowdown in West 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The association of West Coast port operators said yesterday that it had complained to the Justice Department that the dock workers were engaging in a "concerted, systematic work slowdown."
 The group, the Pacific Maritime Association, asked the government to act, asserting that productivity had fallen to 34 percent below normal in Oakland, Calif.; 29 percent below normal in Portland, Ore.; and 27 percent below in Seattle. 
 Joseph Miniace, the president of the association, said, "The International Longshore and Warehouse Union is playing games with the U.S. economy, and inflicting economic pain and hardship on scores of companies and their employees." 
On Sept. 29, the maritime association closed 29 West Coast ports and locked out 10,500 longshoremen, accusing them of engaging in a slowdown. On Oct. 8, President Bush invoked the Taft-Hartley Act and asked a federal judge in San Francisco to order the ports reopened and the longshoremen back to work.
Several economists estimated that the port shutdown had cost the economy at least $1 billion a day.
In response to the association's complaint, the Justice Department sent the association and the union a letter that said, "These are serious allegations."
The letter, from Deputy Assistant Attorney General Shannen W. Coffin, noted that the injunction reopening the ports required that work continue "at a normal and reasonable rate of speed," and without the union's interfering with "the orderly continuance of work." Mr. Coffin noted that the injunction also ordered the union "not to engage in any slowdown or any other kind of work stoppage." 
He asked the union and maritime association to provide information regarding the accusations of a slowdown. If the Justice Department concludes that the union is engaged in an unjustifiable slowdown, one option it has is to ask the judge to cite the union for contempt.
Steve Stallone, a union spokesman, insisted that there was not a deliberate slowdown, although he acknowledged that cargo handling was slower than usual, saying the main reason was extraordinary congestion.
"We're not engaged in a slowdown," Mr. Stallone said. "Even if we wanted to mess up productivity on the docks, we couldn't do half as good a job as the Pacific Maritime Association has done with the logistical disaster they created through the lockout."
Mr. Stallone said the docks were so congested with backed up cargo and trucks that lower productivity was inevitable. Union officials said safety concerns, especially during this period of unusual congestion, were also lowering productivity. 
The association said the reasons cited by the union -- safety and congestion -- could not account for what it termed a sudden and major drop in work levels at several ports. The association said the drop in productivity was far smaller -- 9 percent below normal -- at the nation's largest port, Los Angeles/Long Beach.
The association accused the longshoremen of taking unjustified sick days and accused the union of not providing full crews of workers and delaying the dispatch of workers. Union officials said the ports were so busy that it was hard to furnish all the workers needed.

HEADLINE: Mayor Says Current Deficit May Be as Much as $1 Billion 

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said yesterday that the city's current budget could be as much as $1 billion out of balance, echoing concerns that fiscal monitors have been raising since he and the City Council agreed to it in June.
 It was the first time that Mayor Bloomberg had said that the current deficit could be as much as $1 billion. "If you want to use the number a billion dollars -- could be, it could be a lot less than that," he said in an interview on radio station WOR. 
 If the city were to fall $1 billion short this year, it would deal a severe blow to its plans for closing the giant budget gap that is looming next year. 
Here is why: the Bloomberg administration is currently struggling to cut $1 billion in city spending next month. The mayor has said all along that he hopes to use that money to plug a gap in the 2004 fiscal year, which begins July 1, which he estimates at $5 billion to $6 billion.
Time is money, so starting early is important: a $1 billion cut beginning this year would save the city $2 billion by the end of next year.
But if the current budget is $1 billion out of balance, the city will have to use the savings generated by next month's budget cuts immediately. That would leave the city $1 billion further away from closing next year's formidable gap.
It was not supposed to be that way. When the mayor first announced his plan for $1 billion in midyear cuts in July, he said, "My expectation is that we will not have to use it in 2003, but I think it's prudent to have it."
But in the radio interview yesterday, Mr. Bloomberg said that the city now expected to collect less money in tax revenues in the next eight months than it had originally anticipated.
The size of this year's deficit, he said, "depends on how things work out, how much help we can still get from the federal government, and from state government and from the unions and from the economy."
Nearly as soon as the ink dried on this year's budget, fiscal monitors warned that it could be out of balance. Within weeks of its adoption, the city comptroller's office, the state comptroller's office and the state's Financial Control Board all warned that the budget relied on at least $1 billion in revenues and savings that might not materialize. 
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for the mayor, said that the 7.5 percent cut was intended not only to get a head start on next year's deficit, but also was an insurance policy if this year's budget fell out of balance.
"Under the city's charter, the budget is updated throughout the fiscal year, but the amounts are obviously more severe during a fiscal crisis when you are facing successive $5 to $6 billion deficits," he said.
The City Council now estimates that there are $995 million in risks in this year's budget. Tax collections could fall $320 million short, Council officials said; the city had counted on them to grow by 5.2 percent, but they are now expected to grow by 3.8 percent.
The mayor has yet to realize $252 million in savings from the city's union contracts, and the city has not received the $175 million in airport rents it is counting on.
Gifford Miller, the Council speaker, said that everything from tax increases to layoffs would have to be considered as the city moves to close its budget gaps.
"We're going to be choosing between bad, worse and worst," Mr. Miller said yesterday.

HEADLINE: Greenspan Hails Output Gains in Sluggish Economy 

BYLINE:  By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, hailed the continued strong growth in business efficiency today but gave no hint as to whether the central bank might consider cutting interest rates when it meets in two weeks.
 Mr. Greenspan spoke shortly before the Fed said in its beige book report on regional economic conditions that the economy in most parts of the country was sluggish, with retail sales weak and manufacturing activity slowing. 
 Economists said the lack of a signal from Mr. Greenspan about the Fed's intentions and the muddled outlook for the economy left open the question of whether the central bank would cut rates for the first time in 11 months when it meets on Nov. 6. 
Analysts predicted a month ago that the Fed would probably cut rates before the end of the year. Since then the stock market has recovered some of its losses, the economy has avoided any sharp deterioration and several Fed officials have signaled that they view the current level of interest rates as low enough to keep the halting recovery from last year's recession on track. The Fed's benchmark federal funds target rate is at 1.75 percent, a 40-year low.
The beige book report, which surveyed economic conditions in September and early October, found that retail sales were weak or down in nearly all areas of the country, an indication that consumer spending, which more than any other single factor has kept the economy afloat, may be running out of steam. It said automobile sales had slowed from very high levels and that tourism was mixed.
The report said that manufacturers cited "tough," "stagnant" and "sluggish" business conditions in most places, and noted that manufacturers remained reluctant to invest in plants and equipment. Economists say the economy is unlikely to rebound until businesses are willing to increase capital spending.
Mr. Greenspan had nothing to say about current economic conditions. In a speech to a conference sponsored by the Labor Department and the American Enterprise Institute, a conservative research group, the Fed chairman focused on the growth of productivity, or output per hour, a measure of the economy's ability to produce more for less and the primary determinant of its capacity to expand without generating inflation.
Mr. Greenspan, an optimist about productivity over the long run, marveled at how output per hour had continued to rise at a robust pace even as the economy struggled to put the recession behind it, defying the historical trend of big productivity increases accompanying especially strong economic recoveries. The trend, he said, was "remarkable and encouraging."
Mr. Greenspan noted that productivity growth over the last year "will almost surely be reported as one of the largest advances, if not the largest, posted over the past 30 years." 
He acknowledged that the surge in productivity could taper off. But he listed several reasons it could continue for some time, and pointed to recent studies that concluded that the growth rate in output per hour was probably sustainable at about 2.5 percent a year. At that level it would be below its annual rate of 4.8 percent for the year ended in June, but well above its 1.5 percent annual rate from the mid-1970's to the mid-1990's.
Mr. Greenspan said much of the improvement appeared to stem from the pressure on companies to reduce costs at a time when low inflation has made it all but impossible to raise prices. He said companies seemed to be trimming corporate excesses that had built up during the rapid expansion of the 1990's.
He said the recent surge in productivity might reflect a delay in the ability of companies to take full advantage of their heavy investments in new cost-saving technology toward the end of the 1990's. In the short run, he said, adopting new technology can disrupt businesses as they learn how to use new machinery and software, with the full benefits only visible after a few years.
But Mr. Greenspan did not directly address the the fact that productivity gains can restrain employment growth, increasing the odds of a jobless recovery. 
He touched on the pressure that relentless cost-cutting places on employees, noting that "more demanding workloads eventually begin to tax workers and impede efficiency."

GRAPHIC: Chart/Map of the United States shows economic growth in selected cities across the countries.

HEADLINE: THE 2002 CAMPAIGN: THE DEMOCRATS; 
McAuliffe Describes Jeb Bush As the Democrats' Top Target

BYLINE:  By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 23 

 BODY:
Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic national chairman, said today that his No. 1 goal in the Nov. 5 elections was to defeat Gov. Jeb Bush in Florida and that his No. 1 worry was whether Senator Jean Carnahan, Democrat of Missouri, could hold her seat.
 "Jeb is gone!" Mr. McAuliffe declared brazenly, brushing aside the determination of the White House to protect the president's brother. "There won't be anything as devastating to President Bush as his brother's losing in Florida." 
 At a lunch today with reporters and editors of The New York Times, Mr. McAuliffe said he was thrilled that Mr. Bush planned to campaign almost nonstop until the election, because that would focus attention on domestic issues, where Democrats believe that their strength lies.
More than any other factor, he said, the Democrats' success in turning the economy into an issue would determine whether the party regained control of the House.
"They made a huge strategic error," Mr. McAuliffe said of the White House. "It will force him to talk about the economy."
Mr. McAuliffe said that after Mr. Bush's recent trip to Minnesota, Senator Paul Wellstone, the Democrat, climbed two points in the polls. 
"We hope George Bush goes to all our highly contested races," the Democratic leader said.
As part of the focus on the economy, Mr. McAuliffe said the party would pay for commercials in each area where Mr. Bush campaigned. 
"Wherever President Bush goes," he said, "we're on TV before he gets there, while he's there and the day after, every city." 
The chairman of the Republican National Committee, Marc Racicot, said last week in the same forum that he was not worried about domestic issues and the economy, because the Democrats had been impotent in outlining their economic program. Mr. Racicot said he expected Republicans to retain control of the House and take back the Senate.
Disputing that, Mr. McAuliffe asserted that the Democrats would retain control of the Senate by at least one seat, and possibly as many as three. He conceded that winning the six net seats needed to take over the House was "tough, but it's doable."
He added that he was worried that if the Democrats failed to take over the House, which they lost in 1994, many incumbent Democrats would retire.
Mr. McAuliffe said the party would make its strongest gains in the governors' races, particularly in Florida. He based his enthusiasm about Florida on polls that show a dead heat between Mr. Bush and Bill McBride, the Democratic candidate.
The national party will make an all-out commitment of money and campaign workers to help Mr. McBride, Mr. McAuliffe said. The goal is not only to avenge Al Gore's failure to capture the state in 2000, but also to set the stage for a Democratic presidential candidate in 2004.
"To have a governor in a state in a presidential year for money, message, mobilization," he said, "will help us tremendously. I cannot tell you the impact of us having the governor of Florida heading into the '04 presidential."
Mr. McAuliffe was more subdued about Missouri. The most recent poll, by American Viewpoint, a Republican pollster, shows former Representative Jim Talent, the Republican, leading Mrs. Carnahan, 49 percent to 41 percent. Earlier polls by Democratic pollsters had Mrs. Carnahan ahead.
"This is her first real campaign, full-blown, all-out campaign, and there's a lot of money in that state," Mr. McAuliffe said. "Jean's is probably the race that we all worry about the most."
He had earlier called Senator Robert G. Torricelli of New Jersey the weakest Democratic candidate. Mr. Torricelli later withdrew. 
Mr. McAuliffe called Mr. Talent "a very good campaigner" and noted that after he lost the governor's race in 2000 by one point, he had maintained his political operation.
"She's going to pull it out," Mr. McAuliffe said of Mrs. Carnahan. "But it has really tightened up."
A spokesman for her campaign, Dan Leistikow, said, "We've always known this race would be very close, but we think Senator Carnahan is in a strong position."
Mr. McAuliffe said he was concerned that fears about the sniper could suppress turnout in Maryland and said he approved a suggestion by Gov. Parris N. Glendening to call up the National Guard on Election Day.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Terry McAuliffe, the Democratic chairman, discussing the election. (Carol T. Powers for The New York Times)
