HEADLINE: ART GUIDE 

 BODY:
 A selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Most galleries are closed on Sundays and Mondays, but hours vary and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.

Art Fairs

"ARMORY PHOTOGRAPHY SHOW 2002," Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, North Pavilion, 11th Avenue at 39th Street. Hours: Today through Sunday, 11 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Monday, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m. Admission: $15. Information: (212) 645-6440. The organizers of the Armory Show, which began six years ago in the Gramercy Park Hotel and now fills two piers on the Hudson every February, are bringing forth a spinoff, the Armory Photography Show 2002. Its 83 participants will include contemporary art galleries, including Barbara Gladstone, 303, Matthew Marks, David Zwirner, Team, Greene-Naftali and Lelong, as well as stalwarts of the photography scene like Fraenkel, Howard Greenberg, Julie Saul, Robert Mann and Klotz-Sirmon -- a combination that promises to reflect the way the medium's widespread and expanding presence. A broad range of modern and contemporary material -- some of it freshly minted -- will be presented, along with some videos and occasional single-artist shows and installations (Roberta Smith).

Museums

"AMERICAN ANTHEM: MASTERWORKS FROM THE AMERICAN FOLK ART MUSEUM," 45 West 53rd Street, (212) 265-1040 (through Jan. 5). The last of three shows celebrating the American Folk Art Museum's new building, "Anthem" displays more than 250 objects in the museum's collection, and in the cleverly designed new digs the show really comes on strong. It displays some of folk art's most esteemed icons, among them the "Flag Gate," a weathered farm gate of painted wood in the shape of an American flag; a pair of spiffy lady-and-gentleman portraits by Ammi Phillips; a spirited carousel horse from Coney Island carved by Charles Carmel; and a life-size baseball player at bat, carved by Samuel Anderson Robb. For the first time, the show includes the work of 20th-century self-taught artists in context with earlier folk art in the collection. Also for the first time the museum demonstrates its recently expanded collecting interests beyond the United States, showing the work of 20th-century self-taught Europeans like Adolf Wolfli, Madge Gill and Carlo Zinelli. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $9; $5 for students and 62+ (Grace Glueck).

* "RICHARD AVEDON: PORTRAITS," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 5). Just eight years after the last Richard Avedon show, here's a survey of portraits. The fashion analogy is obvious: the repackaged product, a clever campaign to market the same old goods. But the show is gorgeous: a pitch-perfect mix of modest-size, big and unbelievably big prints, each an exquisitely made object. Whatever else the works might be, they are unforgettable. Celebrity only partly accounts for their status. Mr. Avedon brings other factors to bear: a sense of spectacle, clinical precision, energy, movement even in static head shots (the figures often seem so tense they look ready to jump out of the pictures) and an irrepressible attraction to power. His career dovetails with the era of the paparazzi, the tell-all media and the obligatory scandals and secret sufferings of the rich and fashionable. You might say he raised this cultural fixation to a neurotic art. The trade-off with him is always between style and substance. It's the conflict of our culture. No wonder his pictures are so embedded in our imagination. Hours: Sundays and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 a.m. to 5:30 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays until 9 p.m. Admission: $12; $7 for students and 65+ (Michael Kimmelman).

* JUDY CHICAGO: "THE DINNER PARTY," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Feb. 9). This exhibition welcomes back Ms. Chicago's extravagant installation banquet of ceramic plates and handmade table runners dedicated to 39 women. A feminist landmark, it is joining the permanent collection 22 years after its first appearance at the museum. It is amazing to see. Made with the help of hundreds of volunteers from 1975 to 1979, "The Dinner Party" sums up the first stage of feminist art, reflects the late 70's rematerialization of the art object, and is startlingly prescient of the art of the late 80's and 90's in its ambition to be both aggressively visual and politically charged. Despite being almost as much a part of American culture as Norman Rockwell, Walt Disney, W.P.A. murals and the AIDS quilt, it retains much of its original revolutionary fervor. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 a.m. to 6 p.m. (until 11 p.m. the first Saturday of each month). Admission: $6; $3 for students and 62+ (Smith).

* "CULTIVATED LANDSCAPES: REFLECTIONS OF NATURE IN CHINESE PAINTING WITH SELECTIONS FROM THE COLLECTION OF MARIE-HELENE AND GUY WEILL," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Feb. 9). This show is basically a rotation of the permanent collection, of the kind required to protect light-sensitive silk scrolls and ink-painted album pages. But the Met has a flair for turning necessity into a virtue by reintroducing work along thematic lines and introducing fresh material to lend a sense of event. Such is the case here. At the center of the reinstallation is a group of splendid Ming and Qing dynasty paintings recently given or promised to the museum by the New York collectors Marie-Helene and Guy Weill. They are a genuine attraction in themselves and a logical link in the continuum of this museum's Chinese holdings. Hours and admission: see above (Holland Cotter).

* "DRAWING NOW: EIGHT PROPOSITIONS," Museum of Modern Art, Queens, 45-20 33rd Street, at Queens Boulevard, Long Island City, (212) 708-9400 (through Jan. 6). This generous sampling of work by 26 young artists provides a sweeping, even opulent view of drawing at the threshold of the 21st century. The variety of techniques and materials, the mix of large-scale feats of draftsmanship with clusters of framed works, the broad spate of sources (from American quilt patterns to Japanese anime to 19th-century illustration) and the range of narrative ambition create an exhilarating sense of possibility. The division of the work into eight different approaches, or propositions, balances coherence with diversity. Some of the artists illustrate rather than fully embody the curators' categories and there is an excess of fashionable, even overexposed artists from a handful of hot galleries. Nonetheless, "Drawing Now" is required viewing for anyone remotely interested in today's art. It sets a standard for future shows of its kind. Hours: Thursdays through Mondays from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m; until 7:45 p.m. on Fridays. Admission: $12; $8.50 for students and 65+ (Smith).

* "EXPOSED: THE VICTORIAN NUDE," Brooklyn Museum of Art, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Prospect Park, (718) 638-5000 (through Jan. 5). For the latest overview of British naughtiness, you may once again go to (where else?) Brooklyn, for this show of not very prudish Victorian art. "Exposed" has even more naked women without pubic hair than the last Vanessa Beecroft show at the Gagosian Gallery. The naked young maidens here, shackled to a rock or draped over the oars of a ship (the boatmen bravely stare straight ahead) or riding horses or just standing there with anacondas wrapped around their bodies are Andromeda, the Sirens, Godiva and Harmonia. The artists include Sargent, Frederic Leighton and Herbert Schmalz, whose "Faithful Unto Death" presents half a dozen or so naked damsels, loosely bound to herms, awaiting lions in the Circus Maximus. Lawrence Alma-Tadema imagines apple-flushed Victorian women soaking in a Roman plunge bath. Fortunately, the show does not stint on genuine pornography. Perfume and underwear advertisers today clearly have nothing on the feisty Victorians. The show ends with works by Walter Sickert and Gwen John, artists at the turn of the last century who dispensed with the kinky fantasies of antigravitational breasts and painted what they really saw. From Alma-Tadema to Ms. Beecroft and cold cream commercials. From John and Sickert to Lucian Freud (who could never be confused with Herbert Schmalz). Hours and admissions: See above (Kimmelman)

* "FACING THE MASK" AND "RECENT ACQUISITIONS: SELECTIONS FROM THE PERMANENT COLLECTION," Museum for African Art, third floor, 36-01 43rd Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-7700 (through March 2). The Museum for African Art, formerly of SoHo, makes the leap to a new home in Long Island City, with a very beautiful if surveyish show, "Facing the Mask," which happens to be all about moving. Some of the moving is physical, some psychological and spiritual, and it is embodied in more than 70 stunning masks, no two alike, from across sub-Saharan Africa. Some were used for popular entertainment; others were moral forces incarnate. Their purpose was transport, and they are supplemented by films of masquerades in action. Also on view is a selection of work from the museum's still small but growing permanent collection. Hours: Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 11 to 6 p.m. Admission: $5; $2.50 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

"ADOLPH GOTTLIEB: A SURVEY EXHIBITION," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92nd Street, (212) 423-3271 (through March 2). Gottlieb's painting has not aged as well as that of his colleagues Pollock, Rothko and Newman. His journey leads from 1930's representational pictures that resemble those by his friend Milton Avery to the gridded pictographic works of the 40's to the iconic circle-and-burst paintings of the late 50's, which have been his most memorable works. In the 1960's his canvases expand and brighten under the influence of Color Field painting. This 31-painting exhibition casts an illuminating light on a period of tremendous creative ferment in Western art. Hours: Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Mondays through Wednesdays, 11 a.m. to 5:45 p.m.; Thursdays, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Fridays, 11 a.m. to 3 p.m. Admission: $8; $5.50 for students and 65+ (Ken Johnson).

"MOVING PICTURES," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). This survey of photography with a small selection of video, film and installation art appended may be the largest exhibition of its kind in a major New York museum. Drawn almost entirely from the Guggenheim's permanent collection, it has a snappy yet unobtrusive design by Hani Rashid and ably surveys the expansion of contemporary art by camera-dependent media from the late 1960's to now. It begins with works by Nam June Paik, Bruce Nauman and Robert Smithson, then moves up the museum's ramp through photographs by Nan Goldin, Cindy Sherman and Andreas Gursky, concluding with video and film by artists like Stan Douglas, Shirin Neshat and Pierre Huyghe. An added attraction is the foam-lined, cavelike video galleries perched at the top of the spiral, which give the show a giddy, Hall of the Mountain King finale that seems to say, "Onward and upward with video." Hours: Saturdays through Wednesdays, 10 a.m. to 5:45 p.m; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m. Admission: $12; $9 for students and 65+ (Smith)

* "POUSSIN, CLAUDE AND THEIR WORLD: 17TH-CENTURY FRENCH DRAWINGS FROM THE ECOLE DES BEAUX-ARTS, PARIS," Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, (212) 288-0700 (through Dec. 1). The Ecole des Beaux-Arts, the world's oldest surviving art school (founded in 1648), assembled an enormous collection of works to instruct its students in the discipline of drawing. Those from the 17th century, the great age of Nicolas Poussin and Claude Lorrain, are especially outstanding. The 71 here survey French drawing from 1620 to 1680, when classicism came to French art, aiming to restore High Renaissance ideals of clarity, order and balance, with the Italian painter Raphael as a revered model. The emphasis is on the works of Poussin (1594-1665) and Claude (1604-1682), a history painter and a landscapist. But lesser-known masters like Simon Vouet, Eustache Le Sueur and Charles Le Brun are also included. Wicked doings in the Bible, sex in mythology, the ordered schematics of French architecture and the pomp and circumstance of the French court are some of the subjects covered in the drawings, which should send any aficionado to the Frick on the run. Hours and admissions: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 9 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Admission: $12; $5 for students; $8 for 62+ (Glueck).

* "THE THAW COLLECTION: MASTER DRAWINGS AND OIL SKETCHES, ACQUISITIONS SINCE 1994," Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, (212) 685-0008 (through Jan. 19). This selection of more than 100 European drawings and oil sketches is the latest update on a personal collection that Eugene V. Thaw and his wife, Clare, have been depositing at the Morgan in increments since 1975. The last such show in 1994 left everyone a bit light-headed it was so good. This one has a lot going for it, too, including work by Rembrandt, Ruisdael, Degas and the incomparable Samuel Palmer. A cluster of 19th-century German and Scandinavian works give the proceedings a piney, Romantic air. Nearly half the show is plein-air oil sketches, which the Thaws have recently been acquiring in depth. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, to 8 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 6 p.m. Admission: $8; $6 for students and 65+ (Cotter).

* "BILL VIOLA: GOING FORTH BY DAY," Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Jan. 12). An ambitious meditation on the epic themes of human existence, this frescolike video installation consists of five panels, shot using the latest technology and projected simultaneously on the walls of one huge gallery. Each deals with a specific theme: rebirth, journey through life, disaster, death and resurrection. Inspired by the works of Renaissance painters like Giotto and Luca Signorelli, the show relates as much to still painting as it does to the moving images of cinema and television. Except for a few scenes, the action is almost in slow motion, suggesting the stasis of looking at paintings and allowing the viewer to shift attention from panel to panel without losing focus. The liveliest scene is "The Deluge," in which a series of ordinary street events occurs before the facade of a Classical-looking house. They are interrupted by a tumultuous flood pouring out of the building's apertures that sends people running for their lives. The work was mostly shot before the Sept. 11 disaster, but is amazingly prophetic of it. If some of the imagery is corny, it is still a deeply felt and provocative piece of work. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).

* "WINOGRAND 1964," International Center of Photography, 1133 Avenue of the Americas, at 43rd Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Dec. 1). In 1964 the photographer Garry Winogrand crisscrossed the United States in a slow, black 1957 two-door Ford Fairlaine, taking nearly 20,000 photographs along the way. Here are around 150 of them, most never shown before. Some are not terrific. Winogrand was a hit-and-miss artist, and the show could have been edited. But others are great, and together the images add up to a fresh, divinely eccentric portrait of America after the assassination of President John F. Kennedy. The resonance with 9/11, though obvious, goes unstated. A poor skeptic, Winogrand clearly saw the fragility and the preciousness of what binds people together. Many of the pictures seem fragile, too: they're fleeting stories sometimes so provisional as to be barely coherent, irreducible, like life, to a simple message. Winogrand captured how America once again transformed catastrophe into commerce, an inevitable but also strangely redemptive process. Hours and admission: Tuesdays through Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Fridays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 6 p.m. Admission: $9; $6, students and 62+ (Kimmelman).

Galleries: Uptown

GEORGE BASELITZ, "Paintings and Drawings From the 1960's," Zwirner & Wirth, 32 East 69th Street, (212) 517-8677 (through Nov. 2). Before this German Neo-Expressionist started turning his canvases upside down, he made earthy, saturnine paintings and drawings right side up. His gnarly, muddy pictures from the 60's of people and animals have an evocative, primordial quality and sometimes, as in a small ink portrait of a bare-chested Antonin Artaud, a strange delicacy (Johnson).

MARKUS LUPERTZ, "Semiramis," Knoedler, 19 East 70th Street, (212) 794-0550 (through Nov. 16). Titled after the Babylonian Queen Semiramis, creator of the legendary Hanging Gardens, Mr. Lupertz's paintings, in which rectangles of florid, clotted Abstract Expressionist painting are set off within internal borders, might be a meditation on beauty and decadence. Superficially, these medium-size canvases by the head of the Dusseldorf Academy of Art resemble the paintings of Howard Hodgkin, but they are animated more by oblique irony than by lyrical hedonism (Johnson).

GYORGY ROMAN, "A Survey," Janos Gat, 1100 Madison Avenue, at 82nd Street, (212) 327-0441 (through Nov. 9). This Hungarian painter (1903-1981) had an incredibly adventurous life. Rendered deaf and mute by a childhood bout with meningitis, he went on to become a professional boxer, a candy-maker's apprentice, a world traveler and a novelist. An unpredictable mix of Expressionism, Primitivism, Symbolism and political allegory, his earthy paintings have one eye on war, pestilence and nostalgic memories, the other on the formal and material possibilities of painting itself (Johnson).

Galleries: Chelsea

LARRY BROWN, Sears-Peyton, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 966-7469 (through Nov. 16). Spheres, globes and molecular models drift and tumble through space in Mr. Brown's semi-abstract paintings. The artist, an erstwhile pure abstractionist, grounds his cosmic vision in glazed, sensuously painterly surfaces and contains it within compressive compositions (Johnson).

JITISH KALLAT, Bose Pacia Modern, 508 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-7074 (through Nov. 2). This young Indian artist made his New York solo debut three years ago with work that looked so fully resolved it was hard to imagine where he might take it from there. An answer comes in the new paintings here, in which he has expanded his scale, clarified his compositions and varied his palette. As before, he addresses political subjects -- AIDS, poverty and sectarian violence -- that have a very specific meaning in India, but are also of urgent concern elsewhere (Cotter).

EDDA RENOUF, "Time Lines," Joseph Helman, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 929-1545 (through Nov. 6). Ms. Renouf, who started exhibiting her work in Europe in the early 70's, makes Minimalistic multi-panel abstract paintings, in which rubbed-in shades of red, orange or blue create textures like worn denim. These fields are subtly activated by geometric designs made by selective removal of threads from the canvas. Ms. Renouf means her work to be about time, but its effect is more of elegant, dry formality (Johnson).

CLIFFORD ROSS, "Hurricanes," Sonnabend, 536 West 22nd Street, (212) 627-1018 (through Nov. 2). When a hurricane hits the coast of Long Island and most reasonable people are indoors safe and dry, Mr. Ross is up to his waist in the ocean shooting the waves. In his large, eerily lucid black-and-white photographs, the thrashing surf appears magically frozen into otherworldly landscapes (Johnson).

PETER WAITE, Edward Thorp, 210 11th Avenue, near 24th Street, (212) 691-6565 (through Nov. 2). Mr. Waite's moody photo-derived paintings of modest suburban houses are made with a nice, economical touch that simplifies detail and delicately outlines forms to slightly cartoonish effect. A touching nostalgia calls to mind Edward Hopper. There is an up-to-date conceptual program, too: each home displays an American flag, making the series a meditation on patriotic kitsch (Johnson).

JUDITH WESTPHALEN, Jan Van der Donk, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 691-5973 (through Nov. 21). This Peruvian painter (1922-1976) was a participant in Latin American artistic and intellectual circles. A four-decade survey of works on paper reveals a sensibility of urbane delicacy. Throughout, the artist engages in a dialogue with Cubism and Constructivism, producing compact compositions of layered, translucent planes in muted hues, shot through with cool, spacey light (Johnson).

Galleries: SoHo

"TRUE MEDIUMS," Cavin-Morris, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 226-3768 (through Nov. 2). This fine exhibition features works by psychic mediums who used drawings to materialize receptions from the great beyond. It's not otherworldly imagery so much as the drawing itself that fascinates. Included are ghostly faces drawn with extreme delicacy by Fernand Desmoulin; mandalas like stained-glass windows by Norma Oliver; colorful, stratified landscapes by Agatha Wojciechowsky; and calligraphic flowers penciled by Helen Butler Wells (Johnson).

Other Galleries

* "THE AGES OF MANKIND: TIME TO HOPE," Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 932-7347 (through Nov. 24; daily, 9:30 a.m. to noon and 1 to 5 p.m.). All but unheralded, this show seems to have dropped into New York like an unbidden gift, and what a gift: 100 superb examples of Spanish religious art, which is some of the most rapturous and wrenching religious art ever made, seen in a perfect setting. They include Romanesque madonnas, Gothic crucifixions, paintings of saints by El Greco and Goya, and a handwritten letter by St. Teresa of Avila, all from churches, monasteries and museums in the Spanish provinces of Castile and Leon. The images, among them life-size polychrome sculptures, are sexy, gruesome and, above all, theatrical, projecting big, primary emotions. The effect is gloriously intense (Cotter).

* "BETWEEN WORD AND IMAGE: MODERN IRANIAN VISUAL CULTURE," Grey Art Gallery, New York University, 100 Washington Square East, Greenwich Village, (212) 998-6780 (through Dec. 7). This no-frills exhibition is about the dynamics of cultural borrowing, the inseparability of art and politics, and the interplay of modernism and Islamicism. It begins with painting and sculptures from the 1960's in which Western styles and Iranian themes merge. It continues with riveting photographs documenting the arrival of the Iranian Revolution in 1979. And it concludes with art that the revolution produced: political posters inspired by both the Western counterculture and militant Islamic ideology. Depending on the amount of reflective synthesis you're willing to do, the results can seem richly layered, or disjointed and undercooked. But the materials and the ideas on display are fascinating (Cotter).

Last Chance

* WILLIAM ANTHONY, "Once More With Feeling," Dorfman Projects, 529 West 20th Street, Chelsea, (212) 352-2272 (through Wednesday). Mr. Anthony directs his comical faux-juvenile vision at masterpieces of art. Drawn in scrawly pencil lines and colored by smudgy brushwork, his sock-puppet versions of works like Hieronymus Bosch's "Ship of Fools," Picasso's "Frugal Repast" and Andy Warhol's portraits of Edith Scull are delightfully goofy. And in some cases, like "Sigmund Makes the Scene With Some Cezanne Bathers, Thereby Screwing Up Their Sex Lives," they are almost profound (Johnson).

RUSSELL CROTTY, CRG Gallery, 535 West 22nd Street, Chelsea, (212) 229-2766 (through tomorrow). Mr. Crotty's astronomical interests are realized in his best show yet. Using a fine-point black pen, he draws landscapes with starry skies on white, beach ball-size spheres. Suspended on thin wires, seven of these globes hover through the gallery, creating the ambience of a Minimalist sculpture installation. The artist's drawing simultaneously dissolves the surfaces into illusory spaces and pulls you in for close inspection of the finely textured surfaces (Johnson).

* KAFFE FASSETT, "Pattern as Obsession," Luise Ross, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo, (212) 343-2161 (through tomorrow). Notwithstanding the exhibition's title, this London artist is less obsessed than delightfully inventive in using the domestic arts of knitting, needlepoint, rug hooking and sewing to produce colorful, optically absorbing essays in patternmaking. A funky, folk-art-like quality is belied by the sophisticated play with harmony and dissonance (Johnson).

* EDWIN HALE LINCOLN, "No Record So True," Richard York, 21 East 65th Street, (212) 772-9155 (through tomorrow). Lincoln's magnum opus was a 20-year project culminating in 1914 in a 400-picture catalog called "Wild Flowers of New England." It is a fascinating blend of science, Modernist aesthetics and New England Transcendentalism. Each of the 199 platinum prints shown here is a luminous, perfectly composed marvel of austere beauty and botanical passion (Johnson).

LAURENT MILLET, Robert Mann, 210 11th Avenue, at 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 989-7600 (through tomorrow). Using cardboard, found sticks, wire and paint, this French photographer cobbles together semi-abstract sculptures and then photographs them standing in shallow water at the beach. His pictures are more than documents of whimsical ephemera, as each offers a puzzling conflation of the real and the illusory. Mr. Millet's project is an engagingly wry, low-tech investigation of epistemological uncertainty (Johnson).

* JIM SHAW, Swiss Institute, 495 Broadway, at Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 925-2035, and Metro Pictures, 519 West 24th Street, Chelsea, (212) 206-7100, (through tomorrow). At the Swiss Institute, Mr. Shaw, who sometimes assumes the role of other artists, presents work supposedly by a mediocre abstract painter named Adam Goodman. Goodman, we're told, supports himself as an illustrator under the pseudonym Archie Gunn. Goodman, we're told, is a believer in O-ism, a discount version of Mormonism, which inspired not only his abstractions but dozens of anonymous thrift-store paintings (all by Mr. Shaw, too, of course), on view at Metro Pictures. These are comically clumsy pictures of strange beings, obscure rituals, torture, stagecoaches and much else that makes blissfully little sense. It's all very funny, and as usual with Mr. Shaw, a sly, sardonic take on the mythologies of American art and high-low taste
(Kimmelman).

JAVIER TELLEZ, White Box, 525 West 26th Street, Chelsea, (212) 714-2347 (through tomorrow). Mr. Tellez was born in Venezuela in 1969. His parents were psychologists, and as a child he was familiar with the environment of psychiatric hospitals. That environment is the raw material for much of his work, including the installation that makes up this show. The gallery has been filled with hundreds of toy-size trucks made from bars of soap and boxes of psychiatric medication. There is a captivating but disturbing video of patients in a Venezuelan hospital pushing a giant beach ball from one ward to the next, and finally over the institution's wall. He also has a beautiful piece in the "Queens International" at the Queens Museum, through Nov. 3 (Cotter).

* 25TH-ANNIVERSARY BENEFIT SELECTIONS EXHIBITION, Drawing Center, 35 Wooster Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2166 (through tomorrow). Nearly 400 drawings by artists who have previously exhibited at this valuable institution over the last 25 years create an initial impression of wondrous creative fertility. With extended looking, one starts to feel a certain leveling decorousness, but there are intriguing oddities, like Stavit Allweis's picture of a wild-eyed girl in a pool of water, a kind of surrealistic fairy painting (Johnson).

HEADLINE: DINER'S JOURNAL 

BYLINE:  By Eric Asimov 

 BODY:
It takes courage to put together a menu without a steak on it, or any beef at all, for that matter. It especially takes courage to put together such an uncompromising menu at the corner of Broadway and 88th Street.
 But despite this neighborhood's reputation as a culinary wasteland (or maybe because of it), tables at Aix, Didier Virot's new restaurant, which opened just a few weeks ago, have been awfully hard to come by. 
 Aix is Take Two for Mr. Virot, formerly the executive chef at JoJo and sous-chef at Jean Georges. His first solo effort, called Virot, earned two stars in The Times in 2001 from William Grimes but was short-lived, a victim partly of an inhospitable site in the Dylan Hotel near Grand Central Terminal and of the economic slowdown. At Aix, Mr. Virot has reassembled much of his Virot menu and his Virot cast, including his pastry chef, Jenhangir Mehta. He has also scaled back prices and has adopted a more casual, easy-going atmosphere for his restaurant.
But Mr. Virot thankfully has not pandered to some preconceived notion of what this neighborhood wants. The menu pulses with complexity. He marinates tuna with cucumber and coriander before serving it with sheep's milk yogurt, and makes cannelloni with crabmeat, celery root and clams, serving it in a sweet red chili broth. Still, you don't have to think to enjoy lighter-than-air gnocchi floating on a creamy emulsion with slivers of Jerusalem artichoke for contrast, or supple, luscious foie gras crusted in pistachio, with a sweet mound of potatoes and quince.
Mr. Virot pairs fish with earthy vegetables that give the dishes pungence and body while supporting the star. Roasted sea bass has enough rich flavor to stand up to a piquant olive sauce augmented with carrots and salsify, while daurade, despite its delicate texture, matches up well with the husky flavors of radishes and yellow wax beans. And while beef is not an option, Mr. Virot offers a fine venison loin with a quince beet strudel.
Mr. Mehta is an adventurous pastry chef, who is in top form with dishes like airy licorice pannacotta and a buttery apple brioche with rosemary.
While Mr. Virot has basically stuck to his guns, he has made one concession to the neighborhood. Many of the children in attendance at dinner one recent evening were no doubt pleased to hear the waiters reciting dishes just for them: grilled chicken or penne with tomato sauce.
Aix, 2398 Broadway, at 88th Street, Manhattan, (212) 874-7400. Appetizers, $8 to $16; main courses, $14 to $28; desserts, $8.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Aix on the Upper West Side offers a menu notable for its complexity. (Harry Zernike for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Hong Kong Is Under New Scrutiny 

BYLINE:  By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Credit-rating agencies, investors and bankers are voicing growing concern about the Hong Kong government's finances, citing a huge budget deficit, a stagnant economy and falling consumer prices. 
 The pessimism has begun to hurt local stocks, which slipped 0.2 percent today. And some speculators in futures markets have begun placing modest bets that Hong Kong will have to devalue its currency. Budget problems are even prompting talk of an increase in the territory's flat 15 percent tax on salaries, a tax regime beloved of conservative economists in the United States. 
 The strongest international warning so far came today from Standard & Poor's, which said it might lower Hong Kong's rating for long-term local-currency debts, now at AA-. The rating is unchanged for now, the agency said, and the rating for Hong Kong's long-term foreign-currency debt, now A+, is not at risk.
Antony Leung, Hong Kong's financial secretary and third-ranking government official, promised this afternoon that a task force would solicit the public's views on the territory's fiscal problems. "The government is determined and has plans to tackle the budget deficit," Mr. Leung said. His office said tonight that those plans would be put before a committee of the legislature on Friday.
The budget deficit is equal to 5 percent of economic output and is widening, in large part because revenues have fallen by 30 percent, hurt by a slow economy and a steep decline in property prices; land sales are an important contributor to the government's finances.
The government has four options, none palatable, to curb the deficit. One is to cut spending; it is already doing so on a limited scale, even to the point of small cuts in the wages of civil servants. But this approach risks making economic growth here -- now around 1 percent a year -- even more anemic, or even tipping the economy into recession. 
Another option is to raise taxes sharply, which might also crimp economic growth and might risk prompting more companies to leave Hong Kong, relocating elsewhere in Southern China or moving to Singapore in search of low taxes.
A third option is to step up land sales, but that may depress property prices even further, angering wealthy developers and middle-class condominium owners. 
The fourth option is to devalue the Hong Kong dollar, making exports more competitive and lowering the cost to international companies of basing their Asian operations here. But this policy would make imports like gasoline much more expensive, and might roil financial markets long used to a stable currency. 
At the present exchange rate of about 7.8 to the United States dollar, Hong Kong is the world's most expensive city to live in, even surpassing Tokyo and Osaka, according to a study released in July by Mercer Human Resource Consulting. Apartment rents are higher than in Manhattan.
But prices are falling. Hong Kong said on Tuesday that its consumer price index was 3.7 percent lower in September than a year earlier, among the most severe deflation reported worldwide this year. Still, they are not falling fast enough to make the territory competitive with nearby large cities in Southern China, where rents are about a third of the levels in Hong Kong. 
The currency-board system Hong Kong uses, in which each Hong Kong dollar in circulation is backed by foreign currency held in reserve, has kept the exchange rate pegged at a steady rate but has made it hard to use interest rate cuts to stimulate spending.
Chew Ping, the associate director for Asian sovereign debt ratings at Standard & Poor's, said that with the public opposed to either higher taxes or lower government spending, breaking the currency's peg to the American dollar may become an option. "If the fiscal position continues to deteriorate, the pressures on the peg will intensify," Mr. Chew said. 
Moody's Investors Service said in a report on Sept. 27 that devaluation could bring long-term economic benefits, but warned that there would be short-term financial problems. Moody's said its outlook on Hong Kong's ratings was stable, and it made no change today. 
Paul Coughlin, the managing director for Asian sovereign and corporate debt ratings at Standard & Poor's, said Hong Kong still had considerable financial strength, including sufficient built-up reserves to cover another five years of budget deficits at their present size. It could then borrow to cover the deficits for another four or five years and still be no deeper in debt, relative to the size of its economy, than many Western European nations, Mr. Coughlin said. 
The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, which maintains the currency peg, also has one of the world's largest hoards of foreign exchange. The Hong Kong dollar has been roughly stable against the American dollar since 1983, withstanding an assault by speculators during the Asian financial crisis in 1997 and 1998, when many other countries devalued.
Some prominent economists here say Hong Kong must go on running large budget deficits to restart economic growth, while defending the currency peg. "As long as the path to a balance after five years is spelled out, that's all we need to see," Ajay Kapur, the chief Asian equities strategist at Salomon Smith Barney, said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Hong Kong's central business district includes Cheung Kong Tower, left; HSBC headquarters, center; and Jardine House, right. Hong Kong was returned to China in 1997, and property values have declined since. (Reuters)(pg. W7)

HEADLINE: WPP Revenue Falls About 3% As Profit Outlook Worsens 

BYLINE:  By SUZANNE KAPNER

DATELINE: LONDON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Raising the prospect of a renewed downturn in the advertising industry, the WPP Group said today that its revenue had fallen in the third quarter and that its profit outlook was worsening, not improving.
 Sir Martin Sorrell, the chief executive of WPP, has tended to offer a gloomier outlook than his peers, and has largely been proved right, winning the respect of investors, analysts said. His frankness stands in sharp contrast to the recent muddled messages from some rivals, these analysts said. 
 The Interpublic Group of Companies, for instance, recently caught investors off guard with two pieces of bad news: Earnings would fall well below expectations for the third quarter and the full year because problems at its motor sports division were much worse than had been thought, and a restatement of earnings for the last five years would include charges almost twice as large as it led investors to expect back in August. 
Sir Martin, by contrast, has been steadily guiding analysts to lower their earnings and profits expectations, and WPP has so far avoided surprising the market. He has been saying all along that any recovery in advertising spending would probably be gradual. 
But the timing of that hoped-for recovery has remained elusive. Sir Martin says now that he does not expect it until 2004, when the American presidential election and the Olympic Games may pry open advertisers' pocketbooks.
WPP said today that business was no longer headed downward sharply, as it was in the months after the terror attacks of Sept. 11, 2001, but neither was it turning robustly upward.
"Falling share prices in the summer on both sides of the Atlantic and increasing unemployment has had an impact on consumer confidence, suggesting a potential 'double-dip' recession," the company said in a statement accompanying its revenue figures today.
Frederik Kooij of J. P. Morgan Chase said many advertisers were in a wait-and-see mode. "A lot of companies are hiding behind the uncertainty of war with Iraq, and which direction the consumer is going, as a reason for not pressing the button on advertising spending," he said.
Like some of its rivals, WPP spent lavishly on acquisitions in recent years, and accumulated a lot of debt in the process -- $:1.3 billion ($2 billion) at the end of the third quarter, up from $:978 million ($1.5 billion) a year earlier. The bulk of it, $:806 million ($1.2 billion), was run up to pay for capital spending, acquisitions and bonus payments related to those acquisitions, the company said.
Exchange-rate fluctuations also hurt WPP, turning what would have been a 2.3 percent gain in total revenue into a decline of nearly 3 percent for the quarter ended Sept. 30. Revenue in North America, flat in dollar terms, fell by 6.8 percent when converted to British pounds. 
The company also said its operating profit margins would probably turn out to be smaller in the second half of the year than in the first.

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate; 
Co-ops Are Trying to Refinance Without Penalties

BYLINE:  By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
Like homeowners taking advantage of historically low mortgage rates to reduce their monthly payments, co-op corporations are anxious to refinance underlying mortgages on their buildings. But many co-ops face a hefty penalty if they pay off the current loan before its term expires.
 Lenders have responded by offering what are called "forward commitment/early rate lock" agreements as a way to help co-ops avoid or minimize prepayment penalties. 
 Prepayment penalties are typically either an amount equal to what the lender would lose in interest payments as a result of the prepayment or a percentage of the outstanding principal of the mortgage. 
The forward commitments, which result in a small increase in the interest rate for the loan, generally run for 2 to 10 months but could stretch to one year. Industry professionals said the number of co-ops using such commitments was growing and included 860 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan, with 156 apartments, and Park City Estates, a five-building complex of 1,049 apartments on 98th Street in Rego Park, Queens.
Last February the National Cooperative Bank began offering forward commitments of up to six months, said Edward Howe, senior vice president at the bank's Manhattan office. The bank has used forward commitments on a dozen loans, including a $24.5 million mortgage to Park City Estates.
Gregg Winter, president of Winter & Company Commercial Real Estate Finance, a Manhattan mortgage brokerage firm, said that for some co-ops the forward commitment could dovetail with the expiration of the current loan, eliminating the prepayment penalty. For others it could delay the closing to a point in the existing loan when the prepayment penalty could either be paid or reduced, said Mr. Winter, whose firm has done 10 such deals including the one at 860 Fifth Avenue.
Borrowers pay a premium to lock in the current low rate for several months. It amounts to an interest rate increase of two to five basis points (a basis point is one-hundredth of a percentage point) for each month of the extension.
For example, Mr. Winter said, a co-op that locked in a 5.6 percent rate and delayed the closing for 10 months could get the first four months free and then be charged 5 basis points a month for the remaining 6 months.
Borrowers must also pay a deposit of 2 to 3 percent of the loan, which is refunded when the loan closes and forfeited if it does not close.
Mr. Howe said that some banks, including NCB, offer to add the prepayment fee to the principal of the new loan. Other strategies available to borrowers include paying the forward commitment premium as a one-time fee, rather than increasing the mortgage rate, and negotiating a more lenient prepayment penalty on their new loan.
He said that his bank worked with Park City Estates to lock in a rate of 5.55 percent in August on a 10-year, $24.5 million fixed-rate mortgage with an additional $3 million line of credit, and that it was delaying the closing until December. That is when the prohibition lifts for the co-op to repay its old $13 million mortgage, which carried a 7.9 percent rate. The co-op also borrowed $4 million as an additional line of credit.
Robert I. Oziel, the lawyer for Park City Estates Tenants Corporation, said that in refinancing, the co-op would pay a $600,000 prepayment fee that would be paid off in 18 months because of the new loan's reduced interest rate. The co-op's monthly mortgage payments will be $120,622, an increase of $7,800, which Mr. Oziel said was offset by the $7.5 million more the co-op will receive and use to improve the complex and to invest in high-yield securities.
Mr. Winter said that in the case of 860 Fifth Avenue the co-op took a 10-year fixed-rate mortgage in June for $6.7 million, locking in a 5.95 percent interest rate, but delayed the closing for four months until last Friday. It replaced the co-op's existing $4.6 million loan, which had a 7.15 percent interest rate and would not expire until December 2003.
Les Tanner, the chairman of the board at 860 Fifth Avenue, said the co-op not only got the lower interest rate and borrowed additional money for ongoing capital improvements, but also reduced its annual mortgage payments by $16,000 to $404,000 as well as its prepayment penalty by $50,000, to $286,508. And it was done without raising residents' monthly maintenance cost, Mr. Tanner said, adding that, "it was a win-win."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Charles M. Zsebedics, left, the general manager of Park City Estates in Rego Park, Queens, and Robert I. Oziel, the lawyer for the five-building apartment complex's tenant corporation. The co-op has refinanced its mortgage. (Richard Lee for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS; 
Shares Slump as Doubts About the Recent Rally Increase

BYLINE:  By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Stocks fell for a second day in three yesterday amid concern that gains made in the last two weeks have driven prices higher than justified by the outlook for corporate profit growth.
 Viacom and International Paper dropped as analysts advised investors to sell shares. 
 Duke Energy slipped after saying earnings might be lower next year. 
"We've actually heard some companies that have knocked down fourth-quarter earnings and are cautious," said Matt Brown, who helps oversee $18 billion at Wilmington Trust in Wilmington, Del.
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 13.64 points, or 1.5 percent, to 882.50, with Household International recording the biggest loss. Household International fell $3.62, or 14 percent, to $22.83, on concern that it may face higher borrowing costs.
The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 176.93 points, or 2.1 percent, to close at 8,317.34. Twenty-seven of its 30 components declined. The Nasdaq composite index shed 21.52 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,298.71.
Stocks extended declines during the afternoon after a West Virginia jury found the Union Carbide unit of Dow Chemical responsible in thousands of asbestos-related deaths and illnesses. Other companies with potential asbestos liability, like 3M and Georgia-Pacific, also fell.
"Once we started falling, no one wanted to get in the way," said Art Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company in Boston. "The asbestos situation doesn't help."
Five stocks fell for every four that rose on the New York Stock Exchange, while nine declined for every eight that advanced on the Nasdaq Stock Market.
Some 1.70 billion shares traded on the Big Board, 13 percent more than the three-month daily average.
Viacom, owner of the CBS, MTV and Nickelodeon television networks, dropped $2.86, to $44.32. Richard Bilotti, a Morgan Stanley analyst, lowered the stock to underweight from equal weight, saying advertising revenue will not grow more than 7 percent in 2003. 
The company also has exposure to asbestos lawsuits through CBS, which was acquired by Westinghouse Electric in 1995. Viacom spent $21 million in litigation claims in 2001.
Shares of Omnicom Group slid $4.27, to $59.13, after Lehman Brothers downgraded the stock. 
International Paper declined 90 cents, to $36.84. A Prudential Securities analyst, John Tumazos, expects the company to announce cost reductions to offset soft demand, lower-than-anticipated selling prices and $100 million in pension expenses. He lowered his recommendation to sell from hold.
Duke Energy shed $1.06, to $19.08. The company said earnings in the third quarter plunged 71 percent as power prices tumbled and energy trading slumped. The company said profit might fall in 2003.
Dow Chemical dropped $2.57, to $24.97. The asbestos verdict could expose the company to millions of dollars in punitive damages. Dow said it added $64 million in reserves for lawsuits in the third quarter, bringing the total to $344 million.
3M, which has settled some 200,000 lawsuits related to asbestos over the last 20 years, slid $3.63, to $125.73. Georgia-Pacific, which has costs of $132 million this year from lawsuits related to asbestos, lost 85 cents, to $11.65.
AOL Time Warner, Tyco International and Bristol-Myers Squibb gained after restating quarterly results. AOL Time Warner rose $1.02, to $14.55. Tyco gained $1.55, to $15.49. Bristol-Myers rose 38 cents, to $24.17.
 Treasury bond prices rose. The 10-year note climbed 27/32, to a price of 102 1/32 . The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.12 percent from 4.23 percent on Wednesday.
The 30-year bond jumped 14/32, to 104 11/32 . Its yield dropped to 5.08 percent from 5.16 percent.

HEADLINE: Small Card, Big Spender 

BYLINE:  By Thomas Hine; Thomas Hine is the author of the forthcoming "I Want That! How We All Became Shoppers."

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA 

 BODY:
Inside your wallet or deep in your handbag, your credit cards are at war with one another.
 The moment of truth comes at the moment of purchase, when you're about to meet your needs, realize your desires and jump-start a sputtering economy. Often there is a moment of fumbling about as you shuffle through a deck of identically sized plastic cards, grabbing the first one, regardless of its balance or interest rate. 
 Of course, the credit card companies have only themselves to blame for these crowded wallets; for years they have deluged consumers almost daily with solicitations and offers of new cards. Now, not surprisingly, the companies have decided to introduce new kinds of cards that seek to stand out from the pack. 
Some of the new cards are small and ready for your key chain, like the new half-sized Bank of America Visa. Others are kidney shaped with a little case of their own, like the latest Discover card. Or, like the Discover Clear Platinum card, they are normal size but translucent and bumpy. Like the original Coca-Cola bottle, which was designed to be recognizable purely by touch, these are products for shoppers who are groping in the dark.
All these new designs indicate that the credit industry wants us to think about spending in a new way. Until only a few years ago, a credit card was a credential, something to be guarded and kept secure. One still sees this heritage in the design of the standard green American Express Card, which has the secure look of currency or a stock certificate. Yet the business end of a credit card has long since ceased to be the front, with its raised letters and numbers, but the back, with its magnetic strip filled with information.
Nowadays credit cards are best understood as part of a gesture. You don't proffer it to a person to approve your purchase. You swipe it through a machine to process the sale. The process reflects the way people want to shop: faster and more aggressively. Ubiquitous computer technology makes it easier.
So after decades of trying to convince us that their plastic is gold, platinum or titanium, credit card issuers are now positioning their products as embodiments of fun and freedom. Cards are even migrating to the key chain, where the action is.
One that's already there is the Mobil Speedpass, introduced in 1997. It uses a small radio transponder to communicate with an electronic system located in the gasoline pump; wave the pass near the pump and the cost of the gas is magically deducted from your checking account or added to your credit card bill. Supermarket discount cards, also usually attached to a key chain, have bar codes that when passed over scanners qualify shoppers for discounts and allow the supermarkets to track purchasing patterns.
Key-chain credit cards are the obvious next step. The fight among card issuers for wallet space promises to be like the fight among toothpaste makers for supermarket shelf space. The brand wars have moved from the aisles of the grocery store to our pockets and purses.
If one takes the long view -- the very long view -- these new cards are part of a trend to make purchasing less portentous and more routine. The introduction of low-value coins late in the Middle Ages encouraged commerce by making it possible for many more people to purchase many more things. The introduction of ready-to-wear clothing a century and a half ago freed shoppers' imaginations -- and their spending. Credit and charge cards are only about half a century old; the first credit card, Diners Club, was issued in 1950.
Since then credit cards have become ubiquitous, allowing just about anyone to buy just about anything just about anywhere. Especially in the current climate, free-spending consumers are seen as heroes, the basis of almost all hopes for economic recovery. And while we may have vague misgivings about what we'll do when the bills arrive, in the meantime we embrace every innovation that lets us shop as fast as we can.

HEADLINE: Study Finds Airport-Related Business in New York Hit Hard by 9/11, With 10,000 Jobs Lost 

BYLINE:  By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
Since the World Trade Center attacks, La Guardia and Kennedy Airports have suffered larger economic losses than most other major hub airports in the country, a new study has found.
 Those losses permeate almost every aspect of the two airports' business, from cargo and passenger traffic to hotel vacancies, and have caused the elimination of 16.5 percent of all airport-related jobs in the city since September 2001 -- almost 10,000 jobs. That is by far the largest percentage loss of any industry in the city, including the securities industry, which has lost 9 percent of its jobs since then. 
 The study, to be released next week by the Center for an Urban Future, a nonpartisan policy research group, demonstrates just how economically powerful the airports are and how widely blows to their business are felt. Almost 1,000 jobs disappeared, for example, in the city's trucking and warehouse industries from August 2001 to August of this year, in large part because those companies are heavily dependent on the airports. 
According to the Queens County Economic Development Corporation, 28 percent of all unemployment claims in the city that were directly related to the terrorist attack have come from Queens residents, many of those from airport-related layoffs.
Jonathan Bowles, the chief researcher for the center, said that part of the explanation of the downturn in airport business was the same nationwide and even worldwide: the sagging economy, security concerns, a steep drop in business travel. He added that other factors, like poor access to Kennedy and La Guardia and low wages paid to their workers, had plagued the two airports long before Sept. 11 and significantly hurt their ability to bounce back over the last year.
"If we don't start addressing these issues in the long term," Mr. Bowles said, "then the city is going to lose business, and it's going to lose more jobs."
According to the Federal Aviation Administration, commercial operations at Kennedy declined 17.7 percent from October 2001 through July of this year. Only three other major hub airports did worse: Boston Logan, Los Angeles International and Ronald Reagan Washington National, which was shut completely from Sept. 11 until early October 2001, the longest of any airport.
Six hubs performed worse than La Guardia, which lost 15.5 percent of its business during the 10 months after the attack, the study found.
Mr. Bowles said that although some evidence suggested that business at the city's two airports has begun to pick up slowly along with the rest of the economy, their performance after Sept. 11 showed that they were still poorly positioned to compete with other big airports -- particularly the closest one, Newark Liberty International Airport -- for what experts believe will be significant growth in airport business over the next decade.
Newark is 15 miles from Midtown, slightly less than the 16 miles to Kennedy, but it "is almost universally perceived" as easier to reach, the study notes. This partly explains, for example, why a majority of the overnight delivery business has shifted from Kennedy to Newark over the past 10 to 15 years.
Pasquale DiFulco, a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which controls the three airports, said he would not comment directly on the study, but he emphasized that the authority has worked for a long time on the airports' problems. The authority is committing more than $9 billion to Kennedy to add, among other things, millions more square feet of cargo space and $1.9 billion to build the AirTrain to link the airport to the subway and commuter rail lines.

HEADLINE: Jobless Claims Fall a Bit More Than Expected 

BYLINE:  Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Claims for jobless benefits fell more than expected last week, a report released today by the Labor Department showed, indicating that the economy might be growing enough to limit a rise in unemployment.
 "We've gone from a deteriorating labor market to one that is treading water, but we still haven't gone to one that is creating a lot of new jobs," said Tim McGee, chief economist at the U.S. Trust Corporation in New York, a unit of Charles Schwab. 
 Unemployment applications declined 25,000, to 389,000, for the week ended Saturday, the Labor Department reported. The decline may have been exaggerated by statistical adjustments for the Columbus Day holiday on Oct. 14, which came later than in recent years, the agency said.
Claims this month have averaged 397,000 a week, down from the September average of 425,000. The number of people collecting benefits in the week ended Oct. 12 was the lowest in six weeks, and the insured unemployment rate, which tends to track the jobless rate, fell to 2.8 percent in the week ended Oct. 12 from 2.9 percent the previous week.
Economists had expected claims to fall to 405,000 last week from a previously reported 411,000 a week earlier, based on the median of 32 forecasts in a Bloomberg News survey.

HEADLINE: Oil Companies' Results Are Hurt By Low Margins in Some Units 

BYLINE:  AP 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Several major petroleum companies said today that their third-quarter results had been hurt by lower profit margins in their refining and marketing businesses. 
 The Marathon Oil Corporation's profit in the July-September period was nearly halved at $87 million, while Sunoco reported a third-quarter loss of $9 million. 
 ConocoPhillips, the nation's third-largest integrated oil and gas company, said its $116 million loss was largely a result of one-time charges related to the August merger of Conoco and Phillips. 
But with demand for refined products increasing and refining margins beginning to improve, results should be better in the fourth quarter, said Fadel Gheit, a Fahnestock & Company petroleum analyst. 
"I think the worst is over," he said. "Demand is picking up for seasonal reasons and the economy is hopefully picking up. Industry conditions are not so great, but they're improving." 
The threat of war with Iraq adds uncertainty to the picture, Mr. Gheit said. 
ConocoPhillips said $572 million in one-time charges led to the quarterly loss of 24 cents a share. Excluding those charges, the Houston-based company reported earnings of $456 million, or 94 cents a share, meeting the expectations of analysts surveyed by Thomson First Call. Comparisons with the year-earlier period were not relevant because of the merger of the two companies. 
ConocoPhillips said revenue was $15.7 billion, compared with $6 billion a year ago. 
Marathon's third-quarter profit was equivalent to 28 cents a share. That compared with $170 million, or 62 cents a share, a year earlier. Revenue was $8.5 billion, up from $8.3 billion a year ago. 
Philadelphia-based Sunoco Inc. reported a loss of $9 million in the third quarter, or 12 cents a share, far below analyst expectations of 40 cents a share. Sunoco earned $92 million, or $1.14 a share, a year earlier. 
Revenue for Sunoco, which has to buy crude because it has no exploration or production division, was $3.8 billion for the quarter, up from $3.6 billion in July-September last year.

HEADLINE: NYC; 
An Economy Out of Whack Has a Friend

BYLINE:  By CLYDE HABERMAN 

 BODY:
The news media's interest in Ms. Grubman was so high -- you may judge for yourself how much things have changed since 9/11 -- that the Suffolk County sheriff threw open his jail the other day to reporters and photographers. On the Lizzie Cell Tour, they got to see such fascinating items as the shower and toilet she will use and the baggy uniform she will wear for the next two months.
 Later, a Grubman spokesman all but held his nose in discussing this spectacle. But maybe the Suffolk officials hit on something worth imitating in New York. Why not conduct tours of places that are normally off-limits to the public? This would be done for a fee, substantial but not exorbitant, that would go to the municipal treasury. It obviously needs every dollar it can find. 
 Surely, there is no shortage of New Yorkers and out-of-towners willing to pay a reasonable sum to look around Rikers Island or to see the detention facility next to the Criminal Courts Building, the one commonly known as the Tombs.
Tourists could be charged separately to stroll the "bridge of sighs," the midair walkway connecting the courthouse and the jail. The way things are going, this may prove to be the only bridge toll Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg will get away with. For an extra dollar or two, visitors could even feel what it is like to be handcuffed. It might be billed as the Law and Order Tour, to give it a show biz flourish.
The concept could then be extended.
Ever since the mayor put his new Department of Education in the Tweed Courthouse, that sumptuous building has essentially, and unreasonably, been closed to the public. How about letting in paying visitors, perhaps while the bureaucrats are out to lunch (no pun intended)?
In fact, Mr. Bloomberg could contribute selflessly to the cause by permitting tours of his East Side town house. Wouldn't you want to see how a billionaire lives? For an extra charge, the mayor could offer his services as a guide now and then. Never on weekends, to be sure, because then we might find out if he is in town, and that is supposed to be the greatest secret since the Manhattan Project. But if Fiorello La Guardia could read the funny papers, can't this mayor lead a tour?
No one suggests that hoards of cash can be produced this way. But the city's fiscal distress is so severe that officials may be forced to seize upon any revenue source in sight, no matter how unorthodox. Since taxes are a dirty word, especially on the eve of the election of a governor, perhaps the city should consider an array of new fees. "Fees" doesn't seem to scare politicians as easily as "taxes."
ONE idea that could yield a good deal of money is an annual parking fee for all vehicles registered in the five boroughs. As of last year, there were slightly more than two million, according to the state's Department of Motor Vehicles.
It has long been a mystery, to me anyway, why the automobile is the one piece of personal property that may be left on the street, and without charge except at parking meters. At home, we have no room for an old chest of drawers. To suggest that we be allowed to park it curbside outside our building would be to invite ridicule. Make that a car, though, and no one has a problem.
A flat parking fee of perhaps $50 a year per vehicle, or less than a dollar a week, would raise more than $100 million while hardly putting a great strain on owners. That sum is far from enough to close the mayor's budget gap. But it's a start.
So is a surcharge on chewing gum, which is a major cause of all those hideous splotches that carpet New York sidewalks. Or a substantially higher fine for littering. Or a special charge on law firms and financial companies that are permitted to clog city streets with lines of limousines waiting for hours outside their doors. Or fees for sidewalk sketch artists and similar entrepreneurs taking up precious public space without paying for the privilege.
The list of possible charges could go on, but you get the idea. And one day, when the city is returned to fiscal well-being, it can honor the person who inspired these innovations by declaring Lizzie Grubman Day.
It could be celebrated with a motorcade of sport utility vehicles -- driven in reverse, of course.

HEADLINE: A Fight Over Farms Ends, Opening Way to Wider Europe 

BYLINE:  By ELAINE SCIOLINO 

DATELINE: BRUSSELS, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
A rift between France and Germany over aid to farmers was resolved today, allowing the leaders of the European Union to begin talks on integrating 10 new countries into their club by 2004.
 The project of enlarging their world eastward -- the "big bang," as it is called here -- will create an economic and political entity with the third largest population in the world after China and India, and larger than the United States, Canada and Mexico combined. 
 European leaders and European Union officials congratulated themselves on the progress they have made so far and on the historic importance of the moment.
"This is much more than enlargement," Javier Solana, the European Union's foreign affairs representative, said in an interview. "This is the reconciliation of Europe, where 100 million citizens will become part of the institutions of one European Union." 
The European Union is also in the midst of negotiations chaired by Valery Giscard d'Estaing, the former French president, to draft a new Constitution for the new Europe. At one point he even suggested a name for it: the United States of Europe.
The cost of expansion, at $42 billion over three years, is considered relatively inexpensive -- less than half of the European Union's current annual budget. But there is intense wrangling over who will pay what. And the latest European Union survey of its citizenry showed that only a slight majority support expansion.
The entry of the 10, most of them formerly Communist countries with dysfunctional economies, will further strain western European governments now struggling with the slowest economic growth in a decade. Many member countries are reluctant to finance the vast infrastructure projects that are needed in Central and Eastern Europe. Most contentious was the farm support program, which consumes almost half the European Union's budget.
There had been dire warnings that the farm issue could derail the summit meeting.
Denmark, which currently holds the six-month-long presidency of the European Union, had threatened to keep the 15 heads of state and government in Brussels for as long as it took to hammer out an agreement. "There is no reason to hide that this will be a very difficult summit," Prime Minister Anders Fogh Rasmussen of Denmark told Reuters.
But the difficult issue was finessed rather easily after President Jacques Chirac of France and Chancellor Gerhard Schroder of Germany unexpectedly reached an agreement on payments to farmers, clearing the way for final negotiations on the European Union's move to the east.
Essentially, France, which receives more aid for its farmers than any other member, agreed that beginning in 2007, the European Union will pay French farmers progressively less in direct aid. The money that would have gone to French farmers will instead finance a phasing-in of payments to farmers in the new member states.
France and Germany agreed to give new members 25 percent of the farm aid that the other 15 receive, beginning in 2004 and increasing by increments of five percentage points every year. Overall farm spending, would be capped at 2007 levels, adjusted for inflation. In explaining the French concession, France's foreign minister, Dominique de Villepin stressed that the decision had been made to show the "solidarity" and "responsibility" of Europe.
As he left the meeting with Mr. Schroder, Mr. Chirac stressed to reporters that budget controls should not be restricted to agriculture. France is in favor of "putting a ceiling on, stabilizing agriculture spending after 2006," Mr. Chirac told journalists. "There's a common will to control spending in all areas, not only in agriculture." Earlier this week, Mr. Chirac demanded that Britain renegotiate a multibillion dollar "rebate" that it receives from the European Union every year. The "rebate" was secured in 1984 by then-Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, who argued that Britain paid far more into the European Union budget than it got back in subsidies.
Mr. Chirac met separately with Britain's current prime minister, Tony Blair, before the full meeting formally opened this evening. British officials have said repeatedly that the rebate is "not negotiable," at least until the next budget negotiations four years from now.
Apart from disputes over financing, a number of political issues are clouding the summit meeting. One is the exclusion of Turkey from the list of new members, which includes Cyprus, the Czech Republic, Estonia, Hungary, Latvia, Lithuania, Malta, Poland, Slovakia and Slovenia.
The European Union position is that Turkey, the only Muslim candidate for membership, needs to improve its human rights record and make other political reforms before negotiations can begin. At a news conference today, Mr. Rasmussen praised Turkey for laws adopted in August to abolish the death penalty in peacetime, permit greater freedom of expression and increasing the rights of ethnic Kurds. But he said Turkey now has to put those reforms into effect.
Turkey will receive a date for its admission into the European Union "if and when Turkey fulfills the criteria," Mr. Rasmussen said. "It is up to Turkey itself." Asked whether it was appropriate for the United States to pressure the European Union to admit Turkey, Mr. Rasmussen said, "I have not registered any pressure from the United States."
The United States is displeased that the European Union has not set a date for Turkey, a crucial NATO ally that shares borders with Iraq, Iran and Syria.
"Turkey is not ready," Mr. Solana said. "The United States must understand that putting Turkey into the European Union is not like putting Mexico into a free trade agreement. We treat Turkey far better than you treat Mexico."

GRAPHIC: Map of Europe highlights the current and soon to be members of the European Union.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: THE VIEW FROM ASIA; 
U.S. and Its Asian Partners Strain to Form United Stand on North Korea

BYLINE:  By STEVEN R. WEISMAN 

DATELINE: CABO SAN LUCAS, Mexico, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Bush administration officials struggled today to develop a common strategy on North Korea with Asian partners amid increasing signs of criticism by South Korea, Japan and China that Washington was being too confrontational in its approach.
 There were also indications today of disagreements within the Bush administration over whether to declare as "dead" the 1994 accord in which North Korea promised to stop building nuclear weapons in return for economic benefits from the United States, South Korea and Japan. 
 Last week, the United States disclosed that North Korea had acknowledged the existence of a program to develop highly enriched uranium for a nuclear weapon, and that the North Korean government considered the 1994 agreement "nullified."
Administration officials later said that the United States would scrap the entire agreement, negotiated during the administration of President Bill Clinton, but that this would not be acknowledged publicly. 
These comments set off alarms in Japan, China and South Korea, where officials said the 1994 framework should be preserved and renegotiated to take North Korean concerns into consideration. They called on the United States to continue to negotiate with North Korea over its demands, which include a request that Washington promise not to use nuclear weapons against it.
Today, a senior State Department official, briefing reporters here, said that although Washington would not enter into negotiations with North Korea until it took action to dismantle its nuclear facilities, contacts of a lesser sort were not being ruled out. He also did not rule out more substantive talks between other countries and North Korea, which have been continuing.
"We're in a mode of listening to what the South Koreans say," the official said. "It's important not to assume that there are polar positions."
 The North Korean official news agency reported Friday that a Foreign Ministry official who was not identified said the country was seeking a non-aggression agreement with the United States, long an aim of the North, as a solution for the nuclear issue. 
The United States has said that at least one part of the 1994 agreement -- the presence of international inspectors at a plutonium plant where nuclear weapons were being made before the accord was signed -- must remain in force.
But today the State Department official asserted that no decision had been made on whether other parts of the agreement should also be kept alive, including the next scheduled shipment of fuel oil to North Korea by the United States, which Washington had made a part of the deal. A shipment is due later this year.
The official said he and others were careful to avoid what he called "that four-letter word," by which he meant "dead" -- the term used by others to apply to the 1994 accord.
On the other hand, he said the Bush administration had no interest in negotiating yet another agreement with North Korea similar to the 1994 pact, now that it has proven it would not live up to the previous one. "We bought that horse one time before," he said.
Nonetheless, the official's comments appeared to be intended to assuage the concerns in Asia, especially in South Korea, that the tough talk in Washington was cutting off all avenues to ending the stalemate with North Korea peacefully. Japan and South Korea regard military action against North Korea as unrealistic, since North Korea has a million troops on its border with South Korea and could easily retaliate against South Korea with artillery, rockets and missiles.
The comments from administration officials came as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell met today with the South Korean foreign minister, Choi Sung Hong, and other representatives of 19 Asian and Pacific nations, plus Hong Kong and Taiwan.
Preparations are also under way for a meeting on Friday between President Bush and President Jiang Zemin of China. White House officials say North Korea will be at the top of the agenda for that meeting.
The official said today that there were differences between the United States, South Korea and Japan about how to approach North Korea. Although the Chinese are reported to favor negotiating with North Korea, the official said the Chinese were also concerned about the dangers of nuclear weapons on the Korean peninsula.
President Bush is expected to arrive at this Baja California resort on Saturday, about the same time that a hurricane is expected to hit the region, though probably not near here.
In another sign of disagreement between South Korea and the United States, a top South Korean cabinet official who had his own contacts with North Korea said this week that James A. Kelly, the assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, had mischaracterized North Korea's response when he said North Korea viewed the 1994 agreement as "nullified." In fact, said the South Korean official, Jeong Se Hyun, North Korea did not go quite that far.
Today, Mr. Kelly said he had not seen Mr. Jeong's report. But he said his recollection of North Korea's position on nullifying the accord was "the full fidelity version" of what had been said.

HEADLINE: Connecticut Group Is Formed to Oppose the Expansion of Casino Gambling 

BYLINE:  By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
With support from state and municipal officials, regional business groups, church leaders and residents, a coalition of casino opponents announced today that they had formed a statewide nonprofit group to fight the expansion of casino gambling.
 In a news conference at the Capitol attended by several state lawmakers and Connecticut's attorney general, the newly formed Connecticut Alliance Against Casino Expansion announced that its primary goal was to prevent the construction of a third casino in the state. 
 The group's president, Jeff Benedict, said there was an immediate need to organize before more Indian groups in Connecticut were given the federal recognition they need to move ahead with casino projects.
"State laws can be enacted that can make casinos very unprofitable and unwelcome here," said Mr. Benedict, a lawyer, author and recent candidate for Congress who ran on an anti-Indian-casino platform in the state's Second District. "Our job is to work with the governor and the Legislature to form that policy." 
That eastern Connecticut district includes the Mashantucket Pequots and the Mohegans, each of which operates a hugely successful casino. Together, they produce billions of dollars in annual revenue, including millions for the state in taxes. 
The impetus for the anti-casino coalition quickly formed this summer, after a third Connecticut tribe, the Eastern Pequots of North Stonington, won federal recognition in June. Recognition by the federal government gives tribes the sovereign status of a foreign government and allows them to build casinos in states where gambling is legal. 
Several other tribes, in Bridgeport, Kent and other parts of western Connecticut, also have petitions for recognition pending before the Bureau of Indian Affairs, part of the United States Department of the Interior. The Eastern Pequots have been unable to move ahead with their casino plans because of a lawsuit filed by Attorney General Richard Blumenthal on behalf of the state, seeking to cancel the bureau's decision to bestow recognition.
Richard Velkey, chief of the Schaghticoke Tribal Nation, which expects to receive a preliminary decision on federal recognition next month, said the new coalition was treating tribes unfairly for its own special interests. "They speak as though they're for the people, and yet the people in Bridgeport were for a casino," he said. "If a manufacturer would come into the state of Connecticut and bring in 15,000 jobs, would these people be up in arms?"
The anti-casino group said it would try to repeal the state's "Las Vegas nights" law, which allows church bingo and raffles and provided the legal precedent for the Mashantucket and Mohegan tribes to open casinos. The group said it had raised $75,000 in the last few weeks.
"We are now poised to take control of gambling policy in Connecticut and to take the initiative away from the moneyed interests who have backed so-called tribes pushing casino expansion," said State Senator William H. Nickerson, a Republican from Greenwich.
Nicholas H. Mullane II, North Stonington's first selectman, said the new group would help make people more aware of the negative social and economic impact of casinos. "They take away from a lot of the other commercial endeavors in the state of Connecticut," Mr. Mullane said. "It's a regressive form of business that really has no redeeming value."
Though other anti-gambling and anti-casino groups have been around for years, members of the coalition said theirs was the only statewide group specifically opposed to more casino gambling. 
Connecticut is one of many states where local communities have confronted the prospect of casino gambling. In Maine, where casino gambling is illegal, nine towns are holding referendums on whether to support the Passamaquoddy and Penobscot Indian tribes' efforts to change the law and build a $500 million casino. The State Legislature will probably also take up the issue next year. 
In Iowa, 10 counties, including Dubuque on the Mississippi River, are holding casino referendums. Many northern California communities are also struggling with decisions on proposed casino plans.
