HEADLINE: Bloomberg Is Backing Another Map For Council 

BYLINE:  By DIANE CARDWELL 

 BODY:
A day after a government commission released its first draft of a new map of City Council districts, an alternate plan favored by the Bloomberg administration surfaced.
 The existence of the second plan suggested that the often-competing agendas of the ethnic groups, community representatives, voting rights advocates and elected officials with something to lose or gain in redistricting would not be easily resolved. 
 Commission officials have repeatedly emphasized that the plan released on Wednesday, a proposal for new Council district boundaries to reflect the population shifts of the last decade, is very much a work in progress. Indeed, there had been discussion of releasing both the official plan and the alternate for public review and comment, but officials ultimately decided to release only one. 
"The commission has reviewed numerous alternatives, including plans vetted by individuals and outside organizations," said Richard C. Wager, communciations director for the commission. "The plan put forward by the commission is a culmination of these submissions as well as the determinations of the individual commissioners. And we feel as a commission that this is the fairest proposal of changes to put out at this time."
But the commission's plan is really a Council plan, some officials said, intended to keep incumbents in office. In that plan, an official who has reviewed both proposals said, "No one's in trouble."
The alternate plan for the city's 51 Council districts is in some ways more reflective of the population shifts that have occurred in the city's neighborhoods, said officials who have seen it. 
Both plans propose 29 districts with nonwhite majorities, but the administration's version would place a larger group of Asian residents within a mixed Asian-Latino district in Brooklyn, in an effort to strengthen Asian political influence there, the officials said. They said the plan would consolidate more of the Park Slope neighborhood, now split among districts, into one, which some think would strengthen the influence of that neighborhood's gay and lesbian community. And it would create an additional district with a majority Hispanic population in Queens.
Some advocates would tend to agree with a need for more Hispanic-majority districts. According to an analysis prepared by Angelo Falcon, senior policy executive of the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, the Districting Commission's proposed plan would decrease the number of districts with a Hispanic majority, despite the large increase in the Hispanic population over the last decade.
"Latinos are the fastest growing part of the city's population, so for most people it's logical that there be more Latino districts," Mr. Falcon said. "To see the population grow and have the city say that there will be fewer districts is very discouraging. It's basically like saying to Latino voters that your vote doesn't count as much as that of others."
In addition, Mr. Falcon charged, the plan appears to manipulate the size of the districts in a way that dilutes the Hispanic vote. The charter allows a 10 percent deviation from the ideal population for a district, in this case 157,025 people. That means the combined deviation of the smallest district and the largest must be no more than 10 percent from the ideal. According to Mr. Falcon's analysis, the average population for Hispanic districts was 159,436, above the ideal, while the average population for districts with a majority of white or black residents were both below the ideal.
"By having larger districts, the effectiveness of the average Latino voter is significantly diluted compared to smaller white districts, whose votes would count for more," Mr. Falcon wrote in his report.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: GAPS IN SECURITY; 
Report Finds U.S. Unprepared for Next Terrorist Attack

BYLINE:  By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Despite months of preparations and the spending of millions of dollars, the United States remains extremely vulnerable to a major terrorist attack, particularly at its seaports, power plants and oil refineries, a panel of national security experts has concluded.
 The panel, in a report to be released on Friday, contends that local and state police officials still have little access to intelligence on terrorism suspects, that only a tiny fraction of ships and containers entering American ports are inspected and that most emergency workers are ill equipped to handle biological and chemical attacks. 
 "A year after 9/11, America remains dangerously unprepared to prevent and respond to a catastrophic terrorist attack on U.S. soil," says the report, which was sponsored by the Council on Foreign Relations. "In all likelihood, the next attack will result in even greater casualties and widespread disruption to our lives and economy. 
"The need for immediate action is made more urgent by the prospect of the United States going to war with Iraq and the possibility Saddam Hussein might threaten the use of weapons of mass destruction in America."
The panel includes several members from the United States Commission on National Security -- including its co-chairmen, former Senators Gary Hart and Warren B. Rudman -- and its dire warnings reprise some of the conclusions of that earlier group. 
In March 2001 the commission released a report predicting that a major terrorist attack on American soil was likely and that the country was unprepared to respond.
"We don't blame anyone for this, because it takes a long time to turn a country like this around," Mr. Rudman said in an interview. "But this involves large amounts of money and many locales. And everyone has to be on the same page. You can't assume that because the president signs a bill in the Rose Garden, everything will be fixed."
Other members of the current group included two former secretaries of state, George P. Schultz and Warren M. Christopher; two former chairmen of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Adm. William J. Crowe, retired, and Gen. John W. Vessey, retired; a former F.B.I. director, William H. Webster; and the president of Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Harold E. Varmus.
The report contends that "in virtually every major city and county in the United States," police, fire and other emergency workers lack equipment needed to communicate during an emergency -- a problem that plagued New York City emergency workers after the attack on the World Trade Center.
The panel also found that most local police and fire departments did not have chemical protection gear, portable detection equipment for chemical, biological or nuclear agents or adequate training programs for dealing with such attacks. Local police departments also do not have access to terrorist watch lists provided by the State Department to immigration and consular officials, the panel found. As a result, "The cops on the beat are effectively operating deaf, dumb and blind," and "known terrorists will be free to move about to plan and execute their attacks," the report contends.
The report also focuses heavily on the vulnerability of America's seaports, asserting that the intensive efforts to improve airport and air cargo security in the wake of last year's attacks have overshadowed the potential for attacks through shipping containers, boats and container trucks.
Ninety-five percent of the trade from outside North America to the United States moves by sea, the report says, yet vulnerability studies for the nation's 50 largest ports are still years from being completed. A catastrophic attack at one of those ports could shut down American trade and cripple a large portion of the nation's economy, it concludes.
"If an explosive device was loaded in a container and set off in a port, it would almost automatically raise concern about the integrity of the 21,000 containers that arrive in U.S. ports each day," the report says. "A three- to four-week closure of U.S. ports would bring the global container industry to its knees."
The report recommends establishing 24-hour operations centers in every state to link local and federal law enforcement agencies; developing global standards for security at loading centers for containers; strengthening security at oil refineries and power plants; and increasing federal spending to help local governments buy equipment and improve training.
"The federal government will have to help," Mr. Rudman said. "It's going to take a fair amount of money."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS; 
WITH PROFIT DOWN 71%, DUKE ENERGY TO CUT 1,900 JOBS

BYLINE:  AP 

 BODY:
 Duke Energy said yesterday that its third-quarter profit plunged 71 percent because of weakness in the economy, forcing it to cut 1,500 regular positions and 400 contract workers. Duke's chief executive, Richard B. Priory, said the move would save Duke about $100 million a year. The company, based in Charlotte, N.C., said net income for the third quarter was $230 million, or 27 cents a share, down from $796 million, or $1.01 a share, in 2001. Revenue fell to $4.21 billion, down from $4.78 billion a year earlier. Duke also said it had been subpoenaed by the Commodity Futures Trading Commission and by a federal grand jury about its energy trading activities. The company said it was cooperating with all of the governmental agencies.

HEADLINE: Lower Medicare Payouts Concern Bush Officials 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Bush administration officials say they have become deeply concerned that a cut in Medicare payments to doctors, to be announced next week, will prompt many doctors to limit their participation in the program, reducing access to health care for the elderly.
 Medicare payments to doctors were cut 5.4 percent in January, and Medicare officials said that next week they expected to announce a further cut of 4.4 percent, effective on Jan. 1. 
 Asked to describe the likely effects, Thomas A. Scully, administrator of the Medicare program, said: "You'll have mad doctors. There will be access problems, and seniors will feel it." 
The cuts result from a formula specified in the Medicare law. The Bush administration says it has no discretion to halt the cuts, a contention disputed by doctors and by some influential lawmakers. 
In March, doctors in a dozen states said, in interviews with The New York Times, that they were refusing to take new Medicare patients because Medicare was paying them too little to cover their costs. A second cut will accelerate the trend, doctors said this week.
Many private insurers link their payments to the Medicare fee schedule, compounding the effects of any cut in Medicare reimbursement.
Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, said this week that he and Mr. Scully were "very concerned" about the impending cut.
Administration officials said President Bush's chief of staff, Andrew H. Card Jr., and his senior political adviser, Karl Rove, had taken an interest in the cut, in part because the administration did not want to alienate doctors or the elderly two weeks before Election Day. Democratic candidates are always hunting for evidence to back their argument that Republicans want to cut Medicare.
Dr. Harold M. Sokol, 46, a lung specialist in Albany, said: "My rent, my malpractice insurance premiums, my nurses' wages -- indeed, all our expenses -- have gone up, but Medicare payments are going down. How can we make ends meet? Who will want to do this job? It will be harder for Medicare patients to find physicians willing to treat them."
Doctors fault Congress and the administration. The cuts stem from a formula adopted by Congress in 1997. In his budget request in February, Mr. Bush assumed that the cuts would take effect and did not try to halt them. Congress has considered several bills to increase doctors' fees, but it adjourned last week without passing any of the legislation. Chances for action in a lame-duck session are uncertain.
Proposals to aid doctors have bogged down for three reasons:
*Consumer advocates and some lawmakers insist that before Congress increases Medicare payments to doctors, it must help Medicare beneficiaries struggling with the high costs of prescription drugs. Congress cannot agree on how to provide drug benefits.
*Hospitals, nursing homes and health maintenance organizations say they too face severe financial problems and should get higher Medicare payments if Congress increases payments to doctors. That would significantly raise the cost of any legislation.
*A dispute is raging over whether the Bush administration can unilaterally postpone the cuts in payments to doctors, without action by Congress.
Since March, Representative Bill Thomas, the California Republican who is chairman of the Ways and Means Committee, has repeatedly urged Mr. Scully to increase payments to doctors, to correct "technical errors" in the payment formula. Some White House officials have made similar suggestions.
But Secretary Thompson said, "We don't have the statutory authority" to avoid the cut planned for next year.
In an interview this week, Mr. Scully said: "Medicare's physician fee schedule has a glitch in it. It's clearly broken, and it needs to be fixed. We've scoured the earth to find a lawyer who says we have the authority to fix it administratively, but the lawyers cannot find a way. This question has been examined at the highest levels of the Justice Department and the White House counsel's office."
Robert B. Doherty, senior vice president of the American College of Physicians, which represents doctors specializing in internal medicine, said: "We're heading toward a collapse. If Congress does not establish a predictable, reliable method to update Medicare payments to keep pace with inflation, there won't be enough doctors willing to accept large numbers of Medicare patients."
In the last two years, health care providers have spent tens of millions of dollars lobbying Congress to increase their Medicare payments. Lawmakers say doctors and home care agencies appear to have the strongest case because Congress has actually cut their payments, not just slowed the rate of growth.
Medicare uses a fee schedule to pay doctors. The fee schedule specifies payments for more than 7,000 services ranging from routine office visits to complex surgical procedures. Payments are updated each year, using a formula that allows total spending to rise with Medicare enrollment and economic growth, among other factors.
Doctors say they have been shortchanged for several years because the government underestimated economic growth in the late 1990's and the number of people who would be in Medicare's fee-for-service program. As H.M.O.'s withdrew from Medicare, people returned to the original fee-for-service program, increasing enrollment more than expected.
In effect, said Representative Nancy L. Johnson, Republican of Connecticut, the calculations of the annual Medicare update left out the cost of caring for one million people.
Medicare officials say that if they acknowledged and corrected these mistakes, by increasing payments to doctors in 2003, they could expose the government to lawsuits demanding back pay for errors in previous years.
But doctors note that the Medicare law says "there shall be no administrative or judicial review" of factors used to compute their payments.
AARP, the lobby for the elderly, said Congress should not increase Medicare payments to health care providers unless it authorizes drug coverage for beneficiaries. But the organization also told Congress, "Errors or miscalculations in Medicare payment formulas should be corrected."
In June, the House passed a bill to provide prescription drug benefits to the elderly. The bill would increase Medicare payments to most health care providers, including doctors, who would receive an increase of about 2 percent in each of the next three years. The Senate has taken no action on the bill.
Darrin T. Ocke, a spokesman for the Medical Society of the State of New York State, said: "If Congress stops the erosion of Medicare payments, doctors will renew their commitment to the program. But if it's not fixed, there is a real likelihood of major service disruptions after Jan. 1."

HEADLINE: Has China Become an Ally? 

BYLINE:  By Kenneth Lieberthal; Kenneth Lieberthal is a professor of political science and business administration at the University of Michigan. He served as senior director for Asia on the National Security Council from 1998 to 2000.

DATELINE: ANN ARBOR, Mich. 

 BODY:
American relations with China have improved in a way that few could have imagined when the Bush administration entered office and declared China a "strategic competitor." Now signs of serious cooperation are everywhere. 
 China has worked with the United States on the global counterterrorism effort, will not be the spoiler on a new United Nations resolution on Iraq, has recently adopted stringent regulations on dual-use missile technology exports and other proliferation issues, and is discussing cooperation with the United States on North Korea. 
 Meanwhile, the White House did not oppose Beijing's bid for the 2008 Olympic games, supported China's entry into the World Trade Organization and even acceded to Beijing's concerns about Islamic terrorist activities in the country's northwest Xinjiang region, putting a key group there on the United States' terrorism list. 
President Bush's decision to host Jiang Zemin, the Chinese president, at the Crawford ranch today is another sign of good relations.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Jiang will then attend the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Mexico, where Mr. Bush will see the leaders of our allies Japan and South Korea. The special treatment for Mr. Jiang highlights the remarkable development of United States-China relations, especially since Sept. 11.
The key reasons for this improved relationship are clear. In the wake of the World Trade Center attacks, Mr. Bush welcomed China's cooperation in bringing Pakistan into an anti-Taliban coalition and obtaining a strong United Nations resolution on terrorism. Mr. Bush has made counterterrorism the central focus of American foreign policy, and China has consistently and usefully remained on the right side of this issue. 
Equally important, China's leaders have been eager to stabilize the relationship. They want to avoid confronting the United States, especially when their domestic agenda is full with succession and other issues. They also count on American trade and investment to help keep their economy growing fast enough to maintain domestic stability.
In general, China has adopted a more confident overall approach to foreign policy. Beijing seems now to feel accepted as a major, respected actor in the international arena. It is actively pursuing multilateral approaches to trade and security issues and is rapidly opening its economy to increased foreign investment.
Its foreign policy is increasingly pragmatic, nuanced and consistent, eschewing the petulant stances that seemed in times past to reflect an underlying inferiority complex. In the last year, China has skillfully evaluated and acted on its opportunities for strategic cooperation with the United States.
Yet we should not forget that this relationship has long been characterized by wide swings of emotion, from amity to anger. It may be too early to say that the relationship has stabilized for the long term. Here are three notes of caution. 
First, the counterterrorism effort that now provides the foundation for strategic cooperation could become a source of serious friction. China has no love for Saddam Hussein, terrorism or nuclear weapons on the Korean peninsula, but it worries about American tactics in dealing with these issues. If the United States attacks Iraq without United Nations approval, for example, Beijing will be deeply shaken.
Beijing worries too about the aftermath of an invasion of Iraq. The effects of a war and occupation could undermine governments from those in the Middle East to Pakistan to Indonesia. 
Beijing also fears a spike in energy prices. It has no strategic oil reserve and is a substantial oil importer. High energy prices could produce an extremely unwelcome drag on China's economic growth.
Indeed, on several fronts, China may find that it will need to distance itself from American policy. Beijing is also very much aware that in the name of counterterrorism the United States has vastly increased its military strategic posture all around China's periphery. It has established a military presence in Central Asia, developed military ties with Pakistan and India and strengthened its relations with Russia. Against this background, strategic cooperation could in time slide toward mutual suspicion. 
Second, there are vociferous critics of cooperation in both countries who have been silent but could raise their voices should circumstances change. In Washington, conservative Republicans have been loath to criticize a conservative Republican president, even over warming ties with China. And liberal Democrats have had trouble finding their footing on China's human rights record in the wake of new national security concerns. But they, along with those in the administration who hold dark views of China as a potential military adversary, would become vocal should relations with China begin to unravel.
In China, debate continues over America's long-term goals and China's security. Should serious leadership rifts develop over domestic issues, policy toward the United States could well become part of the political battle. The Chinese military is already highly suspicious of America's recent enhancement of its military power in areas surrounding China, its increased military contacts with and arms sales to Taiwan, and its adoption of pre-emption as a core strategic doctrine.
Third, the Taiwan issue is both hopeful and treacherous, as rapidly growing economic ties across the Taiwan Strait are being matched by an escalating arms race on both sides. The possibility of disaster cannot yet be discounted.
 A merican interests require that we support the maintenance of Taiwan's democratic freedom, prosperity and security. We also have long-standing commitments, affirmed by the Bush administration, not to support a Taiwanese bid for independence. President Bush declared early on that he will do "whatever it takes" to defend Taiwan. But the administration has not taken initiatives to increase the chances of a peaceful resolution of cross-strait issues. 
These issues are intertwined and, although both sides value cooperation, they will remain central to America's relations with China long after the Crawford visit is over.

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE REPUBLICANS; 
One Seat Shy of Control, Lott Battles for Senate

BYLINE:  By CARL HULSE 

DATELINE: BENTONVILLE, Ark., Oct. 21 

 BODY:
Trent Lott was at the AQ Chicken House in the Republican heart of Arkansas today, ostensibly to rally support for Tim Hutchinson, one of the Senate colleagues he was most worried about losing. 
 But Mr. Lott was campaigning as much for himself as for Mr. Hutchinson. 
 "I'm going to make it a little personal," Mr. Lott said as he met with the Republican faithful in the state's rapidly growing northwest corner. "Do you want somebody who knows about Arkansas and is your neighbor? I guarantee you Tim and Arkansas will be better off working with Trent Lott as the majority leader from Mississippi than -- let me just say the words -- with Tom Daschle from South Dakota." 
The crowd jeered at the mere mention of Mr. Daschle, the Democratic leader.
Mr. Lott's name is not on any ballot this year, but he is running as hard as anyone -- and has much to win or lose. The battle for control of the Senate will determine the reach of Mr. Lott's political power and either fulfill or puncture his dream of presiding over the Senate while Republicans control the White House and the House of Representatives.
Mr. Lott, who was elected leader after Bob Dole resigned from the Senate in 1996, is also trying to salvage his own reputation among Senate Republicans and with the White House. His job seemed in jeopardy last year after many Republicans blamed him for not doing enough to stop the defection of Senator James M. Jeffords of Vermont, which gave Democrats control of the Senate.
Mr. Lott has sought to consolidate his Senate support, and last week Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, a potential challenger, made it known that he would not oppose Mr. Lott for leader. Allies of Mr. Lott say that for now he has a "comfortable majority" to be re-elected Republican leader, whether Republicans win or lose control of the Senate. 
Still, Mr. Lott is clearly trying to develop better relations in his caucus by demonstrating that his zeal to win back control of the Senate for Republicans is unflagging.
Should Republicans succeed and complete the trifecta of controlling the House, Senate and White House, Mr. Lott has an ambitious agenda. That agenda is a chief element of his sales pitch as he tries to pick up that one additional Senate seat that will allow him to reclaim the title of majority leader, which was snatched from him when Mr. Jeffords, now an independent, left the Republicans. 
"We will come out of the gates next year fast," Mr. Lott promised.
Confirmation of 50 or more judges nominated by President Bush is high on his list. Making permanent the 10-year tax cuts Congress approved last year is another priority. He said he would pass the Republican version of prescription drug coverage for older Americans, bar a form of late-term abortion opponents call partial-birth abortion and protect gun rights.
"Give us a chance," Mr. Lott implored the crowd at the AQ Chicken House, a restaurant known for pan-fried chicken off Sam Walton Boulevard, a street named for Bentonville's favorite son and the founder of Wal-Mart, its economic lifeblood.
"For two years with President Bush in the White House and with a Republican majority in the House and Senate, I believe we can do things our states and our country would need that would make a difference for generations to come," Mr. Lott said.
Republican senators and others on Capitol Hill say Mr. Lott has at least quieted his critics by effectively countering Mr. Daschle in the legislative arena as well as by his aggressive fund-raising and support of Republican Senate candidates.
"I think most members agree that he has done as good a job as can be done," said Senator Rick Santorum of Pennsylvania, a member of the party's leadership.
Senator Bill Frist of Tennessee, chairman of the Senate Republican campaign effort, conceded that Senate Republicans were in shock for months after Mr. Jeffords defected. But he said that Mr. Lott seized on the gridlock to give Republicans a sense of purpose about retaking control. 
"This election has moved beyond party loyalty to the need to revive the Senate as an effective institution," Mr. Frist said.
Democrats say Mr. Lott's pitch to have Republicans consolidate control of government can help them energize their voters as well. 
"That frightens people," said Terry McAuliffe, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, adding that Americans like divided government.
Referring to the prospect of Republican control of Congress, Tovah Ravitz-Meehan, spokeswoman for the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, said, "Nothing makes our base get out and work harder and longer." She said much of Mr. Lott's campaigning lately had been confined to the Southern tier of states because his style of conservatism might not play so well elsewhere.
Mr. Hutchinson, however, contended that Mr. Lott's appeal would help, particularly in this rock-ribbed Republican section of Arkansas. Mr. Hutchinson knows he will win the area, which he represented in Congress. But he said he needed to run up a big margin here to counter the Democratic strength elsewhere of his opponent, Attorney General Mark Pryor.
"This is a very Republican part of the state, and they get it here," Mr. Hutchinson said about the fight for Senate control. "I think that will be big part of the motivation for a high voter turnout."
Mr. Lott's personal political action committee has contributed about $1.3 million to the National Republican Senatorial Committee, exceeding his own goal of about $700,000. He has given the maximum allowable to almost every competitive Senate candidate.
"I am praying for a chance to do what is right for our country," he told the Arkansans.

HEADLINE: Dead Parrot Society 

BYLINE:  By PAUL KRUGMAN; E-mail: krugman@nytimes.com

 BODY:
A few days ago The Washington Post's Dana Milbank wrote an article explaining that for George W. Bush, "facts are malleable." Documenting "dubious, if not wrong" statements on a variety of subjects, from Iraq's military capability to the federal budget, the White House correspondent declared that Mr. Bush's "rhetoric has taken some flights of fancy." 
 Also in the last few days, The Wall Street Journal reported that "senior officials have referred repeatedly to intelligence . . . that remains largely unverified." The C.I.A.'s former head of counterterrorism was blunter: "Basically, cooked information is working its way into high-level pronouncements." USA Today reports that "pressure has been building on the intelligence agencies to deliberately slant estimates to fit a political agenda." 
 Reading all these euphemisms, I was reminded of Monty Python's parrot: he's pushing up the daisies, his metabolic processes are history, he's joined the choir invisible. That is, he's dead. And the Bush administration lies a lot.
Let me hasten to say that I don't blame reporters for not quite putting it that way. Mr. Milbank is a brave man, and is paying the usual price for his courage: he is now the target of a White House smear campaign.
That standard response may help you understand how Mr. Bush retains a public image as a plain-spoken man, when in fact he is as slippery and evasive as any politician in memory. Did you notice his recent declaration that allowing Saddam Hussein to remain in power wouldn't mean backing down on "regime change," because if the Iraqi despot meets U.N. conditions, "that itself will signal that the regime has changed"?
The recent spate of articles about administration dishonesty mainly reflects the campaign to sell war with Iraq. But the habit itself goes all the way back to the 2000 campaign, and is manifest on a wide range of issues. High points would include the plan for partial privatization of Social Security, with its 2-1=4 arithmetic; the claim that a tax cut that delivers 40 percent or more of its benefits to the richest 1 percent was aimed at the middle class; the claim that there were 60 lines of stem cells available for research; the promise to include limits on carbon dioxide in an environmental plan. 
More generally, Mr. Bush ran as a moderate, a "uniter, not a divider." The Economist endorsed him back in 2000 because it saw him as the candidate better able to transcend partisanship; now the magazine describes him as the "partisan-in-chief." 
It's tempting to view all of this merely as a question of character, but it's more than that. There's method in this administration's mendacity.
For the Bush administration is an extremely elitist clique trying to maintain a populist facade. Its domestic policies are designed to benefit a very small number of people -- basically those who earn at least $300,000 a year, and really don't care about either the environment or their less fortunate compatriots. True, this base is augmented by some powerful special-interest groups, notably the Christian right and the gun lobby. But while this coalition can raise vast sums, and can mobilize operatives to stage bourgeois riots when needed, the policies themselves are inherently unpopular. Hence the need to reshape those malleable facts.
What remains puzzling is the long-term strategy. Despite Mr. Bush's control of the bully pulpit, he has had little success in changing the public's fundamental views. Before Sept. 11 the nation was growing increasingly dismayed over the administration's hard right turn. Terrorism brought Mr. Bush immense personal popularity, as the public rallied around the flag; but the helium has been steadily leaking out of that balloon.
Right now the administration is playing the war card, inventing facts as necessary, and trying to use the remnants of Mr. Bush's post-Sept. 11 popularity to gain control of all three branches of government. But then what? There is, after all, no indication that Mr. Bush ever intends to move to the center. 
So the administration's inner circle must think that full control of the government can be used to lock in a permanent political advantage, even though the more the public learns about their policies, the less it likes them. The big question is whether the press, which is beginning to find its voice, will lose it again in the face of one-party government.

HEADLINE: Days of Diplomacy 

 BODY:
Deep in the heart of Texas, the Bush family is offering some high-powered hospitality to Jiang Zemin. In a trip reminiscent of Deng Xiaoping's visit to Houston in 1979, the Chinese president has toured NASA's Johnson Space Center, been feted by George H. W. Bush, the onetime ambassador to Beijing, and spoken at the presidential library in College Station. Today he will visit the presidential ranch in Crawford and enjoy some Texas barbecue with George W. Bush. 
 The visit, a prelude to this weekend's summit of Pacific rim leaders in Mexico and a swan song for the 76-year-old Mr. Jiang as he prepares to relinquish power, comes at an opportune moment. From Iraq to North Korea, the two nations face a range of difficult diplomatic challenges. By working together to resolve them, Mr. Bush and Mr. Jiang can consolidate the constructive relationship that has been developing between the United States and China in recent months. 
 Relations have improved significantly since the early days of the Bush administration, when the confrontation over an American spy plane threatened to rupture ties. China remains wary of American power, but Beijing's emphasis on economic growth helps account for the thaw. 
Annual trade between the two countries has reached the $100 billion mark. The commitments to invest in China announced this week by Exxon Mobil and Anheuser-Busch are emblematic of the relationship. Hu Jintao, slated to become leader of the Chinese Communist Party next month, supports further economic liberalization. 
Beijing's cooperation in pressing North Korea and Iraq to dismantle weapons of mass destruction will be a crucial test of China's maturity as a global power. It does not suit China to have an erratic North Korean regime in possession of nuclear weapons. Nor does China, which relies on oil imports, want to see Saddam Hussein in a position to destabilize the Persian Gulf region.
Over the weekend, at the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation conference in Cabo San Lucas, Presidents Bush and Jiang will have the opportunity to add Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi of Japan and South Korea's president, Kim Dae Jung, to their discussions about North Korea. These four countries must present a united front in demanding that Kim Jong Il abandon his nuclear weapons program. President Bush must also bolster Mr. Koizumi's determination to tackle Japan's financial crisis, an ongoing drag to global economic growth.

HEADLINE: McCall Faces a Struggle To Emerge From Behind 

BYLINE:  By SHAILA K. DEWAN 

 BODY:
It had been almost a week since the first of two news articles mentioned that Sikhulu Shange would love to hang a "McCall for Governor" sign in his shop window in Harlem, if only he had one.
 But Mr. Shange, the owner of the 125th Street Record Shack, had yet to be enlisted in the effort to elect H. Carl McCall. "Not a sign," he said yesterday. "Not even a call." 
 To be sure, one lone placard is a small thing in the flurry of a statewide race. But since Mr. McCall began his run for the governor, his campaign has been criticized for being slow to respond in far more significant situations.
It took five days for him to put an end to the two-inch headlines about letters he had written on state stationery pitching his relatives' resumes by apologizing and releasing all such letters.
It took six weeks from the time his Democratic opponent dropped out of the primary, thus allowing the Clintons to abandon their public neutrality, for him to plan an evening of events with former President Bill Clinton.
By that time, Wednesday, Mr. McCall's showing in the polls was so poor that the chairman of the Democratic National Committee, Terry McAuliffe, announced that there would be no significant money coming his way unless he shrunk an 11-point gap in the polls to 6 or 7 points. In another hint at internal disorganization, Mr. McAuliffe said the McCall campaign had failed to provide him a list of potential donors. The McCall campaign manager, Allen P. Cappelli, said he would not comment, in the interest of "moving forward." 
The McCall campaign is perceived to be so soporific that in recent days, several news commentators have even pondered whether Mr. McCall could come in third, after the Independence Party candidate, Tom Golisano. Some political scientists dismiss that notion as unrealistic, but in a state where Democrats outnumber Republicans 5 to 3, that the question has been raised at all seems ominous for Mr. McCall.
Mr. McCall, the state comptroller, has had trouble getting across the kind of clear argument voters need to oust an incumbent, strategists say. In recent weeks, he has all but abandoned the story of how he overcame his humble circumstances, a story that tested well with audiences. Instead, he has displayed the innate caution that led some observers to suggest, early in the campaign, that he did not have the desire it would take to win. At a Crain's Breakfast Forum, he proposed the same solution for everything from state budget woes to sluggish economic development: appoint panels of experts.
His education plan, which involves stock words like parental involvement and smaller classes, has not had the sizzle of Mr. Golisano's proposal to spend state lottery money on college tuition for good students.
Even though Mr. McCall denounces Gov. George E. Pataki daily and in no uncertain terms, some Democrats have expressed frustration, saying that the governor has not been taken to task for what they see as his failings.
Shirley O'Connell, a state Democratic committeewoman from Plattsburgh who has been involved in the McCall campaign, expressed mild disappointment.
"I think he's genuinely a nice, nice person," she said of the comptroller. "The fact that he's a gentleman sometimes keeps him from being aggressive as somebody else might be. Sometimes, the way politics is, you have to be aggressive and maybe a little bit nasty."
The campaign's money woes have been well documented, but some strategists say he did not husband what he had, spending too much during a primary he was winning.
"He has had everything but a clear and concise focus and an effective organization," said Philip J. Friedman, a Democratic consultant. "And that's something that Pataki has had from Day 1 and Golisano has had in the last three or four weeks."
But Mr. McCall's many friends, who have helped shape him into the perfect Democratic standard bearer with the sterling resume, have been quick to come to his rescue.
"Carl's presumption is, I guarantee you, in the back of his brain, these guys will take care of it, they'll deliver," said Hank Scheinkopf, one of several Democratic consultants the campaign hired, then sloughed off. "Who would let him down? He's Carl McCall, the golden boy."
Mr. Cappelli said the Mr. McCall campaign's field operation was "humming along."
"We're going to talk about progressive isssues that people care about -- that make a difference in people's lives," he said. "Pataki's failure on education, his failure on the economy, his lack of leadership in difficult times, Carl McCall's experience."
But as they are doing all that talking, Mr. Shange is waiting for his sign.

Bristol-Myers to Restate Results to Reflect Inventory
Bristol-Myers Squibb said it would restate its financial results to reflect its retreat from controversial inventory practices.
 The company also said third-quarter sales were hurt by competition from generic drug makers. Final results will be delayed until the completion of the restatement, which is expected to increase sales and earnings for 2002 and lower them for previous years. Page C2. 

Viacom Meets Forecast in Quarter
Viacom posted record third-quarter results in line with expectations, buoyed by strong performances at its advertising-supported divisions like CBS, MTV Networks and radio. "We are rocking big time," Mel Karmazin, left, Viacom's president, said. He reiterated the company's desire for acquisitions but did not cite targets. Advertising. C6.

Federal Budget Swings to Deficit
The Bush administration said the federal budget deficit for the year that ended Sept. 30 was $159 billion, a sharp swing from the surplus of $127 billion in the prior year. A24.

End to Battle for Cruise Line Seen
Carnival has reached an agreement to buy P&O Princess Cruises for about $5.4 billion in stock, the companies announced today, bringing a long-running battle for the cruise line to a close. C4.

I.B.M. Creates Tiny Logic Circuit
I.B.M. scientists have created not only the world's smallest logic circuit, but possibly the smallest that could ever be made. The entire circuit covers an area less than a trillionth of a square inch. The equivalent circuit made from innovative silicon transistors is 250,000 times as large. A22.

Study Cites Sites Blocked by Google
Google, the popular Internet search engine, has excluded more than 100 Web sites from the French and German versions of its index under pressure from those nations' governments, a new study has found. C8.

Walt Disney will introduce a new dial-up Internet access service aimed at families with children that is a customized version of Microsoft's MSN. C8.

Three Key Stock Gauges Retreat
The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell 13.64 points, or 1.5 percent, to 882.50. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 176.93 points, or 2.1 percent, to 8,317.34. And the Nasdaq composite index shed 21.52 points, or 1.6 percent, to 1,298.71. C9.

Free Shipping Lifts Amazon.com
With sales helped by its offer of free shipping, Amazon.com announced that it had sharply decreased its loss in the third quarter. Using Amazon's pro forma profit calculation, which excluded a $37 million restructuring charge among other items, the company broke even. Analysts had expected a pro forma loss of 5 cents a share. C8.

Vanguard Airlines Set to Liquidate
The chief executive of Vanguard Airlines said that his company, now bankrupt, was preparing to liquidate its assets even as it continued last-minute negotiations with a potential investment group. C4.

More Criticism for Japan's Plan
Prime Minister Junichiro Koizumi's hand-picked economic czar came under fresh attack over his plan for radical action to clean up the country's banking crisis. A10.

HEADLINE: THREATS AND RESPONSES: COMBATING TERROR; 
More Talk on Attacks Than Taxes at Trade Forum

BYLINE:  By TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: CABO SAN LUCAS, Mexico, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Secretary of State Colin L. Powell bumped into his Russian counterpart, Igor S. Ivanov, at a morning kaffeeklatsch today, and all they could talk about were the sniper suspects in Maryland and the hostages in Moscow.
 "Terrible, terrible," they said, commiserating and contemplating man's inhumanity to man. 
 It was another small sign that the Asian-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum here in Mexico has turned from a discussion on trade to a forum on threats. 
Russia's president, Vladimir V. Putin, canceled his trip to the meeting to deal with his hostage crisis. That decision will cost President Bush, who arrives Saturday, a chance to directly lobby the Russian leader to support American plans for action against Iraq.
Kim Dae Jung of South Korea arrived to find his agenda refocused on North Korea's nuclear weapons. Corporate executives and consultants who wanted to talk international trade finance sometimes had to talk amongst themselves.
Such intertwining of foreign and financial policy, of capital and counterterrorism, was the real theme today for the conference's 21 member nations. The tensions of high finance on high alert are a lasting effect of last year's attacks on New York and Washington. The direct costs of the attacks have been estimated at $30 billion, and the economic ripples may soon outreach the initial shock wave.
Given the new and immediate threats around the globe, Secretary Powell said, the trick is to make the world's borders a barrier to terrorist groups while making them translucent for trade. "To make the flow of trade, finance and communication more secure," he said, the world must enhance its "security from global terrorism."
Secretary Powell said that while President Bush would try to stay focused on issues of trade and social development at the conference, "of course, we'll spend some time on the crises of the day." Those crises, he said, included Iraq and "the kinds of terrorist attacks that afflict so many countries today," including three other conference members -- Russian, Indonesia and the Philippines -- this month alone.
The foreign ministers at the conference adopted a joint statement tonight that pledged to "suppress the financing of terrorism" and strengthen security procedures for air travel and shipping. Along those lines, they are working on ways to monitor charities and nonprofit organizations and other money-transfer mechanisms that often go ungoverned.
They are also trying to create a global electronic network of customs and passport records, while trying to keep those security measures from unduly disrupting trade and travel. And they have plans to try to limit the economic fallout from terrorist attacks, especially attacks against energy grids and pipelines, computer links, telecommunications and transportation.
The Bush administration has been pushing such topics on its partners in the group since the Sept. 11 attacks. But Secretary Powell somewhat tempered that agenda today with his reminder that helping the poor was also part of government's mandate, even in a world racked with terror.
"When people see hope in the future, when they see an opportunity to make a living," he said, "then there's no room for anger, no room for the type of terror activity we see."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Robert Zoellick, right, the American trade respresentative, conferred with Secretary of State Colin Powell yesterday at the Asian-Pacific Economic Conference. Terrorism was a prominent theme at the meeting. (Lynsey Addario for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: HOSTAGE DRAMA IN MOSCOW: THE MOSCOW FRONT; 
Chechens Kill Hostage In Siege at Russian Hall

BYLINE:  By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Friday, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
Chechen rebels threatening to blow up a Moscow theater with as many as 700 hostages, including three Americans, turned over the body of a young woman on Thursday in a sign of their resolve and turned a rocket launcher on two other women who escaped the theater Thursday afternoon.
 The grenades fired at the two women who managed to flee caused thundering explosions in the streets outside the music hall, which has been surrounded by scores of Russian soldiers and police. 
 As a gray dawn broke this morning on the second full day of the hostage crisis, the guerrillas abruptly set free 7 unidentified hostages and pledged to release some or all of the 75 foreign hostages held in the crowd.
A top official of Russia's domestic intelligence agency, the Federal Security Service, said for the first time that talks with the captors were being held under "a tense atmosphere" and that releases of others, including children, may be possible.
It was unclear whether the rebels, who have conducted only fitful negotiations with the government through intermediaries of their own choosing, had shifted to direct talks. 
The intelligence official, deputy director Sergei Ignatchenko, said talks had been set back by the bursting of a hot-water pipe which had flooded the first floor of the three-story theatre. The hostage-takers have charged that the incident was a ploy by intelligence agents and have refused to let repair crews into the building.
This morning's new releases and the pledge to set foreigners free were nevertheless a rare sign of progress in a situation which had appeared all but intractable only hours before. The previous evening, the rebels' had insisted that they would set no more of their captives free, and some had said in a videotape made public during the day that they intended to die as martyrs, taking hundreds of hostages with them.
The Chechens, who are demanding an end to Russia's war in the separatist republic, had earlier released 12 other hostages, including a British citizen who was said to be seriously ill, bringing the total freed to 39.
The 75 foreigners still in captivity included three Americans and a fourth who held an American green card, the American ambassador said.
In a midday statement on Thursday, President Vladimir V. Putin denounced the assault as one "planned in foreign terrorist centers," and he said he would not travel to Mexico this weekend for an economic summit meeting, where he had planned to meet with President Bush.
"We will not yield to these provocations," Mr. Putin said. 
The guerrillas, who said they numbered 25 men and 25 women, showed no sign of yielding either. 
The group chillingly underscored their threats in two videotapes delivered anonymously on Thursday to the Moscow bureau of Al Jazeera, the Qatar-based news channel that has often broadcast taped messages from leaders of Al Qaeda. 
In one of the tapes, apparently made before Wednesday night's assault, a man wearing a black wool cap said the rebels were on a "martyrdom operation with orders from the military commander of the Republic of Chechnya."
"I swear by God we are more keen on dying than you are keen on living," he said. 
In a second tape, five women wearing veils stood before a banner proclaiming in Arabic, "God is great." 
"We have chosen this path, the path of struggling for the freedom of the Chechen," one woman said. "It makes no difference for us where we will die. We have chosen to die here, in Moscow, and we will take the lives of hundreds of the infidels with us." 
The tapes and the statements may point to a foreign terrorist role in the hostage crisis, as Mr. Putin indicated. Chechen militants fought alongside Taliban and Qaeda members in Afghanistan, and experts say the separatist movement in Chechnya has been financed in part by Middle Eastern and Asian groups tied to Al Qaeda and terror. But Chechnya itself is a province of mostly moderate Muslims, with pockets of extremism.
Bolstering the charge of foreign involvement, Russian news services reported that the guerrillas had placed telephone calls to Turkey and the United Arab Emirates, but the reports did not make clear the source of the information or when the calls might have been made. 
Underscoring their seriousness, the guerrillas have wired the theater's supporting pillars, seats and even themselves with plastic explosives, according to hostages released from the theater and others speaking from inside on cellphones. 
The rebels said they would blow up the building unless Mr. Putin agreed to withdraw Russian forces from Chechnya, the renegade province that has been the scene of two wars in the last decade. A pro-rebel Web site with a spotty record of truthfulness, www.kavkaz.org, has given the Kremlin seven days to comply.
The 700 captives, who sat down Wednesday evening to a popular musical only to find themselves in a life-and-death drama by the second act, made it clear on Thursday that they believed time to end the standoff peacefully was running out. 
"We beg you to take a sensible decision and to halt military actions in Chechnya," said Prof. Maria Shkolnikova, a heart specialist sent outside the theater briefly on Thursday to issue a statement on behalf of the hostages. "There have been enough wars." 
"Today we have ended up in a life-or-death situation," she said, reading from a handwritten letter. "We have parents, brothers, sisters and children. We greatly value their lives. We beg you to resolve the issue by peaceful means." 
In a midday cellphone call Thursday to the news radio station Echo Moskvy, she pleaded: "Please start doing something. Start troop withdrawals, or they will begin killing us."
The rebels allowed two Jordanian doctors to remove the body of a Russian woman, about 20, who was shot in the chest sometime after the terrorists stormed the southeast Moscow theater complex about 9 p.m. local time on Wednesday. 
A flurry of unverified reports said the woman, who was not identified, had been killed for refusing to end a cellphone conversation, for refusing to sit down and for trying to escape.
The rebels allowed Red Cross workers into the theater, a onetime cultural center for a ball-bearing factory, to attend to a young hostage thought to have appendicitis who was later freed and to treat one captor who suffered from peritonitis.
They also demanded audiences with a string of public figures who they indicated would give their demand a fair hearing, including an award-winning Russian war journalist, Anna Politkovskaya, and three deputies in the Russian Parliament. 
One deputy, Irina Khakamada, was allowed such an audience and later went to the Kremlin, but it was not clear whether she carried any new demands or messages from the rebels. 
She told journalists that she had seen no explosives, but a second deputy who had gone to the theater, Iosif Kobzon, said he had talked to a woman who held a remote-control device and boasted that she could blow up the hall by pressing its button. 
The leader of the group identified himself to intermediaries on Thursday as Abu Bakr. It was not clear whether he was in fact a rebel commander named Movsar Barayev, who has been identified on the pro-rebel Web site and by some who have seen the Jazeera videos as the head of the guerrilla force. 
The Russian journalism Web site gazeta.ru on Thursday identified Mr. Barayev as the nephew of a Chechen warlord, Arbi Barayev, who was notorious for kidnapping and ransoming foreigners at the height of Chechen lawlessness in the late 1990's.
In Washington, Ari Fleischer, the White House spokesman, said Mr. Bush had called Mr. Putin to express solidarity and to offer "whatever Russia needed" to address the crisis. 
At the United Nations, the Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution condemning the hostage-taking as "a heinous act."

HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE FORMER VICE PRESIDENT; 
Gore Calls U.S. Vulnerable To More Bioterror Attacks

BYLINE:  By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Former Vice President Al Gore said today that a "dangerous weakness in our health care system" made the United States vulnerable to terrorist attacks using anthrax, smallpox and other biological weapons.
 Mr. Gore said the threat of such attacks created an urgent need for federal, state and local officials to upgrade the public health system so doctors and hospitals would be better prepared to treat victims of a biological attack. 
 "Much attention has been focused on mobilizing public opinion for war," Mr. Gore said, "but not enough attention has been focused on mobilizing America's first line of defense against biological warfare, our public health system." 
Mr. Gore, who won the popular vote but lost the electoral vote in the 2000 presidential election, is considering another bid for the White House. His speech today, at George Washington University, was the latest evidence of his effort to prove that he would be a viable candidate in 2004. In recent weeks, he has also given speeches on Iraq and the nation's economic problems.
While Congress and the Bush administration have taken steps to upgrade the public health system, Mr. Gore said, they have not done enough.
"The small-scale anthrax attacks of a year ago found that our public health system is in a state of disrepair," Mr. Gore said. "This past summer the uncoordinated response to outbreaks of West Nile virus reminded us again how inadequate our public health system is."
Aides to Mr. Gore said he believed that an immediate infusion of $10 billion was needed to upgrade the health system.
Jerome M. Hauer, an assistant secretary of health and human services, said the Clinton-Gore administration bore much of the responsibility for the current problems.
"We are in a process of catching up," said Mr. Hauer, a former director of emergency management in New York City. "I briefed President Clinton on bioterrorism, but we could never get Donna Shalala, his secretary of health and human services, to understand that this was a threat. We saw no substantial gains in preparedness until George Bush became president and Tommy G. Thompson became secretary."
As an example, Mr. Hauer said, "under the previous administration, the goal was to have 40 million doses of smallpox vaccine by 2005, but we will have 160 million new doses by 2003."
Mr. Gore noted that his father, Albert Gore Sr., who served in Congress for 32 years, was an architect of the Interstate highway system. Just as the nation built highways to enhance national security in the cold war, Mr. Gore said, Americans must bolster the public health system today. With public health, as with highway construction, he said, steps taken for the purpose of national defense will benefit civilians for decades to come.
Mr. Gore denounced Mr. Bush's record on health care, saying the president had done little to expand health insurance coverage, guarantee patients' rights or lower the costs of prescription drugs.
But, Mr. Gore said, the goal of broader insurance coverage, a high priority for the Clinton administration and for Mr. Gore's campaign in 2000, "must now take, temporarily, a back seat to the urgent need" to prepare people for the possibility of an attack with biological weapons.
"We need a new National Defense Public Health Act to address this imminent threat," Mr. Gore said. 
Specifically, he said, doctors and nurses need better training, and the federal government should establish a nationwide network linking public health agencies.
"Rapid communication of information about dangerous disease outbreaks is an essential part of a national bioterrorism response," Mr. Gore said. "But many public health agencies lack equipment as basic as a fax machine or an e-mail account."
Mr. Gore said health costs were soaring and health insurance coverage eroding. State budget crises, resulting in part from "mismanagement of our national economy," have prompted state officials to cut Medicaid, the health program for poor people, and more cuts are likely, he said.
William A. Pierce, a spokesman for the Heath and Human Services Department, said the Bush administration had approved state Medicaid initiatives providing coverage to two million people and improved health benefits for six million others.

HEADLINE: Durable Orders and Consumer Confidence Fall 

BYLINE:  AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Oct. 25 

 BODY:
The nation's hard-hit manufacturers suffered another drop in demand for their products while consumer confidence slid to the lowest level in nearly 10 years, according to reports issued today.
 Housing, however, remained one of the few bright spots as sales of both new and existing homes posted strong increases in September. 
 The Commerce Department said that orders to factories for big-ticket durable goods fell 5.9 percent in September, the biggest decrease in 10 months and the third decline in the last 4 months. The new weakness was led by a huge plunge in orders for communication equipment, but the declines were widespread across most industries. 
Consumer confidence as measured by a University of Michigan survey declined to 80.6 this month, the lowest level since 1993, as Americans were unnerved by the falling stock market and rising concerns about a possible war with Iraq.
The decline was the fifth consecutive one and raised worries that consumer spending, the biggest prop holding up the economy, could be in danger of faltering.
"Unless the downward momentum is quickly halted, the accumulated loss in consumer confidence could tip the economy back into recession," said Richard Curtin, director of the Michigan survey.
The brightest spot for the economy continued to be housing sales, with new-home sales rising 0.4 percent in September, to a record annual rate of 1.021 million units, while sales of existing homes were up 1.9 percent, to an annual rate of 5.4 million units.
Both home and car sales have been strong this year, reflecting the Federal Reserve's decision to keep a crucial interest rate at a four-decade low. But private economists worried about what could take up the slack if consumers decide to take a breather.
"The economy is creeping ahead, but only just barely," said Bill Cheney, chief economist at John Hancock Financial Services in Boston. "As long as another shoe doesn't drop, we'll probably be fine."
The worse-than-expected 5.9 percent decline in orders for durable goods followed news earlier this week of a fourth consecutive monthly decline in the index of leading economic indicators, indicating weakness for the next six months, and the Fed's latest survey of business conditions showing sluggish sales and a lackluster job market.
The 5.9 percent drop in orders for durable goods in September came after a 0.6 percent decline in August and a 4.5 percent drop in June. Only July posted an increase during this period, a gain of 8.5 percent.
Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said factories were struggling to mount an "uneven recovery" with "uncertainty regarding the stock market and possible war in the Middle East" continuing to impede business investment.
Analysts noted that orders for nonmilitary capital goods, considered a barometer of business investment plans, fell 12.6 percent in September.

HEADLINE: Graduate Assistants at Cornell Vote Decisively Against Autoworkers Union 

BYLINE:  By STEVEN GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
In one of the biggest defeats for the fast-growing movement to unionize graduate students, Cornell University announced yesterday that its graduate teaching and research assistants had voted overwhelmingly against joining the United Auto Workers.
 The vote, which took place on Wednesday and Thursday, was 1,351 against union representation and 580 in favor. 
 In the organizing drive, the U.A.W., which represents thousands of white-collar workers across the nation, sought to make Cornell the second private university, after New York University, to have a graduate assistants' union.
"Graduate students at Cornell voted against a union because they feel they have it pretty good and the university has treated them pretty well," said Allen MacKenzie, a graduate research assistant in engineering and a co-founder of At What Cost?, a group opposing unionization. "That doesn't mean things are perfect, but they see other avenues for change."
Mr. MacKenzie said many students disliked the union's political views, especially on environmental issues, citing its opposition to stricter fuel economy standards for cars.
Robb Willer, a graduate student in sociology and an organizer for the union, attributed the defeat to a fear of change. "It's a national movement that like all national movements will experience wins and losses," he said. "But there's still a lot of activism to improve the standard of living for graduate students."
Cornell's president, Hunter R. Rawlings III, had spoken out against unionizing, but fought against it less vigorously than did officials at Yale and Columbia. Graduate students at Columbia and Brown have voted on the issue, but the ballots have been impounded while several schools ask the National Labor Relations Board to reverse its landmark 2000 decision, involving N.Y.U., that gave graduate assistants at private universities the right to unionize.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS; 
The October Rally Extends to a Third Consecutive Week

BYLINE:  By The Associated Press

 BODY:
Optimistic that Wall Street will be able to extend its October rally, investors sent stocks sharply higher yesterday, giving the market's three major indexes their third consecutive winning week.
 Analysts said investors were generally feeling upbeat after strong gains in the previous two weeks and were putting aside fears -- at least temporarily -- that Wall Street's current advance is a bear market rally that will give up its gains. 
 "The market definitely has been feeling the path of least resistance in the upward direction," said Arthur Hogan, chief market analyst at Jefferies & Company. "It's almost a regardless-of-the-news type of rally." 
"The broader market is definitely in rally mode, and today is no different; we're basically having a drift up," he said.
The Dow Jones industrial average climbed 126.65 points, or 1.5 percent, to close at 8,443.99. That came after a drop of 176.93 points Thursday on investor concerns that a rally in the previous two weeks was too much, too soon.
Other markets also finished higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 32.42 points, or 2.5 percent, to 1,331.13, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.15 points, or 1.7 percent, to close at 897.65.
All three gauges had their third consecutive winning week, a feat not seen since the period ended Aug. 23. The Dow finished the week up 1.5 percent, while the Nasdaq rose 3.4 percent and the S.& P. climbed 1.5 percent.
The market lurched up and down on mixed economic reports before climbing in the afternoon.
The Commerce Department reported yesterday that new-home sales rose 0.4 percent in September to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.021 million, the highest rate on record. Economists predict 2002 will be the best year ever for sales of both new and existing homes.
But another Commerce Department report showed a 5.9 percent decline last month in orders to United States factories for durable goods. The drop, the biggest in 10 months, was much larger than the 2 percent decline analysts were expecting.
And the University of Michigan reported that consumer sentiment for October decreased to 80.6 from 86.1 in September, the lowest level since 1993, according to Dow Jones Newswires. Economists were expecting a reading of 81.3.
"The big picture economic and earnings data has been so-so, but the market is holding its own," said Bryan Piskorowski, market commentator at Prudential Securities. "The data suggests we shouldn't be going up, up and away, so we're getting a sloppy, sideways kind of action."
Analysts said investors had become more hopeful after the two-week rally as better-than-expected earnings bolstered stocks. Since hitting a five-year low on Oct. 9, the Dow has gained more than 1,000 points.
But stocks remain vulnerable to bouts of profit taking as investors worry about the market's long-term recovery. Lingering uncertainties including a possible war with Iraq also continue to pressure the market, analysts said.
Gainers included Starbucks, which jumped $1.48, to $23.93, after the company slightly raised its guidance for the fourth quarter and the full year.
Household International rose $1.26, to $24.09, after the company, a provider of consumer loans, said it raised $900 million in two securities offerings.
Pharmaceutical companies got a boost after Lehman Brothers upgraded their stocks. Wyeth gained $1.24, to $34.50, and Schering-Plough jumped $1.23, to $20.35.
Cigna, the insurance and financial services company, tumbled $24.21, or 38.1 percent, to $39.39, after it warned that third-quarter and full-year earnings would be lower than expected, citing higher costs.
Amazon dropped 56 cents, to $19.30, after the Internet retailer reported a narrower third-quarter loss. --------------------

Treasury Prices Up
(By Bloomberg News)
Treasury prices rose yesterday after reports showed durable goods orders and consumer confidence fell more than expected, adding to evidence an economic rebound is slackening.
The 10-year Treasury note rose 8/32, to a price of 102 9/32. The note's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 4.09 percent from 4.12 percent on Thursday.
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond increased 1/32, to 104 12/32. The yield was unchanged at 5.08 percent.

HEADLINE: 8,000 California Birds Killed in Bid to Stop Virus 

BYLINE:  By JOHN M. BRODER 

DATELINE: LOS ALAMITOS, Calif., Oct. 24 

 BODY:
Trying to contain a month-old outbreak of a deadly bird virus known as exotic Newcastle disease, state and federal agriculture officials have killed more than 8,000 birds in Southern California, including thousands of chickens, dozens of household pet birds, several peacocks and four ostriches.
 The devastating infection has not spread to California's commercial poultry operations, most of which are in Northern California, but Canada, Taiwan, Poland and South Korea have already banned imports of most poultry products from the state. The European Union has imposed an embargo on live poultry, hatching eggs and fresh meat from poultry and game birds from the United States until the infection is brought under control, officials said. 
 Officials from the California Department of Food and Agriculture and the United States Department of Agriculture have established an emergency Newcastle disease task force on a military training base in Los Alamitos, about 30 miles south of Los Angeles. 
The group now includes 171 officials to inspect hundreds of homes and small farms in Los Angeles, Riverside and San Bernardino Counties where the infection is feared to have spread. So far, 73 premises have been quarantined in an effort to contain the virus.
Dr. Richard E. Breitmeyer, the State of California's chief veterinarian, said he had seen hopeful signs in recent days that the spread was slowing, although he is far from ready to declare the virus contained.
"We're not finding a lot of cases of massive die-offs," Dr. Breitmeyer said. "Those occurred two to three weeks ago when birds were literally dying in front of our eyes."
He said he had been startled by the number of people in the Los Angeles metropolitan region who keep chickens and other fowl on their property as pets or sources of food.
"The sheer volume of these backyard birds has been eye-opening to us," Dr. Breitmeyer said. "Some of these birds, including chickens, are like pets to these people. It's amazing how emotionally attached people get to them."
The disease was first spotted in late September by a private veterinarian in Compton, a low-income Los Angeles suburb. A client brought in a sick chicken with symptoms similar to those of Newcastle disease: sneezing, weight loss and lethargy. The chicken soon died and was submitted to the state laboratory for testing, where results came back positive for Newcastle disease. State animal health experts quickly moved to try to assess the extent of the infection and began door-to-door inspections of homes and farms raising birds.
Newcastle disease devastated California's poultry industry in the early 1970's, when 12 million birds were destroyed. The disease was traced to imported parrots and macaws from Central and South America, which came in contact with birds from nearby commercial poultry operations. Since then, federal agriculture officials have set up inspection and quarantine stations at the borders to try to keep diseased birds out. But wild birds and smuggled exotic species and fighting cocks occasionally arrive carrying the virus.
The disease is often transmitted at bird shows, cockfights and swap meets and can be carried by humans, although it does not make people sick.
In that regard, it is like foot-and-mouth disease, which is debilitating to livestock but has little effect on humans, Dr. Breitmeyer said. The response by the authorities is similar: kill all the diseased animals and any that might have come in contact with them, then quarantine the premises until the virus is eradicated by disinfectants.
Dr. Breitmeyer said he was not certain how the disease was transported to California this time, but he said the strain here was genetically similar to a viral strain seen in Mexico in 2000 that led to the destruction of 13 million broilers.
Bill Mattos, president of the California Poultry Federation, said he had warned member farmers to impose stringent biosecurity measures at their poultry farms, disinfecting workers when they arrive and leave and giving them laundered coveralls for each shift. Still, migratory birds can transmit Newcastle disease, he said, and there was no assurance that it would not spread northward to California's $2.5 billion poultry industry, with catastrophic economic results.
"When Newcastle gets into a commercial flock, you might as well kill them all," Mr. Mattos said.
When inspectors find a diseased bird, they immediately quarantine the premises and remove all birds on the property, which are quickly killed using carbon dioxide gas. Then investigators trace the movement of the birds to try to locate other diseased flocks. Owners are compensated with state money based on the market value of the birds, although that often leads to difficult negotiations, Dr. Breitmeyer said.
"We try to determine a fair value for the birds, but it doesn't take into account the emotional value they might have to the owners," he said. "But most people are being surprisingly cooperative when we make clear to them how devastating this is to poultry."

HEADLINE: Retailers Like Business Gifts And the Profits They Generate 

BYLINE:  By TRACIE ROZHON

 BODY:
Did you really think corporate perks were out?
 Just in time for the executive who wants to remember colleagues, but is unsure about the rules, Saks Fifth Avenue has issued its new holiday corporate gift catalog, the first one the retailer has published, featuring desktop knickknacks from sterling silver flashlights for $125 to Baccarat bulls for $890. Engraving costs extra. 
 Analysts report that department stores, faced with flagging demand for clothing, are generally turning more to gifts, and that Saks is no exception. Now, besides overhauling its stores' gift departments, Saks is taking on Tiffany, which previously had the market for corporate gifts pretty much to itself -- with, of course, an occasional exception like, say, a pair of his-and-her jets from Neiman Marcus. But Tiffany's, the store with its own special corporate gift catalog, has always been the one to beat. 
To Eric Beder, the director of research with Ladenburg Thalmann, the Saks catalog is part of a changing emphasis at luxury department stores toward gifts: one-size-fits-all and the more "unique," the better. And a big part of the gift market is business customers: chief executives giving to special underlings, events coordinators giving to suppliers and manufacturers giving to top salesmen.
"There's a new focus on gifting, on companies coming out with new distinctive boxes, to further leverage the brand names," Mr. Beder said. "The market for corporate gifts is huge, with incredibly high profit margins."
Mr. Beder says that in contrast to regular store merchandise, 40 percent of which is eventually marked down, corporate gifts sell at full price or not at all -- no sales. So in January, executives will not be getting a chance to buy the New York City toile box in earthenware (Tiffany's) for less than the $75 asking price. Or the Saks doghouse- and-bone sterling key chain (for kennel owners and other dog fanciers) for $60.
At Saks, the new catalog is part of the strategy of Christina Johnson, the chief executive. Ms. Johnson, who took over in February 2000, said she wanted to make Saks more of a destination for gifts. And now, the store has released its first corporate catalog.
"We've never done this before, and we'd like to turn this into a $30 million to $50 million business over the next five years," Ms. Johnson said. That sounds like a lot, but it is not when compared with the total $16 billion-a-year corporate gift market cited in the trade magazines. But that number includes the world's supply of shirts, plastic drinking mugs and tennis balls that are embossed with company logos.
These are not exactly hallmarks of Tiffany -- nor of Saks, where the offerings start with a giant money clip of solid 18-karat gold ($450) on the cover of the new pewter-colored booklet. Saks has placed its money on pewter to rival Tiffany's distinctive cornflower blue boxes. "It's not as iconic as Tiffany's -- yet," conceded Ms. Johnson, "but we're building."
For the less generous boss, there is also a silver-plated computer mouse ($35) or a red nubuck mouse pad ($25), not to mention the Christofle silver-plated Pebble of Peace $85, with the word in 32 languages, inspired by Clara Halter, who designed Le Mur Pour la Paix, or the Wall for Peace, in Paris. 
Ms. Johnson has pulled out the stops at Saks. The company has just hired a separate corporate gift sales staff, with three regional offices in the East, Midwest and West.
This week, Mark L. Aaron, Tiffany's vice president for investor relations, played down the role of corporate gifts in his company's overall earnings profile. "It's only 5 or 6 percent of the total," he said. However, Tiffany reported earnings of $708 million in the first half of 2002, so even 5 percent -- $35 million -- is not exactly chicken feed.
Linda Buckley, also speaking for Tiffany, said its silver and bone-china Christmas tree ornaments always sold well, along with silver styluses for hand-held computers ($65). Pens with the Tiffany "T" logo are also top sellers, she added.
The difference between the corporate gift catalogs, according to Saks, is that Saks does not have to keep its offerings to its own branded products. The company can, and does, offer Burberry raincoats, for example. But Tiffany argues that because it sells only the Tiffany brand, there is an exclusivity to the products they offer.
But in the Saks catalog there are exclusive items that are sold only by Saks. And there are other items, like the Christofle pebble, which the company says are offered only by the manufacturer -- Christofle itself -- and by Saks.
Ms. Johnson pointed to the $200 Dunhill sterling "decision maker," an inch-and-a-half-wide spinner engraved with "Today," "Tomorrow," "Yes" and "No."
But perhaps the most original gift is shown on the last page of the catalog: an old-fashioned snow globe -- the kind you shake and the white stuff begins to fall -- with your company's very own skyscraper inside.
Even with your own building sculpted inside, the globes are just $35 apiece. The only caveat is that you have to order at least 1,500 of them.
