HEADLINE: Two Political Veterans, but Only One Chair 

BYLINE:  By STACEY STOWE 

 BODY:
WHEN Connecticut lost a Congressional seat because of a population decline, and voting districts were redrawn last December, the Fifth District race for the United States House was poised to be the toughest contest in the state this fall.
 It featured the rare combination of two incumbents seeking votes in 41 towns, often among an unfamiliar electorate, and had the potential to tip the political balance in the House to Democratic from the Republican-held majority. 
 Now, weeks away from Election Day, the contest between Nancy L. Johnson and James H. Maloney is not quite as pitched as promised, yet remains, next to the gubernatorial contest, the most closely watched in Connecticut.
A Quinnipiac University poll of Oct. 17 showed Ms. Johnson, a 10-term Republican whose Sixth District of 31 towns was melded into the new Fifth, leading by 56 percent to the 38 percentage of Mr. Maloney, a three-term Democrat. Douglas Schwartz, the director of the Quinnipiac poll, said that given the recent evidence, the race can no longer be considered a tossup. 
Yet political experts said it would be a mistake to discount Mr. Maloney, 53, a married father of three school-aged daughters and the oldest of 10 brothers and sisters, who is described by more than one as a "populist street fighter." Many recall his 1996 victory over Republican Gary Franks, who'd beaten him in 1994, despite his trailing Mr. Franks by some 17 points in the polls just weeks before the election.
Mr. Maloney also squeaked out a victory against Republican Mark Nielsen in 1998 by a few thousand votes. If the sport of politics leans toward boxing metaphors, Mr. Maloney, the experts said, is not yet down for the count.
The newly drawn Fifth District is bordered to the northwest by Salisbury and to the southwest by Danbury, featuring a crazy quilt of Republican small-town strongholds and the blue-collar cities of Waterbury and New Britain long favored by Democrats. This factor, the incumbency of both candidates and a high number of unaffiliated voters has made for a challenging campaign.
So far, it has been a contest marked by a fair bit of mudslinging, mostly over three issues: truth in campaign advertising, negative campaigning and the veracity of the candidates' voting records in Congress. Mr. Maloney's camp has accused Ms. Johnson of not voting for the programs she touts on the stump.
"She says one thing in Connecticut and then votes the other way when she gets to Washington," Mr. Maloney has repeatedly said of Ms. Johnson. Ms. Johnson's squad retorts that Mr. Maloney is still a greenhorn in Congress with few voting notches on his own belt.
"He's written one law to Nancy's 23," said Brian Schubert, Ms. Johnson's press aide. Those 23 bills include individual bills written by Ms. Johnson that are rolled into other legislation and signed into law.
Another high profile topic is the financial divide between the candidates. Ms. Johnson has raised $3 million, Mr. Schubert said and counts President George W. Bush and his father as fund-raisers. Mr. Maloney has raised $1.7 million, with help from former president William J. Clinton and his wife, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton.
Indeed, the Fifth District is listed as the fifth most expensive congressional contest nationwide this year, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, a Washington-based nonpartisan, nonprofit research group that tracks money in politics.
Yet Ms. Johnson, who is a left-of-center Republican and Mr. Maloney, a right-leaning Democrat, share many similar policy views, said Kenneth Dautrich, a professor of political science at the University of Connecticut and director of its poll. Both are willing, for example, to consider privatizing aspects of the Social Security program while not supporting large-scale change to it, he noted.
They are divided on the issue of term limits, a potentially thorny topic for Mr. Maloney, who signed a pledge in 1998 that he would not serve beyond eight consecutive years. If elected in November, the term would be his last. Ms. Johnson, who refused to sign the pledge because she said he believed it is too difficult to be effective at the federal level without at least six to eight years experience, said Mr. Maloney had handicapped himself.
"People know you're there for the last time," she said. But Mr. Maloney said he stands by his decision.
"Congress suffers from people who serve too long and are more responsive to their fellow cronies in Washington that they are to the voters," he said.
If the race is said to turn on any one issue, Mr. Dautrich said, it is personality. Ms. Johnson, the mother of three grown daughters and the wife of a retired doctor, is the first Republican woman to serve on the Ways and Means Committee and the first and only woman to be chairwoman of two of its subcommittees. Her long history in Connecticut politics gives her, at age 67, a cachet of the elder stateswoman with very high name recognition, he said.
Yet Mr. Maloney stepped onto the international stage last year when he traveled twice to Russia to help broker the release of Jack Tobin, a Fulbright scholar studying in that country and imprisoned on charges of drug use and possession.
Mr. Maloney is not considered an "inside Democrat," but is instead something of a loner. By contrast, Ms. Johnson is perceived as a party favorite. 
"This can work to his advantage, actually," Mr. Dautrich said. "He can push his populist stance and note that he doesn't kowtow to anybody."
Mr. Maloney is not afraid to fight hard and bold in a campaign. For example he beat Mr. Franks in 1996 after running an ad featuring a rat scurrying through an abandoned building when it was revealed that Mr. Franks owned some severely decaying property in Waterbury. Mr. Dautrich recalled the ad as "vicious and really negative, but very effective."
Mr. Maloney also has huge support from labor unions, including the backing of the national A.F.L.-C.I.O., whose Connecticut president, John Olsen, is also the chairman of the state Democratic Party. Mr. Maloney pointed out his efforts this summer in preventing the Stanley Works company from reincorporating. The New Britain tool manufacturer sought to relocate its business in name only to Bermuda to save money on taxes, a move that many employees believed would have increased outsourcing of work overseas, resulting in layoffs.
But Ms. Johnson said she too plans to work on a bill to prevent such corporate restructuring, but is aware of the need for a domestic corporation to protect itself from takeovers by foreign companies whose taxes are lower and work force is cheaper.
A huge difficulty for the candidates is that neither can point to the opponent and accuse with any gusto of being inexperienced, Howard Reiter, a UConn political science professor, said, as both are incumbents.
Stuart Rothenberg, who publishes a political report in Washington that is a nonpartisan analysis of American politics and elections, suggested that Mr. Maloney should turn away from whose ads are most accurate and call attention to the slumping economy.
"If he can tap into public angst that the current economic plan is not working, this will sit well with Waterbury and New Britain and other areas in the Fifth with largely working class-voters," he said.
Mr. Rothenberg attributed some of Ms. Johnson's success in the newly configured Fifth District to her ability to move in all social circles.
"One minute she can be with a Republican garden club and the next she's in a bar in Waterbury drinking beer and slapping somebody on the back," he said, a dichotomy acknowledged with a chuckle by Ms. Johnson.
But charisma, polls and advertising aside, Mr. Reiter said that sometimes winning a House seat comes down to the most mundane factor: which party can mobilize the most people to get out and vote on Nov. 5.

HEADLINE: L.I.@WORK; 
Making a Move to the Island a Little Easier

BYLINE:  By WARREN STRUGATCH 

 BODY:
FOR three days in May, John and Christi Ruggieri holed up in a motel in Huntington while Nichole, the oldest of their three children, attended cheerleader tryouts at Huntington High School. The family, then living in Freehold, N.J., planned to close on a Huntington house in September, but that would be too late for Nichole's cheerleading plans.
 "I had been cheerleading for three years, and I wanted to continue in my new school," said Nichole, 14. "My Dad said, 'Do you really want to do cheerleading?' I said yes. So we came in May." 
 Mr. Ruggieri, a New Jersey native, agreed to move to Long Island last year when his employer, Circuit City, asked him to manage the chain's newest store, in Brooklyn. Helping Nichole get adjusted to her new school was paramount, Mrs. Ruggieri said. A native Texan, she has been getting acclimated too. "I even got elected team mom for the cheerleaders," she said. 
Absorbing workers from outside Nassau and Suffolk has been identified as a key goal by the Long Island Association, which says that despite occasional spikes in unemployment, worker shortages loom as a major impediment to economic expansion on the Island.
Attracting people to live and work on Long Island has never been easy, however. Recruiters blame such factors as the cost of living, preconceptions about congestion and traffic, and the difficulty many newcomers experience in finding their way around the Island.
In recent years, however, companies have stepped up their recruitment efforts, often aided by real estate companies. New programs offer a kind of welcome-wagon approach intended as Miracle-Gro for the process of putting down roots in a new community.
The Ruggieris, for example, said their move to Huntington was made smoother through the efforts of the Long Island Relocation Center. A Northport unit of Daniel Gale Real Estate, the relocation center helps companies recruit and transfer people to the region more effectively by helping manage both the real estate part of the transaction as well as the psychological adjustment.
Marie Montchal, a Daniel Gale vice president, estimated that she had helped more than 1,000 people move to Long Island in the 10 years she has been head of the center.
While there are no statistics on how many people are recruited or transferred to Long Island each year, Ms. Montchal said most of the people she helps are professionals and managers. (Companies often invite hourly employees to relocate, but rarely pick up the cost.) 
Because more than half of the jobs offered to people on condition of relocation are turned down, according Ms. Montchal, she positions her service as way for companies to improve their recruiting and transfers.
"Over the past few years a good number of companies on Long Island have become more sophisticated in their recruitment and relocation polices, and for this reason are more successful attracting people from other areas," Ms. Montchal said. "We emphasize that companies have to address the issues around relocation before the employee moves in, not afterwards."
According to a 1996 member survey by the Employee Relocation Council -- whose member companies finance more than 300 household moves a year -- companies that do substantial employee relocating spend about $60,000 for each relocation of a current employee. Costs vary significantly, from an average $14,000 relocating recruits who rent their homes to upward of $75,000 for home-owning senior executives involved in long-distance transfers.
In addition to defraying costs associated with housing differentials, and reimbursing individuals for costs incurred in the move, many companies also woo would-be transfers with a package of services intended to make their move go smoothly. Traditionally, the package has included the services of job counselors and other professionals who help the employee's spouse find a job in the couple's new community. Increasingly, the package is engineered to help the entire family put down roots and to address the psychological impact of the move.
To entice employees to move, they also often throw in the services of relocation specialists like Ms. Montchal, who informally fill such roles as concierge, travel planner, transportation manager and neighborhood greeter. The Gale agency does this, Ms. Montchal said, at no extra charge when handling sales and rentals for the company.
"Typically, I work with someone who's been asked to move to Long Island and doesn't know anyone here, has no sense of what's what and who's where," Ms. Montchal said.
"We familiarize people with Long Island while they're still deciding whether they want to relocate here or not, or to stay beyond the terms of their contract," she continued. "If you just drop them onto the Long Island Expressway, you lose them. They're not going to move here if that's their Long Island experience."
To help newcomers adjust quickly, the relocation center's nine employees give advice on transportation, schools and cultural offerings, and help them recognize the nuances of various communities. The center also customizes packages containing neighborhood-specific information about museums, recreation and outlet shopping.
"We help people identify the best schools, get them the phone number of the utility companies, and do things you need done when you move," Ms. Montchal said. "Relocating is stressful. We try to reduce stress by providing information."
While the Ruggieris managed to fit in right away, other newcomers say they struggle with a sense of isolation that can last years. They blame cultural differences, regional sprawl, dysfunctional transportation and neighborhood insularity -- and, sometimes, their own shyness or homesickness.
Edmund and Shelly Sanctis moved from the San Francisco Bay area to the North Shore earlier this year when Mr. Sanctis accepted an offer to become president of Acclaim Entertainment, a video game company in Glen Cove.
After living several years in Burlingame, Calif., Mr. Sanctis said he found Long Island more diverse and less cohesive.
"In the Bay Area, if you're a software executive, you can assume everybody you meet is in the software industry," he said. "Everybody kind of plugs into that scene."
That commonality provides a kind of social shorthand but also creates what he described as "cultural myopia."
"There's more balance on Long Island, and that's a good thing," he said.
Leigh Jones, a journalist specializing in coverage of law firms and legal matters, moved to Long Island from Oklahoma City in 1999 to work at Long Island Business News in Ronkonkoma. She quickly felt isolated. 
"I was the only person on my managerial level at that job, so there weren't peers for socializing," she said.
As a renter in Bayport, she said she didn't meet many people in her neighborhood, either.
"I wanted to join an arts group, but didn't find out there was one right in my neighborhood until I moved away," she said.
The sense of culture shock can be sharp. Ms. Jones recalls taking her father out to dinner when he visited soon after she settled in. Their waitress spoke so brusquely that her father got up to complain to management.
"I talked him out of it," she said. "I explained that's how people talk on Long Island. People say what they need to say and that's it. They don't even pretend to be polite. If you aren't raised that way it takes some getting used to."
Ms. Jones has since taken a new job with the New York Law Journal, covering Long Island from Mineola. She said she was now more outgoing and as a result felt less isolated.
"I realized I'd have to create my own social network," she said. "I'm dating a guy I met in Starbucks. I just walked up and started a conversation."
In April Timothy and Judith Root moved to a condo in Port Jefferson from a home in Redmond, Wash., when Mr. Root accepted a job offer from BAE Systems, a satellite communications company. Mrs. Root said she was still adjusting to a more hurried lifestyle.
"You're driving along and people are tailgating you and honking," she said. "People get an attitude. I was taught to be courteous to people in public. Sometimes I don't find that reciprocated."
Scott Cerniglia, a store manager with the Best Buy chain, bought a house in Shoreham in July with his girlfriend after his company transferred him here from Boston. Mr. Cerniglia, born in Wisconsin and raised in Minnesota, said he thought population density put pressure on people.
Mr. Cerniglia declared that his immediate neighbors were the exception.
"I live in a great neighborhood, and everyone made us feel welcome from the start," he said. "The first weekend there was a block party. After that an invitation to someone's pool party arrived every weekend, it seemed. People bring you into the community as much as you want to be brought in."
Shelley Sanctis, whose husband is Acclaim's new president, said that despite many welcoming gestures from her neighbors, she still felt something was missing, though she found it hard to explain. 
"Maybe it's a sense of belonging," she said. "I know that doesn't happen quickly. People here seem more established than in Burlingame. They don't share the sense of being new in a community, and what it feels like to be the newcomer."

HEADLINE: Drums Along the Peconic 

BYLINE:  By JULIA C. MEAD 

DATELINE: RIVERHEAD 

 BODY:
RESIDENTS of Riverhead, the poorest town in Suffolk County, are forever trying to overcome negative perceptions of the place they live. The Town of Riverhead has spent considerable money and energy trying to reinvigorate the unincorporated hamlet of Riverhead, which straddles the Peconic River, as a commercial center and tourist destination.
 The effort has been a modest success, with the Tanger Outlet Mall and the Atlantis Marine World aquarium as its principal achievements. But Riverhead's most poverty-stricken, crime-ridden area -- the neighborhood called Riverside -- is entirely beyond the control of the Town of Riverhead. It is in the Town of Southampton, on the south side of the Peconic. 
 To distinguish its territory from Southampton's, Riverhead has installed new street signs along the border announcing when one enters or leaves Riverhead. It has tried to open discussions on splitting the Riverhead school district, which includes both sides of the river. Similarly, it wants the United States Postal Service to split its 11901 ZIP code. It has asked news outlets to stop describing the courthouse and jail, which are on the south side of the river, as being in Riverhead. 
A Riverhead town councilman, Edward Densieski, even wants to block the sidewalks on the bridges over the Peconic. The Traveler Watchman, a local weekly, reported that he told a town board meeting that "I'm not trying to fence out Southampton, but I would like to fence out the prostitutes, drug dealers, drug users and other vagrants."
The Southampton town supervisor, Patrick Heaney, told the paper the proposal "sounds like shades of East Germany."
Joey MacLellan, a Riverhead town spokesman, did not endorse Mr. Densieski's proposal. But he said Riverhead wants to make it clear that Riverside and Flanders, a slightly less blighted community east of Riverside, are Southampton's problem.
"The town has been working hard to revitalize its downtown, but for 27 years Southampton ignored those neighborhoods completely," Mr. MacLellan said. "So the board felt it had to do something."
Community activists in Riverside and Flanders contend that Riverhead's campaign shows too little appreciation for the south-of-the-river neighborhoods, whose residents spend their shopping dollars in downtown Riverhead and the outlet mall.
"It's cutting off Riverhead's nose to spite its face," said David Brewer, a Flanders resident and a founder of the Flanders-Riverside-Northampton Community Association.
But neighborhood residents, long accustomed to official neglect, are reacting with a mixture of gratitude and skepticism to indications that Southampton Town will no longer ignore an area that is in every way the opposite of the Hamptons stereotype.
Mr. Heaney, nearing the end of his first year as Southampton town supervisor, has been following through on a campaign promise to more closely focus town resources on the riverfront neighborhoods. Police patrols and building inspections have increased, and the town plans new streetlights and sidewalks, improvements to public parks, a long-term planning study and town acquisition of a crumbling, vacant building on the traffic circle that is the southern gateway to downtown Riverhead.
Riverside surrounds the traffic circle. Full of abandoned houses, littered lots and boarded-up storefronts, it is known as a place to drive through quickly on the way to somewhere else. Flanders has fewer vacant buildings and a few more middle-class homes. But both communities have suffered for decades from poverty, crime and and the absence of commercial development, sidewalks, playgrounds and other amenities that help give a neighborhood a sense of community.
"This area cries out for revitalization, and we are trying to be responsive," Mr. Heaney said.
Some community activists are encouraged. "I am cautiously optimistic," Mr. Brewer said. "It's been a long time since any attention has been paid to us."
The Rev. Roy L. Pennon, pastor of the Galilee Church of God in Christ in Riverside, said, "We've come a long way, we still have a long way to go, but I am very optimistic."
Dr. Pennon said his mostly African-American congregation of about 275 has begun speaking out and attending civic and government meetings. The congregation welcomes proposals to reduce crime, he said, and has plans to build a day care center in an abandoned house the church recently bought at auction. "In the last year, people here have really started to pull together," Dr. Pennon said.
Mr. Brewer also noted a rise in community spirit. "We were cut off and ignored," he said. "But we're starting to figure out there's strength in numbers."
South-of-the-river residents got a break last month, when at the urging of Southampton officials the state approved a one-shot equalization of the tax rate in the school district, shifting $1.8 million of the tax burden from Flanders and Riverside to neighborhoods inside Riverhead Town.
Riverside and Flanders property owners said they carried a disproportionate share of the tax load because more than half of the district's Southampton part is preserved land, and thus is removed from the tax rolls, and there is little commercial development. But the ruling has prompted Riverhead to consider suing, Mr. MacLellan said, and the Riverhead town supervisor, Robert Kozakiewicz, continues to talk up the idea of dividing the school district.
(Though downtown Riverhead is better off than the Southampton parts, the town-wide picture is reversed. The Suffolk County Planning Commission estimates last year's median family income in Riverhead at $59,131, the lowest of Suffolk's 10 towns. Southampton was in the middle of the pack at $68,861.)
While the two supervisors disagree sharply on the tax situation, both say they agree about the need for commercial development on the Southampton side of the river. They share support for a hotel and marina complex proposed on the south bank, and for an enterprise zone proposed on Route 24, the main road on the south side of the river.
"Anything we do would have a huge return for Riverhead," Mr. Heaney said, adding that Southampton will ask Riverhead business leaders for help in planning a "gateway park" on the Southampton side.
But some residents are not pleased with the prospect of more traffic and more buildings.
"I think it's very significant that Southampton can see we've been neglected and abused, but I believe it will take far more than a one-year tax rate change and some new street lights to give this community what it really needs," said Therese McGuiness, a Flanders resident and frequent critic of Mr. Heaney.
Ms. McGuinness contended that commercial development would only create more traffic and pollution and a greater sense of isolation.
"What kind of jobs are we talking about? Or is it just a mad rush to develop?" she said. "We don't have the roads and infrastructure to handle this. There just hasn't been adequate planning to address all of the inherent problems, and it will take a lot more than a few blue-collar jobs to get people out of poverty."
She argued that Southampton Town is suddenly interested in commercial development in the Riverside-Flanders area simply because it would not be welcome in the town's wealthier neighborhoods.
"None of this would happen if it wasn't an impoverished neighborhood," Ms. McGuinness said. "Change is coming. It's already here. But it's not all good."
Mr. Brewer said he too hopes the town will approach development with caution, but also hopes the hamlet study will lead to rejuvenation of Flanders's traditional maritime uses and rezoning to permit the creation of hamlet centers.
Dr. Pennon said a community-wide revitalization would raise hopes for eradicating the blights of drug abuse and unemployment.
"I think the self-esteem of this entire community is going to improve," he said. "It's long overdue."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Long Island; 
A Giant Weapons Plant Is Renovated Into Offices

BYLINE:  By CAROLE PAQUETTE

 BODY:
THE five flags of the permanent members of the Security Council still fly in front of what was an early site of the United Nations, in Lake Success in Nassau County, just east of the Queens border and 16 miles from Manhattan.
 The United Nations moved out in 1951, however, and the huge property was owned by a series of military contractors until it was sold by Lockheed Martin in 2000 for $21 million to a partnership called I.park Lake Success. 
 Now, the 1.4 million-square-foot complex on 94 acres has been renovated and serves primarily as an office park.
The mix of tenants so far is somewhat different from what the new owners had anticipated. More than half of the space at the complex has been leased, although not to the technology and dot-com companies that had originally been expected. Instead, I.park's tenants are predominantly concerns requiring offices with high-quality finishes and walled rooms. Such spaces bring in higher rents than open industrial space. 
"We are getting significantly more office tenants than we originally planned," said Lynne M. Ward, a principal of I.park Holdings of Greenwich, Conn., which is a partner in I.park Lake Success with Apollo Real Estate Investment Fund IV of Manhattan.
Richard J. Mack, a partner at Apollo, said: "The economy has dictated much of the tenancy. Many of the dot-com and technology companies didn't have the credit."
Of I.park's space, 550,000 square feet has been leased, 450,000 square feet is in negotiations and about 400,000 is still being marketed, Ms. Ward said. Most leases are for 15 years, and the space is being renovated to suit the tenants.
By a ratio of about three to one, Ms. Ward said, the space has been taken by companies seeking traditional office space rather than warehouses. The office tenants include AXA Advisors and Allstate Insurance. Such concerns require "a higher finish to their space and bring in a higher rent," she said. 
Offices at I.park rent for $23 to $25 a foot annually, plus utilities, while warehouse space rents for $12 to $15 a foot, not including taxes or common area maintenance charges. Leasing of the property is through Cushman & Wakefield of Long Island, a division of the national real estate company.
Two years ago, it was estimated that the partnership's total investment in the project would be $70 million, including the purchase price. Today, because of the quality of the office space being created, the projection is that the investment will total approximately $130 million, Ms. Ward said. Nevertheless, she said, "We will be making slightly more profit than we expected because of the higher rents." The start of leasing was later than expected because of the numerous permits required, since half of the property is in the town of North Hempstead and half in the village of Lake Success, Mr. Mack said. 
But the response has been strong, the participants say. "We have a product that most people don't have," said David C. Leviton, a senior director at Cushman & Wakefield's Melville-based Long Island office. "Large blocks of space are available at reasonable rental prices, and every tenant is autonomous with their own air-conditioning units and entries."
He added that the wide placement of the steel supporting columns within the main building -- they are spaced 40 feet apart in one direction and 80 in the other -- enables companies to maximize the number of employees they can assign there. 
The ceilings are 16 to 22 feet high and hold many skylights, so there is a lot of natural lighting. Electricity is provided by a 30-megawatt substation connected to three separate Long Island Power Authority stations, reducing the likelihood of severe power failures.
SOME tenants are using on-site contractors to design and construct their spaces. These contractors include representatives from a Manhattan-based architectural firm, the Phillips Group, and a construction and telecommunications company doing business under the I.park name.
The property's buildings that are being leased have their original bricks, which have been cleaned, and energy-efficient glass windows have been installed. 
The north building -- a three-story, 92,000-square-foot office building that housed the United Nations -- includes the "link building," a section that connects to the 1,150,000-square-foot, single-story main building, where planes and submarine systems were built in the past. 
The single-story, 150,000-square-foot free-standing south building, which was once the foundry, is at the rear of the main building. A single tenant is in negotiations for the site.
The remaining property includes the power station, parking lots for 3,800 cars, two soccer fields that have been donated to the town of North Hempstead, a wooded area with several ponds and several smaller buildings that are used for storage.
The spaces that have already been taken range from 6,500 square feet leased to Cablevision for two studios to 165,000 square feet to The New York Times for a distribution center and warehouse. 
A 10,000-square-foot international food court is in the center of the main building, where the corridors were named by Lockheed Martin after streets in Manhattan, including Broadway and 42nd Street. Five 3,000-square-foot cafes, called pantries, are throughout the buildings. 
The north building, which has a penthouse, has been renovated in a post-modern style that has curved corners and other Art Deco design elements.
AXA has leased 45,645 square feet on the first and second floors. The 25,000-square-foot third floor, which has not yet been leased, looks out on the line of flags and a lawn where a memorial garden is being planned. It will rent for approximately $30 a foot. A 4,000-square-foot penthouse will either be part of the lease or be turned into a conference room for about 60 people, Ms. Ward said.
Tenants of the one-story main building include Allstate, which has leased 81,654 square feet for administrative offices and a claims office with a drive-in facility. 
Allstate, has four offices and 387 employees at I.park and "is a case study" of I.park's initial hope that because of the availability of large blocks of space, companies with operations in several locations would consolidate there because of its access to fiber optics and heavy-duty power supplies, Ms. Ward said.
Long Island Jewish Medical Center, which is across Lakeville Road from I.park, has leased 64,647 square feet for office and medical space and 27,418 square feet for warehouse use.
Another tenant in the main building is a financial institution that has leased 39,381 square feet as a backup facility, a use that more companies are investigating since the Sept. 11 attacks, realtors say. "We are starting to see companies coming out of New York City looking for backup facilities," Mr. Leviton said.
OTHER realtors marketing large space once occupied by military contractors say they, too, are getting inquiries about available space for backup offices for "disaster relief," but haven't signed leases yet.
"There have been some inquiries to date, but nothing we would consider imminent," said Arthur Stern, a partner at Cogswell Realty Group, a co-owner with the Rudin family of Manhattan in the 355,000-square-foot Long Island Business and Technology Center on 82 acres in Great River, which is the site of the former Northrop Grumman avionics facility.
"We get inquiries from time to time about possible disaster relief sites," said Jack O'Connor, executive vice president at Melville-based Grubb & Ellis. 
The real estate services company has been marketing property at Epcal, the industrial park at the site of the former Grumman plant in Calverton, where military aircraft was manufactured. 
One New York City company had been interested in 100,000 square feet at the park for backup, he said, but ultimately did not act. "The bottom line," he said, "is because of the economy companies are hesitant to pay two rents."

HEADLINE: In the Region/Connecticut; 
Building Upscale Rental Projects, Welcome or Not

BYLINE:  By ELEANOR CHARLES

 BODY:
DESPITE high prices for houses and condominiums and the sharp declines in the stock market, home sales remain strong, propelled by low interest rates. The movement of buyers who might once have been renters into ownership is being felt by landlords of rental properties. 
 Even vigorous AvalonBay Communities, ranked fourth behind Equity Residential, Archstone-Smith and Aimco among 19 rental apartment real estate investment trusts, is having its first economic challenge. AvalonBay has announced a delay in its plan to build a 39-story, 588-apartment tower at its Avalon on the Sound project at the train station in New Rochelle, joining the existing 24-story, 412-apartment tower. AvalonBay said that because of economic conditions, construction is being put off until next year. 
 The company calculates that its average rents in the metropolitan New York area have fallen $24 a month, or 1.2 percent. Average rents for its properties were $1,934 in the third quarter of 2001, and $1,910 in the third quarter of this year. Average occupancy dropped 4.3 percentage points in that time, from 97.1 percent in the third quarter last year to 92.9 percent this year, and a vacant apartment remains unoccupied for about 23 days. 
A month's free rent is offered on a case by case basis to attract tenants, and turnover nationwide has increased from 60 percent of all units annually to 65 percent, running up losses for downtime and costs for more frequent redecorating between tenants. 
The tougher rental market has been reflected in AvalonBay's share price, which has been fluctuating in the upper $30's, not far above its low for the year, and about 30 percent below this year's high of $52.65. "This is the first time our share price has taken a sharp drop," said Bryce Blair, president of AvalonBay Communities, based in Alexandria, Va., "reflecting the extraordinarily weak fundamentals throughout the country and in our markets."
Still, the company says it has adequate capital to purchase sites for future development, removing them from the reach of rival developers at a time when property is scarce in upscale areas, where Avalon concentrates its developments.
Hewing largely to a business-as-usual strategy, Mr. Blair said, "we have $700 million worth of construction in 13 communities under way," producing 6 to 10 developments a year. In its 146 complexes with 42,914 apartments in 11 states, rents range from $1,000 for a one-bedroom unit in Northern California to $4,500 for a three-bedroom apartment at the 323-unit Avalon Harbor, near completion in Stamford.
AvalonBay communities tend to attract professionals of all ages and singles and couples with or without children who live there as temporary transferees or while scouting a permanent home or simply because they like the lifestyle. The average stay is 7 to 15 months, but some tenants stay for three to six years or more on renewable leases subject to annual rent increases of a minimum of 5 percent. Some of these rises have been temporarily suspended on a case by case basis as the economy has struggled.
The developments have 102 to 323 apartments, which may be located in a number of low-rise country-style buildings, an urban high rise or a single brick midrise wrapped around a center court and covering an entire city block. Amenity packages, including swimming pools, fitness centers, business centers, barbecue grills, flower gardens, indoor basketball and squash courts, concierges and security systems, can trigger an extra charge of $600 a year.
The company began in Connecticut in 1988 as a regional affiliate of Trammell Crow Residential, had an amicable disconnect from Trammell Crow in 1993 and merged with Bay Communities of San Francisco in 1998, when it went public as AvalonBay Communities. It has regularly battled and frequently slain the dragons of local zoning who object to rental properties within their municipalities, especially projects offering "affordable" units, a feature of many AvalonBay developments. 
"We like doing business where business is tough," said Mr. Blair. It is a phrase he repeats frequently, relating to what the industry calls high-barrier-to-entry communities -- the affluent suburbs of major cities where multifamily rental housing and affordable units are regarded as attracting an undesirable transient clientele whose way of life is considered antithetical to the towns' traditional single-family-home styles.
AN affordable housing law enacted in Connecticut in 1989 allows developers to build more units than they would otherwise be authorized if they set aside 20 or more percent of their apartments for low income tenants. Towns had to prove that the developments were harmful to the community in order to reject them, reducing the authority of local zoning boards and fueling resentment and lawsuits.
"Many of our markets require incorporation of an affordable housing component," Mr. Blair said, "in Massachusetts, Washington State, New Jersey, California -- but New England and the San Francisco Bay area have been the most contentious, and Darien and New Canaan in Fairfield County have been the most difficult in our history." 
In litigation drawn out over more than a decade, Darien finally capitulated last year and abandoned efforts to buy 32 acres to thwart an AvalonBay development. Site work has started on a 189-unit complex with 21 "affordables," set aside for families earning no more than 80 percent of the median income of the area or the state, whichever is lower. 
In an equally protracted case involving an approved referendum to condemn an AvalonBay site in New Canaan that was overturned in court, the company has ended up building on two sites. One site holds a recently completed office building, partly occupied by AvalonBay itself, and the other holds 104 new apartments, opened this month, with 21 affordables. The market rate for a three-bedroom unit (the only size left) is now $2,991, $300 less than when the building first went on the market, said Karen Loyd, the property manager, and 61 percent of the units have been leased. A three-bedroom unit at the affordable rate is $2,400, unchanged; a family of four taking such a unit could earn no more than $58,000 a year.
The Town of Orange tried to condemn AvalonBay property zoned for affordable housing in a five-year legal battle that ended when the court decided Orange's professed need for industrial development was a ruse to keep affordable housing out. Mitchell Goldblatt, the first selectman, said: "The town still doesn't want 168 apartments. The site is not appropriate for housing. It's surrounded by a tool and die company, a Pez factory and Wallach Surgical Devices."
Three lawsuits against AvalonBay by Milford over a proposal for 284 apartments are before an appeals court, on issues of a zone change, a sewer permit and a site plan, while Stratford has cited safety concerns in a suit against a 146-apartment complex.
Around the state, many towns have filed suits over what they characterize as inappropriate development that provides windfalls for developers, and such arguments have made inroads. In 1999 there were court rulings against three developers, favoring the towns of Glastonbury, Newtown and Bridgewater on issues of environmental degradation, potable water and open space. Avalon subsequently withdrew an application in Newtown. 
"Those decisions reminded everyone that affordable housing is not a cakewalk for developers," said Timothy Hollister, a Hartford lawyer who specializes in defending projects that include affordable housing.
"What happened in 2000," he continued, "was a bipartisan effort studied in the Connecticut Legislature for six months" that had the effect of making projects with affordable units less attractive to developers. 
Samuel Fuller, executive vice president for construction and development at AvalonBay, said there was "no question that it minimized use of the law," as a legal wedge to overcome community opposition to multifamily developments. He added: "By reducing profitability, alternative uses for the land become more viable. Watering down the law has deterred us from doing a number of projects we had planned."
As successful as AvalonBay has been in producing a small but significant crop of luxury rental units at less than market rates, it has not, of course, done so for philanthropic reasons. While it still has affordables in projects that are under way, it has been moving in other directions. 
Danbury, for example, where AvalonBay has built 403 units in two projects and is shepherding a new 234-apartment complex through town boards, does not need more housing priced below market rates. "They want multifamily rental housing to encourage employment growth by providing places to live," said Mark Forlenza, AvalonBay's regional vice president for development. In New Rochelle and Jersey City, where revitalization has been ongoing and affordable housing exists, AvalonBay's luxury housing is seen as invigorating the local economy. As part of Norwalk's redevelopment, AvalonBay will build a 314-apartment complex, replacing a downtown Pathmark supermarket, without affordables.
The company keeps and manages its projects for about six years, when some may be sold, in order to avoid rises in maintenance and capital costs. Buyers, according to Mr. Blair, "may turn them into condominiums, but AvalonBay does not and will not do condos," he said, although other developers are converting to avoid the poor rental market. "It's an entirely different business," said Mr. Blair."

CORRECTION-DATE: November 3, 2002

 CORRECTION:
An article in Connecticut and Westchester copies last Sunday about rental housing built by the AvalonBay company misstated its policy on eventual sale of its projects. While the company does sell its developments from time to time, it does not do so after six years; that figure is the average age of its properties. The company has kept most of the properties it has developed, in some cases for more than 20 years.

HEADLINE: A Delicate Balance: Community Facilities And Communities 

BYLINE:  By DAVID W. DUNLAP

 BODY:
NEW YORKERS have always lived shoulder to shoulder with their institutions. But for 40 years, the institutions have had more zoning muscle.
 Schools, universities, hospitals, medical offices, nursing homes, houses of worship and other institutions defined by law as "community facilities" are allowed to build far larger structures than would otherwise be permitted in residential areas. The planning theory is that they serve the general welfare, belong in neighborhoods rather than commercial districts and, by their very nature, need more space to operate efficiently. 
 The planning result, however, has agitated residents from Greenwich Village to Flushing, Queens, as they watch community facilities fill the skyline with bulky profiles and nearby streets with traffic. 
Two dozen neighborhood leaders joined together 12 days ago to form the Citywide Coalition for Community Facility Reform. They question why community facilities need to be up to twice as bulky as nearby buildings, why they are permitted to cluster in certain neighborhoods and even what constitutes a community facility.
At the same time, the City Planning Department is studying proposals for a series of changes in community facility zoning, working with Councilman Tony Avella of Queens, who heads the Council's zoning subcommittee. "The residential character of many neighborhoods throughout the city is being destroyed," he said.
Efforts to revamp the zoning did not get far in the past. Sylvia Deutsch, the planning director under Mayor Edward I. Koch, said she would have reduced the "very disruptive" bulk of community facilities outside Manhattan had Mr. Koch been re-elected. Joseph B. Rose, the director under Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, hoped to open manufacturing zones to community facilities and increase restrictions on medical offices in residential areas.
Parking provisions and manufacturing zones are at the top of the agenda for Amanda M. Burden, the current planning director. "Community facilities provide vital services and are an important part of the fabric of our city," she said. "On the other hand, they, like other land uses, can sometimes have negative impacts on the neighborhoods in which they're located."
For the time being, the revisions will not address the issue of building bulk, though that is the lightning rod in Manhattan. The construction this year of the Kimmel Center for University Life at New York University, on Washington Square South, was one of the sparks behind the creation of the new citywide coalition. The 11-story structure will serve as the student center on completion early next year. Even under construction, it has claimed a prominent place in the familiar vista through the Washington Arch.
"Where arch and sky were previously dramatically framed by lower Fifth Avenue, this view now looks more like a blind alley," wrote Andrew Berman, executive director of the Greenwich Village Society for Historic Preservation and one of the organizers of the new coalition. "Many assumed that given the wealth of historic resources in close proximity to the proposed building, there would be some greater degree of regulation or control over such a large project. There was not."
With 149,700 square feet above ground, the center is 85 percent larger than a private development could be on the same site. In the R7-2 zone, a medium-density apartment house district, dwellings may have a floor area 3.44 times greater than the lot area (or 81,029 square feet in the case of this 23,555-square-foot parcel), while community facilities may have a floor area 6.5 times greater (or 153,107 square feet, just slightly more than the center will have).
From the perspective of New York University, the badly needed center followed the regulatory regime exactly.
"Within an R7-2 zone, this is considered appropriate scale," said John H. Beckman, the assistant vice president for public affairs, noting the presence of other large buildings on Washington Square. "The community facility is not a bonus within the Zoning Resolution. The community facility is a policy within the Zoning Resolution that contemplates the special needs and special contributions that certain institutions make to the life of the city."
"This is part of what we need and our students need to make this a functioning community," he said. "It's not as though we're newly arrived on the block. We've been here since 1831."
Shelly S. Friedman of Friedman & Gotbaum, a lawyer who has represented the building plans of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, 92nd Street Y, Spence School and Council on Foreign Relations, said institutions do not face easy choices.
"The overwhelming concern is adjacency," he said. "Whether you're a hospital, a school or a cultural institution, you'd rather not be in two buildings if you could be in one." If institutions concentrate on a site, he said, they are criticized as too bulky. If they disperse into other properties, they are accused of taking over the neighborhood.
Indeed, it was partly to prevent the acquisition by tax-exempt organizations of large swaths of land -- particularly the most revenue-rich property in commercial districts -- that city planners adopted the generous community-facility zoning in residential areas. If institutions are allowed to construct extra space on smaller sites, so this theory goes, more surrounding property stays on the tax rolls.
When building height limits were proposed during Mr. Rose's tenure, the Greater New York Hospital Association was among the most outspoken opponents.
"The floor-to-floor heights for health-care facilities are higher than in residential buildings," Susan C. Waltman, the senior vice president of the association, testified before the City Planning Commission in 2000. "This is so because they must house operating rooms, special equipment, auditoriums and patient care areas with extensive electrical, plumbing, H.V.A.C. and other special service needs." Height and bulk limits, she said, would be disastrous.
Ms. Burden questions height limits generally -- though she said the image of the Kimmel Center rising over Washington Square "really takes your breath away" -- and said she would concentrate for now on "the impact of both religious institutions and medical facilities on low-density neighborhoods and the huge numbers of people visiting these facilities that were never meant to be regional."
Neighbors in a semisuburban section of Queens have spotted license plates from New Jersey, Connecticut and Pennsylvania on cars parked outside their homes, said Tyler D. Cassell, the president of the North Flushing Civic Association.
In 1990, he said, there were community facilities on seven lots in an eight-block area between Bayside and 34th Avenues, 146th and Union Streets. Today, there are at least 45, including the Evergreen Presbyterian Church, Masjid Hazrat Abubakr, Pillars of Faith Tabernacle and St. Paul Chong Ha-Sang Roman Catholic Chapel and Center.
AMONG the most visible is the Union Plaza Care Center, a nursing home built six years ago in an R-6 district, where a community facility may have 4.8 times as much floor area as its lot area; double the allowable density of residential development.
Though it is strikingly out of scale with its immediate surroundings, the building is no larger than several other institutional structures in the neighborhood, said Charlton Rhee, the assistant administrator.
More important, Mr. Rhee said, is that almost all of its 280 residents come from Flushing. "We feel that we're really an integral part of the community," he said. "The community actually wanted this facility and we generated quite a few jobs."
Less obtrusive on the skyline, but of equal concern to neighbors, are medical offices and houses of worship in existing buildings. "It's become economically viable to buy a one-family house on a small lot on a quiet residential street and all of a sudden have a facility that can fit 500 people and not provide parking," Councilman Avella said.
"They're parking at fire hydrants, intersections, other people's driveways," he said. "This has become quite a nightmare."
Community facility regulations specify that churches provide one off-street parking space for every 10, 15 or 20 fixed seats, depending on the residential district. "If you have a pew bolted to the floor, you fall under normal zoning requirements," Mr. Avella said. "If you have folding chairs, you don't have to provide one parking space."
A more subtle impact of community-facility zoning is in rear yards. A community facility can cover the entire rear yard of a property, which would otherwise have to remain open, up to a height of 23 feet. Doctors' offices are among those that have taken advantage of this provision.
"By far more rear yards have been overrun by optometrists than by major hospitals or private schools," Mr. Friedman said.
There is a further question of what happens if the community facility moves out. A study of rear-yard encroachments prepared in 1997 for Civitas, a civic group, found at least two instances in which the additions had been converted to residential use.
George T. Votis, the chairman of Galt Industries, recently proposed a rear-yard addition at 41 East 62nd Street. It was to have had a multipurpose room for auditions, rehearsals and occasional performances by the Philharmonia Orchestra of London -- in other words, a community facility. (Mr. Votis is the treasurer of the Philharmonia Foundation, the orchestra's fund-raising arm in the United States.)
Mr. Friedman, who usually represents community facilities, argued the other side on behalf of MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, of which Ronald O. Perelman is chairman, owners of the adjoining building at 35 East 62nd Street. Speaking of Mr. Votis's proposal, Mr. Friedman said, "On that theory, I could allow the Boy Scouts to use my living room for a meeting once a month and on that basis build out my rear yard -- were I so fortunate as to have one."
The application has since been withdrawn, said Robert S. Davis, a lawyer for Mr. Votis, "because the foundation did not like being the subject of litigation."
This case illustrates how tricky it can be to administer rear-yard additions. Add to that the complications of balancing institutional and residential needs when it comes to buildings' size, then throw in the constitutional questions posed by any attempt to regulate houses of worship, and it is clear how sensitive the issue of limiting community facilities can be.
Nonetheless, Ms. Burden said that when she was appointed chairwoman of the City Planning Commission nine months ago, after 10 years as a member, "one of the first questions I heard was, 'Are you going to do something about community facilities that nobody has had the nerve to do?' "
"Why not bite off pieces of it?" she said. "That's my approach."

As a community facility, the building is 85 percent larger than a private residential development could be on the same site. (Librado Romero/The New York Times)(pg. 4)

HEADLINE: Organized Sports And Free-for-Alls 

BYLINE:  By ROBERT STRAUSS 

DATELINE: MANALAPAN 

 BODY:
JERRY COLLINCINI, director of parks and recreation in this sprawling central New Jersey town, said he saw the trouble coming at least a dozen years ago as clearly as a batter sees a hanging curve.
 "From the smallest youngsters playing, we were identifying abuse and violence at sporting events as a huge problem, even back then," said Mr. Collincini. "For the most part, unfortunately, it was parents. You just wonder who the games are for." 
 This summer, the State Legislature and Governor McGreevey agreed on what is being called a sports rage bill that speaks to the fragile state of youth sports. The bill, one of the first in the nation to address this subject, passed with overwhelming support in both the Assembly and the Senate. It provides support for youth sports organizations that adopt codes of conduct for players, spectators and coaches. 
It also upgrades the crime of excessive abuse -- either physical or verbal, at events where the participants are under 16 -- from simple assault to aggravated assault, and can result in jail terms of up to 18 months or fines up to $10,000. It also allows leagues to ban violent or abusive players, spectators or coaches and requires them to take anger-management courses before returning.
"I would volunteer myself to be an umpire and I would find people just being plain obnoxious around kids," said a main sponsor of the measure, Senator Steven Sweeney, a Democrat who represents parts of Gloucester, Salem and Cumberland Counties. "A friend of mine took his daughter to a high school football game and he had to take her home because fans were cursing and just being abusive. There was no way to kick people like this out before."
Then he added, "But I admit, it's a shame that it has come to this."
Sports among school-age children never used to be so organized. But more and more, choose-up baseball games and touch football in the streets have gone the way of family cars with fins. In their place, organized youth sports have proliferated. An estimated 38 million children in the United States are involved in organized sports -- 19 million of them in soccer alone -- twice the number as in the early 1980's. Leagues, clinics and tournaments for all ages abound.
Over the recent Columbus Day weekend, for instance, Cape May County held the 10th annual George Pratt Memorial Soccer Tournament, the largest one in the state, in which more than 5,000 players from ages 8 through 14 participated on 356 teams. Even then, organizers said 150 teams had to be turned away for lack of playing fields.
"Soccer may be the biggest these days, but there is no let-up in other sports," said Bill Foelsch, the executive director of the New Jersey Recreation and Park Association. "Even cheerleading is going beyond rooting for football, with its own competitions. Girls are looking for more things, too, like field hockey. Little Leagues have no trouble filling fields."
Yet there is a darker side to the growing reach of organized youth sports, and much of it, say administrators, psychologists and even parents themselves, comes from overzealous parents. The National Youth Sports Coaches Association keeps a log of incidents, and these are some of the incidents from New Jersey that show up on its Web site:
*A baseball coach in Rockaway was fined $1,000 and placed on a five-day work program for grabbing a 13-year-old player by the shirt collar, yanking him to his toes and yelling and cursing in his face.
*In Hazlet, a parent and an umpire exchanged blows during a grade-school baseball game.
*A father in Manalapan punched and verbally abused a youth baseball coach who he said had not given his son enough playing time.
*A soccer game between 8- and 9-year-old girls ended in a fight among parents over where a coach could stand.
*A brawl among parents at a midget football game in Somerdale sent players and cheerleaders scurrying from the field to avoid being swallowed up in the clash.
*In Clayton, the mayor and the council are suing each other over how the youth football league should be run.
"I just hear stories again and again about police having to be called to an under-9 soccer game," said Enrique L. Meana, the youth director of coaching in New Jersey. "The stress to be No. 1 in the league, to have the best of everything, I think it is going to kill youth sports if it doesn't stop."
Though few clashes are as egregious as the fight among two fathers at hockey game in Massachusetts that left one of them dead, the potential is there, and the incidents are far from isolated occurrences.
To try to lower the temperature, Mr. Meana has asked his coaches not to keep standings and, if possible, not even to keep score in leagues where the children are under 10. If more than two teams are invited to play, he wants to call the events festivals rather than tournaments and to avoid giving trophies unless every participant gets one.
"I wanted to put that age limit up to 13, because to concentrate so much on winning at such young ages is harmful," he said, "but, then, I knew parents would look at me like I was crazy. Fortunately, some people understand. I think here in New Jersey we are often ahead of the curve."
While the state is now stepping into the fray, it is not the first entity to take action. Last month, the Nassau County Legislature on Long Island adopted a measure under which parents must agree to teach their children "that honest effort is as important as winning" and that "officials are important parts of the game" whose honesty is not to be questioned. They must not, that is, curse, scream at or threaten the referee. Earlier, Suffolk County, also on Long Island, adopted a similar measure.
As for the current push in New Jersey, the Youth Sports Research Council at Rutgers University has played a pivotal role.
The council, based in the university's Exercise Science and Sport Studies Department, was established in the mid-1980's, according to its director, Gregg Heinzmann.
At that time, Mr. Heinzmann said, there was a concern that youth sports leagues might not be able to get insurance and that coaches might have had to bear any liability. So, the State Legislature passed a bill exempting coaches from personal liability if they took a safety course. Since then, more than 120,000 volunteer coaches in have taken the course at Rutgers, and six other states have modeled courses after it. "That is a good thing," Mr. Heinzmann said. "But now we have another perceived crisis."
Although he supports the proposed measure to rein in overzealous parents and participants, he is also afraid of overreactions.
"I have not seen any credible studies that have substantiated the oft-repeated claim that violence in youth sports is escalating or reached epidemic proportions," he said. "There are two issues. One is clearly more children participating in organized youth sports, which could account for an increase in the absolute number of incidents we hear about. And then there is the plausible explanation that this has captured attention because we have a convenient term for it. There is road rage and airport rage and now sports rage. It has more to do with the rapid pace of life and overcrowding. There is nothing inherent in sport that suggests that this is unique to this activity."
Still, along with Senator Sweeney's bill, there is stark evidence that the state is reacting swiftly to the issue of sports rage: the recreation department in New Brunswick is finishing a sports complex with three baseball fields that according to Mike Blackwell, the recreation director, are designed to be sports-rage proof.
"The key is to keep parents away from the dugouts and home plate, so there won't be any incidents with players, umpires and coaches," Mr. Blackwell said.
At the new complex, a thick, green mesh behind the dugouts and home plate areas obscures vision to limit confrontations. In addition, the stands are positioned farther than usual down the first- and third-base lines so that spectators are a little bit more removed from the main action. Two of the fields are six feet above grade with decorative block around the main part of the field.
"Sometimes when I videotape games, I end up videotaping what parents are doing on the sidelines," Mr. Blackwell said. "I've been coaching 22 years and it has definitely gotten worse in my mind. You try to explain to parents what proper conduct is. But now, maybe we have to do things like this."
Then there is Mike Schapiro, a leader of the huge Mid-New Jersey Youth Soccer Association, which has 75 leagues and 900 teams. He distributes a different kind of videotape, and he initiated a different type of drill after he became appalled at the lack of civility at games involving even the youngest players.
"There was no respect for officials," he said. "Parents were just getting carried away and forgetting that this is supposed to be for the enjoyment of kids. I just felt we had to do something."
Two years ago, he started SAGE, or Set A Good Example, with a seven-step code -- Rule 7, for instance, shows ways to hold down the score of a game so as not to discourage the losing team. Every T-shirt, every trophy, every flier connected to the association has the SAGE logo on it. In addition, during a mandatory meeting with parents, Mr. Schapiro shows a 16-minute video entitled "Kids Come First" that begins with parents jeering on the sidelines and ends with an overload of testimony from children and psychologists imploring parents to cool it.
"In a way, it's a shame we have to have this, but I think here in New Jersey, we are trying to stay ahead of the curve," said Mr. Schapiro, who has set up a foundation called Kindness Counts (www.kindness-counts.org) to distribute the video to other leagues. "We figure if parents start respecting officials and coaches, then kids will, too. It's an epidemic and, frankly, I don't know why otherwise anyone will want to be a referee."
Just why the situation exists at all is a complex question, says Dr. Joel Fish, who runs the Center for Sport Psychology in Philadelphia.
"I think part of it is reflective of the greater importance of sports in our society over the last 15 or 20 years," Dr. Fish said. "In the 1950's or 1960's, you'd ask a kid for three heroes and at least two of them would be politicians or doctors or scientists. Now, at least two of them are athletes. So that filters back to the parents."
In addition, he points out how the changes in society are reflected in the lives of children. He says, for instance, that parents seem to want more structure in their children's play, largely because they are afraid of sending them to a playground unattended. What's more, Dr. Fish says, the league play allows parents -- in this era of two working parents -- a scheduled time to spend with their children.
"But it also increases pressure on winning and losing," he said. "That is a problem. Parents don't seem to think the play time is productive if there isn't this sort of end. There is this ranking of teams and sons and daughters at a younger and younger age. The stakes get higher and higher."
Consider, also, the steep rise -- almost 50 percent -- in the number of youth sports activities, fed largely by an increase in the number of girls playing sports.
For instance in Sparta, a town of about 18,000, there are 50 basketball teams for girls from grade four through eight, say Ginny Hafeman-Mohr, the town's recreation director.
"I think we've been able to start the girls in a healthier way," Ms. Hafeman-Mohr said. "We don't keep standings and don't give trophies, but everyone gets a participation pin. We stress learning new skills and healthy lifestyle and socializing with peers, and it has seemed to work."
She wonders, however, where the girls go when the leagues stop. "There are two lighted basketball courts in the center of town," she said, "and I have to admit, I've never seen girls playing pick-up there."
Whatever advantages the structure provides, many recreation directors and psychologists nonetheless lament the preponderance of supervised leagues over free play, especially for younger children. And they point to studies showing that as many as two-thirds of the youths who play in leagues stop participating in any sports -- even just in school yards -- by high school.
"It's hard to say whether they burn out on playing in leagues or through parental pressure," Dr. Fish said. "You hear a lot of parents talking about scholarships even before the kids are in high school. I'll admit, I have three kids, and when you talk about saving $150,000, it's a mighty inviting thought."
If the pressure from parents in team sports is great, it may well be worse in individual sports. Phil Birnbaum, a consultant to the tennis committee for the New Jersey State Interscholastic Athletic Association, says as many as 20,000 boys and girls play high school tennis in the state.
"Parents may have sunk a lot of time and money in lessons," Mr. Birnbaum said, "and they don't want it wasted."
For his part, Mr. Birnbaum saw the pressure from parents beginning to build in the mid-1980's, when two parents started a brawl at the high school state championships at Princeton University, with one player having to stop play to climb over the fence and break it up.
"In football, at least you are on the sidelines far away from the game," he said. "In tennis, which is self-policing for the most part, parents come right up to the court, yelling, coaching, all sorts of things. I saw one parent tell his son to start a fight with an opponent."
To lower the tensions, at least at high school tennis matches, a rule now prohibits players and coaches from speaking in any language other than English on the court.
"We've had players curse in Russian at their opponents," he said. "Sometimes there is just too much pressure put on kids."
Despite the escalation in violence, no one is saying that leagues should be banned or that parental involvement is inherently a bad thing.
"More kids are getting out and staying healthier and learning life skills," Dr. Fish said. "There is a real connection between a healthy mind and a healthy body. Parents are right in wanting to get their kids out of the house to play. And it is good that this cuts across urban-suburban and socio-economic lines."
Indeed, cities and suburbs all over the state are clamoring for more playing fields. In New Brunswick, the new 15-acre Youth Sports Complex was reclaimed from a former brownfields site in the middle of the city. In Haddon Township, environmentalists and parents are embroiled in a dispute over how much of what used to be a forest tract should be taken for playing fields. More and more school bond issues have new gymnasiums in elementary schools.
"The challenge for us is to provide a balance," said Mr. Foelsch, the head of the state recreation association. "Sports can be such a good thing for kids in a complicated world. It's great that in Newark and in the rich suburbs there are parents now who want to volunteer their time to help. There is an explosion of activities for children."
He cautioned, "We just have to hope that the pressure from some parents doesn't ruin it all."

HEADLINE: HEALTH; 
Helping Those Without

BYLINE:  By KATE STONE LOMBARDI 

DATELINE: OSSINING 

 BODY:
JUST over three decades ago, local community groups here got together to offer children free camp physicals. Not only did they have far more boys and girls take advantage of the free checkups than anticipated, but they also discovered that many of the children examined hadn't had a physical in more than five years. Some had serious conditions that needed further treatment. 
 The event revealed the need for affordable local medical care and led to the start of Open Door, then a free clinic, whose mission embraced the concept that good medical care was a right rather than a privilege. The original practice, begun in 1972 and supported by volunteers, was run out of the basement of the First Baptist Church of Ossining. 
 This week, the Open Door Family Medical Center is celebrating its 30th anniversary. Physically, it bears little resemblance to the small clinic it once was. A full service, primary care practice with offices in Ossining, Sleepy Hollow and Rye Brook, the program serves more than 20,000 patients a year. 
The mission -- to serve the economically disadvantaged -- has remained the same. So has the need. Nearly half the patients seen at the three offices are without health insurance; those who must pay out of pocket are charged on a sliding scale. 
"We've always been committed to the most vulnerable residents in our community," said Lindsay Farrell, president and chief executive officer of Open Door Family Medical Center. "Thirty years ago that was an Afro-American population. The community has changed and we've had an influx of Latinos from Central and South America and the Caribbean as well. The organization has changed to respond to the changing demographics. But the economics of patients haven't changed. We're here for people who can't access the traditional medical system, the uninsured and the folks on Medicaid and Child Health Plus."
The number of Americans without health insurance rose to 41.2 million last year, an increase of 1.4 million, according to a report released by the Census Bureau last month. In New York, the percentage of those without health insurance is even higher than the national average. The Census Bureau reported that 14.6 percent of the population was without insurance in 2001; in New York almost 16 percent was without insurance. 
While there are no published figures of the number of uninsured in the county, Ms. Farrell estimated that in Westchester, the percentage is higher than the state average, given the densely populated communities in the southern parts of the county. Moreover, the figures do not include patients who are out of work and whose extended insurance is running out. Under the federal law known as Cobra, workers are allowed to continue policies for up to 18 months if they pay the full premiums. Nor do the figures include all undocumented immigrants.
Nearly 90 percent of Open Door's patients have incomes at or below the federal poverty level; 45 percent do not have health insurance. Traditionally, the patients who go to the medical center are poor. But Ms. Farrell said recently the medical group has been seeing more middle-class patients who have lost their insurance coverage. Cobra coverage for a family costs $600 a month, on average nearly two-thirds of the total average monthly unemployment check of $939, according to a recent analysis by Families USA, a consumer health care advocacy group in Washington. 
The medical center, with operating costs at roughly $10 million a year, is financed by federal, state and county grants, private foundations and donations and patient fees, including both Medicaid and other insurance payments, and from direct payments from patients.
A visit to Open Door belies the stereotypical image of a clinic that serves the poor. A staff of 13 doctors, 6 dentists, 4 nurse practitioners and 3 mental health counselors provide a range of services, including family practice, internal medicine, pediatrics, obstetrics and gynecology, H.I.V. testing and care, mental health services and dentistry. The medical center is run with an emphasis on preventative care. Babies squirm in their mother's arms in the pediatric waiting room, waiting for checkups and immunizations. Women come for their annual pap smears and mammograms. Patients are educated about managing chronic conditions like diabetes and asthma.
Open Door stresses a team approach to treating illness. For patients who lack benefits, and for whom taking a day off from work means taking a day without pay, it is difficult to schedule visits to multiple doctors. Patients who are being treated for diabetes, for instance, can have their blood sugar measured, see an ophthalmologist, a podiatrist and a nutritionist under one roof on the same day. Patients with H.I.V. may see one of three H.I.V. specialists with the practice, but their visit might also include appointments with the dentist, a psychologist and a nutritionist. The medical center tested more than 2,000 people last year for H.I.V., and treats one third of the AIDS patients in central Westchester.
The expansion of Open Door has not been without controversy. In the early 1990's, the medical center wanted to open an office in downtown Port Chester. Village officials rebuffed the bid for the proposed location, saying that they feared Open Door would eventually buy the building and take it off the tax rolls. But some supporters of the medical center said that the village's opposition was rooted in fear that the new clinic would attract more Hispanics to the area, a charge that village officials denied.
The medical group eventually opened an office in neighboring Rye Brook, and last spring, Open Door added dental services to that office. Dr. Janet Bozzone, director of Open Door's dental program, said she was overwhelmed by the prominence of dental disease she found in communities here. 
"We're really in the third world here in Ossining and Port Chester," Dr. Bozzone said. "I had a little boy in the other day -- he had eight teeth and eight cavities."
Ms. Farrell said that the medical center still hopes to move into a building in downtown Port Chester. The center is also working closely with the Port Chester school system to open a school-based health clinic in the Edison School. Port Chester has high rates of unimmunized children, she said, and many children who suffer from asthma and diabetes. 
"In Port Chester, as in any community where there is a significant population of low-income families, many parents are working on hourly wages and don't have benefits," Ms. Farrell said. "They don't have health insurance, they don't have personal days, they don't have vacations, and it's difficult for parents to give up a day of work to bring their children to the doctor. Imagine the convenience for working parents of having a nurse-practitioner in the school, who can examine the child and send the prescription home in the backpack."

GRAPHIC: Photos: Dr. Christopher Wang examines Mary Ann Parsons at the Open Door Family Medical Center in Ossining. The reception area and the outside of the center, which has been operating for 30 years. (Photographs by Richard L. Harbus for The New York Times)
