HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey; 
New University Plan Could Help Biotech Corridor

BYLINE:  By ANTOINETTE MARTIN

 BODY:
GOV. JAMES McGREEVEY'S proposal to consolidate Rutgers University, the University of Medicine and Dentistry and the New Jersey Institute of Technology into one system is apparently discomfiting to many in the academic world -- but many commercial real estate market specialists say they find the idea compelling. 
 The restructuring would raise the efficiency and prestige of the state's higher-education system and attract more research money, in the view of brokers. They say New Jersey's biotechnology "research corridor" would become markedly hotter property as a result. 
 The corridor is loosely defined as a string of research and development centers, biotechnology companies and labs clustered around academic institutions, stretching from Newark to Princeton.
"The corridor exists; it's important to the state economy," said Cushman & Wakefield's managing director for New Jersey, Christopher Kinum, "but is not being fully realized. There could be a tremendous confluence of resources between our educational institutions and biotech companies, generating nothing but good -- jobs, a revived economy, and more research that can provide cures for major diseases afflicting the world."
Mr. Kinum said the proposed restructuring of the university system is perfectly designed to spur development of more public or private research "compounds," or technical parks, like those that have proliferated near universities in California and Massachusetts.
The state now has such an enclave at the Technology Centre of New Jersey in New Brunswick -- near both Rutgers, the big public university, and the private Princeton University -- which was developed four years ago under the auspices of the state Economic Development Authority. It offers facilities ranging from tiny incubator spaces for start-ups to medium-sized offices and labs. 
Cushman is trying to position itself as a force behind the proliferation of technical parks here. The real estate firm recently established what it calls the Technology Enterprise Group to coordinate efforts to offer services for government entities, businesses and academic research organizations that want to develop research and development facilities, high-tech operations, incubator labs and the like. A former New Jersey secretary of commerce, Gualberto Medina, recently joined Cushman's East Rutherford office as the program's director.
"We are passing into a revolutionary period in the world economy," Mr. Medina said earlier this month. "This economy is now being driven by knowledge-based industries -- 'info tech' and life sciences. In New Jersey, which is one of the nation's foremost high-tech centers, it is also being driven by the integrating of these technologies."
Mr. Medina said more than 355,000 people, almost 10 percent of the state's work force, are employed in life sciences -- pharmaceutical and biotech companies -- or in the electronic technology field.
"The high-tech sector is going to determine the success of New Jersey's economy in the future," Mr. Medina said unequivocally. The proposed reorganization of higher education indicates that the McGreevey administration recognizes this, he added.
New Jersey already has the largest concentration of pharmaceutical company headquarters. Recently, real estate brokers have begun focusing on attracting biopharmaceutical companies, which are often small start-up operations working on cutting-edge medical research, or new and growing entities as the result of a merger.
THIS kind of enterprise may need assistance not only in locating space near academic resources but also in working with government agencies and programs intended to promote growth and in filling fluctuating space needs, brokers said.
For example, Grubb & Ellis is handling the real estate needs of MedPointe Inc., which last year acquired Carter-Wallace Inc., another nationally known pharmaceutical company. New, larger headquarters were quickly leased for MedPointe in Somerset, and last summer a 20,000-square-foot laboratory and research and development space was leased near Princeton, at Cedar Brook Corporate Center in Cranbury Township in Middlesex County.
The Cranbury building is "flex space," intended for flexible use and zoned for research and development, said Doug Petrozzini, the Grubb senior vice president who brokered the lease. The site received $4 million in improvements four years ago, when another business had moved in, and was easily adapted to suit MedPointe. "With more than a million square feet of space remaining at Cedar Brook," Mr. Petrozzini said, "the location also offers almost unlimited future expansion opportunity."
In Bergen County, by contrast, there is something of a trade-off for companies that are starting up or expanding, according to Insignia/ESG, which handles a great deal of business there: great location but older buildings. Currently, there are 107 life sciences companies between Paramus and Montvale and between Teterboro and the George Washington Bridge, according to Insignia/ESG's count. These include such well-established companies as Daiichi Pharmaceutical, Alteon, Quest Diagnostics, Bioreferences Laboratories, Alpharma, Pharmachem and Solgar Vitamin and Herb.
"Bergen County offers easy access to New York City and also Hackensack Medical Center and Newark's University Hospital research facilities," pointed out Jeffrey Babikian, Insignia/ESG's senior managing director in New Jersey. "This allows life science companies greater ease in professional recruitment, as well as the increased opportunity to foster collaboration between scientists."
Insignia/ESG recently brokered a lease for Memory Pharmaceuticals, which conducts research into learning and memory disorders. The company explicitly wanted access to teaching hospitals and a highly educated labor pool, and it leased 30,000 square feet in a 76,000-square-foot building in Montvale that can accommodate its plans to grow.
When a company is looking for start-up space or wants to expand, the stock of previously built laboratories might not seem as appealing as flex space that can be built out to suit it, Mr. Babikian said. On the other hand, he said, prebuilt space can provide a cheaper, faster alternative.
Growth often occurs in quick bursts for biotech companies, he and other market experts noted, making planning ahead a challenge.
Three years ago, Cushman secured a 12,000-square-foot space for Genta Inc., a new biopharmaceutical company specializing in the development of anticancer therapies. Genta expanded its lease twice at Connell Corporate Center in Berkeley Heights, and today the firm occupies 93,000 square feet.
Jeff Heller, the Cushman broker who heads a team managing Genta's space requirements, said he was working with several other companies at the same level of maturity as Genta, and also with several start-ups. Beyond the basics in real estate services, Mr. Heller said, Cushman provides such companies with assistance in interviewing architects, engineers and interior design firms. 
For Genta, Mr. Heller said he had also arranged to introduce the company's principals to Henry Kurz, an account manager with the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission. "Through this introduction, we applied for and were approved for a Business Employment Incentive Program grant that will have significant economic benefits," said Gregg Siefert of Genta.
Mr. Kinum of Cushman described Genta as an incubator company that has grown into "a real company" and said New Jersey needs "many more Gentas."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Connell Corporate Center in Berkeley Heights, where Genta Inc., a fledgling company, has 93,000 square feet. (Timothy Ivy for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: In Land of the Jobless, The Extreme Approach 

BYLINE:  By PATRICIA R. OLSEN 

 BODY:
YOU revamped your resume months ago, networked until you can't stand to look at a telephone and even hired a job coach. You still can't find a job. You're ready to wear a sandwich board to advertise yourself, or send a gimmick along with your resume. Maybe even work for no pay.
 You have company. In September, John Sawicki, 30, who has an M.B.A. and five years' experience as a product manager with Deutsche Bank in Manhattan, signed on with Novantech Solutions, a start-up in Palisades, N.Y., to work free. "Normally someone my age, with my qualifications, would have to be crazy to do this," he said. 
 With unemployment claims steady and companies still delaying hiring because of lower profits and the threat of war with Iraq, desperate times do not just call for desperate measures for job seekers like Mr. Sawicki. They shout for last resorts.
So when Mr. Sawicki, who lives in Brooklyn, learned that Novantech had openings -- albeit not the paying kind -- he did not hesitate. He had been attending graduate school part time while working at Deutsche Bank, but decided to finish his degree full time and try to find a more rewarding position in the technology field. Armed with an M.B.A. in finance and information systems, Mr. Sawicki had been job hunting since his graduation from Fordham University in August 2001.
Novantech's offer of a future salary when the company became profitable seemed attractive. Mr. Sawicki will be learning a new field and gaining marketable skills, and he could continue job hunting in case the company did not turn a profit. "I'd have to be crazy not to take their offer," he said.
Mr. Sawicki was interviewed on a park bench; the company does not have offices yet. But that is fine with him, as long as he can learn. He does a little bit of everything for the company -- marketing, recruiting, updating the Web site, for now, and eventually he hopes to manage projects. He works from his home three days a week while continuing to look for a paid position.
Sacrificing a salary might seem a little extreme, but at least it makes a good impression on a potential employer. Some job hunters, straining to stand out from the crowd, make the mistake of resorting to gimmicks that are more likely to rub hiring managers the wrong way. Christopher Jones, vice president for content development at HotJobs.com, tells the story of an applicant who sent a company a box of chocolates with his resume. Another made a stab at humor, asking a food company in his cover letter whether it was "hungry for a good worker." Yet another put a bag of sand and a gold coin in his packet, promoting himself as "buried treasure."
"That's taking a metaphor a bit too far in the job hunt," Mr. Jones said.
Well, that may not always be true. In creative fields like advertising or television, pushing the envelope is accepted, even admired. Robert Wilson, now a resident of Vermont, recalls his early days of job hunting, when he parlayed a hyped resume, a messenger-delivered follow-up letter and a half-dozen phone calls to the producer of "NBC Nightly News" into an audition, even though he had no on-camera experience.
"I heard that their consumer reporter was leaving, so I wrote and told them what that person had been doing wrong and what I'd do to improve the segment," Mr. Wilson recalled. Alas, he did not get the job.
Stuart Simons is hoping his artistic talent will give him a leg up in his job search. He has his own commercial-photography, illustration and digital-imaging company and went back to school for an M.B.A. Now he wants to sit on the other side of the creative desk. In September, he responded to an ad for a marketing manager with Kiehl's, a Manhattan cosmetics company.
Mr. Simons, a resident of Pound Ridge, N.Y., designed a label with a message styled after an advertisement on one of the company's shampoos and applied it to one of their shampoo bottles. Then he designed a custom box for the bottle and used his resume as packing material. On tissue paper covering the box, he wrote yet another message, about thinking inside and outside the box.
"The whole thing was pretty impressive," he said, although he is still waiting to hear.
The proliferation of such gimmickry comes as no surprise to Gary Chaison, professor of industrial relations in the graduate school of management at Clark University in Worcester, Mass.
"In a job market with few layoffs, people have a sense that there's something they can do to find a job," Mr. Chaison said. "But now, almost everyone at least knows someone who's been laid off, so job seekers feel they have to take extreme measures to be noticed. It's especially sad for people who are highly specialized and aren't able to relocate."
Sad or not, extreme measures can work if they are done right. Allison Hemming is president of the Hired Guns, a Manhattan temporary employment agency, and also the author of a book -- "Work It!"-- about job hunting, due out in February from Simon & Schuster. She said unusual tactics can "build buzz and get your name out there."
But she warns that the technique can backfire. An employer like an ad agency might reward confidence and risk taking, she said, but a more conservative company might find it off-putting or just plain weird.
Mr. Sawicki recently heard from a recruiter. "But the job is with a company that just announced more layoffs," he said. "So I'm hoping for the best and assuming the worst."

HEADLINE: AROUND THE BLOCK; 
Decked Out in Classy Castoffs

BYLINE:  By CHERYL JENSEN

 BODY:
 TESTED: 2003 Land Rover Discovery

WHAT IS IT? Midsize sport utility

HOW MUCH? $34,995 base price (S model); $41,495 as tested (HSE, including $500 for cold-climate package that includes heated front seats).

WHAT MOVES IT? 4.6-liter V-8; four-speed automatic; permanent four-wheel drive; two-speed transfer case.

HOW THIRSTY? Rated at 12 m.p.g. in town, 16 on the highway.

FOUR-WHEEL-DRIVE ALTERNATIVES: Jeep Grand Cherokee Limited V-8, $34,550; Mitsubishi Montero Limited, $37,212; Mercedes-Benz ML500 ($46,015); Lexus GX 470 (estimated $45,000).
HAND-ME-DOWNS can be worthwhile, especially when they come from the Range Rover. For 2003, the Land Rover Discovery inherited a more powerful, less noisy engine and some cosmetic changes that tie the Disco closer to its patrician sibling.
To appeal to Americans' thirst for power, the new Discovery comes with the 4.6-liter V-8 from the previous-generation Range Rover. (The 2003 Range Rover, which starts at $71,865, upgrades to a BMW engine.)
The Discovery's new engine is rated at 217 horsepower, a 15 percent increase from last year's model. Torque is up 20 percent, to 300 pounds-feet. It took the old Disco 11 seconds to go a stop to 60 m.p.h., but the new one pares that to 9.5 seconds, Land Rover says, while losing only 1 m.p.g. in average fuel economy.
The V-8 responds pretty well, a reasonable accomplishment considering its age. The engine's basic design goes back 40 years -- the motor was once used in Buicks, before G.M. sold the tooling -- although it has been regularly updated.
But the engine is still pulling a heavyweight. With all available equipment, including a third row of seats, the Discovery weighs 4,900 pounds. That means some owners may yearn for still more power, particularly if they study the horsepower and torque figures of competitive vehicles that have more sophisticated engines of more recent design.
For an extra $1,000, customers can add forward-facing third-row seats that turn the Discovery into a seven-seater, with head restraints and three-point safety belts for everyone.
For 1999, a new suspension improved the Discovery's ride on pavement. The suspension has been tweaked again.
The front end has been restyled to give the Discovery a closer resemblance to the Range Rover. The most notable change is to the headlights. Instead of the previous rectangular design, the Discovery borrows circular "twin pocket" halogen headlights (a small lamp overlaps a larger one) from the new Range Rover.
Inside, the Discovery hasn't lost its distinctive upper-crust feel. But because Land Rover knows customers trading in sedans for sport utilities don't want noisy, truckish interiors, it focused on muffling engine and road noise as well as reducing those annoying squeaks and rattles -- British tradition be damned.
It is too soon to tell whether these changes will help the 2003 Discovery improve its standings in the quality rankings. Previous models scored well below average for both the industry and the luxury S.U.V. segment, in J. D. Power's initial quality and vehicle dependability studies. In an attempt to foster more good will, Land Rover gives Discovery owners free scheduled maintenance six times during the four-year (or 50,000-mile) limited warranty.
The result of this makeover is a more refined, more competitive, yet still distinctive sport utility. This is just what Land Rover needs because, as usually happens with models late in their life cycles, interest is waning. Sales fell 3.6 percent in 2001 and another 12 percent through September of this year. CHERYL JENSEN

HEADLINE: Personal Business; 
The Search for Sure Footing in a Shaky Work World

BYLINE:  By MAGGIE JACKSON

 BODY:
GREG DRISCOLL took little for granted before accepting the job of president and chief executive of Enerwise Global Technologies, an energy technology company. He interviewed the company's board members and its entire executive team and even spoke with middle managers. He then prodded people outside the company to get a sense of Enerwise's reputation in the industry.
 "In companies like this, everyone has an aggressive view of how fast it's going to grow, so you have to take that with a grain of salt," Mr. Driscoll said. "Today, things aren't always as they seem." 
 Satisfied with the answers he received, he took charge of the company, based in Kennett Square, Pa., last winter. The company began operating 18 months ago as a spinoff of Conectiv Inc. of Wilmington, Del. 
Job seekers and employees on different rungs of the corporate ladder are doing all they can to protect themselves from problems, economic or sometimes ethical, that have been dragging down many companies. Some executives, even those well below the level of chief executive, are trying to negotiate specific contracts and severance packages, or inquiring about liability protection. Others are working to improve their resumes and reputations in their companies, by taking courses, for example, or by volunteering for extra work assignments. 
The trends appear widespread, if too new to quantify, according to interviews with recruiters, outplacement experts, employment lawyers and corporate executives.
"It's pretty apparent that in today's marketplace, there's a flight to quality and safety," said Dale E. Jones, a managing partner at Heidrick & Struggles, the executive search firm based in Chicago. "People want to know where they're going, and how they can minimize the risk."
Employees at all levels have reason to feel vulnerable. As the economy has weakened, many businesses have made large-scale job cuts. Accounting scandals, like those at Enron and WorldCom, have led to thousands of additional layoffs.
As a result, trust in business is eroding. Only 45 percent of workers have confidence in their senior management, down from 50 percent two years ago, according to a nationwide survey, involving 12,750 employees from all major industries, that was conducted last winter by Watson Wyatt Worldwide, the consulting firm. 
In this gloomy business climate, employees are aiming to bolster their career prospects. With survival as the goal, many are trying to make sure they are seen as valuable players in their organizations.
"It causes you to think about your vulnerabilities and what you can do to shore them up," said Tom Ault, a senior vice president at Avnet Inc., an electronics components distributor in Phoenix that has cut its staff by 30 percent in the last two years because of the weak economy and a depressed semiconductor market. "If you stand around wringing your hands about circumstances, you're not going to get anywhere." 
As his jobs have changed and his staff has shrunk to 15 from 100 in the last two years, Mr. Ault has sought out a mentor, taken courses in leadership and strategic planning, spent more time with his boss to learn her expectations and volunteered for assignments beyond his job. His efforts have produced positive feedback from his boss and his customers. "I'm still here," he said. 
At some companies, employees are asking for written performance reviews or updates of past reviews so their accomplishments are noted in writing, said Jeffrey E. Christian, an executive recruiter and the author of "The Headhunter's Edge" (Random House). Mr. Christian advises workers to ask that such report cards include examples of personal ethics. "You can demonstrate that no matter what the company is doing, you're using ingenuity to run your business and be an employee in a respectable manner," he said. 
Getting protection in writing is important for many executives and managers these days, especially at distressed companies. Peter Oppermann, a senior consultant at the New York office of Mercer Human Resource Consulting, has been helping several troubled companies enhance executive severance packages. "We're asked, 'What can we do to give people a better sense of comfort?' " Mr. Oppermann said. "It's not industry-specific. It's not region-specific. It's a trend you see when things are not going well."
MORE executives, even at healthy companies, are seeking outside legal advice and asking about their rights to indemnification -- coverage of legal defense costs offered to corporate officers and directors.
In negotiating his recent offer to become executive vice president for sales and marketing at Formity Systems Inc., a software developer in Murray Hill, N.J., Simon Krieger hired a lawyer and asked for, and received, liability coverage as an officer of the company. "I hadn't asked about liability in the past, because I didn't think it was that important," Mr. Krieger said. "It didn't seem to be much of an issue before."
Executives and job candidates for senior positions are also requesting employment contracts. While the use of such contracts has been rising in recent years, they have often been reserved for top corporate officers, especially in the telecommunications, computer data and health care industries. "What is unusual today is that individuals much lower in the organization are asking for them to protect their income," said Romayne Berry, principal and chief operating officer of Tower Consultants, an executive search firm in Stuart, Fla.
Below the top tier, though, executives do not have the leverage they had a few years ago, when jobs were plentiful. Many requests for contracts, guaranteed bonuses and written criteria for success aren't being met. "Companies have less tolerance to negotiate those points," said Michael S. Sirkin, a partner at the Proskauer Rose law firm and a specialist in benefits and compensation law in New York. "They feel there are alternatives." 
Mr. Driscoll of Enerwise says that more job candidates are asking for employment contracts, even at middle-management levels, but that the company is not granting such requests, except to a few top executives. "There's more interest in downside protections," he said.
Mr. Driscoll's own contract with the company includes severance provisions and a guaranteed bonus.
Anxious employees and executives are going beyond asking for written protection. Some are also trying to keep their options open. While only 12 percent of workers say they are looking for another job or plan to leave their employers, an additional 44 percent are open to a move, according to a 2001 survey of 5,700 employees and managers by Towers Perrin, the human resources consulting firm. 
Tom O'Riordan isn't exactly looking for another position, but he keeps a toehold in the job market. As chief operating officer of Fila USA Inc. in Sparks, Md., he has spent four years helping turn around the American division of the company, the Italian sportswear maker. But the parent is now for sale, a situation that has prompted Mr. O'Riordan to update his resume, hear out recruiters and even go on a few interviews.
"I'm open and more diligent about pursuing some things, even though ultimately I'd prefer to make this work," he said. "At some point, I have to look out for me."
For many employees, avoiding risk is a priority. Even if they cannot get as many written protections as they would like, they are trying to protect themselves by bolstering their employability, asking tough questions and taking a harder look at employers, prospective and current.
Simon Choy, who became director of compensation and benefits worldwide for Tupperware last year, said he was scared off from a competing offer from a technology company when executives brought up severance before he asked. His extensive research on Tupperware, which included talks with sales agents and reading a history of the company, convinced him that Tupperware, based in Orlando, Fla., would give him the stability he craved. 
"I don't want to get into a short-term focus," said Mr. Choy, also director of human resources for Asia and the Pacific. "The bottom line is stability: a company that's solid, a company that's been around a while."

HEADLINE: Business; 
A Time When Greed Wasn't Good

BYLINE:  By WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

 BODY:
 DAVID CALLAHAN, the author of "Kindred Spirits," argues that the values of today's business leaders are very different than those of the Harvard Business School class of 1949 -- many of them World War II veterans. Here are excerpts from an interview. WILLIAM J. HOLSTEIN

Q. What do you mean when you write that this generation of business leaders was shaped by idealism?

A. These guys grew up in a very different America. They were shaped by the Great Depression and by their experiences in World War II. They came out of that with very modest expectations compared to business leaders of today. Many of them just wanted to be able to participate in the economy. They wanted good jobs. They wanted economic security. They wanted to build good companies. Very few of them thought they would become business titans. There was far less wealth in American society then than there is now. They believed that if they paid their dues, worked hard, developed good products, were creative and took risks, they would be rewarded.

Q. Why did these business leaders feel stifled by the first companies they joined after graduating?

A. The corporate culture of the 1950's was very conformist. These guys wanted to take risks and make things happen. They either went to companies where that was encouraged or went out on their own. Someone like Tom Murphy who was at Lever Brothers got involved in a very risky TV company because he wanted to make something happen. Mr. Murphy rose to the top of Capital Cities/ABC. Jim Burke went to Johnson & Johnson but only on his own terms -- that he could cut through some of the red tape. Peter McColough went to Haloid later renamed Xerox which was extremely risky. A couple of them became entrepreneurs.

Q. Why was there not more entrepreneurship as we know it today?

A. Entrepreneurialism was not really a big part of the American business world at that time. There wasn't a lot of venture capital. Remembering the Depression, people didn't feel comfortable taking risk. It wasn't feasible and it wasn't encouraged.

Q. So the class of '49 believed in what you call "patient wealth?"

A. Yes, they came from a time when nobody got rich quickly. The 1930's, 40's, 50's were the period of their youth and early adulthood and it wasn't a time when great fortunes were being made overnight. No one had that in their mentality -- go out and go public and make $1 billion.

Q. Did Harvard Business School really shape their values?

A. I didn't get a sense that Harvard was a place where they learned values. They learned how to run a business and deal with a variety of situations from the case studies. But their values came from growing up in the Depression and fighting in the war. They had low expectations.

Q. Fast-forward to today, when we have members of the baby boom generation and Gen X'ers running many companies. Are these younger business leaders somehow less moral than their elders?

A. I think business leaders of today grew up in an America that had enormous amounts of wealth. Many of them brought into the business world a profound sense of entitlement. They should get things sooner rather than later. Our society has become much more materialistic. Conspicuous consumption that would have been absolutely embarrassing for the 49ers is absolutely the norm today. Not only do people think they should make fortunes quickly, but there are also fewer restrictions on spending in a very conspicuous way. All this produces greed.

Q. Are you saying that baby boomers and Gen X'ers are greedy?

A. I'm hesitant to blame a particular generation. The values of extreme laissez faire ideology have deeply permeated our society. We've had 20 years of deregulation. We've been told that government is the problem, not the solution. Greed has been seen as O.K., even good. Conspicuous consumption isn't frowned upon. In this environment, it's not surprising that you get a corporate leadership class that is greedier than any group since the Gilded Age, the era of the robber barons in the late 1800's.

Q. How did the 49ers manage their wealth differently?

A. Most of the 49ers didn't do much with their money. They weren't buying houses in the Hamptons or building estates. Even though they made a lot of money for their time, their fortunes were much smaller than the fortunes a run-of-the-mill C.E.O. can make today. The reason is that corporate compensation and C.E.O. pay have gone through the roof. The 49ers would be embarrassed to take home the kind of pay packages that are commonplace today. They would have preferred to put that money back into the company and do something productive with it.

Q. Will there be a real backlash against recent corporate abuses?

A. Our attitudes toward corporate greed change in a cyclical way. The pendulum swings. After the Gilded Age, there was a real era of reform. The income tax was enacted. Other reforms were aimed at controlling corporate power. After the excesses of the 1920's, there also was a backlash. I think America is now headed for a new era of corporate reform. Greed is no longer "in."

GRAPHIC: Photo: David Callahan says executives from the class of '49 would be embarrassed by today's pay plans.

HEADLINE: WEDDINGS/CELEBRATIONS: VOWS; 
Elizabeth Ngonzi and John Nandigobe

BYLINE:  By RICHARD LEZIN JONES 

 BODY:
THEIRS was a romance born in boom times. She was a business consultant, he a computer technology specialist. And when John Henry Nandigobe and Elizabeth Natasha Ngonzi began dating in 1999, the promise of their life together seemed as limitless as the prosperity all around them.
 Then came the bust. In the uncertain economic climate after Sept. 11, Ms. Ngonzi chose a career change. And then Mr. Nandigobe lost a job that had seemed secure only a few months before. 
 Forget having a wedding right now, friends said. Be prudent, their families told them. "Everyone said, 'You should wait,' " Ms. Ngonzi said. "We said it didn't make sense for us to put it off just because of this."
Ms. Ngonzi, who was born in Uganda, and Mr. Nandigobe, who was born in Wales to Ugandan parents, became acquainted in 1998, when one of her uncles introduced them at a gathering at his home in Plainfield, N.J. Then, after a chance meeting nine months later, they arranged to have lunch. "We went out for drinks, and it turned into a seven-hour date," Ms. Ngonzi recalled.
Ms. Ngonzi, 32, is a graduate of Cornell, Syracuse and the Culinary Institute of America. She loves preparing and sampling cuisines. She came to the United States at 4, a daughter of Hilda Rwabazaire Paqui, a deputy director in New York for the United Nations Development Program, and Dr. John Ruganda, an English professor at the University of the North in South Africa. Among friends she is known for her easy smile and for being painstaking about the tiniest details and for working doggedly to see them to fruition. 
"I'm a bit of a control freak," she acknowledged, sheepishly.
"A bit?" Mr. Nandigobe, 42, chimed in. He is a broad-shouldered, soft-spoken six-footer who studied at the Royal Institute of Engineering in Stockholm before coming to New York and taking a job at FXall, the online foreign-exchange firm.
When Ms. Ngonzi left her Manhattan consulting job with Arthur Andersen last year to fulfill her dream of opening a catering business in North Brunswick, N.J., Mr. Nandigobe, who is divorced, supported her decision. The business is called Amazing Taste! Self-employment proved a financial struggle. Still, when Mr. Nandigobe lost his job at FXall a few months later in a downsizing, they refused to see the situation as bleak. No, it meant that Ms. Ngonzi had gained a new, eager and very familiar employee. "All of this has just made us stronger," she said. 
And for their wedding, help arrived from far and wide. "We just prayed, and the blessings came," she said. Envelopes began arriving from Uganda bearing donations large and small -- equal parts a product of the African dowry tradition and a way of repaying Mr. Nandigobe, who had given aid to other Ugandans.
Ms. Ngonzi also found discounts on the Web on everything from D.J.'s to hydrangeas. And true to her nature, she produced a spreadsheet, outlining events in five-minute intervals.
Was there anything that she dreamed of that her budget simply would not allow? "Uh, a horse-drawn carriage?" she said.
The Rev. William D. Watley, who is the chief executive of the New Jersey Commerce and Economic Growth Commission, led the ceremony on Oct. 19 at St. James A.M.E. Church in Newark, where guests arrived in suits or traditional African garb like the lavender shuka worn by the bride's mother. Later, for a reception at the Newark Museum, guests were treated to a multicultural menu designed by the bride. It included pad Thai, Jamaican curried goat and fior di latte. 
And Ms. Ngonzi need not have yearned for that horse-drawn carriage. The black Mercedes-Benz she chose seemed to suit her just fine. So much so, in fact, that Ms. Ngonzi said that she nearly skipped her own reception afterward. "We felt like telling the driver, 'Just take us home.' You know, let's just go pick up some Haagen-Dazs and be together."

GRAPHIC: Photos: NEWARK, OCT. 19 -- After a ceremony at St. James A.M.E. Church, there was a reception at the Newark Museum, all planned with precision by the bride. (Photographs by Jill C. Becker for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: INVESTING WITH -- Thomas F. Marsico; 
Marsico Growth Fund

BYLINE:  By CAROLE GOULD

 BODY:
THOMAS F. MARSICO calls managing money a "three-dimensional chess game." 
 He says he juggles three variables to pick stocks for the $670 million Marsico Growth fund: a company's competitive position, its sensitivity to regulatory or geopolitical risks and the macroeconomic environment in which it operates. 
 Missing from that list is rapid growth -- a characteristic he sought when he picked stocks as a fund manager at Janus Capital in Denver in the 1990's. He left that firm in 1997 to start his own company, but until the technology meltdown in 2000, he stuck to his high-octane style of picking stocks. Today, however, he says he avoids most technology companies, which account for less than 7 percent of the fund's assets, versus 20 percent in the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. 
"We believe that all technology companies have the risk of disruptive new technology," eroding market share, he said from his office in downtown Denver, with a view of the Rocky Mountains. 
Now he prefers slower, steady growers. 
"We're looking at companies that can provide unit growth, because they'll be more valuable than companies that need to increase prices to make money," he said.
That focus has helped minimize the fund's losses during the recent tough times for big stocks. The portfolio lost 7.2 percent a year, on average, for the three years through Thursday. That places it in the top 9 percent of all funds that buy large growth stocks, which lost 15 percent a year, on average, according to Morningstar Inc. The S.& P. 500 lost 11 percent during that time.
The fund the lost 4.4 percent in the last 12 months, versus losses of 20.8 percent for its group and 17.4 percent for the index.
Mr. Marsico, 47, is the chief executive of Marsico Capital Management, the fund's adviser; its sale to Bank of America was completed in January 2001. He also manages the $1.3 billion Marsico Focus fund.
He uses no computer screens or Wall Street research to choose the 30 to 50 stocks in the Growth fund from about 400 primarily American companies with market capitalizations of at least $7 billion.
Over all, he aims to beat returns of the S.& P. 500 by three to five percentage points by selecting companies that provide consistent returns from easy-to-understand businesses.
The earnings growth rate of the portfolio companies is still relatively high, if not turbocharged. It was 21 percent a year in the last five years, compared with 9.3 percent for the index.
In analyzing companies' financial statements, Mr. Marsico looks closely at the appended footnotes. Generally, the presence of many footnotes means red flags, he said.
He also examines a company's ratio of debt to total capitalization. He prefers a ratio of less than 20 percent for the manufacturing and marketing sectors but allows more for financial services companies.
Mr. Marsico began buying shares of Porsche, the German automaker, in November 2001, paying 364 euros a share, on average. The stock, which trades on the Frankfurt exchange, is now at 488.5 euros.
He called Porsche "a great unit growth story, with the highest operating margins in the industry and little competition in the luxury performance car market." He expects earnings growth to average 15 percent, annualized, over the next five years.
 HE also likes the Fannie Mae, the biggest buyer of mortgages. He has been buying shares since August, paying $70.26, on average; they now trade at $68.50. Fannie Mae is benefiting from the strong housing market, Mr. Marsico said.
"Housing affordability is at an all-time high, given the current levels of employment and a low level of interest rates," he added. He projects annual earnings growth to average 13 percent over the next five years.
Consolidation has strengthened the market position of Tenet Healthcare, said Mr. Marsico, who began buying its shares in the spring of 2001. Tenet, which owns and manages hospitals, has growing numbers of patients in three medical areas -- cardiovascular, neurological and orthopedic -- that require high levels of care, he added. 
"When people are in hospitals for problems that require a lot of treatment," he said, "you can spread the fixed costs of the hospital visits over a higher revenue base."
He expects earnings growth to average 15 to 18 percent over three to five years. 
He paid an average of $30.49 for the shares, adjusted for splits. They now trade at $49.31.

HEADLINE: MIDSTREAM; 
Long After the Windfall, Back to Some Basics

BYLINE:  By JAMES SCHEMBARI; James Schembari is an editor at The Times. His column on the prime earning, spending and striving years appears the fourth Sunday of each month. E-mail: jimschem@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
NOW that the money is gone, I have at least answered one question: How did it feel to be rich?
 It felt soothing. Financial pressures melted away, and my lifelong habit of squeezing a buck seemed to be over, much to the joy of my spendthrift family. 
 But the feeling was fleeting. The money that my wife, Christine, inherited last year didn't last long enough for me to wallow. It has all been "invested," our cash flow stinks and I'm back to begging the kids to turn off a light now and then. Do they think we bought stock in the power company or something? We didn't. 
A few months ago, when I first wrote about the inheritance that my wife received from her grandfather's estate, money the size of an average Wall Street bonus, I pointed out that our generation is expected to inherit at least $11 trillion in assets in the next 20 years. I spoke to Bibi Gaston, 43, a landscape architect from Lake Worth, Fla., who was inheriting about $100,000, and an artist, also from Florida, who asked that her name not be used. She was getting about $250,000.
Then I went to several advisers, asking them what all of us should do with our sudden wealth. Putting the money in the stock market -- for example, through the Section 529 education plans run by the states -- was the main answer.
Good advice at the time, but Christine and I didn't take it. Although we wrestled with what to do with the money, we put it temporarily in a money market account, earning about 2.5 percent interest. Ms. Gaston did the same thing. The 529 plans sounded good to me, especially one for our youngest child, Joseph, 7, who is the only of our four children not to have a mutual fund in his name. (We had opened funds for the others to help pay for college and never got around to Joe once he arrived in 1994. I have always felt guilty about that.)
But Christine had other ideas. She had long wanted to renovate our attic, turning it into two bedrooms to get our three sons out of the one room they shared. We decided to do that, which left about half the money. Christine then gave 10 percent to our church and, in another act of charity, bought me a used sports car for my 50th birthday, remembering that I had once told her that it had been my dream car. How could I disagree?
That left enough money for Joe and his siblings, but before I could get it into the 529 plan and a few stocks I had my eyes on, Christine had another idea. Why not invest the money in a vacation house? We can't go wrong with real estate, she said, and we would actually get some use out of it. After all, Christine's grandfather had made most of his money in real estate, so it seemed appropriate.
These moves were made before the stock market plummeted. I don't want to sit here and say my wife was a genius, so I'll have someone else say it.
"By not investing last year, you were either brilliant or lucky by avoiding one of the worst investment periods in decades," said Gerald Silver, a vice president at Salomon Smith Barney in New Brunswick, N.J. "But I'm cautious on real estate right now. The masses are pulling money out of the market and putting it into real estate. I'm not sure if you chased something that had already appreciated."
I'll spare my wife that assessment. Mr. Silver had advised me when we first received the money and, looking over how we ignored every bit of his advice, he took the high road and didn't yell at me. But he did say that I needed to relieve my guilt and fund that 529 plan for Joe. And if Christine and I were as smart as we claim, we would have taken advantage of the weak market to pick up some bargains, like Pfizer and General Electric.
"Big money is made investing in bear markets," he said. "I believe that anyone who can invest in high-quality companies will be a lot wealthier in a few years."
But wealth isn't always the issue. Ms. Gaston isn't much interested in the stock market, either. She said the money had given her the freedom to take the time to change her life. She said she plans to sell her house, maybe go to divinity school, "get away from material things and get in touch with my spirituality."
"The money my father left me allows me to breathe a bit more," she said.
Fine, Mr. Silver said, but she should first meet with a financial adviser to determine her short- and long-term goals.
"She is probably better off not making any drastic changes right now until she decides what lifestyle changes she wants to make," he said. "Then she needs to invest accordingly."
THE artist in Florida used $4,000 of the money to open individual retirement accounts for her and her husband, but the rest of the first $100,000 she inherited was spent to pay off her debts. She said she will receive another distribution from the estate this year and hopes to use some of it to take college courses. Beyond that, she has no plans for the money except to make sure there's enough for college for her two children.
Again, Mr. Silver suggested the 529 plans, urged her to put more into retirement plans and praised her for taking care of her debts. "Step 1 is pay down all the debt first," he said.
He saved his raised eyebrow for me. The car troubled him.
"When you get a windfall, you always have to spend something on enjoying yourself," he said, "but I probably wouldn't have spent as much on the car from a percentage basis."
Killjoy.

HEADLINE: Investing; 
Restyling Your Portfolio for Europe's New Face

BYLINE:  By CONRAD DE AENLLE

 BODY:
AN investment in emerging markets is often an implicit bet that they will someday join those of the developed world, allowing their businesses to benefit from sounder political, economic and financial systems. For many, that day may never arrive, but in the case of 10 European countries, it has been scheduled for the year after next. 
 The announcement this month that the European Union expects to admit 10 new members in 2004 is expected to provide fresh impetus for what is known as "the convergence play" -- investing on the belief that development in these countries will accelerate, approaching Western European levels as the entry date approaches. 
 Eight of the recommended countries are in Central or Eastern Europe and were either part of the Soviet Union or once in its sphere of influence: Hungary, Poland, the Czech Republic, Slovakia, Slovenia and the Baltic states of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. The other newcomers are the Mediterranean islands of Cyprus and Malta. 
Several of the countries have thriving stock and bond markets. Their performances over the last year stand out in bold contrast to returns almost anywhere else.
The largest of these markets, those of Poland, Hungary and the Czech Republic, show gains in dollar terms for the 12 months through Thursday, according to indexes compiled by the HSBC Group. Poland was up 3.5 percent, Hungary by 32.6 percent and the Czech Republic by 40 percent. Of the seven smaller markets, the best was Slovenia, up 95.3 percent, and the worst was Cyprus, down 25 percent.
Three American mutual funds -- ING Russia, T. Rowe Price Emerging Europe and Mediterranean and Vontobel Eastern European Equity -- have more than $15 million in assets and concentrate their holdings in the emerging markets of Europe. But the ING fund focuses on Russia, and the T. Rowe Price fund had most of its assets in Russia, Israel and Turkey as of June 30, according to Morningstar, leaving only the Vontobel fund with a concentration in the European Union candidates.
With more than half of its assets in Poland and Hungary through June 30, the Vontobel fund returned 7.1 percent for the year through Thursday.
Three closed-end mutual funds trading on the New York Stock Exchange also invest in emerging European markets. They are the Central European Equity fund, the Morgan Stanley Eastern Europe fund and the Templeton Russia and Eastern Europe fund. All have gained at least 25 percent in the 12 months through Thursday.
Closed-end funds, which have a fixed number of shares, are traded throughout the day like stocks. Unlike mutual funds, they may be priced at discounts to their asset values. That is the case for the three emerging European funds.
WHILE markets languish elsewhere in the world, many Central and Eastern European economies are still expanding, aided by extensive investment in manufacturing by richer neighbors, most notably Germany. They have long been lured to the east by the prospect of European Union expansion.
A further recent attraction of these markets is the dominance of low-cost manufacturers that excel in lean times like these. Once the new countries join in 2004, reducing trade and employment barriers, the pace of investment is expected to accelerate.
"Convergence is an ongoing economic process, and political integration is part of that," said Mark Robinson, a manager of the Europe Convergence Equity fund for J. P. Morgan Fleming Asset Management, a Luxembourg subsidiary of J. P. Morgan Chase; the fund is not available to American investors. "This is just the unfolding of capitalism," Mr. Robinson said.
One measure of the market economies' evolution, he said, is the ratio of private borrowing for mortgages and investment to economic output, he said. 
"It started off at the end of the Communist era with a financial sector that was zero percent of gross domestic product," he said. "Now credit to G.D.P. is 25 percent in Poland and nearer 50 percent in Hungary and the Czech Republic."
Some investors say that share prices already reflect the likelihood of European Union entry -- and that the easy money has already been made.
"From an investment point of view, the really interesting places in terms of convergence are further east: Turkey, Bulgaria, Romania," said Jerome Booth, a fund manager at Ashmore Investment Management in London, a specialist in emerging-markets portfolios. "Poland, Czech and Hungary, we know they're going to join."
Nevertheless, he said, currencies of these three Central European countries have remained strong against the euro, showing that "people from Western Europe are continuing to buy the story," he said. 
Once the 10 candidates join the European Union, their citizens will be granted the same rights as those in the senior member states, although some changes will be gradual -- including subsidies for farmers and the right to live and work throughout the union. The new members would need to meet more rigorous requirements to participate in the euro currency, now shared by 12 of the 15 existing states.
Before the union expands officially, an accession treaty must be signed next year by the existing members and the following year by the 10 candidate states. As part of the process, Irish voters, through a referendum on Oct. 19, approved a European Union treaty setting forth some of the enlargement conditions. Before the accession votes occur, some fine print -- setting terms of entry -- must still be approved.
This month, a European Union report said many candidate countries needed to improve labor productivity, bolster their health care systems and civil service and fight corruption. Because further economic reform is likely, Mark Mobius, president of Templeton Emerging Markets, expects continued robust gains.
"The journey is more important than the destination because the E.U. has certain requirements and targets that countries have to meet financially, socially and politically," he said. "This process is very good for the region, and we don't think it's all priced into stock markets."
Mr. Robinson said the downfall of the Soviet Union had allowed Hungary, Poland and the Czech Republic to throw out the old system and build a new one from scratch.
"They have been able to leapfrog Western Europe to some extent," he said. "The labor market is probably more flexible in Hungary than in Germany."
Mr. Robinson's portfolio holds some banking stocks, reflecting his view that private credit markets in Eastern Europe will keep growing at prodigious rates. Among them is Hansabank in Estonia, which has a return on equity of about 20 percent even though the global industry is struggling.
Two other banks in the portfolio are OTP of Hungary, which he said has a high share of the retail market there and may be a takeover target by a Western institution, and Bank Pekao in Poland, of which UniCredito Italiano has a controlling stake.
Financial services companies are prominent in the portfolios of American funds focusing on the region. The T. Rowe Price fund owns OTP and Hansabank, and Vontobel Eastern European Equity holds those two plus Pekao. Both funds also hold Komercni Banka, a Czech institution.
Many companies favored by Mr. Robinson are subsidiaries of Western companies that are sprucing them up financially, restructuring their operations and improving profitability. These include Stomil Olsztyn, a Polish tire manufacturer controlled by Michelin of France, and Matav, the Hungarian phone company that is a subsidiary of Deutsche Telekom.
"They have been in there for several years and done a decent job of restructuring," Mr. Robinson said.
Matav, which is listed on the New York Stock Exchange, "is a mini-version of Deutsche Telekom without the debt," he said.
"They've been cutting the work force and improving productivity," he added.
He also owns shares of Estonia Telecom and Telekomunikacja Polska, or TPSA, a Polish affiliate of France Telecom.
MR. MOBIUS is less enthusiastic about telecommunications companies, saying he owns "a little bit" of TPSA and Matav, but no more because he finds the valuations "not that appealing."
He prefers energy concerns like the Polish refinery PKN. He also likes the region's banking sector but would rather invest through Western institutions that are taking hefty stakes in Central European banks. He likes Erste Bank of Austria, which he described as "our entree into Eastern European banking."
Another sector he recommends is pharmaceuticals. He likes the Hungarian company Gedeon Richter.
European Union expansion will be positive for Western Europe as a whole, said Joachim Fels, an economist at Morgan Stanley. Enlargement "adds to pressure for reform" in all member states, he said.
Still, the biggest gains are bound to accrue to the new members themselves, said Mr. Booth at Ashmore. "Very clearly, integration into the E.U. is a huge economic and social benefit in the long term," he said. "That's why they all want to be in, to be part of a much larger internal market. This is a very important historical process."

HEADLINE: Doing Their Nails With a Hammer 

BYLINE:  By KATE BETTS 

 BODY:
FOUR decades of feminism have shown that women are capable of crewing on the space shuttle, defeating chess grandmasters and fighting wars. Even that male bastion, the Augusta National Golf Club, is feeling the heat from barricade-storming women.
 But when it comes to home repair, suddenly we're helpless, helpless, helpless, as Neil Young once sang. Men fix leaky faucets. Women stand by cluelessly holding the wrench thingy. 
 Enter a new wave of power women -- not those who want to be boardroom fixtures, but those obsessed with bathroom fixtures -- who are determined to teach other women more about home repair than just the seven digits of the super's telephone number. Designing tools especially for women, writing easy-to-read manuals and dispensing tips on Web sites, these Ms. Fix-Its seek to demystify, and even glamorize, home repair. 
"There's definitely still a 'damsel in distress/knight in shining armor' mentality when it comes to women and home repair," said Allegra Bennett, the author of three home repair books, including "When a Woman Takes an Ax to a Wall" (Renovating Woman Books, 2002). "We tend to want someone else to do the work in the house, but honestly, there's nothing more empowering than fixing something you were afraid of."
Barbara Kavovit, the chief executive of Anchor Construction, a Manhattan interior construction-management company that has worked in Carnegie Hall Tower and Bloomingdale's, is taking her know-how to the mass market with a line of tools for women. She is determined to prove that confidence can come from a handful of claw hammers and slip-joint pliers, maybe even a putty knife.
"I think it started with 'Sex and the City,' actually," said Ms. Kavovit, a single mother who cringes at the thought of relying on a superintendent. "That episode when Samantha moved into the meatpacking district and the curtains fell down? I thought, If only she had a toolbox."
Ms. Kavovit's Pradaesque lightweight screwdrivers have sculptured rubber handles in gray and turquoise, and the grips are indented to accommodate fragile French manicures like Ms. Kavovit's. "See this?" she said during an interview in her office, pointing to the place where the thumb rests on a screwdriver. "How many times have you broken a nail doing this?"
Her idea coincides neatly with the continuing home-improvement boom, in which women are playing an increasingly prominent role. Sales of home-improvement products reached a record $187.6 billion last year, 40 percent of it spent by women, according to the Home Improvement Research Institute in Tampa, Fla. Home-improvement television shows have come a long way from "This Old House." The new hits -- "Trading Spaces," on the Learning Channel, and "Designing for the Sexes," on Home and Garden Television -- prominently feature women as fixer-uppers.
"It's like the 70's, when women were entering the work force, but they still didn't know how to invest their own money," Ms. Kavovit said. The idea behind her Barbara K! tool kits is that Rosie the Riveter can also be Rosie the Riveting. The kits come in sleek molded turquoise plastic cases. Bed Bath & Beyond plans to carry them beginning in January. A starter kit, for $60, has the basics, including a hammer, a 6-in-1 screwdriver and an adjustable wrench. 
Users can graduate to specialized kits for plumbing, electrical repairs, painting, staining and refinishing, and to power tools. Ms. Kavovit also plans to sell the kits on a home-shopping channel.
To those who wonder why women need tools different from men's (aren't wrenches unisex?), Ms. Kavovit explained that hers are ergonomically designed for a smaller hand and are lighter, and thus easier to use.
Even the old-school guru Bob Vila, the original host of "This Old House," agreed that such products have a place. "Obviously, a woman could walk into any hardware store and buy any tool," Mr. Vila, now a spokesman for Craftsman tools, said. "But most American tool manufacturers are paying more attention to this market, and they're making friendlier, more ergonomic and lighter-weight tools. More women are single parents who have to be Mrs. Fix-It and problem-solvers in the home."
In February 2000, Tomboy Tools, an online company, was established by five Denver-area women frustrated by the lack of woman-friendly home-repair products and information. Their idea is to sell tools and tips through a Web site and at Tupperware-style parties in homes. Tomboy's 80 "associates" demonstrate how to use the tools, and guests exchange repair and remodeling tips.
"The problem I have is that any tools that have been for women are like second-class citizens -- they're cheaper," said Lynda Lyday, a host of "Talk2DIY," a call-in show on DIY cable television. "We need construction-grade tools that are going to be ergonomically correct."
Last month, "Dare to Repair: A Do-It-Herself Guide to Fixing (Almost) Anything in the Home," by Julie Sussman and Stephanie Glakas-Tenet, was published by HarperResource. The book, a cheeky romp through domestic disasters like clogged bathtub drains, cheerfully demystifies repair terminology by explaining the likes of closet augers, circuit maps and slip nuts.
The authors conceived their book out of frustration: their husbands were both in the Central Intelligence Agency (Ms. Tenet's, George J. Tenet, is the director of central intelligence) and were never around to fix things.
"We're just so used to depending on our fathers or our husbands," Ms. Sussman said. "When I was growing up, our household chores were divided by gender. And I don't want my daughter or my son to grow up like that."
Shoshana Berger, the editor in chief of ReadyMade magazine, a do-it-yourself guide geared to first-time homeowners, said younger women are a lot less shy about rolling up their sleeves and grabbing a Stillson wrench. "We get a lot of letters from women saying, 'I'm the only 26-year-old with a band saw -- thank you for creating a magazine I can relate to,' " Ms. Berger said. "Younger people are definitely not filling the same traditional archetypes that our parents did."
Take Shari Markbreiter, a Manhattan interior designer, whose father gave her a power drill for her 18th birthday, in the 1980's. "I wanted pearls," she said, "but I think he was acknowledging the feminist movement. It was his way of saying be independent, do it yourself."
And she did. Even though her husband has a degree in engineering, Ms. Markbreiter said she is the one who does the repairs in their home.
Five years ago Martha McCully, an executive editor of InStyle magazine, broke up with her boyfriend, bought a house in East Hampton and oversaw its renovation. "I did not want to wait to get married to own a house," she said, "but being a homeowner as a single woman is kind of overwhelming. A lot of women want to do this, but they don't have the confidence.
"But in the last five years, I think that's changed tremendously. Women are more financially independent and feeling more confident that they can do things they couldn't do before. I marvel at myself -- that I know how to fix things in my house now, like running toilets. Last weekend I redid my walkway with bluestones."
Ms. Kavovit was a pioneer in tool belt empowerment for women. Ten years ago, she felt that she had hit a glass ceiling as an assistant trader on the commodities desk at the Mitsubishi Corporation. ("My boss overturned my desk," she said. "I realized there was no place for me to go beyond being a glorified secretary.") At that point, she decided to build a business around the idea that women are intimidated by contractors. Posting herself in the parking lot of a mall in Scarsdale, N.Y., she asked women who owned their own homes to hire her as a liaison with the contractors and the tradesmen working on their houses. She also hired a handyman and went door to door fixing cracked tiles, sealing driveways and cleaning gutters.
Soon she relocated to Manhattan and plunged into the all-male world of big city interior construction, building a company that in 2000 did $76 million in business, she said.
But the downturn in the economy forced Ms. Kavovit to reappraise the construction business. "Now isn't a great time to build a skyscraper," she said. "It's a time when people want to stay close to home and do more for themselves."
So she hit on the idea of designing tools. "Women are no-nonsense," she said. "They're not going to be tricked by a gimmick."
She pored over Pantone color charts to pick the perfect color (pink, she said, is patronizing to women) for tools both serious and good-looking. She chose turquoise, which she points out is the same shade as the Gillette Venus razor, one of the most successful packaged goods of recent seasons. She constantly repeats her belief that a wrench is never just a wrench in a woman's hand; it is a tool of self-respect.
"I can't stress how important it is for women to have independence and confidence," said Ms. Kavovit, recounting the time her son, now 4, was locked in the bathroom and she was helpless because she didn't have the tool necessary to open the lock (an Allen wrench, or hex key).
"Now I could do anything myself," she said. "I could build an addition to my house. It makes you feel powerful."

HEADLINE: ON THE JOB; 
The Floor Shook, But They Didn't

BYLINE:  By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

 BODY:
When times are tough, do the tough really get going? The answer is: Sometimes. As the mail indicates, maybe the best strategy for maintaining business in a weak economy is simply to sit tight. But when the outlook is bleak, well-planned action may also pay off in a big way.
 Catherine E. Sutter, the president and owner of Pro-Tec Mobile Communications of Casa Grande, Ariz., was facing fierce competition in difficult economic times. Owning and operating wireless radio stations that allow hundreds of business clients throughout Phoenix and Tucson to dispatch their fleets of vehicles, Miss Sutter was up against six major wireless carriers: AT&T Wireless, Sprint PCS, Nextel Communications, Verizon Communications, Alltel and Western Wireless. 
 What did she do?
Nothing, she says.
"What I saw happening to the cellular industry was exactly what happened to the local two-way radio shops that were forced to compete against one another 15 years ago," she writes.
"There were too many of us providing mobile two-way service to the consumer. All of us were guilty of giving away radios and installations at cost. None of us would raise our rates for fear that our hard-earned customer would jump ship to our competitor."
Faced with a familiar situation, Miss Sutter says she paid off her company's long-term debt, sat back and waited.
As the fight for customers continues, she says, her sites are built and her company is debt free. Contemplating this competitive edge, she adds, "I now have the luxury of educating the big carriers about how to keep customers."
Until a couple of months ago in Portland, Ore., Tamara M. Seymour, now a freelance writer, was the senior marketing manager and creative director for Household International, a consumer finance company based in the Chicago suburb of Prospect Heights. In the best literary tradition, she introduces her account of taking exceptional measures to avert a drastic fate with a biblical overview:
"In the beginning, an entrepreneur created a company, and the company was private and profitable," she writes. "And the entrepreneur sold his small company to a much larger Fortune 100 company. And the giant corporation said, 'Let there be efficiency'; and there were many layoffs."
She continues: "The work unit I managed served as the acquired company's internal advertising agency, responsible for the creative development and production of all its marketing communications. We were miraculously spared during the downsizing -- seems no one knew what to do with our little group, since we were an anomaly within a well-established parent organization that traditionally relied on external ad agencies. But the new management liked our pretty pictures, and the customer response rates to our ads were high."
Still, danger lurked. "We knew the day would come when we would have to prove our value to Chicago," Ms. Seymour writes. "Since we relied on internal clients to feed us business, we launched a widespread self-promotion campaign."
Designers and copywriters stayed late to develop a whole new identity for the eight-member group, including a catchy "agency" name and logo. They published a colorful promotional kit with business cards, a team biography and samples of their finest work. They visited satellite offices in other areas of the country, "passing out promo kits like Bibles at a revival," as Ms. Seymour puts it.
Ms. Seymour slipped in a plug or two -- along with some favorable comparisons with the cost of doing business with outside ad agencies -- at high-level management meetings.
"Within six months, we had booked half a dozen new clients and locked ourselves in as the primary creative service provider for our division of the corporation," she writes.
"And to ensure we would not be forgotten, we offered follow-up care in the form of occasional gifts. For example, top managers who enlisted our services received a set of original greeting cards, handcrafted in-house, to send to their own customers and vendors during the holidays. These types of simple and kind gestures were a big hit and helped to secure our team's popularity.
"For a while, hoop-jumping was a way of life in our little creative corner of a profit-driven world. But with tireless self-promotion, our collectively bleak outlook was transformed. We generated exciting new business for ourself and bulked up the company's bottom line.
"And in the end, we all kept our jobs."

HEADLINE: Business; 
A New Company Tries to Sort the Web's Chaos

BYLINE:  By JOHN MARKOFF

DATELINE: SAUSALITO, Calif. 

 BODY:
BY Silicon Valley standards, it was an unassuming debut.
 Last weekend at a Marin County conference on biological and cultural diversity, Groxis, Paul Hawken's new software company, was sandwiched by the booths for Birkenstock sandals and PowerBars. 
 Mr. Hawken is best known for as a co-founder of Smith & Hawken, a California catalog and store that sells high-end gardening equipment, and for his writings, which blend environmentalism and capitalism. 
But at a time when the valley's digerati are bemoaning a technology industry recession and the death of innovation, Mr. Hawken's Grokker software, which is intended to allow personal-computer users to visually make sense of collections of thousands or hundreds of thousands of text documents, is creating a buzz. The software is attracting significant interest from large corporations and universities.
At the conference, Groxis employees began taking orders after people told the company that they were willing to pay for the program, which had not yet been released; 200 copies were sold that weekend.
Groxis, based in Sausalito, is trying to solve an old problem, but it is growing exponentially with the explosion of electronic information brought about by the Internet.
"The computer world has been alphanumeric, but we perceive things visually," said Mr. Hawken. He said he is now working on a new book and has used his program to organize a collection of more than four million Web bookmarks. "It's the first time as a writer I have too much information, but it's manageable," he said.
Groxis (pronounced GRAHK-sis) is named for a term in "Stranger in a Strange Land," by the science fiction writer Robert Heinlein. To "grok" something is to understand it completely.
The reference is driven home by the fact that today, according to the Groxis designers, 84 percent of Web surfers go no further than the first page of document titles in searching for information. While that may be appropriate for some searches, other queries, like one for the phrase "exotic vacations," may leave Web sites of interest deeply buried by search engines.
The popular search engine Google uses ranking techniques to sort through thousands of possible Web pages displaying what are often the most desirable pages first.
IN contrast, Grokker builds a visual map of the general categories into which documents fall by using what computer software designers call metadata, which describes each Web page or document. The program currently works with the Northern Light search engine, the Amazon online catalog and as a tool for scanning a user's own PC file collection.
Previously, there have been thousands of research efforts in text visualization and dozens of commercial attempts to go beyond traditional directory listing approaches for organizing information.
The Xerox Palo Alto Research Center did work in this area in the 1990's and spun off Inxight Software, a company in Sunnyvale, Calif., that now offers tools for the management of text data. Early on, Alta Vista, the first search engine, offered a so-called refine feature that permitted a graphical view of information returned after the query.
There are also Web search tools ranging from KartOO (www.kartoo.com) to Vivisimo (www.vivisimo.com) that provide alternative ways of viewing or categorizing the expanse of information accessible on the Web. Tim Bray, a designer of the XML Internet protocol, a commonly used format for storing and exchanging information on the Internet, has created Antarctica Systems (www.antarti.ca), a company based in Vancouver, British Columbia, that offers a geographically oriented visualization approach.
So far, none of the visualization tools have succeeded commercially.
"The universal reaction is that people say, 'Oh, how pretty,' " said Danny Sullivan, editor of Search Engine Watch, a British Web site (searchenginewatch.com) that tracks the search engine industry. "However, they don't continue to use them. People forget that text is visual and reading a list is a very helpful way of organizing information."
The basic ideas underlying the Groxis technology were developed by Jean-Michel Decombe, a French computer researcher, who in the late 1990's worked for the Silicon Valley start-up Metacode, which was developing automatic categorization. When Metacode was acquired in 2000 by Interwoven, another Silicon Valley content management concern, Mr. Decombe joined with Mr. Hawken and R. J. Pittman, a computer scientist and venture capitalist, to acquire the visualization technology he had been working on.
Mr. Decombe argues that Grokker is a more universal approach to the problem of visualizing textual information than what has been found in previous tools, which focus more on navigation than on categorization.
"The difference is that we have no single paradigm," said Mr. Decombe, who is Groxis's chief technology officer. Instead, Grokker offers a wide palette of different ways to view information. Under Mr. Hawken's guidance, Groxis is also hoping to refine a business strategy that will make Grokker a widely used research tool.
The Grokker software, offered in versions that include a basic $149 program, will appear first as a preview beta version available at the Groxis Web site (www.groxis.com), according to the company.
At Stanford, the library has modified its online Socrates catalog system to be viewed by Grokker. "It shows sufficient promise that we're thinking of giving it to our entire community," said Michael Keller, the university librarian. "Potentially, it will not only give our students and faculty a way to view their own information world but also our wildly multifarious array of thousands of e-journals and hundreds of databases."
Grokker has also drawn the attention of Interface Inc., based in Chicago, a big carpeting company. In March, the company plans to begin a division, Interface Flor, offering a Grokker-based catalog that will permit Web customers to view, organize and select from 50,000 samples.
